text: SINCE THE 1980S, when I began writing the essays that comprise my Makers
label: Paragraph

text: of Modern Architecture, of which this is the third volume, the building art
label: Paragraph

text: has undergone such a thoroughgoing transformation that it would be largely
label: Paragraph

text: unrecognizable to most of the figures included in this open-ended series of
label: Paragraph

text: career assessments. This should not be surprising, given that the oldest of
label: Paragraph

text: my subjects, Frederick Law Olmsted, was bom nearly two centuries ago
label: Paragraph

text: (one indication that the Modern Movement in architecture, of which he was
label: Paragraph

text: an important precursor, has long become a historical development).
label: Paragraph

text: However, the most extreme changes have occurred during the three decades
label: Paragraph

text: when these texts were originally published in The New York Review of
label: Paragraph

text: Books. Technological advances that emerged during that period in
label: Paragraph

text: architecture are no less remarkable than those from horse-drawn vehicles to
label: Paragraph

text: space travel, handwritten communications to electronic media, or
label: Paragraph

text: phrenology to gene therapy.
label: Paragraph

text: For example, although there are striking formal similarities between the
label: Paragraph

text: work of two major figures discussed in this volume, Antoni Gaudi and
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Gehry—both of whom designed idiosyncratic, biomorphic structures
label: Paragraph

text: wholly at odds with the predominantly rectilinear rule of Western
label: Paragraph

text: architecture since Classical antiquity—the means by which they realized
label: Paragraph

text: their heterodox visions could not have been more different. Gaudi drew on
label: Paragraph

text: millennia of ingenious fabrication techniques indigenous to his native
label: Paragraph

text: Catalan region, a tradition that began with Roman colonists but remained
label: Paragraph

text: localized until the nineteenth century and the international dissemination of
label: Paragraph

text: those techniques by an older compatriot of his, Rafael Guastavino. The
label: Paragraph

text: execution of Gaudi’s marvelously bizarre designs also depended on the
label: Paragraph

text: availability of cheap artisanal labor, for although the architect plotted his
label: Paragraph

text: innovative structures with an exceptional but largely intuitive knowledge of
label: Paragraph

text: engineering, he still needed the help of skilled craftsmen, who were often
label: Paragraph

text: required to improvise onsite adjustments that no amount of forethought, in
label: Paragraph

text: those low-tech times, could have anticipated.
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry, in contrast, ingeniously co-opted computer software devised for
label: Paragraph

text: the aviation industry to plot the increasingly irregular forms of his
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, a conceptual masterstroke that opened a new universe of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural design for him and an emergent generation of coprofessionals.
label: Paragraph

text: But the technical innovations of the past three decades have not been
label: Paragraph

text: limited to the digital realm and include a host of new building materials
label: Paragraph

text: once undreamed of, such as translucent concrete that transmits light through
label: Paragraph

text: load-bearing walls, powerful adhesives that enable the installation of huge
label: Paragraph

text: windows without intrusive mullions, and biodegradable plastics as strong as
label: Paragraph

text: aluminum but half its weight. And although natural methods of passive
label: Paragraph

text: climate control have been part of vernacular building traditions since time
label: Paragraph

text: immemorial, the LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design)
label: Title

text: rating system of the United States Green Building Council—a private,
label: Paragraph

text: nonprofit architectural sustainability group founded in 1993—has promoted
label: Paragraph

text: a wide array of energy-conservation strategies that have profoundly
label: Paragraph

text: changed business-as-usual attitudes toward the issue of climate change.
label: Paragraph

text: As with the two preceding installments of this series, the chapters in this
label: Paragraph

text: volume are arranged more or less chronologically, by the subject’s date of
label: Paragraph

text: birth or the approximate order in which she or he rose to prominence. And
label: Paragraph

text: although none of these books purports to be a full-fledged narrative of
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture, taken as a whole they offer a veritable mosaic of the
label: Paragraph

text: profession’s major protagonists from the mid-nineteenth century to the
label: Paragraph

text: present day. There are several notable reappearances here. Frank Lloyd
label: Paragraph

text: Wright, a figure of fathomless depth to scholars and perennial interest to the
label: Paragraph

text: general public, appears in all three volumes, a sign of his unparalleled place
label: Paragraph

text: in the American architectural pantheon. Renzo Piano likewise is included in
label: Paragraph

text: each book, although that has had more to do with his having commanded so
label: Paragraph

text: many of the most coveted cultural commissions of the past thirty years,
label: Paragraph

text: when he has reigned as the world’s most prominent designer of performing-
label: Paragraph

text: and visual-arts buildings. (Le Corbusier—more important in the global
label: Paragraph

text: picture than either Wright or Piano—was in Volumes [ and II.)
label: Paragraph

text: Two chapters, in Volume I and the present collection, are devoted to
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Kahn, who, along with Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown
label: Paragraph

text: (discussed in Volume I) and Gehry (Volumes I and IID, can be safely cited
label: Paragraph

text: as the most significant American architects in the six decades since
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s demise. Also in both the first and third volumes are estimations of
label: Paragraph

text: the work of David Childs and Santiago Calatrava, whose headline-making
label: Paragraph

text: schemes at New York’s Ground Zero gave them extraordinary visibility
label: Paragraph

text: during the decade and a half that it took them to execute those projects. As
label: Paragraph

text: with its two predecessors, the components of this book were prompted by a
label: Paragraph

text: variety of topical occurrences, including the completion of culturally
label: Paragraph

text: significant public buildings (such as Piano’s addition to Kahn’s Kimbell Art
label: Paragraph

text: Museum in Fort Worth and Gehry’s Fondation Louis Vuitton in Paris); the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of new structural forms (the super-tall, super-thin condominium
label: Paragraph

text: towers that began to appear in Midtown Manhattan during the second
label: Paragraph

text: decade of the new millennium); major museum exhibitions (including
label: Paragraph

text: retrospectives on Wright, the Wiener Werkstatte, and Gehry); and, as
label: Paragraph

text: always at a paper devoted to reviewing books, new architectural
label: Paragraph

text: publications.
label: Paragraph

text: In recent years many of those have been monographs that focus on
label: Paragraph

text: architects of a half-century earlier whose heyday was followed by a period
label: Paragraph

text: of posthumous obscurity. This often happens when tastes and fashions
label: Paragraph

text: change, and it falls to a younger generation of scholars to look with fresh
label: Paragraph

text: eyes at buildings that can seem embarrassingly dated. In Volume II, I
label: Paragraph

text: discussed the revival of interest in Eero Saarinen and Edward Durell Stone,
label: Paragraph

text: and the renewed enthusiasm for what is now known as Midcentury Modern
label: Paragraph

text: continues in this collection with similar reevaluations of Paul Rudolph,
label: Paragraph

text: Minoru Yamasaki, and their many contemporaries whose tough-looking
label: Paragraph

text: concrete structures earned them the label of New Brutalists. Even the
label: Paragraph

text: developer-built suburban housing tracts that so altered the postwar character
label: Paragraph

text: of middle-class American habitation have lately been the beneficiary of
label: Paragraph

text: scholarly analyses referred to in these pages.
label: Paragraph

text: Such studies are often undertaken by graduate students in search of
label: Paragraph

text: unclaimed dissertation topics, but apart from that impetus there is always
label: Paragraph

text: good reason to reexamine the merits of discredited or neglected architecture
label: Paragraph

text: after contemporary prejudices subside. However, in reconsidering the fifty-
label: Paragraph

text: five chapters of this series, it now seems to me that the most fascinating
label: Paragraph

text: rediscoveries are not of postwar male architects but rather of women
label: Paragraph

text: architects who managed not only to prevail but to excel in a profession that
label: Paragraph

text: remained so adamantly male-dominated and openly misogynistic for most
label: Paragraph

text: of the twentieth century. The most notable example of such myopia—to
label: Paragraph

text: give this habitual omission its most charitable definition—was the absence
label: Paragraph

text: of Lina Bo Bardi from the canon of indispensable twentieth-century
label: Paragraph

text: architects, and even the most cursory overview of her accomplishment
label: Paragraph

text: indicates that she would have long enjoyed her current high critical status
label: Paragraph

text: were she a man.
label: Paragraph

text: In general, the prospects of women entering architectural practice today
label: Paragraph

text: are much improved in comparison with those thirty years ago, to say
label: Paragraph

text: nothing of sixty, when even the leading female figures in the profession
label: Paragraph

text: were routinely subjected to discrimination and harassment. Natalie de Blois,
label: Paragraph

text: for example, who died in 2013 at the age of ninety-two, was among the few
label: Paragraph

text: women of her generation to reach the highest echelons of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: practice in this country. Blois, who as a senior partner at Skidmore, Owings
label: Paragraph

text: & Merrill helped design several of the firm’s most noteworthy buildings of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1950s and 1960s, was fired from an earlier job because she rejected a
label: Paragraph

text: male superior’s sexual overtures. But even at SOM, the period’s paradigm
label: Paragraph

text: of corporate architectural culture, she had to endure repeated humiliations,
label: Paragraph

text: such as being excluded from meetings with prospective clients and from
label: Paragraph

text: group photographs with her male colleagues. When Blois was pregnant
label: Paragraph

text: with one of her three children, Gordon Bunshaft, the firm’s cantankerous
label: Paragraph

text: design principal (“He took all the credit and she did all the work,” as one
label: Paragraph

text: feminist advocate has explained their collaborative dynamic), told her that
label: Paragraph

text: she should not attend the opening of a corporate headquarters they’d
label: Paragraph

text: worked on together if she had not given birth by then.
label: Paragraph

text: Although social mores may change in the short term, human nature rarely
label: Paragraph

text: does in any significant manner. Thus I believe that the specifically personal
label: Paragraph

text: approach I have taken in these essays, far from reinforcing a discredited
label: Paragraph

text: Great Man approach to history, helps to explain the inner workings of an art
label: Paragraph

text: that has become increasingly mysterious to the general public since the
label: Paragraph

text: professionalization of building design began during the second half of the
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth century. To be sure, for millennia the construction industry
label: Paragraph

text: remained very much a closed shop, with knowledge of the building art
label: Paragraph

text: jealously guarded as a trade secret transmitted by familial dynasties or trade
label: Paragraph

text: guilds intent on monopolizing lucrative sources of income. Yet to a far
label: Paragraph

text: greater extent than was possible in the Industrial Age, the lay public in
label: Paragraph

text: premodern times could closely observe the building process and gain some
label: Paragraph

text: understanding of its nature, or even, as with the scores of cathedrals erected
label: Paragraph

text: throughout Christendom during the Middle Ages, directly participate in the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of a monument used by the entire community.
label: Paragraph

text: No wonder that this lost ideal of social integration was invoked by
label: Paragraph

text: Modernist architects in the immediate aftermath of World War I, most
label: Paragraph

text: movingly by the founders of the Bauhaus, the cover of whose founding
label: Paragraph

text: manifesto of 1919 was decorated with Lyonel Feininger’s Expressionist
label: Paragraph

text: woodcut Kathedrale. (Indeed, the very name of this multidisciplinary
label: Paragraph

text: design school has echoes in the word Bauhtitte—a builder’s lodge adjacent
label: Paragraph

text: to those great medieval churches, the equivalent of the far less
label: Paragraph

text: prepossessing job-manager’s trailers we now see on modem construction
label: Paragraph

text: sites.) Overall, though, the social aspects of architecture today are quite
label: Paragraph

text: different from those of earlier epochs, and have depended much more on
label: Paragraph

text: the interpersonal relations between architect and client than, say, those
label: Paragraph

text: between master mason and clerical hierarchy.
label: Paragraph

text: At the heart of this customary imbalance of architectural power—the
label: Paragraph

text: perpetual tug-of-war between economic necessity and artistic desire—lies
label: Paragraph

text: the basic fact that nothing can get built unless someone agrees to pay for it.
label: Paragraph

text: Although distinguished architects of the modern period, from the Adam
label: Paragraph

text: brothers in the eighteenth century onward, have been able (given the
label: Paragraph

text: financial backing of others) to create structures that can be sold on
label: Paragraph

text: speculation—most often residences but also office buildings—the
label: Paragraph

text: profession for the most part remains in the thrall of patronage. Except for a
label: Paragraph

text: recent increase in design/build architects, who act as their own contractors
label: Paragraph

text: and developers, there has been no widespread change equivalent to the one
label: Paragraph

text: that began with the rise of a middle-class market for paintings in
label: Paragraph

text: seventeenth-century Holland, which removed the creation of art from
label: Paragraph

text: complete dependency on princely patronage.
label: Paragraph

text: The ability, indeed the necessity of architects to convince others to
label: Paragraph

text: employ them—whether on the basis of their social insight (Olmsted, Bo
label: Paragraph

text: Bardi), otherworldly spirituality (Gaudi, Kahn), extraordinary charm
label: Paragraph

text: (Calatrava, Rafael Vifioly), political ideology (Albert Speer, Gerdy Troost),
label: Paragraph

text: or technological expertise (Frei Otto, Piano), to name just several of the
label: Paragraph

text: practitioners I discuss in this book—cannot be discounted as an integral
label: Paragraph

text: component of their exceptional success. Highly developed social skills can
label: Paragraph

text: propel architects of mediocre artistic ability to great heights, as was
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated by the stellar careers of Philip Johnson and I. M. Pei, neither
label: Paragraph

text: of whom was a very talented designer.
label: Paragraph

text: Conversely, a lack of what’s known colloquially as “people skills” can
label: Paragraph

text: doom even the most gifted professional. When I served as an adviser on an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural search committee in the early 2000s, I watched in dismay as
label: Paragraph

text: the perfect person for the job lost the commission by never once
label: Paragraph

text: establishing eye contact with his potential clients as he gave his
label: Paragraph

text: presentation. Instead he talked right over their heads, which one member of
label: Paragraph

text: that committee cited as the determining reason not to hire him. In one-on-
label: Paragraph

text: one situations this architect can be delightfully engaging, but his tendency
label: Paragraph

text: to seem remote and aloof in more formal settings is at painful odds with
label: Paragraph

text: such virtuosos of the client pitch as Piano, whose lyrical evocations of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture as the noblest of human endeavors have likely won him as
label: Paragraph

text: many projects as his lengthy roster of superbly executed buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet no matter how high-minded they may be, all architects know that if
label: Paragraph

text: they do not have a client, they do not have a building. (Gaudi coped with
label: Paragraph

text: the countless human vicissitudes that hampered the progress of his
label: Paragraph

text: masterwork, the church of the Sagrada Familia, by insisting that “God is my
label: Paragraph

text: client,” while the Lord’s representatives on earth made this saintly master
label: Paragraph

text: builder miserable.) But even when it comes to architects whose work I do
label: Paragraph

text: not much admire (Rudolph and Calatrava, to name but two included here),
label: Paragraph

text: one cannot question the seriousness with which they addressed their tasks
label: Paragraph

text: or the strong confidence their patrons had in them.
label: Paragraph

text: As with every other human undertaking there is a dark side to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, which was exposed most sinisterly during the modern period
label: Paragraph

text: in the Third Reich, whose leader was a frustrated architect and urban
label: Paragraph

text: planner manqué. For decades after World War II, any serious discussion of
label: Paragraph

text: Nazi construction was strictly verboten in academic circles, as if
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledging the central part that architecture played in the Fihrer’s
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive takeover of the arts in German culture implied approval of
label: Paragraph

text: his malign program for political subjugation through every possible
label: Paragraph

text: medium. Once it became permissible to talk about this long-suppressed
label: Paragraph

text: subject, a parallel increase of interest in traditional styles during the 1970s
label: Paragraph

text: and 1980s emboldened some contrarians, most notably the neoconservative
label: Paragraph

text: Postmodernist Léon Krier, to openly admire Nazi architecture. Thus
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged, Hitler’s chief architect, Albert Speer—who survived a postwar
label: Paragraph

text: prison term and made a second fortune from best-selling memoirs
label: Paragraph

text: unparalleled in their mendacity—expected the critical rehabilitation of his
label: Paragraph

text: architectural corpus despite the atrocities he perpetrated as a high-ranking
label: Paragraph

text: member of the Nazi regime.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from the centrality of technological matters, the most salient aspect
label: Paragraph

text: of the building art since the millennium has been the exponential growth
label: Paragraph

text: (though “metastasis” might be the better term) of the cult of celebrity,
label: Paragraph

text: which has taken the long-standing emphasis on individual inspiration in this
label: Paragraph

text: necessarily collaborative medium to grotesque new extremes. Today’s
label: Paragraph

text: relentless commercial emphasis on “branding” has been a setback for those
label: Paragraph

text: who want to acknowledge that the creation of architecture would be
label: Paragraph

text: impossible without the participation of numerous specialists on each
label: Paragraph

text: project. However much a principal architect might drive the process, in the
label: Paragraph

text: same way that a movie director is the auteur of a production, it is hugely
label: Paragraph

text: misleading to perpetuate persistent stereotypes of the individual genius.
label: Paragraph

text: To their credit, two of today’s most important architects have insisted that
label: Paragraph

text: their firms’ corporate identities stress the collaborative nature of their work:
label: Paragraph

text: the Office for Metropolitan Architecture, of which Rem Koolhaas is the
label: Paragraph

text: most widely recognized principal, and the Renzo Piano Building Workshop,
label: Paragraph

text: which even though it highlights the name of its founder implies a more
label: Paragraph

text: generous sharing of credit than the customary “and Partners” or “and
label: Paragraph

text: Associates.” It might be said that both Koolhaas and Piano are both secure
label: Paragraph

text: enough about their own celebrity not to worry about what their offices are
label: Paragraph

text: called, and concerned that the future livelihoods of their coworkers not be
label: Paragraph

text: dependent on their firms’ sole identification with one all-too-mortal
label: Paragraph

text: individual.
label: Paragraph

text: But such nomenclature straddles an earlier tendency to name
label: Paragraph

text: architectural practices after their principalsk—McKim, Mead & White;
label: Paragraph

text: Skidmore, Owings & Merrill—and the recent preference for cryptic titles
label: Paragraph

text: believed to efface such personal associations and epitomized by Ennead
label: Paragraph

text: Architects (formerly Polshek Partnership, a change made upon the
label: Paragraph

text: founder’s retirement, and based on a Greek-derived term for a group of
label: Paragraph

text: nine, the number of remaining partners in that practice). But the allure of a
label: Paragraph

text: widely recognized name dies hard, and even though James Polshek’s office
label: Paragraph

text: was renowned for its dependably fine if rarely spectacular work, his
label: Paragraph

text: successors preferred a concocted moniker more reminiscent of a sport-
label: Paragraph

text: utility vehicle than an architectural atelier.
label: Paragraph

text: Today’s mania for constant extrapersonal validation—especially through
label: Paragraph

text: our all-pervasive electronic media—threatens the most likely means we
label: Paragraph

text: have, and have always had, for gauging the successful outcome of a
label: Paragraph

text: building commission: through some direct understanding by architects of
label: Paragraph

text: what their clients want and, reciprocally, clients who trust that an architect
label: Paragraph

text: understands and is willing to act upon their requirements. In rare
label: Paragraph

text: circumstances such transactions rise above the level of mere expediency
label: Paragraph

text: and enter the realm of art. That condition is never dependent on high
label: Paragraph

text: expenditure, as evidenced in the last chapter of this book by Maya Lin’s
label: Paragraph

text: Riggio-Lynch Chapel, a church humble enough for Saint Francis of Assisi
label: Caption

text: but grand enough for Dr. Martin Luther King. In some essential way this
label: Paragraph

text: small but powerful sanctuary expresses the “quiet inner voice” I wrote
label: Paragraph

text: about in my initial 1999 essay on Piano. That expression of architecture’s
label: Paragraph

text: ability to elevate life in countless ways can still be heard from time to time
label: Paragraph

text: in the profession, drowned out though it often is by the distracting modem
label: Paragraph

text: clamor of money, fame, and self-interest. To the heroines and heroes who
label: Paragraph

text: appear in this book and its two forerunners, I give thanks for my fruitful
label: Paragraph

text: career in helping to document their struggles and triumphs in this most
label: Paragraph

text: daunting of all art forms, a task I have attempted to fulfill as
label: Paragraph

text: sympathetically as possible.

text: FREDERICK LAW OLMSTED
label: Title

text: THE NEARLY UNIVERSAL acclaim that greeted New York City’s High Line—
label: Paragraph

text: the linear greenway built between 2006 and 2014 atop an abandoned
label: Paragraph

text: elevated railway spur that opened in 1934 on Manhattan’s Lower West Side
label: Paragraph

text: —reconfirmed the transformative effect parks can have on the quality of
label: Paragraph

text: urban life. Well before the project’s completion, real estate prices began to
label: Paragraph

text: soar in the vicinity of this one-and-a-half-mile-long wonder of adaptive
label: Paragraph

text: reuse. The surrounding neighborhood subsequently became among the
label: Paragraph

text: trendiest and costliest in town, and thousands visit it daily, many from
label: Paragraph

text: abroad. Yet however much the High Line has enriched the megalopolis
label: Paragraph

text: (economically not least of all), its social effects pale in comparison to the
label: Paragraph

text: revolutionary vision of the public park as promulgated by its greatest
label: Paragraph

text: American exponent, the nineteenth-century polymath Frederick Law
label: Title

text: Olmsted.
label: Paragraph

text: Besides being an experimental farmer, prolific journalist, crusading
label: Paragraph

text: publisher, military health-care reformer, and insightful social critic,
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted was also the greatest advocate and impresario of the public realm
label: Paragraph

text: this country has ever produced. Now best remembered as the codesigner,
label: Paragraph

text: with the British-born architect Calvert Vaux, of New York’s Central Park of
label: Paragraph

text: 1857-1873, he was even more important as the veritable inventor of
label: Paragraph

text: landscape architecture as a modern profession (see Illustration 1a). For
label: Paragraph

text: apart from Olmsted’s exceptional and apparently innate abilities as a
label: Paragraph

text: horticulturist—he had little formal training—he systematically conceived
label: Paragraph

text: the large-scale reshaping of the natural terrain to an extent unimaginable to
label: Paragraph

text: such illustrious and influential antecedents as Capability Brown in Georgian
label: Paragraph

text: England and Andrew Jackson Downing (Olmsted’s beloved mentor) in pre—
label: Paragraph

text: Civil War America.
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted can also be said to have Americanized high-style landscape
label: Paragraph

text: design, despite all he learned from British sources about felicitous
label: Paragraph

text: composition. He created vistas like a series of Constable paintings with an
label: Paragraph

text: almost cinematic revelation of one breathtakingly arranged Arcadian
label: Paragraph

text: tableau after another, but whenever possible he used native species to make
label: Paragraph

text: his schemes seem like spontaneous emanations of the ecology rather than
label: Paragraph

text: artificial impositions. Though he was hardly averse to transporting the best
label: Paragraph

text: available plant material over long distances, and had mature trees and
label: Paragraph

text: shrubs for Central Park shipped in quantity from England, Olmsted always
label: Paragraph

text: closely studied local settings for indigenous characteristics that he
label: Paragraph

text: reproduced with astounding fidelity. Likewise he shunned the strenuous
label: Paragraph

text: exoticism of Victorian gardening, with its cedars of Lebanon, Argentinian
label: Paragraph

text: pampas grasses, Mexican agaves, Chilean monkey puzzle trees, and
label: Paragraph

text: Norfolk Island pines that flaunted horticulture’s new imperial scope.
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted and his collaborators created scores of parks large and small—in
label: Paragraph

text: Boston and Fall River, Massachusetts; Baltimore; Bridgeport, Hartford,
label: Paragraph

text: New Britain, and New London, Connecticut; Chicago; Detroit; Louisville,
label: Paragraph

text: Kentucky; Milwaukee; Montreal; Buffalo, Newburgh, and Rochester, New
label: Paragraph

text: York; Newport, Rhode Island; Philadelphia; and San Francisco. He also laid
label: Paragraph

text: out campuses for the University of California at Berkeley, Stanford
label: Caption

text: University in Palo Alto, and the University of Chicago; Mountain View
label: Paragraph

text: Cemetery in Oakland, California; as well as one of America’s earliest
label: Paragraph

text: planned suburbs, Riverside, Illinois. He was responsible for the nation’s
label: Paragraph

text: first state park—the Niagara Reservation, which got rid of the commercial
label: Paragraph

text: mess that disgraced the famous waterfalls. At his urging the Yosemite
label: Paragraph

text: Valley was put under federal jurisdiction, the first public land to be thus
label: Paragraph

text: protected, and his 1896 report to Congress about the valley is now seen as a
label: Paragraph

text: mission statement for the then-nascent National Park movement.
label: Paragraph

text: Central Park, which launched Olmsted’s landscaping career and inspired
label: Paragraph

text: communities across the country to commission similar projects from him,
label: Paragraph

text: emerged at a pivotal moment in the recognition of our environmental
label: Paragraph

text: treasures and their increasing endangerment. A distinctively American form
label: Paragraph

text: of nature worship—exalted through the writings of the Transcendentalists
label: Paragraph

text: Ralph Waldo Emerson and Henry David Thoreau, the poetry of William
label: Title

text: Cullen Bryant, and the art of Hudson River School painters, including
label: Paragraph

text: Thomas Cole and Frederic Edwin Church—grew into a widely accepted
label: Paragraph

text: non-sectarian sort of spirituality. This resulted in a significant change in
label: Paragraph

text: public attitudes toward the environment, which for the first two centuries of
label: Paragraph

text: European settlement in the Western Hemisphere were more about
label: Paragraph

text: despoilment than preservation. Lewis Mumford later called this shift “an
label: Paragraph

text: effort to make reparations to nature.”
label: Paragraph

text: The saga of Central Park began in 1844, when Bryant wrote a New York
label: Paragraph

text: Post editorial that urged the country’s burgeoning metropolis to establish an
label: Paragraph

text: appropriately grand public pleasure ground. The idea languished in the
label: Paragraph

text: politically corrupt city, where no official activity was free from favoritism
label: Paragraph

text: and graft. Under the so-called spoils system, the elected party had absolute
label: Paragraph

text: control over public funds and distribution of municipal jobs, with abrupt
label: Paragraph

text: shifts in allocations and appointments when power changed hands, which it
label: Paragraph

text: did with surprising frequency in mid-nineteenth-century New York City.
label: Paragraph

text: High among Olmsted’s many accomplishments was his ability to buck this
label: Paragraph

text: entrenched self-interest and bring his dream to fruition.
label: Paragraph

text: The seed of that vision was planted in 1850 during his trip to Europe to
label: Paragraph

text: study new farming methods, though as always Olmsted’s restless eye
label: Paragraph

text: absorbed everything of interest. Soon after debarking in Liverpool he
label: Paragraph

text: visited Birkenhead Park of 1841-1847 in the eponymous town across the
label: Paragraph

text: River Mersey from the great seaport. Laid out by Joseph Paxton—the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape gardener who with the engineer Charles Fox designed the Crystal
label: Paragraph

text: Palace of 1850-1851 in London—the 125-acre Birkenhead tract was the
label: Paragraph

text: earliest urban park in Britain developed with public funds and open to all
label: Paragraph

text: classes.
label: Paragraph

text: This represented an enormous advance in the gradual democratization of
label: Paragraph

text: civic culture that began during the Enlightenment. Just as the establishment
label: Paragraph

text: of the first public museums in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth
label: Paragraph

text: centuries extended the audience for art beyond the aristocracy, so Paxton
label: Paragraph

text: improved upon forerunners such as Green Park and Hyde Park in London,
label: Paragraph

text: which were created from former royal hunting preserves but open only to
label: Paragraph

text: gentlefolk.
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted’s perceptive 1851 report on this innovation, “The People’s Park
label: Paragraph

text: at Birkenhead, near Liverpool,” is among the forty-seven essays,
label: Paragraph

text: memoranda, and excerpts from his travel dispatches, along with sixty
label: Paragraph

text: letters, collected in the Library of America’s thoroughly inspiring Frederick
label: Paragraph

text: Law Olmsted: Writings on Landscape, Culture, and Society (2015),
label: Caption

text: authoritatively edited by the preeminent expert on the master, Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Beveridge. Also in 2015, publication of the ninth volume of Olmsted’s
label: Paragraph

text: correspondence culminated the heroic project initiated by Johns Hopkins
label: Paragraph

text: University Press in 1972. If this collection does not numerically surpass the
label: Paragraph

text: forty-six volumes of Adams family papers issued by Harvard University
label: Caption

text: Press since 1954, it nonetheless represents the most ambitious initiative of
label: Paragraph

text: its kind on behalf of an American artist or designer in any medium, and
label: Paragraph

text: deservedly so.
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted’s seminal essay on the People’s Park epitomizes not only his
label: Paragraph

text: breezy, conversational, inimitably American voice, but also predicts, in
label: Paragraph

text: startlingly prescient detail, what by the end of the decade would become
label: Paragraph

text: Central Park. His text reveals that it was not stylistic considerations that
label: Paragraph

text: took precedence for him, but rather a design’s social implications. As he
label: Paragraph

text: wrote of that momentous field trip:
label: Paragraph

text: In studying the manner in which art had been employed to obtain from
label: Paragraph

text: nature so much beauty, . . . I was ready to admit that in democratic
label: Paragraph

text: America, there was nothing to be thought of as comparable with this
label: Paragraph

text: People’s Garden. Indeed, I was satisfied that gardening had here
label: Paragraph

text: reached a perfection that I had never before dreamed of. . . . We passed
label: Paragraph

text: through winding paths, over acres and acres, with a constant varying
label: Paragraph

text: surface, where on all sides were growing every variety of shrubs and
label: Paragraph

text: flowers, with more than natural grace, all set in borders of greenest,
label: Paragraph

text: closest turf, and all kept with most consummate neatness. At a distance
label: Paragraph

text: of a quarter of a mile from the gate, we came to an open field of clean,
label: Paragraph

text: bright, green-sward, closely mown, on which. . . a party of boys... .
label: Paragraph

text: were playing cricket.
label: Paragraph

text: Beyond this was a large meadow with rich groups of trees, under
label: Paragraph

text: which a flock of sheep were reposing, and girls and women with
label: Paragraph

text: children, were playing. While watching the cricketers, we were
label: Paragraph

text: threatened with a shower, and hastened back to look for shelter, which
label: Paragraph

text: we found in a pagoda. . . . It was soon filled . . . and I was glad to
label: Paragraph

text: observe that the privileges of the garden were enjoyed about equally
label: Paragraph

text: by all classes. There were some who even were attended by servants,
label: Paragraph

text: and sent at once for their carriages, but a large proportion were of the
label: Paragraph

text: common ranks, and a few women with children, or suffering from ill
label: Paragraph

text: health, were evidently the wives of very humble laborers. . . .
label: Paragraph

text: All this magnificent pleasure-ground is entirely, unreservedly, and
label: Paragraph

text: forever the People’s own. The poorest British peasant is as free to
label: Paragraph

text: enjoy it in all its parts, as the British Queen.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1840s, New York City was flooded by somewhere between a
label: Paragraph

text: million and a million and a half immigrants, mainly Irish and German, who
label: Paragraph

text: were largely unaccustomed to living in a dense, heterogeneous urban
label: Paragraph

text: setting. Olmsted grasped how a park like Birkenhead could serve New York
label: Paragraph

text: as a vast outdoor classroom for mass acculturation, where uneducated
label: Paragraph

text: newcomers would be on an equal footing with the established citizenry and
label: Paragraph

text: observe modes of improving behavior—in dress, deportment, and leisure
label: Paragraph

text: pursuits—that they otherwise might not encounter. Also in Olmsted’s article
label: Paragraph

text: we find a veritable checklist of features later realized in the 843-acre
label: Paragraph

text: Central Park: the serpentine pathways, the Mall shaded by American elms,
label: Caption

text: the grassy Sheep Meadow, the glades and underbrush of the Rambles, and
label: Paragraph

text: the spacious ball fields of the Great Lawn. Even the Greensward Plan, the
label: Paragraph

text: name that Olmsted and Vaux gave their competition-winning New York
label: Paragraph

text: design, is prefigured here.
label: Paragraph

text: Central Park was laid out four decades before Manhattan’s first
label: Paragraph

text: automobile fatality in 1899, but urban equine traffic was also often deadly;
label: Paragraph

text: in 1900 there were some two hundred horse-related deaths in New York
label: Paragraph

text: City. Thus Olmsted and Vaux’s strict division of circulation in the park
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledged the ever-present danger of such accidents by consigning
label: Paragraph

text: heavy east-west vehicular traffic to crosstown transverses sunk well below
label: Paragraph

text: surface level, while above-grade pedestrian footpaths dipped beneath north—
label: Paragraph

text: south roadways through small bridges and short tunnels. (The partners, who
label: Paragraph

text: until they ended their partnership refused individual credit for any specific
label: Paragraph

text: design solution, seem to have gotten this idea from a pedestrian underpass
label: Paragraph

text: in John Nash’s Regent’s Park of 1812-1835 in London.)
label: Caption

text: Their concept of dual circulation soon became an article of faith among
label: Paragraph

text: progressive planners in the United States and Europe. Clarence Stein and
label: Paragraph

text: Henry Wright’s much-praised 1929 design for Radburn, New Jersey—
label: Paragraph

text: touted as the “New Town for the Motor Age”—so effectively segregates
label: Paragraph

text: cars and people that children can walk to local schools and playgrounds
label: Paragraph

text: without crossing a street. Stein, whose Central Park West apartment
label: Caption

text: overlooked the 65th Street Transverse, said that he discovered what became
label: Paragraph

text: known as “the Radburn idea” simply by peering out his front window.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet for all the priority Olmsted and Vaux gave to traffic patterns, it
label: Paragraph

text: remains hard to believe that almost everything one now sees in Central Park
label: Paragraph

text: is man-made (see I]lustration 1b). This impression depends entirely on their
label: Paragraph

text: adherence to the naturalistic ethos of the eighteenth-century British
label: Paragraph

text: Romantic landscape movement, which supplanted the strictly formal,
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical, geometric approach typified by the seventeenth-century
label: Paragraph

text: French master André Le Notre, who in turn drew on earlier Italian
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance models. In contrast, the softly undulating outlines and gentle
label: Paragraph

text: contours of a new British landscape style that came into vogue around 1750
label: Paragraph

text: evoked the so-called line of beauty expounded by William Hogarth and
label: Paragraph

text: other aesthetic theorists, who believed that the graceful Rococo S-curve was
label: Paragraph

text: the basis for all visual harmony.
label: Paragraph

text: Capability Brown and his principal follower, Humphry Repton, sought to
label: Paragraph

text: make their landscapes seem as though they had evolved naturally over time
label: Paragraph

text: rather than being newly formed by the hand of man, exactly what Olmsted
label: Paragraph

text: achieved time and again in his work. Renderings and photographs of
label: Paragraph

text: Central Park in its early years remind us that it took four decades for it to
label: Paragraph

text: grow into the mature form we recognize today. Olmsted’s ability to imagine
label: Paragraph

text: how a barren stretch of urban wasteland could be turmmed into an idyllic
label: Paragraph

text: glade that looks as if it had been there forever is further demonstrated in
label: Paragraph

text: several of his before-and-after sketches of Central Park. These and other
label: Paragraph

text: visual documents make it clear how complicated that task was, with a host
label: Paragraph

text: of now invisible infrastructural underpinnings that needed to be put into
label: Paragraph

text: place—foundations for roads and paths, soil emendation and storm
label: Paragraph

text: drainage, rerouting existing streams and ponds, dynamiting rock
label: Paragraph

text: outcroppings—before any planting could begin.
label: Paragraph

text: Frederick Law Olmsted was born in 1822 to a successful Hartford
label: Paragraph

text: merchant who long remained his son’s financial mainstay, much as that
label: Paragraph

text: other towering nineteenth-century design and social reformer William
label: Paragraph

text: Morris was supported by a rich parent until he finally found his professional
label: Paragraph

text: footing. Olmsted received an excellent secondary education at the Phillips
label: Paragraph

text: Academy in Andover, Massachusetts, but poor health kept him from
label: Paragraph

text: matriculating at Yale as planned. He then began a fitful decade of assorted
label: Paragraph

text: occupations—from dry goods clerk to apprentice seaman on a China trade
label: Title

text: ship that sailed to Canton and back in 1843-—1844— before his father staked
label: Paragraph

text: him to a 125-acre farm on Staten Island. (Miraculously, the old Olmsted
label: Paragraph

text: homestead still stands, though in decrepit condition, near that outer
label: Paragraph

text: borough’s busy Hylan Boulevard. It was bought by the city of New York in
label: Paragraph

text: 2006 to prevent its destruction, and ought to be restored as befits an
label: Paragraph

text: important cultural landmark.)
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout his life, Olmsted displayed an extraordinary ability to
label: Paragraph

text: immerse himself in a new subject and fully master it. To better cultivate his
label: Paragraph

text: Staten Island property he studied the emergent applied science of
label: Paragraph

text: progressive farming and land management enabled by recent discoveries in
label: Paragraph

text: plant biology, industrial chemistry, and agricultural machinery. Yet the
label: Paragraph

text: young would-be agronomist had many competing interests, and found that
label: Paragraph

text: the relentless dawn-to-dark drudgery of farm work kept him from other
label: Paragraph

text: pursuits. His watchful father saw the problem and admonished, “Your farm
label: Paragraph

text: will require your close & undivided personal attention at all times & I hope
label: Paragraph

text: no extraneous or unimportant matters . . . will take up your mind & time.”
label: Paragraph

text: However, important matters continued to distract the endlessly curious
label: Paragraph

text: Fred, mainly journalism, a direct outgrowth of the acute powers of
label: Paragraph

text: observation and thoughtful analysis so evident in his personal
label: Paragraph

text: correspondence. Setting aside full-time farming, he served a two-year stint
label: Paragraph

text: as an editor of Putnam’s Magazine, founded in New York in 1853 as an
label: Paragraph

text: American-minded alternative to the Anglocentric literary journal Harper’s
label: Paragraph

text: New Monthly Magazine. This job ended when Putnam’s foundered after the
label: Paragraph

text: Panic of 1857, not the last time a nationwide financial crisis affected his
label: Paragraph

text: career.
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted’s extensive travels throughout the southern and southwestern
label: Paragraph

text: United States during the 1850s to report on social and economic conditions
label: Paragraph

text: for The New-York Daily Times produced sharply perceptive columns that
label: Paragraph

text: were subsequently collected in three volumes, the first and best of which—
label: Paragraph

text: A Journey in the Seaboard Slave States (1856)—remains a classic on a par
label: Paragraph

text: with Alexis de Tocqueville’s endlessly cited American critique of a
label: Paragraph

text: generation earlier. Although Olmsted was not an abolitionist, he supported
label: Paragraph

text: the proposal that slave owners should be compensated for the value of their
label: Paragraph

text: freed human chattel as the most equitable and practicable means of
label: Paragraph

text: avoiding the looming conflict between North and South. That solution—
label: Paragraph

text: which likely would have been far less costly than the Civil War in money,
label: Paragraph

text: let alone blood—was of course never implemented.
label: Paragraph

text: The Cotton Kingdom, a compendium of his travel writings published in
label: Paragraph

text: 1862 during the Civil War, gave a harsh view of the region’s inhabitants,
label: Paragraph

text: and debunked even their much-vaunted southern hospitality:
label: Paragraph

text: The citizens of the cotton States . . . work little, and that little, badly;
label: Paragraph

text: they earn little, they sell little; they buy little, and they have little—
label: Paragraph

text: very little—of the common comforts and consolations of civilized life.
label: Paragraph

text: Their destitution is not material only; it is intellectual and it is
label: Paragraph

text: moral. ... They were neither generous nor hospitable. . . .
label: Paragraph

text: When hostilities broke out Olmsted had already completed his principal
label: Paragraph

text: work on Central Park, and was thus able to transfer to the war effort the
label: Paragraph

text: formidable executive skills he’d developed in marshaling the huge platoons
label: Paragraph

text: of contractors and workmen for a logistically complex job. He became head
label: Paragraph

text: of the US Sanitary Commission, an agency created after the incompetence
label: Paragraph

text: of the US Army’s Medical Department became a national scandal. Long
label: Paragraph

text: before the founding of the American Red Cross (1881) and the Department
label: Paragraph

text: of Veterans Affairs (1930), the Sanitary Commission tried to ameliorate the
label: Paragraph

text: appalling conditions inflicted on wounded and diseased soldiers. Of the
label: Paragraph

text: 620,000 men who lost their lives in the Civil War, two thirds succumbed to
label: Paragraph

text: illness, and Olmsted struggled to stem that toll in a period when the very
label: Paragraph

text: basics of hygiene and sanitation were doubtful.
label: Paragraph

text: After the war he returned to finish his work on Central Park, and with
label: Paragraph

text: Vaux began planning the sequel that some consider an even more exquisite
label: Paragraph

text: composition: their 585-acre Prospect Park of 1865-1873 in nearby
label: Paragraph

text: Brooklyn. But Olmsted still kept a hand in the literary world as a financial
label: Paragraph

text: backer of The Nation, the liberal political journal founded in 1865, to which
label: Paragraph

text: he was an occasional contributor. Olmsted and Vaux dissolved their firm in
label: Paragraph

text: 1872 after increasing disagreements, but the Panic of 1873 deterred
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted’s rapid rebound. When economic conditions improved he quickly
label: Paragraph

text: reestablished himself with the help of two new partners—his nephew and
label: Paragraph

text: adopted son John Charles Olmsted and his younger biological son,
label: Paragraph

text: Frederick Law Olmsted Jr., who headed the firm until he retired in 1949.
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted Brothers finally went out of business in 1980.
label: Paragraph

text: By the first half of the 1890s—the period covered by the ninth volume of
label: Paragraph

text: the Olmsted correspondence—the grand old man had become not merely a
label: Paragraph

text: national but a continental eminence, as demand for his services impelled
label: Paragraph

text: him to shuttle continually among far-flung projects from Maine to
label: Paragraph

text: California and Michigan to Kentucky. Most experimental among them was
label: Paragraph

text: his comprehensive planning of the Biltmore Estate in the North Carolina
label: Paragraph

text: Blue Ridge Mountains for George Washington Vanderbilt Il. The
label: Caption

text: centerpiece of this 125,000-acre property is Richard Morris Hunt’s Biltmore
label: Paragraph

text: House of 1889-1895, still the largest private residence in America, a French
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance Revival chateau like those favored by Vanderbilt’s plutocratic
label: Paragraph

text: kin and kind on New York’s Fifth Avenue. Olmsted urged his client, who
label: Paragraph

text: had run the Vanderbilt family farm on Staten Island, not far from Olmsted’s
label: Paragraph

text: old property, to rise above the empty ostentation of Gilded Age display and
label: Paragraph

text: instead turn the surrounding land into a model of moder sustainable
label: Paragraph

text: forestry, an idea the multimillionaire admirably endorsed. The Biltmore
label: Paragraph

text: Estate, now owned by a family trust, has become a hugely popular tourist
label: Paragraph

text: destination and attracts more than a million visitors each year.
label: Paragraph

text: Not all of Olmsted’s late projects were so happy. His work at the World’s
label: Paragraph

text: Columbian Exposition of 1893 in Chicago fell victim to the rigid formality
label: Paragraph

text: of the fair’s Beaux Arts—inspired layout, in which monumental Classicizing
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were surrounded by enormous lagoons that impeded easy
label: Paragraph

text: circulation. One critic wrote that although Olmsted’s contribution was
label: Paragraph

text: “unquestionably very fine to look at,” it was “totally unsuited for practical
label: Paragraph

text: purposes.” The designer conceded as much, and wrote that the fair would
label: Paragraph

text: have been much better without “perhaps a third of all that was exhibited and
label: Paragraph

text: ... an innumerable lot of trifling concession coops and shantees with slight
label: Paragraph

text: regard to the landscape design.”
label: Paragraph

text: But this was a rare flub in an otherwise unbroken sequence of successes
label: Paragraph

text: that gave many American cities their finest civic features, especially
label: Paragraph

text: Boston’s dazzling “Emerald Necklace” park system (which comprises the
label: Paragraph

text: Back Bay Fens, the Arnold Arboretum, and Wood Island Park, among other
label: Paragraph

text: things) and the refashioning of Buffalo’s topography through parkways,
label: Paragraph

text: squares, and lakefront improvements. In 1895, the seventy-three-year-old
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted began to notice short-term memory lapses, and though his letters
label: Paragraph

text: from that year show no sign of cognitive impairment, his sons also
label: Paragraph

text: recognized his increasing decline and eased him out of the family business.
label: Paragraph

text: Before long he had full-blown dementia, and he lived out the last five years
label: Paragraph

text: of his life in a cottage at the McLean Hospital near Boston, where he died
label: Paragraph

text: in 1903 amid grounds he had laid out long before.
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted’s status as a national figure was confirmed by the invitation in
label: Paragraph

text: 1874 to landscape the grounds of the United States Capitol in Washington,
label: Caption

text: D.C., a tricky assignment that gave this sprawling and oddly proportioned
label: Paragraph

text: structure—erected in fits and starts to the designs of several different
label: Paragraph

text: architects throughout the first half of the nineteenth century—a softening
label: Paragraph

text: frame of majestic trees and a virtual pedestal of shrubberies worthy of the
label: Paragraph

text: project’s grandeur. This deeply symbolic scheme also paid indirect homage
label: Paragraph

text: to a national heritage of unparalleled natural splendor, which Olmsted, more
label: Paragraph

text: than anyone save the pioneering conservationists George Perkins Marsh and
label: Paragraph

text: John Muir, identified, celebrated, enhanced, extended, and preserved. Yet
label: Paragraph

text: even Olmsted, for all his uncanny foresight about how his parks would
label: Paragraph

text: function in a future beyond his possible imagination, could never have
label: Paragraph

text: predicted how instructive they would be in our polarized postmillennial
label: Paragraph

text: America, so different from the egalitarian society his unifying designs
label: Paragraph

text: vigorously promoted.
