text: ANTONI GAUDI
label: Title

text: ALTHOUGH SACRED STRUCTURES Of all sorts have been central to every culture
label: Paragraph

text: throughout history, religious architecture has attained even greater
label: Paragraph

text: importance in times of social upheaval. This was certainly true in mid-
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth-century Barcelona, the ancient Mediterranean seaport that had
label: Paragraph

text: lately become an economic powerhouse with the advent of industrialized
label: Paragraph

text: textile manufacturing. As the strains caused by this rapid shift from small
label: Paragraph

text: workshop to large factory production worsened, many felt that the Roman
label: Paragraph

text: Catholic Church was unresponsive to the travails of increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: downtrodden urban laborers. Thus during the 1870s pious (and wealthy)
label: Paragraph

text: barcelonés conceived a monumental building project for a working-class
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhood that they hoped would stem religious disaffection by harking
label: Paragraph

text: back to the devotional fervor, communal brotherhood, and civic pride
label: Title

text: fostered by the construction of grand cathedrals during the Middle Ages.
label: Paragraph

text: The result is one of the most celebrated shrines in Christendom, known in
label: Paragraph

text: Catalan as the Temple Expiatori de la Sagrada Familia (Expiatory Temple
label: Paragraph

text: of the Holy Family). It was begun in 1882 using the conventional neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic designs of Francisco de Paula del Villar, who after two years of
label: Paragraph

text: persistent quarrels with diocesan supervisors quit and handed the job over
label: Paragraph

text: to his largely untested assistant Antoni Gaudi. Over the next four decades
label: Paragraph

text: Gaudi worked toward a church that would be both intensely personal yet
label: Paragraph

text: embracingly universal, startlingly unprecedented though rooted in tradition,
label: Paragraph

text: and altogether far more rich and strange than anything del Villar ever
label: Paragraph

text: dreamed of (see Illustration 2a).
label: Paragraph

text: Although many cathedrals feature elaborate ensembles that depict scenes
label: Paragraph

text: from the Gospel, the program of the Sagrada Familia sculptures makes most
label: Paragraph

text: others seem rather subdued. Gaudi’s jam-packed Nativity Facade, executed
label: Paragraph

text: between 1894 and 1930, offers a paradisiacal vision of (holy) family life
label: Paragraph

text: amid a panoply of grottoes dripping with stalactites, dense with leafy
label: Paragraph

text: bocage, and alive with all sorts of fauna and flora. You have to look closely
label: Paragraph

text: to find Jesus, Mary, and Joseph through all the busy detail, a bit like some
label: Paragraph

text: divine “Where’s Waldo?” game. One can scarcely imagine what this
label: Paragraph

text: teeming jumble would have looked like had it been painted in polychrome,
label: Paragraph

text: as Gaudi wanted to do in the manner of ancient Greek sculpture and
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Above the sanctuary rise eight elongated sugarloaf spires (four were
label: Caption

text: completed before the Spanish civil war, and another quartet has been added
label: Paragraph

text: since, with another ten yet to come). Their surfaces are multicolored mosaic
label: Paragraph

text: and they are surmounted by torqued and faceted pinnacles topped with
label: Paragraph

text: marvelous finials like radiant monstrances. Unfurled down the sides of the
label: Paragraph

text: towers, where only angels can read them, are trompe 1’oeil scrolls joyously
label: Paragraph

text: inscribed “Excelsis,” “Hosanna,” and “Sanctus.”
label: Paragraph

text: Contrary to the common misnomer, the Sagrada Familia is not a
label: Paragraph

text: cathedral—site of a bishop’s throne, or cathedra—though it was elevated to
label: Paragraph

text: the status of a “minor basilica” when Pope Benedict XVI consecrated the
label: Paragraph

text: half-finished church in 2010. Still under construction after more than a
label: Paragraph

text: century and a quarter of financially and politically related fits and starts, it
label: Paragraph

text: is scheduled to conclude in 2026, the centennial of the architect’s death.
label: Paragraph

text: (Gaudi succumbed at seventy-three after he was hit by a tram on his way
label: Paragraph

text: from the Sagrada Familia to the parish church where he attended vespers
label: Paragraph

text: every evening.)
label: Paragraph

text: The Sagrada Familia, Barcelona’s top tourist attraction, welcomes some
label: Paragraph

text: three million visitors annually—nearly twice the city’s population—and
label: Paragraph

text: their admission fees have been the major source of revenue for completing
label: Paragraph

text: the edifice. The architect is a cult figure not only in his native region, where
label: Paragraph

text: he exemplifies the unruly Catalan spirit to political separatists, but as far
label: Paragraph

text: away as Japan. There in 2011 the hugely popular manga artist Takehiko
label: Paragraph

text: Inoue—whose usual subject is basketball—published a book that seeks to
label: Paragraph

text: pinpoint the source of Gaudi’s inspiration, an ultimately futile task when it
label: Paragraph

text: comes to such a complex, and to some extent inexplicable, figure.
label: Paragraph

text: The architectural historian Judith Rohrer has written that the Sagrada
label: Paragraph

text: Familia (originally meant to house pharos-like searchlights in its pinnacles)
label: Paragraph

text: was intended to “serve as a beacon of faith, proclaiming the revived piety of
label: Paragraph

text: the Spanish people, while atoning for the sins, both public and private, of a
label: Paragraph

text: modernist, materialist age.” The strain of deep conservatism implicit in that
label: Paragraph

text: formulation—which brings to mind the militant antimodemism of Pope
label: Paragraph

text: Pius [X, who died shortly before the Sagrada Familia’s inception—makes
label: Paragraph

text: one understand why proletarian radicals did not necessarily view this costly
label: Paragraph

text: exercise in spiritual advertisement as a social improvement program.
label: Paragraph

text: The new church was dedicated to the Holy Family because Saint Joseph
label: Paragraph

text: was a Carpenter with whom the city’s laborers might personally identify.
label: Paragraph

text: But empathetic feelings among that target audience were perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: undermined when the architect’s iconography for the Temptation portal
label: Paragraph

text: (one of several thematic groupings that in addition to the Nativity include
label: Paragraph

text: the Rosary, the Way of the Cross, and the Crucifixion) revealed a figure of a
label: Paragraph

text: demon proffering a workman a spherical Orsini bomb—the handheld
label: Paragraph

text: weapon favored by fin-de-siécle anarchists.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus despite the populist appeal of the Sagrada Familia’s exuberant
label: Paragraph

text: forms and idiosyncratic decoration, a severely critical undertone lodged in
label: Paragraph

text: some people’s minds. Lingering resentment took a violent turn when in
label: Paragraph

text: 1936, during the Spanish civil war, Republican rioters broke into Gaudi’s
label: Paragraph

text: old studio and destroyed his plaster models for the church. Indeed, as late as
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s, when my wife, Rosemarie Haag Bletter, did research as a
label: Paragraph

text: graduate student in Barcelona on Gaudi’s lesser-known contemporary Josep
label: Paragraph

text: Vilaseca, she was habitually quizzed by different factions about her attitude
label: Paragraph

text: toward the completion of Gaudi’s church, a political litmus test under the
label: Paragraph

text: Franco regime, which looked upon gaudisme as a cover for seditious
label: Paragraph

text: Catalan dissidents.
label: Paragraph

text: This was a tricky question to answer in any case, because Gaudi certainly
label: Paragraph

text: realized that no one designer could live long enough to see such a grandiose
label: Paragraph

text: endeavor through to completion. And although he left detailed instructions
label: Paragraph

text: for parts of the structure still unbuilt during his lifetime, he expected (and
label: Paragraph

text: accepted) that other designers would put their own, likely quite different,
label: Paragraph

text: stamp on it, as happened with cathedrals such as Chartres, with its
label: Paragraph

text: mismatching early Gothic and Flamboyant spires.
label: Paragraph

text: “Great temples were not the work of one architect,” Gaudi observed, but
label: Paragraph

text: those in charge at the Sagrada Familia today have drawn on his work to the
label: Paragraph

text: exclusion of all other possibilities. To be sure, a highly skilled, deeply
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated group of architectural, engineering, and decorative arts
label: Title

text: professionals was directed from 2012 onward by the Barcelona architect
label: Paragraph

text: Jordi Fauli (who spent the preceding two decades as an associate on the
label: Paragraph

text: project). The team hewed as faithfully as possible to the letter of Gaudi’s
label: Paragraph

text: vision, but one wonders about the spirit. As a visit to the Sagrada Familia
label: Paragraph

text: today indicates, there is such a thing as being too conscientious. Employing
label: Paragraph

text: the most advanced computer imaging technology, it has been possible to
label: Paragraph

text: reconstitute elements once thought irretrievably lost after Gaudi’s models
label: Paragraph

text: were shattered. Yet the newest portions of the Barcelona landmark utterly
label: Paragraph

text: lack the tactile quality of the parts of the Sagrada Familia carried out while
label: Paragraph

text: Gaudi was alive. The sense of an artist being physically involved is
label: Paragraph

text: conspicuously missing from the most recent additions there.
label: Paragraph

text: Gaudi’s conception evolved in three distinct phases—1890, 1913-1915,
label: Paragraph

text: and 1921-1926—marked by models that varied significantly from one to
label: Paragraph

text: the next. Rohrer suggests why the version being realized today, based on
label: Paragraph

text: that final revision, seems somehow less Gaudiesque than might have been
label: Paragraph

text: expected:
label: Title

text: There is a certain angularity to the forms that emerge in this model,
label: Paragraph

text: less fluid in its continuity than Gaudi’s earlier work. While not
label: Paragraph

text: abandoning the ruled surfaces of double curvature that were so much a
label: Paragraph

text: part of his structural thinking, he nevertheless tumed in the last phase
label: Paragraph

text: of his work toward intersecting and interlocking polyhedral geometries
label: Paragraph

text: that yield an angular, prismatic, crystalline, almost cubist effect.
label: Paragraph

text: Although translating Gaudi’s reconstituted designs for the Sagrada
label: Paragraph

text: Familia into building components has been made infinitely easier by digital
label: Paragraph

text: scanning programs, there is a world of difference between the sharply
label: Paragraph

text: rendered parts that emerge from this process and the far more
label: Paragraph

text: improvisational results Gaudi was able to coax from artisans on site, his
label: Paragraph

text: habitual working method. Given the figurative arthritis that set into Gaudi’s
label: Paragraph

text: supple organic forms late in his career, strict fidelity to those last pieces of
label: Paragraph

text: work might not have been the wisest course, either. The completed nave of
label: Paragraph

text: the Sagrada Familia looks disturbingly fake, and in many places jarringly
label: Paragraph

text: slick, especially the grid-patterned, polished stone floor that brings to mind
label: Paragraph

text: the lobby of a 1980s corporate headquarters by Philip Johnson. Perhaps in
label: Paragraph

text: the fullness of time all this bright, precision-cut stonework will mellow into
label: Paragraph

text: pleasing decrepitude, but that now seems unlikely.
label: Paragraph

text: Few mainstream architects have dared emulate Gaudi directly. Today’s
label: Paragraph

text: most obvious claimant to his mantle as maverick master is Frank Gehry,
label: Paragraph

text: whose Olympic Fish pavilion of 1989-1992 in Barcelona (part of the
label: Paragraph

text: Olympic Village erected for the 1992 games) exudes the antic energy of his
label: Paragraph

text: antecedent’s biomorphic fantasias. However, the steel-mesh skin of Gehry’s
label: Paragraph

text: design is uniformly detailed and tastefully monochromatic in a High
label: Paragraph

text: Modernist mode antithetical to Gaudi’s colorful and irregular surface
label: Paragraph

text: treatments. Much more Gaudiesque in its decorative flair is Gehry’s A Rose
label: Paragraph

text: for Lilly, a fountain dedicated to the memory of Lillian Disney, widow of
label: Caption

text: the famed animator and film producer, in the garden adjacent to his Walt
label: Paragraph

text: Disney Concert Hall of 1989-2003 in Los Angeles. The surfaces of this
label: Paragraph

text: biomorphic sculpture, shaped like the honoree’s favorite flower, are inlaid
label: Paragraph

text: with shards of broken china similar to the Catalan architect’s work in
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona’s Park Giiell. Tellingly, the alacrity with which the civic sponsors
label: Paragraph

text: of Gehry’s Guggenheim Museum Bilbao (1991-1997) accepted his wildly
label: Paragraph

text: unorthodox scheme says much about the persistence of the adventurous
label: Paragraph

text: cultural attitudes Gaudi fostered in Spain a century earlier.
label: Paragraph

text: Artists in other mediums have responded to Gaudi’s example with more
label: Paragraph

text: abandon. Although it remains unclear how much the Italian-American
label: Paragraph

text: outsider sculptor Simon Rodia knew about him, there is no question that
label: Paragraph

text: Rodia’s Los Angeles landmark, known as the Watts Towers (1921-1954),
label: Paragraph

text: bears a striking resemblance to the Sagrada Familia in the outlines of its
label: Paragraph

text: spires and its hand-molded mortar surfaces studded with discarded china
label: Paragraph

text: fragments. And from the 1950s onward, the eccentric Austrian artist
label: Paragraph

text: Friedensreich Hundertwasser fabricated a series of oddly shaped, brightly
label: Paragraph

text: colored, and whimsically patterned houses in several European locales that
label: Paragraph

text: led to his being dubbed “the Austrian Gaudi.”
label: Paragraph

text: Astonishingly, given his current réclame, Gaudi languished in critical
label: Paragraph

text: limbo for three decades after his death, in part because of the Spanish civil
label: Paragraph

text: war and the cultural pariahdom visited on the Franco regime long
label: Paragraph

text: afterward. The architectural historian Nikolaus Pevsner, single-minded in
label: Paragraph

text: his promotion of a Modernist machine aesthetic, focused on Gaudi’s
label: Paragraph

text: decorative impulse but largely ignored his considerable structural
label: Paragraph

text: achievements. In his polemical Pioneers of Modern Design (1936), Pevsner
label: Paragraph

text: finds Gaudi’s fairy-tale-Gothic episcopal palace at Astorga (1887-1893)
label: Caption

text: “nightmarish” and his mysteriously organic chapel at the Colénia Giiell
label: Caption

text: (1898 and 1909-1915) “horrible.” He discerns in Gaudi’s creations not a
label: Paragraph

text: miraculous inventiveness but a “frantic desire for the unprecedented” and a
label: Paragraph

text: “delight in the arbitrary curve.”
label: Paragraph

text: However, there was nothing at all capricious about Gaudi’s parabolas and
label: Paragraph

text: catenaries, which he calibrated just as scientifically as his great engineering
label: Paragraph

text: contemporaries did their innovations, and without any of the high-tech aids
label: Paragraph

text: architects now routinely rely on. Although he scorned the use of buttresses
label: Paragraph

text: as a lazy structural crutch and was determined to find other ways to support
label: Paragraph

text: the Sagrada Familia’s high, thin walls, he also sought to avoid Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: horrors like the collapse of the choir of Beauvais cathedral in 1284 or the
label: Paragraph

text: tower of Ely cathedral in 1322.
label: Caption

text: Gaudi gauged the strength of his arches and vaults with mock-ups from
label: Paragraph

text: which he suspended sandbags on ropes to simulate the gravitational forces
label: Paragraph

text: that would bear on the executed masonry, rather than depending solely on
label: Paragraph

text: the mathematical formulae through which he arrived at his structural
label: Paragraph

text: configurations. “I am a geometrician,” the architect insisted, a riposte to
label: Paragraph

text: those who saw only willfulness in his deceptively arbitrary-looking forms.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, neurotic menace lurks everywhere in Pevsner’s fretful
label: Paragraph

text: surveys. Gaudi’s roofs are “like the backs of dinosaurs” and the ironwork of
label: Paragraph

text: his balconies “might stab you at any moment.” Although Pevsner remained
label: Paragraph

text: obtusely immune to the sheer bravura that has made Gaudi arguably the
label: Paragraph

text: world’s most beloved architect, he later softened his tone somewhat and
label: Paragraph

text: attributed that animus to an excess on his part of pro-Modernist zeal. Yet his
label: Paragraph

text: earlier position helps explain why Gaudi’s work was hardly appreciated at
label: Paragraph

text: the mid-twentieth century.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the Expressionists and Surrealists esteemed Gaudi as a fellow
label: Paragraph

text: visionary, popular attitudes began to change dramatically in the 1960s, a
label: Paragraph

text: decade of worldwide social and cultural ferment that made Gaudi’s work
label: Paragraph

text: speak to a young generation alert to imaginative and expressive qualities
label: Paragraph

text: long dismissed as pathologically bizarre, especially in architecture. Indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: there is something almost psychedelic in his freewheeling aesthetic,
label: Paragraph

text: characterized by distorted forms, propulsive patterns, kaleidoscopic colors,
label: Paragraph

text: and quirky materials. The rediscovery of Art Nouveau during the 1960s
label: Paragraph

text: carried Gaudi along with other newfound fin-de-siécle heroes of the
label: Paragraph

text: burgeoning counterculture, including Aubrey Beardsley, Alphonse Mucha,
label: Paragraph

text: and Louis Comfort Tiffany. Growing public interest was reflected in shows
label: Paragraph

text: of Gaudi’s work held at Richmond’s Virginia Museum of Fine Arts (1964)
label: Caption

text: and New York’s Museum of Modern Art (1966).
label: Paragraph

text: Ulrich Conrads and Hans G. Sperlich’s illustrated history Phantastische
label: Title

text: Architektur (1960) contained several Gaudi designs and found an even
label: Paragraph

text: wider audience in its English-language edition, The Architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: Fantasy: Utopian Building and Planning in Modern Times (1962).
label: Paragraph

text: Published that same year, Antoni Gaudi, by the Barcelona-born Modernist
label: Paragraph

text: architect Josep Lluis Sert and James Johnson Sweeney (then director of the
label: Paragraph

text: Guggenheim Museum), stressed not the architect’s phantasmagoric bent but
label: Paragraph

text: instead an unexpected pragmatism. As Sweeney and Sert write:
label: Paragraph

text: It is curious to note that Gaudi always designed taking into
label: Paragraph

text: consideration the practical methods by which his plans could be
label: Paragraph

text: carried out. He chose warped surfaces because model makers and
label: Paragraph

text: masons can construct them easily, as both the hyperboloids and the
label: Paragraph

text: hyperbolic paraboloids are ruled surfaces which can be easily
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced by straight steel rods, thus providing a considerable
label: Paragraph

text: economy.
label: Paragraph

text: Gaudi has never wanted for admirers among his countrymen, but it was
label: Paragraph

text: the American architectural historian George R. Collins (1917-1993) of
label: Paragraph

text: Columbia University who made a long-overdue reappraisal that became one
label: Paragraph

text: of the most successful attempts to elevate an artist’s critical standing in
label: Paragraph

text: modern times. During a 1959 research trip to Spain, Collins came upon a
label: Paragraph

text: large cache of unpublished Gaudi drawings, and the following year
label: Paragraph

text: published Antonio Gaudi, the first English-language monograph on the
label: Paragraph

text: architect (using the then-prevalent Castilian, not the now preferred Catalan,
label: Paragraph

text: version of the subject’s first name). Although only 136 pages long, this tour
label: Paragraph

text: de force of concision and insight definitively verifies Gaudi’s structural
label: Paragraph

text: genius and remains an unsurpassed introduction. Collins followed his
label: Paragraph

text: breakthrough with further publications (including a pioneering
label: Paragraph

text: bibliography) and influential exhibitions.
label: Paragraph

text: Gaudi’s emergence followed and paralleled that of Rafael Guastavino
label: Paragraph

text: (1842-1908), a decade-older Catalan contractor-builder who studied at the
label: Paragraph

text: same Barcelona technical college where Gaudi later went, and who worked
label: Paragraph

text: for at least one major Gaudi client, the Batll6 textile manufacturing clan.
label: Paragraph

text: Just as Gaudi drew on a host of age-old local construction traditions,
label: Paragraph

text: including a method for spanning large overhead spaces, Guastavino
label: Paragraph

text: regularized and industrialized the lowtech, cost-efficient Catalan method of
label: Paragraph

text: tile vaulting. This technique can be traced back to fourteenth-century Spain
label: Paragraph

text: but may have had its origins in similar methods devised by the ancient
label: Paragraph

text: Romans who colonized Iberia.
label: Paragraph

text: In search of international markets for his tile-vaulting concept,
label: Paragraph

text: Guastavino displayed a proposed scheme for “Improving the Healthfulness
label: Paragraph

text: of Industrial Towns” at the 1876 Centennial International Exposition in
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia, where it won an honorable mention. This encouraged him to
label: Paragraph

text: immigrate to the United States five years later, when he arrived in New
label: Paragraph

text: York with a $40,000 nest egg but soon lost it in a Manhattan tenement
label: Paragraph

text: construction speculation. He recovered financially when in 1885 he filed
label: Paragraph

text: the first three of his firm’s two dozen patents (a third of which were for
label: Paragraph

text: acoustical improvements to make tiled interiors less noisy) for the Arch
label: Caption

text: System, in which thin, grooved, slightly curved terra-cotta tiles are layered
label: Paragraph

text: to form a continuous curved surface with more tensile strength than a single
label: Paragraph

text: thicker stratum, and set with fast-drying plaster. His favored mortar—which
label: Paragraph

text: included Portland cement (an early-nineteenth-century invention, mixing
label: Paragraph

text: limestone and clay}—added further strength to vaults that were sometimes a
label: Paragraph

text: mere two inches thick.
label: Paragraph

text: This allowed a space to be spanned without the full scaffolding needed
label: Paragraph

text: for conventional brick or stone vaulting, which supports itself only after the
label: Paragraph

text: central keystone is inserted into the apex of an arch. Guastavino’s system
label: Caption

text: was quicker and cheaper than traditional masonry methods because it
label: Paragraph

text: significantly reduced labor time and preparatory materials. Furthermore, the
label: Paragraph

text: result was not only sanitary (impervious to damp and rot, plus easy to
label: Paragraph

text: clean) but, most important, fireproof, a widespread public safety concern
label: Paragraph

text: following several catastrophic nineteenth-century urban conflagrations.
label: Paragraph

text: Guastavino’s first big American success was his work on McKim, Mead
label: Paragraph

text: & White’s Boston Public Library of 1887-1895. In a tour de force of design
label: Caption

text: variation, he came up with different ceiling patterns for each room in the
label: Paragraph

text: large structure, a veritable three-dimensional catalog for his product’s
label: Paragraph

text: versatility. Significantly, he left the handsome structural tile work fully
label: Paragraph

text: exposed rather than covering it with plaster, an attitude that anticipated the
label: Paragraph

text: Modernist practice of celebrating functional elements by letting them show.
label: Paragraph

text: Thereafter his thriving company supplied Catalan-style roofs and ceilings to
label: Paragraph

text: hundreds of architectural firms over the next eight decades.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1961, a crucial connection occurred to Collins at a memorial service in
label: Paragraph

text: I. N. Phelps Stokes’s St. Paul’s Chapel of 1904-1907 on the Columbia
label: Caption

text: campus, when he had an epiphany about how closely the structure’s
label: Paragraph

text: exposed Guastavino vaulting resembled the work of Gaudi. This eureka
label: Paragraph

text: moment changed how architecture scholars understand a crucial chapter in
label: Paragraph

text: the history of modern design and suggested a missing link between
label: Paragraph

text: Catalonia and the Americas. A year later, when the Guastavino family
label: Paragraph

text: business folded and its records were about to be discarded, Collins secured
label: Paragraph

text: them for his school’s Avery Architectural and Fine Arts Library, an
label: Paragraph

text: invaluable act of cultural salvage. The Guastavino office’s meticulous
label: Paragraph

text: working drawings allow a full understanding of a structural methodology
label: Paragraph

text: that would otherwise be lost to us today. In fact, many large architectural
label: Paragraph

text: firms for whom the family worked would confidently leave portions of their
label: Paragraph

text: own blueprints blank but labeled “Guastavino here” to indicate that vaults
label: Paragraph

text: would be skillfully filled in by their trusted collaborator. No wonder the city
label: Paragraph

text: of Barcelona in 1999 renamed a street bordering Gaudi’s Finca Giiell of
label: Paragraph

text: 1884-1887 the calle George Collins.
label: Caption

text: Antoni Placid Guillem Gaudi i Cornet was born in Catalonia in 1852,
label: Paragraph

text: though it remains unclear whether that occurred in the town of Reus, where
label: Paragraph

text: his father and grandfather worked as coppersmiths, or in the family’s
label: Paragraph

text: ancestral village of Riudoms. The architect attributed his innate sense of
label: Paragraph

text: volumetric enclosure to his antecedents’ skilled craftsmanship of boilers,
label: Paragraph

text: kettles, and other heating devices. Whether or not Gaudi’s virtuosic grasp of
label: Paragraph

text: irregular forms was genetic or acquired through close observation, he
label: Paragraph

text: certainly could visualize space in three dimensions, an attribute far from
label: Paragraph

text: common among the general public and not to be taken for granted among
label: Paragraph

text: design professionals, either.
label: Paragraph

text: As the art historian Gijs van Hensbergen relates in his absorbing Gaudi:
label: Paragraph

text: A Biography (2001), the future architect from an early age displayed an
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional aptitude for mathematics, and as a teenager he and two friends
label: Paragraph

text: dreamed up an imaginative if overreaching scheme to tum a derelict local
label: Paragraph

text: monastery into a full-service tourist destination. Gaudi’s father, instead of
label: Paragraph

text: encouraging his progeny to continue in the family trade as was usual at that
label: Paragraph

text: time, sold inherited land to help finance the medical studies of Antoni’s
label: Paragraph

text: older brother and then his second son’s architectural education at
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona’s Escuela Superior de Arquitectura.
label: Paragraph

text: There have been numerous studies of Gaudi’s many sources of influence,
label: Paragraph

text: especially the authoritative French architect and theorist Eugéne-Emmanuel
label: Paragraph

text: Viollet-le-Duc, whose combination of eclectic historicizing motifs and
label: Paragraph

text: modern industrial materials is everywhere evident in Gaudi’s oeuvre. But
label: Paragraph

text: there is also a psychological complexity to the Catalan master’s work that
label: Paragraph

text: sets him above and apart from not only other European practitioners of his
label: Paragraph

text: time but also from the most talented of his contemporaries in Barcelona.
label: Paragraph

text: For all his stunning ingenuity, Gaudi did not emerge from a cultural
label: Paragraph

text: vacuum, and he was but one—albeit the most extravagantly gifted—among
label: Paragraph

text: an extraordinary generation of local architects who espoused the new credo
label: Paragraph

text: of Modernisme, the distinctive Catalan variant of Art Nouveau, which drew
label: Paragraph

text: heavily on the Romantic revivalist Renaixenga (renaissance) movement of
label: Paragraph

text: mid-nineteenth-century Spain.
label: Paragraph

text: This brilliant cohort included Lluis Doménech i Montaner (creator of
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona’s stupendous Palau de la Musica Catalana), Josep Vilaseca i
label: Paragraph

text: Casanovas (who designed the city’s neo-Moorish Arc de Triomf), and Josep
label: Paragraph

text: Puig i Cadafalch (whose step-gabled Casa Amatller stands next to Gaudi’s
label: Paragraph

text: saurian-roofed Casa Batll6 of 1905-1907 on the Passeig de Gracia,
label: Caption

text: Barcelona’s street of Modernisme dreams). There was a strong measure of
label: Paragraph

text: competitive display among Barcelona’s new industrial elite, and they vied
label: Paragraph

text: with one another in hiring these and other exponents of the new architecture
label: Paragraph

text: to design domestic showplaces of unabashed grandeur.
label: Paragraph

text: If a tycoon’s town palace could directly advertise the source of his
label: Paragraph

text: wealth, so much the better, as Gaudi achieved with his first major
label: Paragraph

text: residential commission, Casa Vicens (1878-1880), a multicultural
label: Paragraph

text: extravaganza for a brick and tile manufacturer that has been restored and is
label: Paragraph

text: now open to the public. This learned exercise in the Mudéjar style—the
label: Paragraph

text: term refers to Muslims who remained in Spain after the expulsion of the
label: Paragraph

text: Moors—juxtaposes panels of blue and white tiles in a bold checkerboard
label: Paragraph

text: pattern against tawny brick worked into daring variations on traditional
label: Paragraph

text: themes of the Mozarabic Arabs (Iberian Christian Arabs who lived under
label: Paragraph

text: Moorish rule). But as accomplished as Casa Vicens is, it exhibits none of
label: Paragraph

text: the curvaceous organic continuity that Gaudi attained in his later and most
label: Paragraph

text: famous works, exemplified by Casa Mila (1905-1910), a six-level
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona apartment building with an undulating facade that turns a
label: Paragraph

text: chamfered corner between two perpendicular streets. Clad in limestone, this
label: Caption

text: landmark is popularly known as La Pedrera (the quarry) because of its
label: Paragraph

text: craggy, cliff-like elevation and the flowing horizontal lines of the projecting
label: Paragraph

text: cornices on each story, which evoke the layering of geological strata (see
label: Paragraph

text: Illustration 2b).
label: Paragraph

text: Another hallmark of Gaudi’s architecture is ceramic embellishment.
label: Paragraph

text: Although mosaics had been incorporated into buildings since Classical
label: Paragraph

text: antiquity, he eschewed purpose-made components and instead appropriated
label: Paragraph

text: irregular shards of domestic pottery in a Catalan technique called trencadis.
label: Paragraph

text: Irregular pieces of broken dishes and teacups are readily identifiable on the
label: Paragraph

text: crazy-quilt surfaces of several of the architect’s constructions in the Park
label: Caption

text: Giiell (1900-1914), where a quite unmenacing trencadis-encrusted dragon
label: Paragraph

text: welcomes visitors at the entrance stairway, and the undulating Sea Serpent
label: Paragraph

text: Bench, similarly enriched with recycled crockery, offers a dazzling resting
label: Paragraph

text: place and vantage point on the central terrace overlooking Barcelona and
label: Paragraph

text: the sea beyond.
label: Paragraph

text: Gaudi’s most important private patron was the textile magnate Eusebi
label: Paragraph

text: Giiell i Bacigalupi, for whom he executed five major commissions in and
label: Paragraph

text: around the Catalan metropolis. The first of these was for Bodegas Giiell
label: Paragraph

text: (1882-1897), a winery in the seaside town of Sitges southwest of the city,
label: Paragraph

text: which remained in operation until 1936. Next came Palau Gitiell (1885-
label: Paragraph

text: 1889), an imposing mansion erected not in a plutocratic enclave but in what
label: Paragraph

text: was then the city’s artists’ quarter (during the early 1900s the young
label: Paragraph

text: Picasso’s studio was directly across the narrow street). The building’s
label: Paragraph

text: otherwise severe masonry facade is dominated by a powerful pair of
label: Paragraph

text: parabolic entry and exit arches screened with intricate ironwork in the form
label: Caption

text: of coiled snakes that surround the initials “E” in one portal and “G” in the
label: Paragraph

text: other. The architect’s expansion of the industrialist’s country estate, Finca
label: Paragraph

text: Giiell (1887), was followed by his primitive chapel at Colonia Giiell (1898-
label: Paragraph

text: 1915), the enlightened industrialist’s company town. With its cavernous
label: Paragraph

text: interiors and mysterious lighting, this jewel-like sanctuary seems a direct
label: Paragraph

text: precursor of Le Corbusier’s Ronchamp chapel.
label: Paragraph

text: Last in this remarkable series was the phantasmagoric Park Giiell, a
label: Paragraph

text: hillside residential development more practically based in planning terms
label: Paragraph

text: on recent English Garden City prototypes. However, it failed as a real estate
label: Paragraph

text: speculation and was turned into a municipal park. On this forty-two-acre
label: Paragraph

text: site Gaudi designed a host of endearingly strange infrastructural features,
label: Paragraph

text: including cascading stairways, snakelike pergolas, arcades composed of
label: Paragraph

text: tilting columns, as well as habitable follies for caretakers of the lushly
label: Paragraph

text: landscaped property.
label: Paragraph

text: The architect himself lived in one of those outbuildings for many years,
label: Paragraph

text: but toward the end of his life moved into makeshift quarters at the Sagrada
label: Paragraph

text: Familia to save time on commuting. This increasingly solitary and
label: Paragraph

text: fanatically devout monomaniac—a celibate vegetarian who never married
label: Paragraph

text: and was often mistaken for a vagrant because of his disheveled appearance
label: Paragraph

text: and distracted demeanor—was looked upon in his old age as a secular saint,
label: Paragraph

text: especially after 1910, when he forswore new jobs and devoted himself
label: Paragraph

text: solely to his all-consuming masterwork. And although intimations of
label: Paragraph

text: mortality weighed heavily on this phenomenally ambitious artist, we can
label: Paragraph

text: only hope that he believed the words long attributed to him when he was

text: Like Wright, Mahony was entranced by the woodblock prints of Japanese

text: Much of Olgivanna Wright’s reminiscences deal with how she and her

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Schnitzler and Sigmund Freud. Yet the singular contributions to the visual
label: Paragraph

text: arts that the Viennese made during this epoch have never loomed large
label: Paragraph

text: enough in general chronicles of Modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: The constant rewriting of art history is not solely the province of critics
label: Paragraph

text: and scholars; cultural institutions exert enormous influence on the way the
label: Paragraph

text: past is perceived. This has been demonstrated most forcefully by the strong
label: Paragraph

text: Francophile bias of New York’s Museum of Modern Art, whose founding
label: Paragraph

text: director, Alfred H. Barr Jr., set out a Gallocentric narrative of Modernism—
label: Paragraph

text: a begat-begat-begat genealogy that began with Cézanne and posited Cubism
label: Paragraph

text: as the central development of twentieth-century art. Barr’s highly selective
label: Paragraph

text: account deeply affected received opinion for many decades. However, even
label: Paragraph

text: some loyal supporters of MoMA became aware of how much has been
label: Paragraph

text: neglected because of Barr’s preferences. Among them is Ronald Lauder, the
label: Paragraph

text: New York cosmetics heir, art collector, and longtime trustee of the Modern,
label: Paragraph

text: who served as its board chairman from 1995 to 2005 and cofounded the
label: Paragraph

text: Neue Galerie, a privately funded Manhattan museum devoted to Austrian
label: Paragraph

text: and German Modernism, in 2001.
label: Paragraph

text: The idea for the Neue Galerie began with Serge Sabarsky, a Vienna-born,
label: Paragraph

text: New York-based dealer in Expressionist art who in 1993 bought a Beaux
label: Paragraph

text: Arts mansion on the corner of Fifth Avenue and East 86th Street and started
label: Paragraph

text: a foundation devoted to advancing awareness of that underrepresented
label: Paragraph

text: work. After Sabarsky’s death in 1996, his friend and client Lauder took
label: Paragraph

text: over the as-yet-unrealized project and created what has become an
label: Paragraph

text: indispensable part of the city’s cultural life, not least because the Neue
label: Paragraph

text: Galerie’s high standards of programming and presentation have almost
label: Paragraph

text: single-handedly redressed MoMA’s systematic overemphasis on the School
label: Paragraph

text: of Paris. This upstart institution’s importance was never more clearly
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated than with its 2017 exhibition “Wiener Werkstatte, 1903-1932:
label: Paragraph

text: The Luxury of Beauty,” a comprehensive survey of the applied arts
label: Paragraph

text: collective founded in Vienna by the architect Josef Hoffmann, the artist
label: Paragraph

text: Koloman Moser, and the patron and collector Fritz Waerndorfer.
label: Paragraph

text: The Wiener Werkstaétte (Viennese Workshops) was a direct offshoot of
label: Paragraph

text: the Vienna Secession, the maverick faction of avant-garde painters,
label: Paragraph

text: sculptors, and architects established in 1897 by Hoffmann, Klimt, Moser,
label: Paragraph

text: and the architect Joseph Maria Olbrich, when they seceded from the
label: Paragraph

text: stultifyingly conservative Union of Austrian Artists in search of more
label: Paragraph

text: adventurous creative opportunities. (Olbrich designed its Vienna
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters and exhibition hall, the Secession Building of 1897-1898, a
label: Caption

text: mysteriously windowless structure topped with an openwork dome
label: Caption

text: composed of three thousand gilded bronze laurel leaves, which wags
label: Paragraph

text: instantly dubbed das goldene Krauthappel—the golden cabbage head, in
label: Paragraph

text: local slang.) This breakaway confraternity in turn led to the establishment
label: Paragraph

text: of the Wiener Werkstdtte six years afterward. And although Hoffmann
label: Paragraph

text: broke with the Secession in 1905 because of internecine conflicts about
label: Paragraph

text: exactly how they should pursue their avowed common goal of the
label: Paragraph

text: Gesamtkunstwerk (total work of art), these young revolutionaries all shared
label: Paragraph

text: values that were at the very heart of the Austrian avant-garde.
label: Paragraph

text: The Neue Galerie exhibition made a wholly convincing case for the
label: Paragraph

text: Wiener Werkstatte’s brief efflorescence of incomparably exquisite high-
label: Paragraph

text: style design, which included furniture, glassware, ceramics, metalwork both
label: Paragraph

text: precious and base, jewelry, wallpaper, fabrics, graphic design, and the
label: Paragraph

text: charming artists’ postcards with which the art alliance inexpensively
label: Paragraph

text: propagandized its ambitious agenda. With particularly piquancy it
label: Paragraph

text: juxtaposed many works by Dagobert Peche —the Wiener Werkstatte
label: Paragraph

text: stalwart who might be seen as the organization’s id because of his
label: Paragraph

text: untrammeled and often disruptive inventiveness—with those of Hoffmann,
label: Paragraph

text: the group’s rational superego. And although several scholars have already
label: Paragraph

text: proposed this notion, the show and its magisterial catalog, now the basic
label: Paragraph

text: reference on the subject, confirmed that the Wiener Werkstatte was no less
label: Paragraph

text: than the missing link between Art Nouveau and Art Deco.
label: Paragraph

text: Stereotypical notions of the group and its clientele have perpetuated
label: Paragraph

text: clichés of a decadent imperial society obliviously waltzing on the rim of a
label: Paragraph

text: political volcano. To be sure, the rarefied objects produced by this
label: Paragraph

text: decorative-arts consortium now seem characteristic of a pre-Great War
label: Paragraph

text: culture of plutocratic privilege—in stark contrast to the output of the
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus, which was founded the year after that devastating conflict ended.
label: Paragraph

text: But because the Wiener Werkstatte managed to persist beyond the downfall
label: Paragraph

text: of the Austro-Hungarian Empire for more than a decade—a period no less
label: Paragraph

text: economically difficult for greatly diminished Austria than for its co-
label: Paragraph

text: combatant Germany—it is incorrect to see it as a cultural hothouse flower.
label: Paragraph

text: The Wiener Werkstatte went through several successive phases to survive
label: Paragraph

text: financially, and if one of its many product lines was not selling, there was
label: Paragraph

text: no philosophical compunction against coming up with something
label: Title

text: completely different to please consumers, at least within its expansive
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic parameters. This noble experiment in radical design was nothing
label: Paragraph

text: less than a conduit for a richly multicultural, if politically untenable, society
label: Paragraph

text: that was coming apart at the seams bit by bit. Although there are strong
label: Paragraph

text: underpinnings of Classicism in many of its designs—such as Hoffmann’s
label: Paragraph

text: famous brass centerpiece (circa 1924), a fluted, footed bowl with
label: Paragraph

text: extravagant curlicue handles that spiral wildly outward with irresistible
label: Paragraph

text: insouciance—this tension between tight control and wild abandon gives the
label: Paragraph

text: Wiener Werkstatte’s creations a contradictory quality so much in tune with
label: Paragraph

text: that time, and ours as well.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from the duality of so many individual Wiener Werkstatte designs
label: Paragraph

text: —which often juxtaposed urban sophistication and peasant vitality, as in
label: Paragraph

text: Vally Wieselthier’s ceramic sculptures of women who seem equal part
label: Paragraph

text: jaded showgirl and feckless milkmaid—the group’s broad range defies easy
label: Paragraph

text: definition. In its more folkloristic manifestations one can detect an affinity
label: Paragraph

text: for the Magyar side of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, while evocations of a
label: Paragraph

text: far older empire—the Byzantine—are evident in jewelry designs such as
label: Paragraph

text: Hoffmann’s rectilinear brooches, so densely encrusted with multicolored
label: Paragraph

text: semiprecious stones that they recall the jewels of the empress Theodora as
label: Paragraph

text: depicted in the Ravenna mosaics. It now seems incredible that one company
label: Paragraph

text: could turn out both Bertold Léffler’s anorexic stoneware bud vases (circa
label: Paragraph

text: 1906) and then a year later Michael Powolny’s chubby ceramic putti
label: Paragraph

text: representing the four seasons (high-style precursors of the kitschig Hummel
label: Paragraph

text: figurines first made in 1935). Moser’s silver-and-niello sugar box of 1903, a
label: Paragraph

text: cubic form further reinforced by its all-over black-and-silver-checked
label: Paragraph

text: surface, is as severe as a Donald Judd sculpture. Conversely, Peche’s
label: Paragraph

text: bombastic walnut writing desk of 1922 is so massive and overwrought that
label: Paragraph

text: it could be best described as Babylonian Baroque. Yet they all bore the
label: Paragraph

text: superimposed double-W label devised for the firm by Moser (who also
label: Paragraph

text: came up with distinctive initialed logos for each of its participating artists),
label: Paragraph

text: and one cannot say that any single aesthetic represents the Wiener
label: Paragraph

text: Werkstatte, which can only be understood in all its bewildering complexity.
label: Paragraph

text: The group faced the same basic problem that bedeviled several of its
label: Paragraph

text: earlier counterparts in the British Arts and Crafts Movement, including the
label: Paragraph

text: Century Guild of Artists, established by Arthur Mackmurdo in 1883; the
label: Paragraph

text: Art Workers’ Guild, founded in 1884 by the architect William Lethaby and
label: Paragraph

text: others; and C. R. Ashbee’s Guild and School of Handicraft (1888). Each of
label: Paragraph

text: them was self-consciously modeled after medieval craftsmen’s guilds
label: Paragraph

text: (though with less emphasis on exclusionary job protection, a central
label: Paragraph

text: element of those precursors of modern labor unions). They all espoused a
label: Paragraph

text: return to preindustrial fabrication methods and a commitment to bringing
label: Paragraph

text: good design to the masses. Yet they wound up producing objects—even
label: Paragraph

text: those not made from intrinsically precious materials—that were so labor-
label: Paragraph

text: intensive that they could never compete with machine-made items that the
label: Paragraph

text: working class could afford, and thus became luxury goods for the rich.
label: Paragraph

text: Design reform groups that were established along conventional business
label: Paragraph

text: models fared better financially than their utopian counterparts. William
label: Paragraph

text: Morris’s London-based home furnishings concern, Morris & Co. (as it was
label: Paragraph

text: renamed in 1875 to capitalize on its mastermind’s increasing renown),
label: Paragraph

text: weathered successive changes in popular taste and lasted until 1940, forced
label: Paragraph

text: out of business only by the Blitz.
label: Paragraph

text: Interestingly, it was not the earnest Morris, a crusading socialist, to
label: Paragraph

text: whom the Vienna avant-garde gravitated among British designers, but
label: Paragraph

text: rather the Scottish architect Charles Rennie Mackintosh, whose work was
label: Paragraph

text: darker and more emotionally complex than the heartily straightforward
label: Paragraph

text: ethos of the Arts and Crafts Movement. Not for nothing was Mackintosh’s
label: Paragraph

text: Glasgow circle called “The Spook School,” in response to the wraithlike
label: Paragraph

text: quality and spiritual subtext of its decorative schemes. Indeed, one of the
label: Paragraph

text: Wiener Werkstatte’s signature motifs—repetitive right-angled grids in wood
label: Paragraph

text: or metalwork—came directly from Mackintosh, and the group’s prime
label: Paragraph

text: mover was nicknamed “Quadrat-Hoffmann” because of his extreme
label: Paragraph

text: fondness for square patterns. Mackintosh’s designs were extensively
label: Paragraph

text: published in the new half-tone-illustrated international applied art journals
label: Paragraph

text: (especially The Studio, founded in London in 1893, and Deutsche Kunst
label: Paragraph

text: und Dekoration, established in Darmstadt in 1897) that allowed a rapid and
label: Paragraph

text: reciprocal exchange of design ideas across great distances. He also met
label: Paragraph

text: several of his Viennese admirers in 1902 at the First International
label: Paragraph

text: Exposition of Modern Decorative Arts in Turin, which led the Wiener
label: Paragraph

text: Werkstatte’s greatest early benefactor, Fritz Waerndorfer, to commission a
label: Paragraph

text: music room for his suburban Vienna villa from Mackintosh despite the
label: Paragraph

text: abundance of local talent available to him. This otherworldly environment
label: Paragraph

text: was completed in 1903, the year that the Wiener Werkstaétte opened for
label: Paragraph

text: business.
label: Paragraph

text: The economic premise of early design reform groups was always shaky.
label: Paragraph

text: The Bauhaus was a rare exception, thanks to its being a state-sponsored
label: Paragraph

text: school (hence its official name, Staatliches Bauhaus) and thus free from the
label: Paragraph

text: financial pressures of a commercial enterprise. In due course its numerous
label: Paragraph

text: design patents and licensing agreements (especially the hugely popular
label: Paragraph

text: Bauhaus wallpaper lines) brought in a steady if not enormous income that,
label: Paragraph

text: with admirable equity, was parceled out to students who devised the
label: Paragraph

text: product prototypes in their workshop classes. The Wiener Werkstatte, in
label: Paragraph

text: contrast, was a money pit from its inception. This has long been known, but
label: Paragraph

text: the most comprehensive account yet of the group’s parlous finances is laid
label: Paragraph

text: out in disheartening detail by Ernst Ploil in the 2017 Neue Galerie
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition catalog. Ploil sums up the Wiener Werkstatte’s economic
label: Paragraph

text: dilemma by quoting a letter from Hoffmann to the Belgian engineer and
label: Paragraph

text: financier Adolphe Stoclet—patron of the architect’s Gesamtkunstwerk
label: Paragraph

text: masterpiece, the Palais Stoclet of 1905-1911 in Brussels (see Illustration
label: Caption

text: 4b). As Hoffmann wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: The lady [Miss Wittgenstein] wanted (for months now) two
label: Paragraph

text: candelabra, each two meters tall, of gilded wood. Finally the drawings
label: Paragraph

text: were finished and correct, and a cost estimate was drawn up in my
label: Paragraph

text: absence. That alone is madness, since it is simply impossible to
label: Paragraph

text: produce a cost estimate for an object you haven’t yet made... .
label: Paragraph

text: Fortunately, Miss Wittgenstein came and said the estimate was too
label: Paragraph

text: high. And at that moment I already told her that we were freed of any
label: Paragraph

text: obligation because she did not accept the estimate and that now we
label: Paragraph

text: will not make the candelabras at any price, because we no longer make
label: Paragraph

text: unique objects. ...
label: Paragraph

text: “Strange,” said Miss Wittgenstein, “and we always thought you
label: Paragraph

text: were getting extremely rich from these commissions.” And I said to
label: Paragraph

text: her: “You can best see just how much such commissions can enrich us
label: Paragraph

text: (she wanted to pay eight thousand crowns [equal to more than
label: Paragraph

text: $100,000 today] for the candelabras) from the fact that now we simply
label: Paragraph

text: no longer accept such commissions.”
label: Paragraph

text: Miss Wittgenstein (an unspecified sister of Ludwig’s, perhaps the future
label: Paragraph

text: Margaret Stonborough-Wittgenstein, who was painted by Klimt in 1905)
label: Paragraph

text: was a member of a steel-manufacturing dynasty that had converted from
label: Paragraph

text: Judaism to Protestantism and was the second richest in Austria, after the
label: Paragraph

text: Rothschilds. And as Christian Witt-Dorring explains in the catalog:
label: Paragraph

text: The Werkstatte was supported by a small group of artists and primarily
label: Paragraph

text: Jewish wealthy families that were relatives or friends or were
label: Paragraph

text: connected by economic interests and backed the project of Vienna’s
label: Paragraph

text: artistic springtime with their commissions. The members of the Jewish
label: Paragraph

text: families had generally assimilated into Vienna’s Christian culture in
label: Paragraph

text: the second generation after Austria-Hungary’s Jewish population
label: Title

text: obtained full civil rights from around 1860. Their desire to integrate fit
label: Paragraph

text: well with . . . [the] search for a modern Austrian style . . . which
label: Paragraph

text: gained acceptance in the international market as the “Vienna style,”
label: Paragraph

text: [and] offered the assimilated Jewish population the potential of a
label: Paragraph

text: feeling of belonging that was not defined in terms of nation.
label: Paragraph

text: Another mainstay of the Wiener Werskstatte was the Primavesi family,
label: Paragraph

text: descended from Italian Jewish bankers who during the eighteenth century
label: Paragraph

text: emigrated from Lombardy to Moravia (now part of the Czech Republic but
label: Paragraph

text: ruled by the Austrians from 1809 to 1918). Hoffmann designed two large
label: Paragraph

text: residential schemes for members of that clan. He carried out a complete
label: Paragraph

text: interior remodeling of the baronial Primavesi Country House near the
label: Caption

text: Moravian town of Winkelsdorf (1913-1914) for the entrepreneur and
label: Paragraph

text: parliament member Otto Primavesi. And for Otto’s younger cousin and
label: Paragraph

text: brother-in-law, the banker and industrialist Robert Primavesi, and his wife,
label: Paragraph

text: Josefine Skywa, he created the neo-Classical Villa Skywa-Primavesi in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna (1913-1915), which includes a large formal garden (as does the
label: Paragraph

text: Palais Stoclet). Otto Primavesi took over Waerndorfer’s role as the
label: Paragraph

text: commercial director of the Wiener Werkstatte in 1915, and he and Robert
label: Paragraph

text: became its principal underwriters after Waerndorfer’s financial collapse.
label: Paragraph

text: The idealistic but impractical Waerndorfer came from yet another rich
label: Paragraph

text: Jewish family, whose profitable cotton mills allowed him to realize his
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic dreams. Yet this true believer’s unstinting support of the Wiener
label: Paragraph

text: Werkstatte soon had disastrous economic consequences. As Witt-Dérring
label: Paragraph

text: writes, “Waerndorfer’s absolute faith in Hoffmann’s genius oscillated
label: Paragraph

text: between the extremes of ‘Can I afford it?’ and ‘I owe it to the world to
label: Paragraph

text: afford it,’” but the latter attitude invariably won out. This Maecenas’s
label: Paragraph

text: willful lack of caution eventually impoverished him, to the extent that he
label: Paragraph

text: immigrated to the US, became an artist, and during the Great Depression
label: Paragraph

text: took up farming in a Philadelphia suburb, where he died a month before the
label: Paragraph

text: outbreak of World War IL.
label: Paragraph

text: Josef Franz Maria Hoffmann, the beneficiary of Waerndorfer’s unstinting
label: Paragraph

text: if perhaps foolhardy support, was born in 1870 in a small Moravian town
label: Paragraph

text: where his father was mayor. The Hoffmanns were Catholic and
label: Paragraph

text: Deutschmdhrer (German Moravians), an ethnic and linguistic minority
label: Paragraph

text: (about one third of the predominantly Czech region’s population) better
label: Paragraph

text: known by the 1930s as Sudeten Germans, whom Hitler used as his pretext
label: Paragraph

text: for breaking up the two-decade-old Czechoslovak Republic when he
label: Paragraph

text: occupied the German-majority Sudetenland in 1938. Hoffmann first
label: Paragraph

text: attended a state-sponsored crafts school in Brno, Moravia’s largest city, but
label: Paragraph

text: then moved on to Vienna’s far more prestigious Academy of Fine Arts,
label: Paragraph

text: where he studied under Otto Wagner (and after his graduation in 1895 went
label: Paragraph

text: to work in his architectural office, where he befriended Olbrich).
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner was not only the foremost Austrian master builder of the period
label: Paragraph

text: but also a force of such wide-ranging influence that his stature is difficult to
label: Paragraph

text: appreciate these days, when architects rarely wield such broad cultural
label: Paragraph

text: power. In our own time Philip Johnson perhaps came closest, although he
label: Paragraph

text: possessed neither Wagner’s high professorial credentials nor critical regard.
label: Paragraph

text: The so-called Wagnerschule (Wagner School) of the master’s many
label: Paragraph

text: disciples dominated Central European architecture for decades; there was
label: Paragraph

text: never a Johnson School, except perhaps for his eager acolyte Robert A. M.
label: Paragraph

text: Stern, who patterned his busy but vacuous design career all too closely on
label: Paragraph

text: the surface-over-substance ethos of his power-broker paragon.
label: Paragraph

text: Hoffmann was weirdly secretive, especially as the impresario of a
label: Paragraph

text: business enterprise so dependent on social interactions. For example, he had
label: Paragraph

text: an aversion to being touched and refused to eat food prepared by any cook
label: Paragraph

text: whose hands repelled him. He kept two apartments in Vienna, one where he
label: Paragraph

text: received people he could not otherwise put off and a second for a wife and
label: Paragraph

text: child whose existence he kept secret even from his employees. They were
label: Paragraph

text: later startled to discover that he had a grown son, Wolfgang, who went on to
label: Paragraph

text: become an architect, though one of little consequence, and immigrated to
label: Paragraph

text: the US, where he died in 1969.
label: Paragraph

text: Even after Hoffmann became preoccupied with the Wiener Werkstatte he
label: Paragraph

text: pursued an independent architectural career, based mainly on residential
label: Paragraph

text: commissions, many of them for supporters and clients of his design
label: Paragraph

text: consortium. But he also received significant institutional commissions,
label: Paragraph

text: including his Sanatorium Purkersdorf of 1903-1905 (see Illustration 4a), an
label: Paragraph

text: addition to the Westend Sanatorium in the Lower Austrian Luftkurort (air
label: Paragraph

text: spa) of Purkersdorf. This three-story, rectangular, flat-roofed, bilaterally
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical structure was exceptional at the time for its absence of
label: Paragraph

text: projecting ornament of any sort, with windows set flush into the smooth
label: Paragraph

text: white stucco walls, a Minimalism that would point to the later, even more
label: Paragraph

text: severe work of Adolf Loos, the turn-of-the-century Austrian architect now
label: Paragraph

text: most readily identified with such simplicity. (Loos, who was five days older
label: Paragraph

text: than Hoffmann, is best remembered for something he never said
label: Paragraph

text: — “Ornament is a crime”—a distortion of the title of his 1910 book-length
label: Paragraph

text: essay Ornament and Crime, in which he noted a parallel between primitive
label: Paragraph

text: societies’ love of ornament and modern criminals’ propensity for tattoos,
label: Paragraph

text: and argued that “freedom from ornament is a sign of spiritual strength.”)
label: Paragraph

text: With its comprehensively customized design coordinated down to the
label: Paragraph

text: smallest detail, the Sanatorium Purkersdorf was every bit as much a
label: Paragraph

text: Gesamtkunstwerk as the Palais Stoclet, although infinitely less opulent, in
label: Paragraph

text: keeping with the emergent Modernist belief that calm, neutral surroundings
label: Paragraph

text: were conducive to both physical and mental health. Although this facility
label: Paragraph

text: specialized in curative baths and physical therapy rather than the treatment
label: Paragraph

text: of tuberculosis—the focus of such later architectural landmarks as Jan
label: Paragraph

text: Duiker and Bernard Bijvoet’s Sanatorium Zonnestraal in Holland and Alvar
label: Caption

text: Aalto’s Paimio Sanatorium in Finland—it signaled that health-care design
label: Paragraph

text: would become a major focus of the Modern Movement’s comprehensive
label: Paragraph

text: attitude toward social reform.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout the twentieth century, international expositions were
label: Paragraph

text: important showcases for a nation’s cultural identity as expressed through
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, and it was a sign of Hoffmann’s increasing stature in his
label: Paragraph

text: homeland that he was chosen to design the Austrian pavilion at four of
label: Paragraph

text: them: the International Fine Arts Exhibition of 1911 in Rome; the
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund Exhibition of 1914 in Cologne; the Exposition internationale des
label: Paragraph

text: arts décoratifs et industriels modernes of 1925 in Paris (which famously
label: Paragraph

text: gave its name to Art Deco design); and the Venice Biennale of 1934. The
label: Paragraph

text: first two of these temporary buildings were fairly similar Stripped Classical
label: Paragraph

text: compositions, replete with stylized pediments, colonnades, and pilasters
label: Paragraph

text: like the Villa Skywa-Primavesi. An altogether more unusual scheme was
label: Paragraph

text: his Paris pavilion, one of the fair’s architectural highlights and appreciated
label: Paragraph

text: as such at the time, enough to earn the architect a Légion d’Honneur.
label: Paragraph

text: Asymmetrical in layout unlike its two predecessors, the 1925 Austrian
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion was a further departure from his earlier work thanks to its
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive stucco exterior, which featured broad horizontal bands that
label: Paragraph

text: undulated in curving profile like supersized Classical molding, an effect
label: Paragraph

text: that gave the walls a sensuous rhythm. Inside, one decorative-arts gallery
label: Paragraph

text: comprised a veritable Wiener Werkstatte showroom. Hoffmann reverted to
label: Paragraph

text: a symmetrical format in his Venice Biennale pavilion, which is centered by
label: Paragraph

text: a monumental ground-to-roof portal that bisects the horizontally grooved
label: Caption

text: stucco facade and is wrapped with a glass clerestory strip. This is the only
label: Paragraph

text: one of his exhibition buildings to survive.
label: Caption

text: Even before the Wiener Werkstatte went under in 1932, Hoffmann turned
label: Paragraph

text: to the design of social housing sponsored by the municipal authorities of
label: Paragraph

text: Austria’s capital city, which at the time was termed das Rote Wien (Red
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna) for its far-left sympathies. Avowedly apolitical—“I don’t know
label: Paragraph

text: anything about it,’ he demurred when questioned about the issues of the
label: Paragraph

text: day—like countless other Gentiles he apparently felt no compunction about
label: Paragraph

text: remaining in Austria after Hitler annexed it in March 1938. As Eduard
label: Paragraph

text: Sekler writes in the standard monograph, Josef Hoffmann: The
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Work (1985), “Hoffmann welcomed the new regime because
label: Paragraph

text: it promised economic progress and, above all, revived his architectural
label: Paragraph

text: practice,” despite his close and longstanding connections to Jews who
label: Paragraph

text: suddenly found themselves in grave danger.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, he quickly accepted a commission from his country’s new rulers.
label: Paragraph

text: Now that Germany had absorbed Austria, it no longer needed its embassy in
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna, which Hoffmann was asked to remodel into the headquarters for the
label: Paragraph

text: occupying armed forces, the Haus der Wehrmacht. Furthermore, he
label: Paragraph

text: accepted a high bureaucratic appointment from the notorious Baldur von
label: Paragraph

text: Schirach, the Nazi gauleiter of Vienna who was sentenced at Nuremberg to
label: Paragraph

text: twenty years in prison. The architect’s collaboration seems not to have
label: Paragraph

text: harmed him greatly during the decade he had left after the war ended, and
label: Paragraph

text: although during that final phase he built almost nothing, it had more to do
label: Paragraph

text: with his seeming to be old-fashioned rather than politically tainted. He died
label: Paragraph

text: in relative obscurity in 1956 at the age of eighty-five.
label: Paragraph

text: Another major figure in the Wiener Werkstatte saga was Joseph Urban,
label: Paragraph

text: the Vienna-born architect who immigrated to the US in 1911 and was
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: IN 1970 IT would have seemed preposterous to assert that the two greatest
label: Paragraph

text: architects of the twentieth century were Le Corbusier and Edwin Lutyens.
label: Paragraph

text: Although each during his lifetime was considered supreme in his respective
label: Paragraph

text: sphere—Le Corbusier among modernists, Lutyens among traditionalists—
label: Paragraph

text: their comparative influence differed tremendously. Whereas Le Corbusier’s
label: Paragraph

text: precepts became the predominant lingua franca of world architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: Lutyens embodied the final effulgence of Classicism, which the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement had supposedly rendered irrelevant. Unequal as _ these
label: Paragraph

text: antithetical figures may still seem to some, their complementary
label: Paragraph

text: preeminence was acknowledged as early as the 1920s.
label: Paragraph

text: The concurrence during that decade of Lutyens’s British imperial capital
label: Paragraph

text: of New Delhi and Le Corbusier’s visionary proposals for drastically
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilding Paris prompted Indian urbanists to ask both men to devise plans
label: Paragraph

text: for a new subcontinental city. Lutyens demurred: “With Corbusier I think
label: Paragraph

text: your friends would be far happier and his flow of language would carry
label: Paragraph

text: them all.” Le Corbusier finally got to build such a city with his Punjabi
label: Paragraph

text: regional capital at Chandigarh of 1951-1964. Lutyens was respectful if
label: Paragraph

text: skeptical of the Swiss-French radical, and in a 1928 review of his Towards a
label: Paragraph

text: New Architecture rightly faulted Le Corbusier’s illogical transposition of
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean materials and forms to northern climates.
label: Paragraph

text: Today’s more inclusive view of the building art makes it easier to
label: Paragraph

text: contend that although Lutyens was by no means a Modernist, he was most
label: Paragraph

text: definitely a modern architect, and a very great one at that. While he largely
label: Paragraph

text: disdained innovative construction methods, he responded to the new needs
label: Paragraph

text: of the twentieth century with restless imagination, as demonstrated by his
label: Paragraph

text: up-to-date corporate headquarters, admirable workers’ housing, and
label: Paragraph

text: incomparable memorials to  Britain’s victims of unprecedented
label: Paragraph

text: industrialized combat during World War I.
label: Paragraph

text: Lutyens worked in four successive but frequently overlapping (and
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes recurrent) stylistic modes: Arts and Crafts, Art Nouveau, Neo-
label: Paragraph

text: Georgian, and High Classical. To all of them he brought an unruly vivacity
label: Paragraph

text: that was his most noteworthy quality. His vernacular version of Arts and
label: Paragraph

text: Crafts, familiarly known as the Surrey Style, featured traditional regional
label: Paragraph

text: motifs, including prominent redbrick chimneys, large multiple gables,
label: Paragraph

text: overhanging red tile roofs, small-paned casement windows, and elevations
label: Caption

text: clad in varying combinations of brick, stucco, tile, clapboard, half-
label: Paragraph

text: timbering, or sandstone. Asymmetrical massing suggested additions
label: Paragraph

text: accreted over time, a characteristic of old country houses.
label: Paragraph

text: Always attuned to shifts in taste and eager to give clients what they
label: Paragraph

text: wanted, Lutyens was more accommodating than his hugely talented
label: Paragraph

text: contemporaries C. F. A. Voysey and C. R. Ashbee, whose careers foundered
label: Paragraph

text: as they clung to Arts and Crafts principles long after they’d gone out of
label: Paragraph

text: fashion. Lutyens next had a brief Art Nouveau phase, seen in houses such
label: Paragraph

text: as the Bois des Moutiers of 1898 in Normandy, with its exaggeratedly steep
label: Paragraph

text: roofs and elongated oriel windows in the manner of Charles Rennie

text: Mackintosh. But he was intrinsically wary of the new free style, as he wrote
label: Paragraph

text: of an extremely stylized Mackintosh tearoom in Glasgow: “The result is
label: Paragraph

text: gorgeous! and a wee bit vulgar! . . . All just a little outré, a thing we must
label: Paragraph

text: avoid, and shall too.”

text: With the demise of Art Nouveau during the new century’s first decade,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of designs inspired by his idol Christopher Wren, a shift that Lutyens, an
label: Paragraph

text: inveterate punster, called his “Wrenaissance.” Moving on from that phase,
label: Paragraph

text: his first full-blown essay in Classicism was Heathcote of 1905-1907, an
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical composition channels the quirky designs of the early-
label: Paragraph

text: eighteenth-century Mannerist Nicholas Hawksmoor and announces that
label: Paragraph

text: Lutyens will not be playing Classicism by the cautious Adam Revival
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph
