text: was likely dazzled by Emily’s high status, but despite his ardor and
label: Paragraph

text: professional prospects, Lutyens’s lack of a fortune (even more of an
label: Paragraph

text: impediment than his comparatively lowly birth) precluded an immediate
label: Paragraph

text: engagement. After protracted negotiations with her family, he made Emily
label: Paragraph

text: the beneficiary of a life insurance policy worth the current equivalent of
label: Paragraph

text: $1.67 million, and they married in 1897. The high premiums for what was
label: Paragraph

text: tantamount to a reverse dowry drained the architect’s resources for years,
label: Paragraph

text: but his bartered bride remained incorrigibly spoiled. She pulled rank on him
label: Paragraph

text: constantly and complained that it was impossible to run their London house
label: Paragraph

text: with fewer than ten servants.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite their early protestations of everlasting love, Lutyens and Lytton
label: Paragraph

text: were disastrously mismatched. She worshiped his talent but craved an
label: Paragraph

text: intimacy undermined by the architect’s single-minded devotion to his work.
label: Paragraph

text: At home he’d immerse himself in endless games of solitaire during which
label: Paragraph

text: he’d unconsciously puzzle out pending designs. He’d hoped that her
label: Paragraph

text: aristocratic connections would bring him prestigious jobs, but he received
label: Paragraph

text: far more referrals from Gertrude Jekyll. Worse yet, she found their sex life
label: Paragraph

text: unbearable (as detailed in her letters to him and confidences to her
label: Paragraph

text: daughters), and after she bore five children turned him out of the conjugal
label: Paragraph

text: bed in 1914.
label: Paragraph

text: Emily had meanwhile become a fanatical adept of Theosophy, the
label: Paragraph

text: Eastem-inflected spiritual cult that held the teenaged Indian mystic Jiddu
label: Paragraph

text: Krishnamurti to be a messiah. During much of her marriage she made a
label: Paragraph

text: separate, peripatetic life chasing after Krishnamurti with her husband’s
label: Paragraph

text: money, a rejection particularly painful to Lutyens because it reiterated the
label: Paragraph

text: emotional neglect of him by his religiously obsessed mother. He found
label: Paragraph

text: some comfort in an amitié amoureuse with the likewise unhappily wed
label: Paragraph

text: Victoria Sackville-West (mother of Vita), for whom he designed three
label: Paragraph

text: houses, over which they quarreled to an apparently enjoyable degree. The
label: Paragraph

text: Lutyenses remained wed until his death from lung cancer at age seventy-
label: Paragraph

text: four on New Year’s Day in 1944.
label: Paragraph

text: The architect was painfully shy and nervously inarticulate, serious
label: Paragraph

text: deficiencies in a field so dependent on personal interaction. He attempted to
label: Paragraph

text: mask his verbal and social un-ease with a strenuously jocular demeanor
label: Paragraph

text: marked by non-stop chatter and a torrent of puns. He averred that “India
label: Paragraph

text: expects every man to do his dhoti,” and observed of a fish course, “This
label: Paragraph

text: piece of cod passeth understanding.” His notion of appropriateness could be
label: Paragraph

text: astoundingly faulty, as when he told the formidable Queen Mary that the
label: Paragraph

text: tiny pillows monogrammed MG and GM in the dollhouse he designed for
label: Paragraph

text: her signified “May George?” and “George May,” the latter a play on her
label: Paragraph

text: private family nickname. She reacted, he reported, like a “frightened mare.”
label: Paragraph

text: Yet many others found his irrepressible bonhomie and boundless sense of
label: Paragraph

text: fun entrancing, and after Lutyens stopped going about at night with his
label: Paragraph

text: downer of a wife—to the great relief of countless hostesses who loved him
label: Paragraph

text: and hated her—he became one of London’s most sought-after dinner guests.
label: Paragraph

text: Lutyens’s expansion into international practice paralleled the British
label: Paragraph

text: Empire’s global reach. He designed his nation’s pavilion at expositions in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris (1900), Rome (1911), and Antwerp (1930) in a succession of different
label: Paragraph

text: styles—tespectively Elizabethan, Classical, and the Mughal-Classical
label: Paragraph

text: hybrid he devised for New Delhi. After he was awarded the American
label: Paragraph

text: Institute of Architects’ Gold Medal in 1924, the British government
label: Caption

text: returned the compliment and asked him to design its new embassy complex
label: Paragraph

text: in Washington, his only work in the US. Rather than flaunting Britannic
label: Paragraph

text: majesty, Lutyens’s Neo-Georgian embassy brings to mind both an English
label: Paragraph

text: country house and the redbrick Wren Building of 1695-1700 at the College
label: Caption

text: of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Virginia, attributed to Christopher
label: Caption

text: Wren. Because the hilly site near Washington Cathedral had to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate both the ambassadorial residence and the chancery, the
label: Paragraph

text: architect separated the living and working functions and joined the
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular mansion and the squared-C-shaped office wing with a two-story
label: Paragraph

text: pedimented bridge that contains the ambassador’s study above the main
label: Caption

text: entry arch.
label: Paragraph

text: The arrival sequence is thrilling. One gets out of a car under the porte
label: Paragraph

text: cochere and then ascends a grand stairway with deep treads that slow your
label: Paragraph

text: pace to a stately gait and increase anticipation. On the piano nobile, a
label: Paragraph

text: spacious ballroom (used for investitures and other ceremonies) faces three
label: Paragraph

text: French doors that open onto a two-story stone-columned portico, which in
label: Paragraph

text: turn leads to the terraced garden. This splendidly orchestrated spatial
label: Paragraph

text: progression never fails to impress. Architectural jests abound throughout.
label: Paragraph

text: For example, column capitals are carved with swags and a scallop shell that
label: Paragraph

text: mimic eyes, nose, and open mouth, while the circular patterns on a curving
label: Paragraph

text: wrought-iron stairway bannister were inspired by bubbles in a glass of
label: Paragraph

text: champagne. Lutyens’s biographer Jane Ridley perfectly summarizes the
label: Paragraph

text: overall effect as “light-heartedly subversive, like a Noél Coward lyric.”
label: Paragraph

text: When the newly crowned King George V and Queen Mary journeyed to
label: Paragraph

text: India to receive the homage of maharajahs at the Delhi Durbar of 1911, the
label: Paragraph

text: monarch surprised the assembly by announcing that the capital of the Raj
label: Paragraph

text: would be moved there from Calcutta. Lutyens’s newly minted city-planning
label: Paragraph

text: credentials—he had laid out the town center for Hampstead Garden Suburb
label: Paragraph

text: in North London in 1908—won him the commission of a lifetime to design
label: Paragraph

text: this new British administrative center of India. He immediately
label: Paragraph

text: comprehended that no one man could act as both urban design chief and
label: Paragraph

text: project architect for New Delhi’s numerous government structures, and thus
label: Paragraph

text: chose as his collaborator an old colleague from the George and Peto office,
label: Paragraph

text: Herbert Baker, whose Union Buildings of 1910-1912 in Pretoria, capital of
label: Paragraph

text: the newly formed Union of South Africa, offered comparable scale and
label: Paragraph

text: experience no other British architect could match. It was a decision Lutyens
label: Paragraph

text: would come to regret bitterly.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Lutyens’s radial city plan for New Delhi followed French
label: Paragraph

text: Baroque prototypes, including Pierre-Charles L’Enfant’s Washington, D.C.,
label: Paragraph

text: there was consensus that the official architecture of the new capital should
label: Paragraph

text: incorporate Indian references. But Lutyens was at first openly dismissive of
label: Paragraph

text: historical construction on the subcontinent. “I do not believe there is any
label: Paragraph

text: real Indian architecture at all, or any great tradition,” he declared. Even the
label: Paragraph

text: universally beloved Taj Mahal he found wanting, and insisted that when
label: Paragraph

text: viewed from any angle other than the front it was “untidy.” His initial
label: Paragraph

text: contemptuousness of this rich architectural heritage makes it all the more
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable that in the end he tuned New Delhi’s centerpiece and his own
label: Paragraph

text: masterpiece—the Viceroy’s House of 1912—1930—into a brilliant fusion of
label: Paragraph

text: Hindu, Buddhist, and Mughal motifs seamlessly subsumed and
label: Paragraph

text: superimposed onto an unapologetically Classical plan. Somewhat larger
label: Paragraph

text: than the Palace of Versailles, it is crowned by Lutyens’s distinctive
label: Paragraph

text: sandstone dome modeled after a bell-shaped Buddhist stupa, rather than his
label: Paragraph

text: less felicitous initial plan to reinterpret the cupola of St. Paul’s Cathedral by
label: Paragraph

text: Wren (which was also the prototype for Thomas U. Walter’s United States
label: Paragraph

text: Capitol dome of 1855-1866). The architect’s multicultural stylistic
label: Paragraph

text: synthesis allowed the Viceroy’s House to be renamed Rashtrapati Bhavan
label: Paragraph

text: (President’s House) with complete credibility after India won independence
label: Paragraph

text: from Britain.
label: Paragraph

text: Understandably, a two-decade undertaking of this magnitude was fraught
label: Paragraph

text: with problems, a saga grippingly told in Robert Grant Irving’s definitive
label: Paragraph

text: account, Indian Summer: Lutyens, Baker, and Imperial Delhi (1981).
label: Caption

text: Financial strains twice threatened to cancel the project: at the outset during
label: Paragraph

text: the Great War and again near the end during the Great Depression. Lutyens
label: Paragraph

text: and Baker were at loggerheads from the very beginning. Their rivalry came
label: Paragraph

text: to a climax when Baker’s mirror-image secretariat buildings—each with an
label: Paragraph

text: incongruous Italian Baroque dome and tower, flanking King’s Way (now
label: Caption

text: Rajpath), the grand central avenue leading to the Viceroy’s House—were
label: Paragraph

text: repositioned, which required altering the upward gradient of the roadway.
label: Paragraph

text: An overworked and distracted Lutyens had approved the level change
label: Paragraph

text: without realizing that his dome would now be obscured during part of the
label: Paragraph

text: approach. This exacting perfectionist was thenceforth obsessed with
label: Paragraph

text: correcting his oversight, but regrading the avenue proved too costly. That
label: Paragraph

text: the dome’s brief disappearance and return actually heighten the drama of
label: Paragraph

text: his conception was immaterial to Lutyens because he had not intended it,
label: Paragraph

text: unlike the many other architects, even great ones, who are willing to take
label: Paragraph

text: credit for some serendipitous circumstance and claim it as intentional.
label: Paragraph

text: The work that made him a national hero was his Cenotaph of 1919-1920
label: Paragraph

text: in London. To give focus to peace celebrations in London, Prime Minister
label: Paragraph

text: David Lloyd George—a master of public stagecraft who concocted the
label: Paragraph

text: Prince of Wales’s investiture ceremony at Caernarfon Castle in 1911 as a
label: Paragraph

text: mini-coronation to appeal to his Welsh constituents—commissioned
label: Paragraph

text: Lutyens to design a temporary commemorative set piece on a traffic island
label: Paragraph

text: in Whitehall, the thoroughfare that connects Trafalgar Square and the
label: Paragraph

text: Palace of Westminster. This exquisitely proportioned but severely restrained
label: Paragraph

text: plywood structure—in the implicit form of a sarcophagus raised thirty-five
label: Paragraph

text: feet above street level atop a narrow plinth—immediately struck such a
label: Paragraph

text: responsive chord with the public that the architect was asked to render it
label: Paragraph

text: permanent in stone as Britain’s principal war memorial.
label: Paragraph

text: This deceptively simple scheme is in fact extraordinarily complex, a
label: Paragraph

text: quality typical of Lutyens at his best. What seem like straight lines are
label: Paragraph

text: actually very subtle arcs in the Greek tradition of entasis, a slight narrowing
label: Paragraph

text: of verticals to prevent an upright structure from appearing to bulge at the
label: Paragraph

text: top. Even more than its Classical references, the Cenotaph (the Greek word
label: Paragraph

text: for an empty tomb) atavistically connects with prehistoric monoliths that
label: Paragraph

text: remain unsurpassed as cynosures of collective memory. Moreover, the
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional level of abstraction Lutyens achieves here allows viewers to
label: Paragraph

text: project their own emotions onto a design unencumbered by intrusive
label: Paragraph

text: representational elements, a condition that makes Maya Lin’s Vietnam
label: Paragraph

text: Veterans Memorial in Washington, D.C., and Michael Arad’s National
label: Caption

text: September 11 Memorial in New York City commensurately powerful.
label: Caption

text: Even before hostilities ended, Lutyens was asked to serve, along with
label: Paragraph

text: Baker and Reginald Blomfield, as an architectural adviser to the newly
label: Paragraph

text: organized Imperial War Graves Commission (IWGC) for planning military
label: Paragraph

text: cemeteries in France and Belgium. The war’s horrendous death toll—about
label: Paragraph

text: one million British Empire soldiers were killed—resulted in 967
label: Paragraph

text: cemeteries. Lutyens designed 140 of them, ranging in size from 25 to
label: Paragraph

text: 10,773 graves. His first major contribution was to propose that each burial
label: Paragraph

text: field contain a War Stone, a twelve-foot-long horizontal monolith
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of both an altar and a sarcophagus but devoid of overt religious
label: Paragraph

text: symbols. Rudyard Kipling, whose words THE GLORIOUS DEAD are inscribed
label: Caption

text: on the Cenotaph, also composed the epitaph for the War Stones: THEIR NAME
label: Paragraph

text: LIVETH FOR EVERMORE. His only son had died in action in France in 1915,
label: Paragraph

text: aged eighteen.
label: Paragraph

text: Although more than a dozen other architects took part in this immense
label: Paragraph

text: project (including many who had served in the war), certain organizing
label: Paragraph

text: principles were followed by all of them in order to confer visual unity and
label: Paragraph

text: comradely equality on the entire effort. Yet the general outlines also
label: Paragraph

text: allowed for individual responses to specific locales and differing historical
label: Paragraph

text: circumstances. However, even a cursory overview of the program makes
label: Paragraph

text: clear that Lutyens’s cemeteries are the commission’s finest. His experience
label: Paragraph

text: with Gertrude Jekyll afforded him a firm grasp in siting and landscaping
label: Paragraph

text: each graveyard. The small shelters he designed to give visitors a place to sit
label: Paragraph

text: or take refuge from the elements, as well as to enshrine a register inscribed
label: Paragraph

text: with the names of all those interred there, are at once as dignified as
label: Paragraph

text: Classical temples and as inviting as English garden gazebos. Planted with
label: Paragraph

text: trees, shrubs, and flowers reminiscent of a Home County garden, the
label: Paragraph

text: graveyards—which to this day are impeccably maintained thanks to the
label: Paragraph

text: vigilance of grateful British, French, and Belgian governments as well as
label: Paragraph

text: private volunteers—fulfill Rupert Brooke’s famous vision of “a foreign
label: Paragraph

text: field / That is for ever England.”
label: Paragraph

text: But unquestionably Lutyens’s most affecting military monument is his
label: Paragraph

text: Memorial to the Missing of the Somme of 1927-1932 at Thiepval, France
label: Caption

text: (see Illustration 5b). Rising the equivalent of fourteen stories over open
label: Paragraph

text: countryside near the site of one of the Great War’s bloodiest massacres, this
label: Paragraph

text: brick-and-stone structure is composed of a series of intersecting arches set
label: Paragraph

text: at right angles to each other. They increase in height as they move inward
label: Paragraph

text: from the periphery and culminate in the tallest, central arch, an arrangement
label: Paragraph

text: that creates sufficient wall space for the engraved names of the 73,357
label: Paragraph

text: British Empire soldiers who went missing there in 1916.
label: Paragraph

text: As one moves around this enigmatic construct—part cathedral, part
label: Paragraph

text: watchtower, part sphinx—its apparent massiveness is continually subverted
label: Paragraph

text: by the many apertures cut straight through it. The age-old triumphal arch
label: Paragraph

text: motif has never felt more hollow, the void left by death never more gaping.
label: Paragraph

text: While paying all honor to the fallen, this masterpiece of funereal art does
label: Paragraph

text: not console, and in its realistic address of the horrors that prompted it
label: Paragraph

text: reveals the life-enhancing genius of Edwin Lutyens at its most urgent and
label: Paragraph

text: timeless.
label: Paragraph

text: JAN DUIKER
label: Title

text: THE EXCEPTIONAL LONGEVITY of many moder architects would seem to
label: Paragraph

text: indicate that master builders are an uncommonly hardy lot, if we consider
label: Paragraph

text: such celebrated centenarians as Oscar Niemeyer, I. M. Pei, and Margarete
label: Paragraph

text: Schiitte-Lihotzky; nonagenarians, including Philip Johnson and Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Lloyd Wright; to say nothing of octogenarians far too numerous to mention.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from the steady extension of the human lifespan in developed
label: Paragraph

text: countries during the twentieth century, one wonders if so many architects
label: Paragraph

text: reach an advanced age because so few of them begin to receive major
label: Paragraph

text: commissions before they turn forty, and often not until they are in their
label: Paragraph

text: fifties. Perhaps there is some unknowable process of occupational self-
label: Paragraph

text: selection involved, similar to that among symphony orchestra conductors,
label: Paragraph

text: another unusually superannuated demographic.
label: Paragraph

text: The pursuit of architecture on a high level can be an agonizingly slow
label: Paragraph

text: climb for the ambitious. After the thunderous acclaim that greeted the
label: Paragraph

text: opening of Frank Gehry’s Guggenheim Museum Bilbao in 1997, the
label: Paragraph

text: architect mordantly remarked that it took him until he was almost seventy
label: Paragraph

text: to become an overnight global sensation. At the opposite end of the
label: Paragraph

text: actuarial tables are the highly talented architects whose lives were so much
label: Paragraph

text: shorter than average that their achievements seem all the more miraculous
label: Paragraph

text: in retrospect. Among major twentieth-century practitioners this was
label: Paragraph

text: especially true of Eero Saarinen, who succumbed to a brain tumor that
label: Paragraph

text: ended his decade-long independent career—a nonstop succession of
label: Paragraph

text: dramatically styled, much-publicized designs for high-profile corporate,
label: Paragraph

text: educational, and governmental clients—just days after his fifty-first
label: Paragraph

text: birthday. But he was able to achieve so much in so little time because this
label: Paragraph

text: uncommonly precocious talent began working at age fifteen on small
label: Paragraph

text: decorative design tasks for his Finnish émigré father Eliel (who was then
label: Paragraph

text: building the Cranbrook Academy of Art in Michigan) and thanks to the
label: Paragraph

text: long-established reputation of the family firm had a rapid solo ascent after
label: Paragraph

text: the elder Saarinen’s death in 1950.
label: Paragraph

text: The unanswerable question of what might have been hovers over the
label: Paragraph

text: memory of all artists who die at an early age. But how they are perceived in
label: Paragraph

text: the long view of history has more to do with the quality, not the quantity, of
label: Paragraph

text: what they leave behind. The hugely prolific Austrian-born German-based
label: Paragraph

text: architect and industrial designer Joseph Maria Olbrich (1867—1908)—
label: Paragraph

text: whose work had a direct influence on Frank Lloyd Wright that remained
label: Paragraph

text: unacknowledged by the proudly independent American—left such a
label: Paragraph

text: considerable artistic legacy that his premature demise from leukemia at
label: Paragraph

text: forty is now little remembered. The all-too-youthful victims of war,
label: Paragraph

text: accident, or epidemic are exemplified by the Italian architect Antonio
label: Paragraph

text: Sant’Elia, who was killed in action at twenty-eight during the Great War,
label: Paragraph

text: before he had a chance to build much of anything, but who produced
label: Paragraph

text: visionary schemes of such inventive audacity that he remains a staple of
label: Paragraph

text: survey histories. Matthew Nowicki, a socially conscious Polish architect
label: Caption

text: whose career had been stalled by World War II, soon afterward won one of
label: Paragraph

text: the major planning commissions of the period: the design of Chandigarh,
label: Paragraph

text: the new capital city of the Punjab. But he died at forty when his plane
label: Paragraph

text: crashed in Egypt on his way home from India in 1950 (whereupon that
label: Paragraph

text: dream job passed to Le Corbusier). And the death from AIDS in 1996 of the
label: Paragraph

text: hugely promising Los Angeles architect Franklin D. Israel—whose
label: Paragraph

text: contemporaries include such now major figures as Rem Koolhaas, Thom
label: Paragraph

text: Mayne, Tod Williams, and Billie Tsien—reminds us of the wide swath that
label: Paragraph

text: plague cut through the arts during the twentieth century’s two concluding
label: Paragraph

text: decades.
label: Paragraph

text: To this twentieth-century necrology must be added one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: unjustly neglected figures in modern architecture, Jan Duiker, who died at
label: Paragraph

text: forty-four and whose posthumous reputation is now overshadowed by his
label: Paragraph

text: better-known Dutch contemporaries J. J. P. Oud and Gerrit Rietveld (both of
label: Paragraph

text: whom lived three decades longer than he did). Despite its small size, the
label: Paragraph

text: Netherlands between the two world wars encompassed some of the most
label: Paragraph

text: densely settled areas in Europe, with a population of around seven million
label: Paragraph

text: and a lively but highly factionalized architecture scene. During those years
label: Paragraph

text: the Netherlands witnessed an extraordinary outpouring of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: excellence, in three successive waves. Most conspicuous was the so-called
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam School, a circle of like-minded urbanists that included Michel
label: Paragraph

text: de Klerk, Piet Kramer, and Joan van der Mey—all of whom produced
label: Paragraph

text: freewheeling reinterpretations of traditional Dutch building forms with an
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionistic edge (as did Duiker himself at the outset of his career).
label: Paragraph

text: Because Holland was a noncombatant in World War I, civic construction
label: Paragraph

text: sponsored both by municipal governments and by nonprofit private building
label: Paragraph

text: societies proceeded apace throughout the 1910s. Dutch authorities put
label: Paragraph

text: strong emphasis on urban planning, social welfare projects, and public
label: Paragraph

text: housing, which would exert a wide influence on new architecture across
label: Paragraph

text: Europe during the years of widespread rebuilding that followed the end of
label: Paragraph

text: hostilities, particularly in Germany. The concentrated activity of the
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam School, which continued into the mid-1920s, made it one of the
label: Paragraph

text: most significant architectural reform movements of the early twentieth
label: Title

text: century.
label: Paragraph

text: Earlier in that decade, avant-garde developments elsewhere in Europe
label: Paragraph

text: inspired an emergent generation of Dutch architects to turn from the
label: Paragraph

text: predominant redbrick mode of their homeland and adopt the minimalist
label: Paragraph

text: machine aesthetic now commonly—if inaccurately—known as the Bauhaus
label: Paragraph

text: style. In Holland the equivalent tendency was dubbed De Stijl (the style),
label: Paragraph

text: which placed a particular emphasis on aesthetically pleasing surface
label: Paragraph

text: compositions that Duiker deemed too superficial to be the basis for an
label: Paragraph

text: architectural philosophy. His opinion was shared by Le Corbusier, who
label: Paragraph

text: dismissed the De Stijl exhibition held at the Paris gallery L’Effort Moderne
label: Paragraph

text: in 1923. Duiker’s published criticisms of De Stijl—a circle that included,
label: Paragraph

text: among others, Oud, Rietveld, and the architect Robert van ’t Hoff, as well
label: Paragraph

text: as the painters Piet Mondrian and Theo van Doesburg—understandably
label: Paragraph

text: aroused their enmity. Van Doesburg, who published De Stijl, the group’s
label: Paragraph

text: hugely influential journal (now considered an essential document of early
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism), effectively banned Duiker’s work from its pages, a major
label: Paragraph

text: reason why his posthumous reputation has languished. Yet there was even
label: Paragraph

text: dissent among De Stijl members, evident in 1926 when Oud declared that
label: Paragraph

text: van Doesburg lacked even “the slightest notion of building.”
label: Paragraph

text: Duiker instead aligned himself with yet another progressive Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: faction, De 8, which was founded in 1927 by six young architects (now
label: Paragraph

text: known only among architectural experts) who believed in a more
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic, structurally based approach than the De Stijl group. The name
label: Paragraph

text: De 8 did not derive from the number of founders but instead came from the
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch word acht, a homonym that can mean either “attention” or “eight.”
label: Paragraph

text: One of the group’s participants who had served in the army recalled the
label: Paragraph

text: command geef acht (pay attention) and deemed it a fitting call to
label: Paragraph

text: architectural action. Duiker joined the half-dozen originators in 1928,
label: Paragraph

text: became De 8’s president five years later, and presided over its merger with
label: Paragraph

text: yet another architectural coterie, Opbouw (construction), headed by the
label: Paragraph

text: architect and tubular-steel furniture pioneer Mart Stam, who edited the
label: Paragraph

text: conjoined organization’s magazine, De 8 en Opbouw.
label: Paragraph

text: Johannes Duiker—more familiarly known as Jan—was bom in The
label: Paragraph

text: Hague in 1890, where his father was a school principal and his mother a
label: Paragraph

text: teacher. He studied architecture at the Netherlands’ foremost institution for
label: Paragraph

text: the profession, the Delft University of Technology, where he met a fellow
label: Paragraph

text: student, Bernard Bijvoet, who would become his principal architectural
label: Paragraph

text: collaborator. After Duiker and Bijvoet received their diplomas in 1913, they
label: Paragraph

text: began working in the architectural firm of their main professor, Henri
label: Paragraph

text: Evers, who was then designing Rotterdam’s neotraditional city hall of
label: Paragraph

text: In 1916 they set up their own practice in Zandvoort, a coastal town west
label: Paragraph

text: of Amsterdam. Among the pair’s early commissions was the Karenhuis of
label: Paragraph

text: 1916-1920 in Alkmaar, a low-rise old age home that fits seamlessly into the
label: Paragraph

text: redbrick vernacular of that charming cheese-market town and is now
label: Paragraph

text: designated a national monument. The partners won the competition for this
label: Paragraph

text: scheme because they provided more individual housing units than any of
label: Paragraph

text: the other entrants. But this symmetrical four-winged building, sheltered by
label: Paragraph

text: a massive attic roof, brings to mind the comforting solidity of the British
label: Paragraph

text: Arts and Crafts Movement even as its clean lines, strong horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: fenestration, and lack of fussy detailing look forward to the startling new
label: Paragraph

text: directions advanced Dutch architecture was about to take.
label: Paragraph

text: The predominant architectural influence in early-twentieth-century
label: Paragraph

text: Holland was Hendrik Petrus Berlage (1856-1934), a generational father
label: Paragraph

text: figure akin to his older Viennese contemporary Otto Wagner in his powerful
label: Paragraph

text: influence on countless followers. Berlage’s vigorous redbrick structures
label: Paragraph

text: conveyed much the same strength and gravitas as those of his older
label: Paragraph

text: America counterpart H. H. Richardson. But when young Dutch architects of
label: Paragraph

text: the early twentieth century looked abroad for inspiration, they were
label: Paragraph

text: particularly responsive to the works of Frank Lloyd Wright, who might be
label: Paragraph

text: called Richardson’s spiritual grandson because his early mentor Louis
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan in his own youth worked for and was influenced by Richardson.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s particular popularity among Dutch architects was due in large
label: Paragraph

text: part to to the spirited advocacy of his foremost champion in Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: Hendrikus Theodorus Wijdeveld (1885-1989), yet another very long-lived
label: Paragraph

text: architect, who founded the influential arts magazine Wendingen (turnings)
label: Paragraph

text: in 1918 and edited it until it folded during the Great Depression in 1931.
label: Paragraph

text: Six years before that Wijdeveld devoted an entire issue of his periodical to
label: Paragraph

text: that American master and reissued the contents in book form as The Life-
label: Paragraph

text: Work of the American Architect Frank Lloyd Wright. It served as the basic
label: Paragraph

text: reference for the decade and a half until publication of Henry-Russell
label: Paragraph

text: Hitchcock’s In the Nature of Materials 1887-1941: The Buildings of Frank
label: Title

text: Lloyd Wright. Appearing as it did at a particularly low point in Wright’s
label: Paragraph

text: wildly fluctuating fortunes, Wijdeveld’s richly illustrated encomium helped
label: Paragraph

text: bolster his subject’s international reputation at a time when this middle-
label: Paragraph

text: aged has-been could barely find work in the US.
label: Paragraph

text: The impact of Wright’s designs in the Netherlands and its foreign
label: Paragraph

text: possessions was widespread, as seen, for example, in adaptations of his
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic overhanging roofs by Willem Marinus Dudok for several of
label: Caption

text: his remarkable schools in Hilversum during the 1920s, as well as in his flat-
label: Paragraph

text: roofed Hilversum Town Hall of 1928-1931, with its lingering echoes of
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s Unity Temple. Duiker and Bijvoet channeled Wright in their
label: Paragraph

text: closely clustered group of fourteen seaside villas of 1921-1923 in the
label: Paragraph

text: Hague beach community of Kijkduin. These transposed Prairie Houses,
label: Paragraph

text: several of them semidetached, are demonstrably Wrightian in their
label: Paragraph

text: combination of redbrick, horizontal wood siding, and stucco, with ground-
label: Paragraph

text: hugging profiles and deep eaves, as well as porte cocheres, verandas, and
label: Paragraph

text: planters that extend out to embrace the sandy seaside landscape. Some of
label: Paragraph

text: their interiors are even embellished with leaded-glass windows in abstract
label: Paragraph

text: geometric patterns, much like those in Wright’s revolutionary Prairie
label: Paragraph

text: Houses of 1900-1914.
label: Paragraph

text: The worldwide transmission of Wright’s ideas through his admirers in
label: Paragraph

text: Holland can likewise be seen in the Dutch colonial architect Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Prosper Wolff Schoemaker’s Preanger Hotel of 1929 in Bandung, Java.
label: Caption

text: This exotic structure’s strong horizontality and distinctive Mayan-inspired
label: Paragraph

text: stone ornamentation closely resemble Wright’s Imperial Hotel of 1914—
label: Paragraph

text: 1923 in Tokyo, which is nearer to the erstwhile Dutch East Indies than
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam. Though Schoemaker’s sobriquet of “the Frank Lloyd Wright of
label: Paragraph

text: Indonesia” seems a bit overreaching, there can be little doubt that he too
label: Paragraph

text: was looking closely at the output of this American innovator.
label: Paragraph

text: Later on, Duiker and his cohort paid closer attention to Russian
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivism, which emerged well before the October Revolution but
label: Paragraph

text: quickly became the built embodiment of the radical new regime that
label: Paragraph

text: promised a complete reshaping of society in all its aspects, not least
label: Paragraph

text: architecturally (until the new style fell out of favor with Communist Party
label: Paragraph

text: functionaries in the early 1930s and was superseded by the sub-Classicism
label: Paragraph

text: preferred by Stalin). Constructivism stressed its departure from
label: Paragraph

text: conventional approaches to building through its emphasis not just on the
label: Paragraph

text: frank exposure of a building’s function but also its actual structure, based
label: Paragraph

text: on a belief that it was dishonest to hide the inner workings of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: beneath an opaque exterior. What better conjunction of theory and practice
label: Paragraph

text: in this regard than to apply this idea to the healing powers of modern
label: Paragraph

text: medicine?
label: Title

text: The life and death of buildings is more than mere metaphor when it
label: Paragraph

text: comes to one category of architecture closely identified with the Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Movement: the sanatorium. These facilities for the treatment of tuberculosis
label: Paragraph

text: have been as emblematic of changing attitudes toward architecture as of
label: Paragraph

text: shifting views on contagion. Whereas Romantics saw consumption (as TB
label: Paragraph

text: was long popularly known) as an expression of personal tragedy—
label: Paragraph

text: exemplified by Alexandre Dumas’s La Dame aux camélias—Thomas Mann
label: Paragraph

text: signaled a wider shift in societal perceptions by drawing an analogy
label: Paragraph

text: between tuberculosis and the ills of the modern world; two of his most
label: Paragraph

text: memorable works (Tristan and The Magic Mountain) are set in Alpine
label: Paragraph

text: sanatoriums.
label: Paragraph

text: The design of European health-care facilities in the twentieth century got
label: Paragraph

text: off to a strong start with Josef Hoffmann’s Sanatorium Purkersdorf of
label: Paragraph

text: 1903-1905 in Austria, whose severely simple exterior—flat-roofed and
label: Paragraph

text: devoid of projecting ornament—anticipated the flat surfaces of the
label: Paragraph

text: International Style by two decades (see Illustration 4a). But the modern
label: Paragraph

text: clinic attained transcendent qualities with Duiker and Bijvoet’s Sanatorium
label: Paragraph

text: Zonnestraal of 1926-1931 near Hilversum (see Illustration 6a). Built on a
label: Caption

text: hillside in an idyllic country setting, this white-framed assemblage of low-
label: Paragraph

text: slung, flat-roofed pavilions seems to be (as is famously said of the
label: Paragraph

text: Elizabethan stately home Hardwick Hall) “more glass than wall,” and
label: Paragraph

text: exemplifies the most daring structural advances of Modernism. Yet its sleek
label: Paragraph

text: efficiency and lack of sentimentality did not inhibit a comforting aura, and
label: Paragraph

text: the facility conveyed a feeling far different from the antiseptic anonymity of
label: Paragraph

text: conventional hospitals. As the architectural historian Barry Bergdoll writes
label: Paragraph

text: in the monograph Sanatorium Zonnestraal: History and Restoration of a
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Monument, this pathbreaking scheme elided “the hopes for
label: Paragraph

text: restoring tuberculosis victims through sun and ventilation and the utopian
label: Title

text: hopes of the modern movement that architecture might be socially
label: Paragraph

text: transformative.”
label: Paragraph

text: This new approach, rationalized and reductive, was ideally suited to the
label: Paragraph

text: requirements of sanatoriums. The nearly invisible window-walls of this
label: Paragraph

text: revolutionary building format, taken to an unprecedented extreme by
label: Paragraph

text: Duiker and Bijvoet, provided generous access to sunlight and fresh air,
label: Paragraph

text: believed to be cures for tuberculosis. The International Style’s proscription
label: Paragraph

text: against applied ornament and dust-catching decorative details further served
label: Paragraph

text: the sanatorium’s requirements for the hygienic easy-to-clean surfaces
label: Paragraph

text: deemed essential to the containment of this highly contagious ailment.
label: Paragraph

text: These ideas caught on quickly, as evidenced by Alvar Aalto’s Paimio
label: Paragraph

text: Sanatorium of 1929-1932 in southern Finland, an International Style high-
label: Paragraph

text: rise that took several organizational cues from Duiker and Bijvoet’s
label: Paragraph

text: scheme.
label: Paragraph

text: Zonnestraal (“sunbeam” in Dutch) began as a commission from an
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam diamond workers’ health-care cooperative in 1919, in response
label: Paragraph

text: to the alarming rate of tuberculosis among cutters and polishers who could
label: Paragraph

text: not help but inhale dangerous amounts of diamond dust. Because
label: Paragraph

text: sanatoriums were usually sited in rural areas with low air pollution levels,
label: Paragraph

text: Zonnestraal’s sponsors bought a 286-acre estate—a varied terrain of
label: Paragraph

text: woodland and heath—on the outskirts of Hilversum (which would soon
label: Paragraph

text: become the center of Holland’s radio broadcasting industry).
label: Paragraph

text: But funding for the sanatorium stalled and the design partners drifted
label: Paragraph

text: apart. In 1925 Bijvoet relocated to Paris, where he worked with Pierre
label: Paragraph

text: Chareau on the celebrated Maison de Verre of 1928-1932, a glass-walled
label: Paragraph

text: private house—cum—medical office on the Left Bank that ingeniously
label: Paragraph

text: combined both functions through a host of inventive structural strategies.
label: Paragraph

text: When Dutch government subsidies at last allowed final plans for
label: Paragraph

text: Zonnestraal to be drawn up in 1926, Duiker was primarily responsible, with
label: Paragraph

text: considerable help from the structural engineer Jan Wiebenga, whose
label: Paragraph

text: technical expertise is reflected in the building’s poured-concrete framework.
label: Paragraph

text: The unusually lightweight, almost immaterial feeling Duiker and
label: Paragraph

text: Wiebenga gave to this sprawling, two-story complex—attributable to a
label: Paragraph

text: cantilever-support system that enabled floor and ceiling slabs to be
label: Paragraph

text: extended far beyond the core and obviated the need for solid outer walls—
label: Paragraph

text: was likened by one Dutch critic to “a small town in Japan, or . . . white-
label: Paragraph

text: painted ocean-liners with tall smokestacks, bridges, and crow’s nests.” Such
label: Paragraph

text: nautical imagery was apt. In his revolutionary manifesto Vers une
label: Paragraph

text: architecture (1923), Le Corbusier cited the no-nonsense functionalism of
label: Paragraph

text: modern transatlantic ships as a major source for his Purist aesthetic, which
label: Paragraph

text: was quickly adopted by his admirers in Holland’s Nieuwe Bouwen (new
label: Paragraph

text: building) movement, a catchall term for the many Dutch avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: factions working toward the same general goals.
label: Paragraph

text: Duiker’s spacious arrangement of Zonnestraal’s five free-standing
label: Paragraph

text: structures—a central administration building at the north end, with four
label: Paragraph

text: long, narrow residential wings splayed in pairs below it to maximize
label: Paragraph

text: southern exposure—approximated the outline of a butterfly. Furthermore,
label: Paragraph

text: the grouping seems to hover above the ground, a floating quality enhanced
label: Paragraph

text: by continuous rows of deep balconies outside each patient’s room, where
label: Paragraph

text: beds could be moved into the open air as weather permitted. The
label: Paragraph

text: sanatorium’s clientele was at first intended to be all male, limited to low-
label: Paragraph

text: wage diamond cutters, with a special emphasis on occupational therapy to
label: Paragraph

text: get those family breadwinners back on their feet financially as well as
label: Paragraph

text: physically. But when public funds were needed to bring the faltering
label: Paragraph

text: scheme to completion at the onset of the Great Depression, government
label: Paragraph

text: officials insisted that the facility treat patients of all backgrounds, and
label: Paragraph

text: individual dormitories were dedicated to men, women, and children.
label: Paragraph

text: Though Zonnestraal was hailed internationally upon completion, it
label: Paragraph

text: lacked classic (and collectable) furniture made specifically for the project,
label: Paragraph

text: as opposed to Hoffmann’s reclining Purkersdorf Sitzmaschine or Aalto’s
label: Paragraph

text: bent-plywood Paimio armchair, and in time the Hilversum complex slipped
label: Paragraph

text: from the canon. That decline paralleled the abatement of the “white plague”
label: Paragraph

text: after the advent of antibiotics in the 1940s, which led to the virtual
label: Paragraph

text: eradication of tuberculosis; by 1970 Zonnestraal was abandoned and
label: Paragraph

text: demolition loomed. Luckily, enlightened municipal authorities of
label: Paragraph

text: Hilversum, which arguably has more distinguished early Modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture than almost any other comparably sized European community,
label: Paragraph

text: wisely forestalled the decrepit sanatorium’s destruction. After numerous
label: Paragraph

text: feasibility studies, a full-scale restoration was begun in 2001 by Hubert-Jan
label: Paragraph

text: Henket and Wessel de Jonge, best known as the founders of Docomomo,
label: Paragraph

text: the Modernist historic preservation society they launched in 1988.
label: Paragraph

text: Henket and de Jonge (who won the 2010 World Monuments Fund/Knoll
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism Prize for their work on Zonnestraal) here set new standards of
label: Paragraph

text: authenticity in recreating details and finishes in accord with period
label: Paragraph

text: techniques. To make a self-financing enterprise out of the former
label: Paragraph

text: sanatorium, the architects designed a four-building assisted-living facility
label: Paragraph

text: for the property in an appropriately neo-Corbusian mode and placed it at a
label: Paragraph

text: respectful remove from the landmark ensemble. The sanatorium itself has
label: Paragraph

text: been adapted for present-day health issues by including obesity and sports-
label: Paragraph

text: injury clinics, and can be visited at times that do not interfere with its
label: Paragraph

text: operations. (The former administration building can now be rented for
label: Paragraph

text: weddings and other parties.)
label: Paragraph

text: In 1928, Christian Zervos, the influential publisher of Cahiers d’Art and
label: Paragraph

text: now best remembered for his multivolume catalogue raisonné on the works
label: Paragraph

text: of Picasso, faulted Zonnestraal for its lack of “either monumentality or
label: Paragraph

text: charm.” But in its happily restored state, this structurally ingenious,
label: Paragraph

text: gracefully composed, playfully turreted scheme fairly radiates a charisma
label: Paragraph

text: equal to any of the finest architecture of the interwar years. Zonnestraal’s
label: Paragraph

text: embracing intimacy and palpable humility make the postmillennial
label: Paragraph

text: resurrection of Duiker and Bijvoet’s architectural gem no less than a
label: Paragraph

text: modern miracle.
label: Paragraph

text: Duiker’s most conspicuous post-Zonnestraal design was for the
label: Paragraph

text: Openlucht school of 1929-1930 in Amsterdam, which embodied one of the
label: Paragraph

text: period’s prevalent notions of education reform—that children would learn
label: Paragraph

text: better if they were not cooped up in conventional classrooms but afforded
label: Paragraph

text: the physically and mentally bracing effects of fresh air (see Illustration 6b).
label: Paragraph

text: To be sure, the chronic inattentiveness of primary and secondary school
label: Paragraph

text: students has plagued educators for centuries, but the fairly recent realization
label: Paragraph

text: that adequate sleep and proper diet might have more to do with pupils’
label: Paragraph

text: concentration than brisk ventilation seems not to have been a priority
label: Paragraph

text: among proponents of the fresh-air theory, and a vogue for outdoor
label: Paragraph

text: education swept Europe during the early twentieth century.
label: Paragraph

text: This commission suited Duiker’s specific architectural aims perfectly.
label: Paragraph

text: Buildings generally stand up in one of two ways: either through the support
label: Paragraph

text: of load-bearing exterior walls (such as Duiker used for the massive brick
label: Paragraph

text: exterior of the Karenhuis in Alkmaar) or through an inner structure that
label: Paragraph

text: carries the weight of floors from within. The higher a load-bearing-wall
label: Paragraph

text: building, the thicker its periphery needs to be at its base; the tallest structure
label: Paragraph

text: of this kind ever erected, Daniel Burnham and John Wellborn Root’s
label: Paragraph

text: seventeen-story Monadnock Block of 1891-1893 in Chicago, has six-foot-
label: Caption

text: thick ground-floor masonry to support it, more like a fortified Florentine
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance palazzo than a modern office building.
label: Paragraph

text: But this wasteful use of materials was recognized as unnecessary once
label: Paragraph

text: the economy and adaptability of reinforced concrete skeletons were fully
label: Paragraph

text: understood by architects, engineers, and their clients as the twentieth
label: Paragraph

text: century progressed. Duiker exploited his rapidly expanding technical know-
label: Paragraph

text: how to free the exterior of the four-story Openlucht school (on which
label: Caption

text: Bijvoet came back to consult as well) so that its outer walls could be
label: Paragraph

text: composed of sliding floor-to-ceiling planes of glass that roll back to create a
label: Paragraph

text: veritable outdoor environment for the pupils inside. Though this was not
label: Paragraph

text: always a feasible option in the North Sea climate of Holland, Duiker went
label: Paragraph

text: on to use the same structural format in his Nirwana apartment house of
label: Paragraph

text: 1930 in The Hague, a block of luxury apartments that differed from the
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam prototype in that its periphery was not entirely retractable.
label: Paragraph

text: The Duiker building that most clearly displays the influence of Russian
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivism is the Handelsblad Cineac Cinema of 1934, a small
label: Paragraph

text: screening room on a busy central Amsterdam commercial street. It stands
label: Paragraph

text: directly across from the city’s most flamboyant interwar movie palace,
label: Paragraph

text: Hijman Louis de Jong’s Theater Tuschinski of 1919-1921, a vibrant mash-
label: Paragraph

text: up of late Art Nouveau, early Art Deco, and Amsterdam School stylistic
label: Paragraph

text: motifs. In contrast to this sumptuous showcase for first-run commercial
label: Paragraph

text: films, the Cineac Cinema (owned by the Dutch business newspaper NRC
label: Paragraph

text: Handelsblad) was conceived as a self-consciously utilitarian outlet for the
label: Paragraph

text: nonstop presentation of newsreels, a relatively recent development in mass
label: Paragraph

text: communications. Duiker felt that the immediacy of such documentary films
label: Paragraph

text: demanded a more forthright aesthetic than the seductive showbiz glitz
label: Paragraph

text: epitomized by the escapist fantasy of the Tushcinski.
label: Paragraph

text: A basic concern for Duiker was how to make his little theater visible
label: Paragraph

text: amid its cluttered surroundings. Apart from his disinterest in lush
label: Paragraph

text: ornamentation of the sort that distinguishes the Tuschinski’s elaborately
label: Paragraph

text: articulated terra-cotta fagade, he was given a tight budget. Newsreels were a
label: Paragraph

text: new form of entertainment whose profitability was far from guaranteed, but
label: Paragraph

text: as it turned out the fast-moving political and social developments of the
label: Paragraph

text: 1930s made it a medium very much in touch with the hectic tenor of those
label: Paragraph

text: unsettled times, well before television became widely available. In order to
label: Paragraph

text: make the Cineac Cinema stand out among its neighbors, the architect
label: Paragraph

text: reduced it to a billboard-like essence, with a diagonally angled rooftop
label: Paragraph

text: framework that displays the theater’s name spelled out in large neon letters
label: Paragraph

text: and repeated on a vertical banner perpendicular to the street for maximum
label: Paragraph

text: legibility from near and afar.
label: Paragraph

text: Duiker was clearly taking major cues from one of the Russian
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivists’ hallmark inventions, the propaganda kiosk for
label: Paragraph

text: dissemination of news in various formats. This might be either a fixed
label: Paragraph

text: installation or even a vehicle such as a truck or railroad car that was
label: Paragraph

text: retrofitted to its new function and transported to outlying destinations to
label: Paragraph

text: inform local inhabitants of the revolution’s latest developments. Propaganda
label: Paragraph

text: kiosks were akin to three-dimensional billboards in their bold graphic
label: Paragraph

text: legibility, and they often incorporated electronic sound amplification to
label: Paragraph

text: attract further attention from passersby; some even enclosed small
label: Paragraph

text: screening rooms for the projection of short film clips. Further characteristic
label: Paragraph

text: of the Constructivist ethos, Duiker designed the fagade of the Cineac with a
label: Paragraph

text: transparent strip window that allowed the workings of its projection room to
label: Paragraph

text: be seen from the street, a veritable teaser for what was going on inside.
label: Paragraph

text: (This same basic idea was expressed by Diller Scofidio + Renfro with their
label: Paragraph

text: 2003-2010 remodeling of New York’s Juilliard School of Music, in which
label: Caption

text: they revealed the institution’s dance studios to the full view of passersby on
label: Paragraph

text: Broadway.)
label: Paragraph

text: Commercial buildings of great architectural distinction are often more
label: Paragraph

text: prone to destruction than other landmarks, for once they cease to make
label: Paragraph

text: money for their owners they are frequently demolished unless a new
label: Paragraph

text: function can be found for them—the reason why so many of the grand
label: Paragraph

text: cinema palaces of the interwar years have disappeared. When film
label: Paragraph

text: newsreels were made obsolete by the wider availability of television news
label: Paragraph

text: in the 1960s, the Cineac became a grind-house for second-run movies, and
label: Paragraph

text: the rise of home video put an end even to that reprieve in 1995. Thereafter
label: Paragraph

text: Duiker’s hardy little survivor briefly became a Planet Hollywood theme
label: Paragraph

text: restaurant, but when that venture failed the structure was carved up into
label: Paragraph

text: apartments with yet another restaurant space on the street front. Through all
label: Paragraph

text: these changes the exterior has remained remarkably intact, including the all-
label: Paragraph

text: important Cineac signage. Duiker himself lived for only a few months after
label: Paragraph

text: his final small masterwork was finished. His far too early death, from
label: Paragraph

text: leukemia, was an ironic end for a man who set so much store in the healing
label: Paragraph

text: powers—both physical and psychic—of the new form of architecture he did
label: Paragraph

text: so much to advance.

text: ALBERT SPEER / GERDY TROOST
label: Title

text: AMONG THE ODDER conceits of the Romantic movement was the vogue for
label: Paragraph

text: rendering new buildings as ruins. Inspired by Piranesi’s moody vedute of
label: Paragraph

text: noble Roman monuments in picturesque decay, late-eighteenth-and early-
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth-century architects such as John Soane had their latest works
label: Paragraph

text: depicted as they might look millennia in the future—bare ruin’d choirs and
label: Paragraph

text: whited sepulchres that spoke of vanished glory and implied emotional
label: Paragraph

text: depth. This bizarre practice was revived by Albert Speer, Adolf Hitler’s
label: Paragraph

text: master builder, who appealed to his patron’s apocalyptic instincts by urging
label: Paragraph

text: him to anticipate their projects’ Ruinenwert (ruin value) and thereby
label: Paragraph

text: approve extra expenditures to guarantee that the Thousand-Year Reich
label: Paragraph

text: would leave architectural remains equal to those of the ancients. Speer’s
label: Paragraph

text: vision was fulfilled much sooner than he expected, and among the more
label: Paragraph

text: popular picture postcards that Allied soldiers sent back home from
label: Paragraph

text: Germany in 1945 were images of the architect’s Reich Chancellery of
label: Paragraph

text: 1936-1939 in Berlin as a blasted shambles and Hitler’s country house of
label: Paragraph

text: 1935-1937 in Berchtesgaden as a hollowed-out wreck.
label: Caption

text: Yet several major examples of Nazi architecture—a_twelve-year
label: Paragraph

text: outpouring of publicly financed construction that encompassed everything
label: Paragraph

text: from the Autobahn system of 1933 onward and the 1936 Berlin Olympic
label: Title

text: Stadium to officer-training schools and extermination camps—were so
label: Paragraph

text: solidly crafted that even Allied saturation bombing could not reduce them
label: Paragraph

text: to rubble. Some have served several successive German governments, such
label: Paragraph

text: as Ernst Sagebiel’s sprawling, stone-clad Aviation Ministry of 1934-1935
label: Paragraph

text: in Berlin, which was first recycled by the Communist East Germans as the
label: Paragraph

text: House of Ministries, then after reunification was used by the government’s
label: Paragraph

text: restitution agency, and now houses the nation’s Finance Ministry.
label: Paragraph

text: Two decades after the war, the still-vexing question of how and even
label: Paragraph

text: whether to deal with this long-taboo chapter in twentieth-century culture
label: Paragraph

text: was finally addressed at the Modern Architecture Symposia (MAS), three
label: Paragraph

text: biennial conferences held at Columbia University in 1962, 1964, and 1966
label: Paragraph

text: to define and codify the Modern Movement for the first time as a historical
label: Paragraph

text: development. Participants included many of the period’s leading
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and art scholars—including Alfred H. Barr Jr., Vincent Scully
label: Paragraph

text: Jr, and Rudolf Wittkower—but transcripts of most of these fascinating
label: Paragraph

text: proceedings remained unavailable until the publication in 2014 of a new
label: Paragraph

text: critical compendium of highlights edited by Joan Ockman and my wife,
label: Paragraph

text: Rosemarie Haag Bletter, with Nancy Eklund Later.
label: Caption

text: For the second of the three symposia, which dealt with the 1930s, the
label: Paragraph

text: historians Henry-Russell Hitchcock and George R. Collins invited the
label: Paragraph

text: principal benefactor of the series, Philip Johnson, to discuss Nazi
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, a logical enough choice because of his fascist sympathies
label: Paragraph

text: during the period under discussion and the throwback Stripped Classicism
label: Paragraph

text: of his most recent buildings. But Johnson demurred, doubtless worried that
label: Paragraph

text: his shameful political past would harm his blossoming architectural
label: Paragraph

text: practice. Instead, this still-touchy subject was handled, albeit somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: obliquely, by the Vienna-born Harvard historian Eduard Sekler, who
label: Paragraph

text: examined architectural reactions to Hitler in their native Austria, rather than
label: Paragraph

text: the main manifestations of Nazi construction in Germany. With perhaps an
label: Paragraph

text: excess of Viennese evasiveness, Sekler admitted that until then he’d
label: Paragraph

text: considered Nazi design merely “a rather distasteful interval.” More
label: Paragraph

text: pointedly, a Columbia graduate student (and later Cornell architectural
label: Paragraph

text: history professor), Christian F. Otto, delivered a short, sharp overview of
label: Paragraph

text: the ideological roots of urbanism in the Third Reich, which he characterized
label: Paragraph

text: as “a perversion of the traditions of German architectural and planning
label: Paragraph

text: theory” with one goal: “the absolute control of the leader over the led.”
label: Paragraph

text: The MAS discussions did not address the lack of women in the
label: Paragraph

text: profession—an issue that would not fully emerge until the 1970s—but even
label: Paragraph

text: if they had it was unlikely that much attention would have been accorded
label: Paragraph

text: Gerdy Troost, who figures prominently in Hitler at Home (2015), by the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural historian Despina Stratigakos. Although a book about the
label: Paragraph

text: Fihrer’s taste in interior decoration might seem like a Mel Brooks joke, the
label: Paragraph

text: crucial part that aesthetics played in advancing the National Socialist
label: Paragraph

text: Though the Modern Movement in architecture reflected many advanced
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Berthold Konrad Hermann Albert Speer was born in Mannheim in 1905,
label: Paragraph

text: the son of an architect who made no pretense of his love for money and a
label: Paragraph

text: grasping, social-climbing mother. It is indicative of Kitchen’s painstaking
label: Paragraph

text: scholarship that he accepts nothing his tenaciously mendacious subject said
label: Paragraph

text: at face value, not even Speer’s account of his own birth. Although he
label: Paragraph

text: claimed it took place amid the dramatic conjunction of a thunderstorm and
label: Paragraph

text: noonday bells pealing from an adjacent church, his biographer found that
label: Paragraph

text: the sanctuary in question was not built until the boy was six, and
label: Paragraph

text: furthermore that it rained in Mannheim that day only later in the afternoon.
label: Paragraph

text: Thereafter Kitchen catches him in dozens of lies, big and small, throughout
label: Paragraph

text: this harrowing account.
label: Paragraph

text: Speer studied architecture at what is now the Technical University in
label: Paragraph

text: Berlin under Heinrich Tessenow, whose architecture was characterized by
label: Paragraph

text: what Eduard Sekler called an “unassuming, rather charming simplicity . . .
label: Paragraph

text: [that] had its roots in the same soil where folklore and classicism grew side
label: Paragraph

text: by side.” Tempting as it may be to see Speer’s Third Reich fever dreams as
label: Paragraph

text: inflated versions of Tessenow’s pared-down Classicism, he utterly lacked
label: Paragraph

text: his teacher’s delicate touch, gift for faultless proportions, and sense of
label: Paragraph

text: humane scale. An architectural third-rater by any measure, Speer would
label: Paragraph

text: have languished at some back-office drafting table had he not joined the
label: Paragraph

text: Nazi Party in 1931. Such were his networking skills that a year later he was
label: Paragraph

text: asked to refurbish the party’s Berlin headquarters.
label: Paragraph

text: Within months of Hitler’s takeover he improvised a stunning scheme that
label: Paragraph

text: secured his place in the Nazi hierarchy. The annual National Socialist
label: Paragraph

text: convocation in Nuremberg, held on campgrounds outside the city, took on
label: Paragraph

text: added importance once Hitler gained political legitimacy. But before Speer
label: Paragraph

text: was able to execute his Brobdingnagian stadium of 1935-1937, he had to
label: Paragraph

text: come up with a suitably impressive interim solution. In 1933 he
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: around the perimeter of the assembly grounds, pointed them upward, and
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: or, alternatively, formed the bars of a gargantuan virtual cage. This coup de
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: loathsome in the entire history of this art form.
