text: THE LEVITT BROTHERS
label: Title

text: ALTHOUGH THE GREAT RECESSION of 2007-2009 was set off when the United
label: Paragraph

text: States housing bubble burst, not long afterward amnesiac Americans again
label: Paragraph

text: began speculating in domestic real estate. The steep rise in residential
label: Paragraph

text: property values during the final two decades of the twentieth century still
label: Paragraph

text: lingered in many people’s minds, as did the widespread memory among the
label: Paragraph

text: baby-boom generation that the family house was the best investment their
label: Paragraph

text: parents ever made. People in this country seemingly cannot resist the
label: Paragraph

text: temptation to “flip” real estate—that is, buying and reselling in the short
label: Paragraph

text: term to make a quick profit.
label: Paragraph

text: Midway through the millennium’s second decade, recovery in the
label: Paragraph

text: national housing market remained spotty—in 2015, 7.4 million home
label: Paragraph

text: mortgages were seriously “underwater” (i.e., the balance of the loan was
label: Paragraph

text: more than 25 percent higher than the property’s current assessed value)—
label: Paragraph

text: but a healthy local economy could still support flipping even modest
label: Paragraph

text: residences, though perhaps not as profitably as a few years earlier. Several
label: Paragraph

text: cable TV channels broadcast series that followed this process, including
label: Paragraph

text: Flip This House, Flipping Virgins, Rehab Addict, and my personal favorite,
label: Paragraph

text: Flip or Flop. This program starred a telegenic young Southern California
label: Paragraph

text: couple who took down-at-the-heels Orange County tract houses, remodeled
label: Paragraph

text: them to suit contemporary tastes—with loftlike “open concept” floor plans,
label: Paragraph

text: spa-inspired bathrooms, and obligatory granite kitchen countertops—and
label: Paragraph

text: often made a five-figure return on their investment, although some of their
label: Paragraph

text: cost estimates seemed suspiciously low and their completion schedules
label: Paragraph

text: improbably speedy to anyone who has ever done home improvements. Flip
label: Paragraph

text: or Flop (which ended in 2017 after four years when the co-stars divorced)
label: Paragraph

text: and other examples of what has been called real estate porn remind us that
label: Paragraph

text: there is a huge inventory of postwar suburban housing stock all around the
label: Paragraph

text: country, much of it in the style we now call midcentury modern, although
label: Paragraph

text: more exists in hybrid modes that mix traditional and contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: elements. Millions of detached single-family houses were erected on the
label: Paragraph

text: outskirts of American cities between the end of wartime building material
label: Paragraph

text: restrictions in 1947 and the onset of the oil embargo recession in 1973.
label: Paragraph

text: In his study Detached America (2015), James A. Jacobs states that during
label: Paragraph

text: the quarter-century after the war “private builders and building companies
label: Paragraph

text: constructed about 35,500,000 housing units . . . [of which] the
label: Paragraph

text: overwhelming majority . . . were the detached single-family houses that
label: Paragraph

text: define suburbia.” The mass migration at midcentury—by 1950 more
label: Paragraph

text: Americans lived in suburbs than in cities—represented a thoroughgoing
label: Paragraph

text: reformulation of our domestic landscape and a colossal demographic
label: Title

text: upheaval. This immense shift grew out of the pent-up demand created by
label: Paragraph

text: nearly two decades of severely curtailed construction during the Great
label: Paragraph

text: Depression and World War II. An acute housing shortage was exacerbated
label: Paragraph

text: by a sharp increase in postwar birth rates, which resulted in a whirlwind of
label: Paragraph

text: suburban residential development that had been anticipated but delayed for
label: Paragraph

text: some time. For if planners could not have predicted the back-to-back
label: Paragraph

text: economic and military traumas of the 1930s and 1940s, housing reformers
label: Paragraph

text: had long foreseen a looming crisis in the uncontrolled growth of older
label: Paragraph

text: urban centers.
label: Paragraph

text: The proliferation of automobile ownership during the century’s second
label: Title

text: and third decades gave new if short-lived impetus to the Garden City
label: Paragraph

text: Movement, founded in 1898 by the British planning theorist Ebenezer
label: Paragraph

text: Howard, who opposed unlimited urban growth in favor of multiple,
label: Paragraph

text: moderate-sized “conurbations” with dwellings and workplaces in
label: Paragraph

text: convenient proximity. Such medium-density centers would ideally be
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by undeveloped greenbelts for recreation and as barriers against
label: Paragraph

text: pollution. Yet this congenial middle ground between urban overcrowding
label: Paragraph

text: and rural isolation made little headway in the US, despite the spirited
label: Paragraph

text: advocacy of the critic Lewis Mumford and his fellow members of the
label: Paragraph

text: Regional Planning Association of America, which was organized in 1923
label: Paragraph

text: by the architect and planner Clarence Stein to promote New Towns in
label: Paragraph

text: America.
label: Paragraph

text: A rare application of Garden City principles in this country was Stein and
label: Paragraph

text: Wright’s Radburn, New Jersey, of 1928-1930, the only partially realized
label: Paragraph

text: but nonetheless internationally influential “New Town for the Motor Age.”
label: Paragraph

text: Yet however intelligently Radburn accommodated the burgeoning car
label: Paragraph

text: culture, it did not incorporate businesses (beyond a few shops for local
label: Paragraph

text: residents)—a crucial component of British New Towns, which sought to
label: Paragraph

text: integrate the domestic and professional spheres of life more intimately—
label: Paragraph

text: and it became by default a commuter suburb, albeit a very fine one, for
label: Paragraph

text: people with jobs in nearby cities, especially Newark and New York.
label: Paragraph

text: Importantly, Radburn was predicated on the radical belief of the nineteenth-
label: Paragraph

text: century political economist Henry George that “we must make land
label: Paragraph

text: common property.” Thus, although Radburn’s homeowners hold title to
label: Paragraph

text: their dwellings, the ground beneath them is retained in trust for all by a
label: Paragraph

text: cooperative association. This egalitarian principle removed a major
label: Paragraph

text: financial incentive that typically drives developers and investors who can
label: Paragraph

text: make money from the sale of unbuilt plots (usually at steadily increasing
label: Paragraph

text: prices) if a community thrives, as was done with Seaside, Florida, founded
label: Paragraph

text: in 1981 and a paradigm of the neotraditional New Urbanism Movement in
label: Paragraph

text: the United States. For this and other reasons, the wholly noncommercial
label: Paragraph

text: Radburn idea never caught on in the States.
label: Paragraph

text: The great unanswered question about the suburbanization of mid-
label: Paragraph

text: twentieth-century America is this: Could it have been done better? A more
label: Paragraph

text: intelligent approach to design was certainly shown by the Case Study
label: Paragraph

text: House Program—the loose association of like-minded Modernist architects
label: Title

text: organized in 1945 by John Entenza, the editor of the California-based Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Architecture magazine, who solicited superior prototypes for residential
label: Paragraph

text: living from some of the period’s most imaginative designers. However,
label: Paragraph

text: their plans were neither conceived for mass production nor geared to
label: Paragraph

text: providing the cheapest possible dwelling per square foot. In contrast,
label: Paragraph

text: affordability, not design distinction, was the overriding motivation for the
label: Paragraph

text: best-known postwar tract-house manufacturers, the Levitt brothers—
label: Paragraph

text: William, who headed the company (established in 1929 by their father,
label: Paragraph

text: Abraham, the son of a Russian rabbi), and Alfred, its chief architectural
label: Paragraph

text: designer and planner.
label: Paragraph

text: William Jaird Levitt and Alfred Stuart Levitt were born in Brooklyn in
label: Paragraph

text: 1907 and 1912, respectively, and although both studied at New York
label: Paragraph

text: University, neither of them took a degree. Their father was a real estate
label: Paragraph

text: lawyer who in the mid-1920s accepted vacant real estate plots in Rockville
label: Paragraph

text: Center, a Long Island suburb, from a bankrupt client in lieu of cash
label: Paragraph

text: payment. When builders with whom he had joined in a speculative project
label: Paragraph

text: to erect forty houses on the property defaulted, he asked his sons to
label: Paragraph

text: complete the job, which they successfully did shortly before the stock
label: Paragraph

text: market crash.
label: Paragraph

text: The brash, outgoing Bill Levitt was a born salesman and perfect front
label: Paragraph

text: man for the family-owned operation, whereas the retiring Al was artistically
label: Paragraph

text: inclined. The pragmatic Abe Levitt once said of his younger son, “Alfred
label: Paragraph

text: loved to draw, but he didn’t know what a two-by-four was.” Oddly, despite
label: Paragraph

text: the aspiring master builder’s obvious knack for creating houses from an
label: Paragraph

text: early age, he never had any formal design education nor did he ever receive
label: Paragraph

text: an architecture license, and thus always needed a registered architect to sign
label: Paragraph

text: and seal his plans.
label: Paragraph

text: The Great Depression notwithstanding, the Levitt firm went on to
label: Paragraph

text: construct small groups of high-end houses on Long Island before World
label: Paragraph

text: War II. But when the Levitt brothers were drafted into the military they
label: Paragraph

text: observed a number of industrialized engineering and fabrication techniques
label: Paragraph

text: that could be profitably applied to the mass production of lower-priced
label: Paragraph

text: dwellings for returning servicemen, the postwar period’s most obvious
label: Paragraph

text: growth market. They were only two of many servicemen with some prior
label: Paragraph

text: connection to architecture or the construction industry who discovered
label: Title

text: transformative ideas for improving building methods and materials thanks
label: Title

text: to the necessarily improvisatory and innovative atmosphere stimulated in
label: Paragraph

text: the armed forces by the all-out war effort.
label: Paragraph

text: To cut expenses on the very different kind of houses they decided to
label: Paragraph

text: build when peace came, the Levitts’ no-frills, wood-frame structures did not
label: Paragraph

text: have an excavated basement, but instead were erected atop a concrete slab
label: Paragraph

text: poured directly onto the ground and inlaid with radiant heating (a method
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright pioneered in his low-cost Usonian houses of the 1930s
label: Paragraph

text: onward, which featured several other concepts that Alfred Levitt proudly
label: Paragraph

text: admitted he’d swiped from the grand old master). Although it is often
label: Paragraph

text: assumed that Levitt houses were prefabricated, they were merely
label: Paragraph

text: standardized, with interchangeable components and simplified assembly
label: Paragraph

text: strategies that resulted in considerable economies.
label: Paragraph

text: Therefore the company could deliver compact, freestanding “minimum
label: Paragraph

text: houses”—a term that originated in Weimar Germany’s social-housing
label: Paragraph

text: movement as das Existenzminimum (the minimum required dwelling area)
label: Paragraph

text: —that war veterans could buy for less per month in total carrying charges
label: Paragraph

text: than the going rental rates for many city apartments. The Levitt company
label: Paragraph

text: required no down payment, and the low-interest, thirty-year mortgages
label: Paragraph

text: provided to vets by the Federal Housing Administration put these houses
label: Paragraph

text: within easy reach of even those with moderate incomes. Who could resist
label: Paragraph

text: owning a brand-new homestead in the countryside with the last word in
label: Paragraph

text: kitchens and bathrooms, instead of leasing an old inner-city apartment with
label: Paragraph

text: a Claw-foot tub and no backyard?
label: Paragraph

text: The first houses offered by the Levitts in their now famous development
label: Paragraph

text: in Hempstead, New York, thirty-seven miles east of Manhattan—initially
label: Paragraph

text: called Island Trees but renamed Levittown after marketers discovered that
label: Paragraph

text: the family name signified quality to consumers—were completed in 1947
label: Paragraph

text: (see Illustration 8a). (They were initially for rent only, with an option to buy
label: Paragraph

text: after one year, but became available for outright purchase in 1949.) The
label: Paragraph

text: 750-square-foot floor plan comprised a living room, kitchen, two bedrooms,
label: Paragraph

text: and one bathroom, with an unfinished partial attic space suitable for future
label: Paragraph

text: expansion. This tidy Cape Cod cottage sold for $6,990 (more than $78,000
label: Paragraph

text: in current value), but the brothers soon found that buyers would willingly
label: Paragraph

text: pay somewhat more for upgrades, and in 1949 they introduced an equally
label: Paragraph

text: successful 800-square-foot ranch-style version for $7,990 (equivalent to
label: Paragraph

text: nearly $84,000 today). Though the dimensions of these initial Levittown
label: Paragraph

text: houses seem minuscule by current standards—the median size of new
label: Paragraph

text: single-family American houses is 2,521 square feet, more than three times
label: Paragraph

text: larger than the Levitts’ first offerings—they were considered capacious
label: Paragraph

text: enough by a generation long inured to overcrowding at home during the
label: Paragraph

text: deprivation of the Depression and the housing shortage of the war years,
label: Paragraph

text: when separate bedrooms for each child and multiple bathrooms were
label: Paragraph

text: unheard of except among the rich.
label: Paragraph

text: The Levitt brothers’ venture into mass production was backed up by the
label: Paragraph

text: bountiful provision of home-financing benefits through the Servicemen’s
label: Paragraph

text: Readjustment Act of 1944. Commonly called the GI Bill, it contrasted
label: Paragraph

text: dramatically with the disgraceful treatment of World War I veterans at the
label: Paragraph

text: onset of the Great Depression, when the 1932 Bonus Army March on
label: Paragraph

text: Washington was violently suppressed. Along with generous tuition
label: Paragraph

text: subsidies for former servicemen—this country’s most extensive foray into
label: Paragraph

text: socialized higher education—the 67,000 mortgages guaranteed through the
label: Paragraph

text: GI Bill made home ownership possible for more citizens than ever before
label: Paragraph

text: (except nonwhites, who received fewer than one hundred of those loans).
label: Paragraph

text: To take advantage of this bonanza in government-guaranteed home
label: Paragraph

text: ownership—a key component of encouraging a large, stable, taxpaying
label: Paragraph

text: middle class—as-tute entrepreneurs across the country quickly copied the
label: Paragraph

text: Levitts’ cost-efficient formula.
label: Paragraph

text: In her book Houses for a New World (2015), the architectural historian
label: Paragraph

text: Barbara Miller Lane investigated the output of a dozen lesser-known tract-
label: Paragraph

text: house developers in four diverse regions—New England, the mid-Atlantic,
label: Paragraph

text: the Midwest, and Southern California—and analyzed the period’s typical
label: Paragraph

text: Cape Cods, ranches, and split-levels with the serious formal analysis once
label: Paragraph

text: reserved for high-style architecture. Her tour de force of research is all the
label: Paragraph

text: more impressive because she assembled documentation akin to that
label: Paragraph

text: previously available on the residential work of important postwar figures
label: Paragraph

text: such as Richard Neutra, William Wurster, and Marcel Breuer but largely
label: Paragraph

text: overlooked for builders other than the Levitts. Her vivid evocation of the
label: Paragraph

text: postwar suburban building boom recalls a hopeful time when a popular
label: Paragraph

text: American middle-class weekend pastime was to pile the kids and in-laws
label: Paragraph

text: into the family car and drive around looking at model houses, whether or
label: Paragraph

text: not you were actively shopping for a new place.
label: Paragraph

text: Lane found newspaper advertisements and promotional materials for
label: Paragraph

text: subdivisions that were clearly aimed at wives (who wielded huge influence
label: Paragraph

text: about housing decisions even though their husbands were the breadwinners)
label: Paragraph

text: and stressed the transformational nature of life in these up-to-the-minute
label: Paragraph

text: dwellings. A revealing example of that direct emotional appeal to women
label: Paragraph

text: can be found in a 1955-1957 sales brochure for Cinderella Homes, a new
label: Paragraph

text: Anaheim, California, subdivision not far from the recently completed
label: Paragraph

text: Disneyland. This booklet depicts a princess-like figure and regal coach next
label: Paragraph

text: to a rendering of a sprawling ranch-style house and the words “your every
label: Paragraph

text: wish for a home . . . come gloriously true.” The Disneyesque iconography
label: Paragraph

text: chimes perfectly with the opening lines of “Young at Heart,” Johnny
label: Paragraph

text: Richards and Carolyn Leigh’s 1953 hit song for Frank Sinatra: “Fairy tales
label: Title

text: can come true / It can happen to you. .. .”
label: Paragraph

text: A phenomenon as pervasive as this vast population redistribution could
label: Paragraph

text: not have gone unnoticed by commentators in various disciplines, and an
label: Paragraph

text: extensive literature on the new suburbanization quickly developed. Critical
label: Paragraph

text: responses tended to be negative from the outset, typified by such debunking
label: Paragraph

text: books as the newspaperman John Keats’s The Crack in the Picture Window
label: Caption

text: (1956) and a dubious pop psychological report by the physician Richard E.
label: Paragraph

text: Gordon, his wife Katherine K. Gordon, and the journalist Max Gunther
label: Paragraph

text: titled The Split-Level Trap (1960), which claimed that the new suburbs
label: Paragraph

text: made people physically and mentally ill. In due course several
label: Paragraph

text: methodologically sound (and now classic) studies—led by the sociologist
label: Paragraph

text: Herbert Gans’s The Levittowners: Ways of Life and Politics in a New
label: Title

text: Suburban Community (1967) and the urban historian Kenneth Jackson’s
label: Paragraph

text: Crabgrass Frontier: The Suburbanization of the United States (1985)—
label: Title

text: presented more nuanced interpretations. So did The Suburban Myth (1969)
label: Paragraph

text: by the historian (and future literary biographer) Scott Donaldson, who
label: Paragraph

text: argued that mass-produced postwar housing had less to do with the malaise
label: Paragraph

text: of corporate conformity than the persistence of the Jeffersonian ideal (“the
label: Paragraph

text: champion American myth of all time”), which a century and a half earlier
label: Paragraph

text: established patterns of individual exurban living that worked against the
label: Paragraph

text: development of cohesive communities.
label: Paragraph

text: Lane attempts to make a case for the architectural virtues of midcentury
label: Paragraph

text: tract houses, and traces the origins of their organizational formats to
label: Paragraph

text: specific parts of the country where they originated before spreading
label: Paragraph

text: nationwide. Thus we learn that the once-trendy split-level, which typically
label: Paragraph

text: combined three strata within a two-story shell—
label: Paragraph

text: a basement level on a slab, containing the garage, a utility enclosure,
label: Paragraph

text: and sometimes a small “den”; then, half a level up, the living room and
label: Paragraph

text: kitchen; then, another half level up, the bedrooms and bath (usually
label: Paragraph

text: over the garage)
label: Title

text: —emerged in hilly areas where the semi-submerged garage could be dug
label: Paragraph

text: into a sloping site, and were particularly suited to the terrain of New Jersey.
label: Paragraph

text: She also points out that because the interior volumes of the split-level were
label: Paragraph

text: stacked, the “footprint” could be half as large as that needed for a single-
label: Paragraph

text: story ranch, which saved on land costs.
label: Paragraph

text: Furthermore, Lane minimizes the damage caused by racial segregation,
label: Paragraph

text: which systematically banned blacks from buying into new suburban
label: Paragraph

text: developments for two decades. She writes:
label: Paragraph

text: There was a very significant melting-pot experience in the new
label: Paragraph

text: postwar communities. Italians, Jews, Catholics, Irish, Polish, and
label: Paragraph

text: others who had been segregated in American cities and excluded from
label: Paragraph

text: earlier American suburbs now mingled freely, forming new kinds of
label: Paragraph

text: communities that they valued intensely. I think that this experience
label: Paragraph

text: may have helped Americans to become more accepting of diversity,
label: Paragraph

text: even where color lines were initially maintained. In fact, suburbs
label: Paragraph

text: became integrated more quickly than cities: by the 1970s, barriers
label: Paragraph

text: were broken down nearly everywhere.
label: Paragraph

text: However, an entire generation of African-Americans was unable to
label: Paragraph

text: participate in the grand social experiment of post-war suburbanization. As
label: Paragraph

text: James Jacobs writes in Detached America, this gross injustice was
label: Paragraph

text: committed by the federal government:
label: Title

text: The FHA did not, as is commonly held, develop racially neutral
label: Paragraph

text: policies that were then applied in a racist manner. Rather, FHA policy
label: Paragraph

text: itself was purposefully written in a way to exclude nonwhite
label: Paragraph

text: Americans, using the abstract notion of “market demands” as blanket
label: Paragraph

text: justification for discrimination in sales. A prejudiced appraisal system
label: Paragraph

text: for mortgages passed over existing houses that were believed by
label: Paragraph

text: officials to pose a risk for devaluation—those in mixed-race
label: Paragraph

text: subdivisions, for example, or properties in older urban neighborhoods
label: Paragraph

text: —which further reduced access to the financial windfall that became
label: Paragraph

text: available to white veterans and their families.
label: Paragraph

text: To be sure, many blacks did make it to suburbia, though not easily. By
label: Paragraph

text: 1960 there were an estimated 2.5 million African-Americans living in
label: Paragraph

text: suburbs; a decade later, after passage of the Fair Housing Act of 1968, that
label: Paragraph

text: number almost doubled, to 4.6 million. But Jacobs observes that blacks
label: Paragraph

text: moved into older inner-ring suburbs vacated by cynically manipulated
label: Paragraph

text: “white flight”:
label: Title

text: Such neighborhoods frequently became available for black ownership
label: Paragraph

text: through blockbusting, a process structured by the purposeful use of
label: Paragraph

text: racial anxiety and panic to undermine the residential housing market,
label: Paragraph

text: ultimately for the profit of real estate brokers. These agents convinced
label: Paragraph

text: white residents that they should sell their properties at below-market
label: Paragraph

text: values because blacks were beginning to buy in the neighborhood, and
label: Paragraph

text: their property values were bound to fall even more. Agents then turned
label: Paragraph

text: around and sold the properties to black buyers at inflated prices . . .
label: Paragraph

text: [and] departing white families often ended up in a new house on the
label: Paragraph

text: suburban periphery.
label: Paragraph

text: There were hardly any mid-twentieth-century equivalents in design
label: Paragraph

text: quality of the exemplary Greek Revival house plans that were widely
label: Paragraph

text: disseminated through carpenters’ pattern books for many decades after the
label: Paragraph

text: American Revolution—the main reason vernacular construction in this
label: Paragraph

text: country maintained such a high general standard, even in rural regions, until
label: Paragraph

text: the Civil War. Instead, the semi-modern yet quasi-traditional forms devised
label: Paragraph

text: by most 1950s and 1960s American developers were fundamentally
label: Paragraph

text: derivative and debased, no matter how evocative they may now seem of
label: Paragraph

text: their period. None of the houses documented by Lane, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: displays the nearly faultless proportional logic—especially the pleasing
label: Paragraph

text: relation of the part to the whole—that distinguished even run-of-the-mill
label: Paragraph

text: construction by itinerant early-nineteenth-century craftsmen in this country.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus the New Urbanists—revisionist planners who since the 1980s have
label: Paragraph

text: promoted American housing developments with a stronger sense of
label: Paragraph

text: community values, which they feel can be fostered by traditional design
label: Paragraph

text: elements, including front porches and sidewalks—have looked not to
label: Paragraph

text: postwar suburbia but to premodern prototypes, including pattern book
label: Paragraph

text: designs. Yet the higher density of dwellings espoused by the New Urbanists
label: Paragraph

text: is not in itself a solution, especially since few such enclaves have
label: Paragraph

text: effectively addressed the continually vexing place of the automobile in a
label: Paragraph

text: society slow to pursue more ecologically responsible transportation options.
label: Paragraph

text: Because midcentury tract houses tended to be built very close together
label: Paragraph

text: (units were usually no more than twenty-five feet apart), their side
label: Paragraph

text: elevations were often left as windowless blanks. Another accommodation to
label: Paragraph

text: privacy was the strip window, inserted high on bedroom walls to admit light
label: Paragraph

text: but prevent neighbors from looking in. This lack of direct visual connection
label: Paragraph

text: with the outdoors could recall a jail cell, and although tract houses were
label: Paragraph

text: physically proximate, they often felt emotionally isolated.
label: Paragraph

text: Another problem with postwar suburban developments was their dull
label: Paragraph

text: uniformity, determined by lot lines more than any other factor. Though
label: Paragraph

text: some builders tried to vary streetscapes by shifting and flipping similar
label: Paragraph

text: layouts this way and that, there were limits to what could be achieved in
label: Paragraph

text: such tightly packed settings. The major problem was that these designs
label: Paragraph

text: were insufficiently conceived in all three dimensions. The backs of even
label: Paragraph

text: architect-designed houses can sometimes seem like afterthoughts, but the
label: Paragraph

text: minimally detailed rear elevations of typical 1950s and 1960s American
label: Caption

text: subdivision schemes were perfunctory in the extreme, and presented a bleak
label: Paragraph

text: aspect until landscaping could soften their stark appearance, though most
label: Paragraph

text: suburban backyards typically contained an unsightly jumble of recreational
label: Paragraph

text: paraphernalia.
label: Paragraph

text: Developers focused almost solely on the street fagade to make an
label: Paragraph

text: arresting first impression on prospective buyers, a quality known in the real
label: Paragraph

text: estate trade as “curb appeal.” Thus onto the front of these generic boxes
label: Paragraph

text: they added an array of more-or-less traditional appliqués—touches of brick
label: Paragraph

text: or field-stone to give greater heft to the predominant asbestos shingles or
label: Paragraph

text: wood (and occasionally aluminum) siding; nonfunctioning window
label: Paragraph

text: shutters; wrought-iron railings and Colonial-inspired lighting fixtures; and
label: Paragraph

text: that ubiquitous symbol of the postwar suburban home, the picture window.
label: Paragraph

text: But because such flourishes were typically treated as marketing devices
label: Paragraph

text: rather than emanations of an integrated design, detailing tended to have a
label: Paragraph

text: tacked-on quality that inadvertently underscored the thin character of mass-
label: Paragraph

text: produced construction.
label: Paragraph

text: There were some notable exceptions to this lack of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: distinction, particularly on the West Coast, where the public was more
label: Paragraph

text: receptive to popularized forms of modern architecture and eagerly
label: Paragraph

text: embraced the prevailing new style—updated reinterpretations of the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional California ranch house. One of its most vigorous champions was
label: Paragraph

text: the architect/builder Cliff May (1909-1989), whose flair for self-promotion
label: Paragraph

text: —evident in such best-selling books as his Western Ranch Houses (1956)—
label: Paragraph

text: was equaled by strong design skills that have made his sprawling, light-
label: Paragraph

text: filled, well-crafted structures a byword for pleasurable, informal indoor-
label: Paragraph

text: outdoor living and desirable properties on the resale market to this day. The
label: Paragraph

text: same is true of the developer Joseph Eichler (1900-1974), whose houses
label: Paragraph

text: (mostly in the San Francisco Bay Area) were more fully informed by High
label: Paragraph

text: Modermism than May’s but now are similarly prized as among the best of
label: Paragraph

text: their kind.

text: Interesting though it is to see midcentury tract houses treated with
label: Paragraph

text: scholarly gravitas, for the most part these are not designs particularly
label: Paragraph

text: worthy of preservation or emulation. They paid little attention to
label: Paragraph

text: sustainability or energy conservation, were predicated on a restrictively
label: Paragraph

text: traditional model of family life that seems outdated if not oppressive to
label: Paragraph

text: many Americans today, and few of these structures were so solidly built
label: Paragraph

text: that they can do without substantial retrofitting as they enter their sixth or
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: architectural terms.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1940, only about 40 percent of Americans were homeowners; by 1965
label: Paragraph

text: that figure had soared to almost 63 percent. The extraordinary social
label: Paragraph

text: mobility indicated by these numbers seems all the more poignant when one
label: Paragraph

text: considers a reverse development in the United States recently. In 2007—
label: Paragraph

text: 2009, before the full impact of the Great Recession was felt, 66.4 percent of
label: Paragraph

text: housing units were owned by their occupants. By 2014 that figure had
label: Paragraph

text: dropped to 64.7 percent, the lowest since 1995.
label: Paragraph

text: Rather than glamorizing the white-bread world of Eisenhower-era
label: Paragraph

text: cookie-cutter suburbia, I prefer to think of more socially admirable efforts
label: Paragraph

text: such as Reston, Virginia, twenty miles west of Washington, D.C., which
label: Paragraph

text: was founded in 1964 by the developer Robert E. Simon. (His initials
label: Paragraph

text: formed the first three letters of this start-from-scratch community’s name.)
label: Paragraph

text: With its sensible and salable mix of housing formats, including clustered
label: Paragraph

text: town houses and high-rise condominiums, and encouragement of businesses
label: Paragraph

text: that provided jobs for its residents, Reston more closely resembled
label: Paragraph

text: European New Towns than postwar American suburbs. As Simon’s 2015
label: Paragraph

text: New York Times obituary noted:
label: Paragraph

text: He laid out a town of open spaces, homes and apartments that would
label: Paragraph

text: be affordable to almost anyone, racially integrated, economically self-
label: Paragraph

text: sustaining, pollution-free and rich in cultural and _ educational
label: Paragraph

text: opportunities.
label: Paragraph

text: That is something to be nostalgic about. You’d have to look very hard in
label: Paragraph

text: the suburbs of America today to find a single builder following his high
label: Paragraph

text: example.
label: Paragraph

text: As for the Levitt brothers, their central part in making affordable single-
label: Paragraph

text: family houses more widely available than ever before in our country’s
label: Paragraph

text: history seems attributable to a conjunction of circumstances unlikely to ever
label: Paragraph

text: occur again here, most importantly a huge demographic demand supported
label: Paragraph

text: by generous government subsidies, the very opposite of the inequality in
label: Paragraph

text: income and social advancement that has become a_ hallmark of
label: Paragraph

text: postmillennial America. Thus it was perhaps not entirely surprising when in
label: Paragraph

text: a 2017 speech at, of all things, a Boy Scout summer jamboree, President
label: Paragraph

text: Donald Trump delivered a bizarre denunciation of William Levitt, a real
label: Paragraph

text: estate developer of far greater import than either himself or his father.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Trump began by citing Levitt’s “unbelievable success,” he went
label: Paragraph

text: on to claim:
label: Title

text: In the end he failed and he failed badly. Lost all of his money. He went
label: Paragraph

text: personally bankrupt. And he was now much older. And I saw him at a
label: Paragraph

text: cocktail party. And it was very sad because the hottest people in New
label: Paragraph

text: York were at this party... .
label: Paragraph

text: And I see, sitting in the comer, was a little old man who was all by
label: Paragraph

text: himself. Nobody was talking to him. I immediately recognized that
label: Paragraph

text: that man was the once-great William Levitt of Levittown.
label: Paragraph

text: According to The New York Times, “After asking Mr. Levitt what went
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: my momentum. I lost my momentum.’” James Levitt, a son of the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: I find that Donald Trump’s use of a story regarding my dad in a
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat negative light is, at best, pure hypocrisy. Donald Trump
label: Paragraph

text: couldn’t hold a candle to my dad’s achievements. My dad worked very
label: Paragraph

text: hard to earn his money. He paid his contractors and suppliers for their
label: Paragraph

text: work and efforts. He believed in integrity as a business ethic. . . .
label: Paragraph

text: Trump may have chosen that word [momentum] to use as an
label: Paragraph

text: political and business fronts. In his comments, Trump uses the word
label: Paragraph

text: ... then acknowledges that it can be lost. Perhaps he’s telegraphing his

text: own feelings.

text: THE NEW BRUTALISTS
label: Title

text: LITERATURE THAT TAKES a wistful backward glance at the outmoded manners
label: Paragraph

text: and mores of the previous forty or fifty years—most famously Proust’s A la
label: Paragraph

text: recherche du temps perdu—has a direct parallel in architecture. Time and
label: Paragraph

text: again we have seen reawakened interest in the disdained buildings of two
label: Paragraph

text: generations earlier, a span still within living memory but not quite yet
label: Paragraph

text: history. For example, Oxford aesthetes of the 1920s (a coterie that included
label: Paragraph

text: John Betjeman, Osbert Lancaster, and Evelyn Waugh) discovered new
label: Paragraph

text: charm in ornate Victorian monuments that their parents’ contemporaries
label: Paragraph

text: dismissed as eyesores. The bizarre, proto-psychedelic fantasies of the
label: Paragraph

text: Catalan outlier Antoni Gaudi emerged from a half-century of oblivion in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1960s and enthralled an international counterculture. And the 1970s saw a
label: Paragraph

text: new vogue for the jazzy modernistic riffs of Art Deco, which four decades
label: Paragraph

text: earlier was banned from the new Museum of Modern Art by its mandarin
label: Paragraph

text: tastemakers Alfred H. Barr Jr. and Philip Johnson as populist kitsch.
label: Paragraph

text: With almost clockwork inevitability, a sudden concatenation of
label: Paragraph

text: postmillennial books indicated that the rehabilitation of yet another once-
label: Paragraph

text: reviled phase in the building art was underway. The architecture in question
label: Paragraph

text: is an industrial aesthetic that arose in postwar Britain and was dubbed New
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalism, a semi-ironic, quasi-pejorative label on the order of Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: (which implied the barbarism of the Goths) and Baroque (from the
label: Paragraph

text: Portuguese word for a misshapen pearl). The Swedish architect Hans
label: Paragraph

text: Asplund coined the term nybrutalism in 1949, and four years later its
label: Paragraph

text: English translation was used for the first time in the British journal
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Design. There the wife-and-husband architects Alison and
label: Paragraph

text: Peter Smithson wrote that an unexecuted house of theirs would have had
label: Paragraph

text: “no finishes at all internally, the building being a combination of shelter and
label: Paragraph

text: environment. Bare brick, concrete, and wood. . . . Had this been built, it
label: Paragraph

text: would have been the first exponent of the New Brutalism in England.”
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to its echoes of art brut—Jean Dubuffet’s name for outsider
label: Paragraph

text: art—New Brutalism was also an oblique riposte to New Humanism, a set of
label: Paragraph

text: beliefs inspired by Geoffrey Scott’s influential book The Architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: Humanism (1914). But Scott’s call for a return to Arts and Crafts design
label: Paragraph

text: principles in the year that the Great War broke out was scorned as escapist
label: Paragraph

text: nostalgia by many young midcentury Modernists. Among them was the
label: Paragraph

text: postwar period’s foremost British architecture critic, Reyner Banham, who
label: Paragraph

text: with his love of modern technology and scant empathy for the Arts and
label: Paragraph

text: Crafts Movement’s focus on social-reform issues belittlingly described New
label: Paragraph

text: Humanism as “brickwork, segmental arches, pitched roofs, small windows
label: Paragraph

text: (or small panes at any rate)—picturesque detailing without picturesque
label: Paragraph

text: planning. It was, in fact, the so-called ‘William Morris Revival,’ now
label: Paragraph

text: happily defunct. .. .”
label: Paragraph

text: Yet it was not a utopian nineteenth-century dreamland that Brutalism
label: Paragraph

text: countered as much as the thin, commercialized version of the International
label: Paragraph

text: Style that after World War II gained ascendance through economic
label: Paragraph

text: expediency. Brutalism’s striking departure from the steel-skeleton-and-
label: Paragraph

text: glass-skin conformity of routine, profit-oriented Modernism was defined by
label: Paragraph

text: its contrary emphasis on raw concrete (béton brut in French) in massive
label: Paragraph

text: forms of imposing scale, idiosyncratic shape, rough finish, and
label: Paragraph

text: uncompromising forcefulness, with a building’s inner workings and
label: Paragraph

text: services—structure, plumbing, electricity, heating, and ventilation—
label: Title

text: unabashedly exposed and indeed emphasized. Brutalism soon became a
label: Paragraph

text: worldwide craze, as this comparatively economical means of fabrication
label: Paragraph

text: offered a cost-effective alternative to hand-riveted metal construction and
label: Paragraph

text: allowed a broader array of sculptural effects than those obtainable with
label: Paragraph

text: rectilinear frameworks.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from Brutalism’s most influential exemplar—Le Corbusier’s Unité
label: Paragraph

text: d’Habitation in Marseilles (1947-1952), a marvel of multiunit high-rise
label: Paragraph

text: housing that attracted hordes of young architects even before it was
label: Paragraph

text: completed—other conspicuous manifestations of the style include Louis
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s Richards Medical Research Laboratories at the University of
label: Title

text: Pennsylvania in Philadelphia (1957-1960), which was inspired by the
label: Paragraph

text: distinctively slender medieval defensive towers of the Tuscan hill town of
label: Paragraph

text: San Gimignano; Marcel Breuer and Hamilton Smith’s Whitney Museum of
label: Caption

text: American Art in New York City (1963-1966), a squared-off inverted
label: Paragraph

text: ziggurat in concrete and granite complete with a nonfunctioning moat and
label: Paragraph

text: drawbridge; and Denys Lasdun’s Royal National Theatre in London (1967—
label: Caption

text: 1976), which the retrogressive Prince Charles once described as “a clever
label: Paragraph

text: way of building a nuclear power station in the middle of London without
label: Paragraph

text: anyone objecting.” And although the boldly modeled concrete architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of Japan’s postwar Metabolist group is often considered an independent
label: Paragraph

text: episode, designs such as Kenzo Tange’s Olympic Stadium in Tokyo (1961-—
label: Paragraph

text: 1964), with its swoopingly dynamic tentlike roof, can be placed under the
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalist rubric.
label: Paragraph

text: The extent to which New Brutalism took hold internationally can be
label: Paragraph

text: gathered from a geographical range that encompasses Paul Rudolph’s
label: Paragraph

text: intricately multilevel Yale Art and Architecture Building in New Haven
label: Caption

text: (1958-1963; see Illustration 11a) and the cubic heap of Moshe Safdie’s
label: Paragraph

text: Habitat 67 housing at the 1967 World’s Fair in Montreal, as well as less
label: Paragraph

text: familiar oddities like the rotund Beehive—the New Zealand Parliament’s
label: Paragraph

text: Executive Wing in Wellington (1964-1977) by Basil Spence—and Rinaldo
label: Paragraph

text: Olivieri’s La Pyramide (1968-1973), a mixed-used ziggurat in Abidjan,
label: Paragraph

text: Ivory Coast. That global diffusion is further confirmed in byways such as
label: Paragraph

text: Skopje, the Macedonian city so extensively (and firmly) rebuilt in dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: concrete forms after a devastating 1963 earthquake that some have
label: Paragraph

text: suggested that this out-of-the-way destination be promoted to architectural
label: Paragraph

text: tourists as the “Brutalist Capital of the World.”
label: Paragraph

text: However, not every big, tough-looking building, even if made of
label: Paragraph

text: concrete, is necessarily Brutalist. The new popularity of the subject has
label: Paragraph

text: prompted overeager enthusiasts to take the broadest conceivable definition
label: Paragraph

text: of the style, regardless of Banham’s dictum that “in order to be Brutalist, a
label: Paragraph

text: building has to meet three criteria, namely the clear exhibition of structure,
label: Paragraph

text: the valuation of materials ‘as found’ and memorability as image.” Banham,
label: Paragraph

text: fixated on materials and engineering, asserted that New Brutalism at last
label: Paragraph

text: fulfilled a central philosophical aim of the Modern Movement. Praising the
label: Paragraph

text: first celebrated British example of Brutalism, the Smithsons’ Hunstanton
label: Paragraph

text: Secondary Modern School in Norfolk (1950-1954), he wrote in his seminal
label: Paragraph

text: 1955 Architectural Review essay “The New Brutalism”:
label: Title

text: Whatever has been said about honest use of materials, most modern
label: Paragraph

text: buildings appear to be made of whitewash or patent glazing, even
label: Paragraph

text: when they are made of concrete or steel. Hunstanton appears to be
label: Paragraph

text: made of glass, brick, steel and concrete, and in fact is made of glass,
label: Paragraph

text: brick, steel and concrete. Water and electricity do not come out of
label: Paragraph

text: unexplained holes in the wall, but are delivered to the point of use by
label: Paragraph

text: visible pipes and manifest conduits. One can see what Hunstanton is
label: Paragraph

text: made of, and how it works, and there is not another thing to see except
label: Paragraph

text: the play of spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet this restrictive attitude about “truth to materials’—a_ principal
label: Paragraph

text: Modernist shibboleth that began among moralizing Victorian theorists and
label: Paragraph

text: has persisted ever since—was in essence little different from the judgmental
label: Paragraph

text: admonitions of Arts and Crafts adherents about the inherent soullessness of
label: Paragraph

text: the machine. Banham went on to expand his argument at book length in The
label: Paragraph

text: New Brutalism: Ethic or Aesthetic? (1966), which inexplicably has been out
label: Paragraph

text: of print for years and deserves republication as a revealing document of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural historiography by a first-rate polemicist.
label: Paragraph

text: There are several reasons for the postmillennial change in perceptions
label: Paragraph

text: about Brutalism, which remained in fashion for only about twenty years
label: Paragraph

text: during the 1960s and 1970s. As the landmarks preservation movement has
label: Paragraph

text: repeatedly demonstrated, what was once underappreciated or even despised
label: Paragraph

text: in architecture often attains new value when its existence is threatened,
label: Paragraph

text: whether one personally likes a currently démodé style or not. The most
label: Paragraph

text: immediate concern about Brutalism now is its conservation, as many of
label: Paragraph

text: these seemingly invulnerable, fortresslike edifices are beginning to fall
label: Paragraph

text: apart. Like other experimental architects of the modern age, the Brutalists
label: Paragraph

text: were more intent on getting their innovative designs built than worrying
label: Paragraph

text: about how well they would last for the ages, and their command of new
label: Paragraph

text: materials and construction techniques often lagged behind their visions. But
label: Paragraph

text: the debate over whether these purposefully unlovely creations should be
label: Paragraph

text: restored to their original state or left to decay remains largely unresolved.
label: Paragraph

text: Another major factor in the reexamination of Brutalism is the part that
label: Paragraph

text: postgraduate academicians play in methodically advancing topics that have
label: Paragraph

text: yet to be fully investigated. While there will always be doctoral
label: Paragraph

text: dissertations on unexamined facets of the great architectural masters, Ph.D.
label: Paragraph

text: advisers often guide their students toward neglected or discounted subjects,
label: Paragraph

text: with the hope that fresh analysis will yield worthwhile results. Thus we
label: Paragraph

text: have seen the scholarly literature steadily progress far into the twentieth
label: Paragraph

text: century, and it was only a matter of time until we reached Brutalism.
label: Paragraph

text: That there is a definite element of fandom in the Brutalist revival there
label: Paragraph

text: can be no doubt. In the introduction to his paean Raw Concrete: The Beauty
label: Paragraph

text: of Brutalism (2016) the British architectural historian Barnabas Calder
label: Caption

text: passionately declares his infatuation:
label: Paragraph

text: I am a lover of concrete. The great outburst of large concrete buildings
label: Paragraph

text: in the 1960s and ’70s, the style known as Brutalism, thrills me. I love
label: Paragraph

text: the unapologetic strength of these buildings, and the dazzling
label: Paragraph

text: confidence of their designers in making their substantial mark. I love
label: Paragraph

text: the optimism they seem to embody, their architecture promising
label: Paragraph

text: bullishly that new technologies can improve almost every corner of
label: Paragraph

text: human life. Most of all, I love the way the buildings look: rough, raw
label: Paragraph

text: concrete, streaked by rain and dirt, forming punchy, abstract shapes;
label: Paragraph

text: soaring cliffs of tower block or entire cities within cities.
label: Paragraph

text: But it might also be argued that this aggressively Neoprimitive ethos
label: Paragraph

text: represented an outright rejection of High Modernism’s belief in the
label: Paragraph

text: perfectibility of mankind through advanced technology, a rejection
label: Paragraph

text: expressed in intentionally crude finishes that hardly improve with age.
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalism, which reflected the bleak worldview of existentialism so
label: Paragraph

text: pervasive in the 1950s, reveled in its flagrant uncouthness and lack of
label: Paragraph

text: finesse in much the same way that the Angry Young Men of postwar British
label: Paragraph

text: literature, drama, and filmmaking flaunted their contempt for anything that
label: Paragraph

text: hinted at poshness, polish, or privilege. Where Barnabas Calder sees
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalism’s confidence and optimism, others perceive a palpable angst and
label: Paragraph

text: inward-tuming defensiveness that make many of these designs seem more
label: Paragraph

text: like penal institutions or military em-placements than housing estates, arts
label: Paragraph

text: centers, or schools sponsored by an egalitarian and beneficent welfare state.
label: Paragraph

text: In yet another familiar progression, subsequent building modes often
label: Paragraph

text: foster dissatisfactions that make earlier, diametrically different approaches
label: Paragraph

text: look appealing by comparison, which helps account for major reversals of
label: Paragraph

text: taste. The wholly uningratiating nature of Brutalism perversely appeals to
label: Paragraph

text: dystopian undercurrents in modern society, and pessimists both envious of
label: Paragraph

text: and sickened by today’s all-pervasive consumer culture might find this grim
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic better suited to the ongoing decline of the postindustrial West—
label: Paragraph

text: and especially Europe—than a prettified approach to public architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Even taking a more positive point of view, after the flimsy cartoon-
label: Paragraph

text: Classical pastiches of Postmodernism in the 1980s, the nervously
label: Paragraph

text: fragmented angularity of Deconstructivism in the 1990s, and the
label: Paragraph

text: postmillennial proliferation of computer-generated Blobitecture, the
label: Paragraph

text: undeniable material heft and protective aura of Brutalism can seem
label: Paragraph

text: reassuring to those threatened by an increasingly multivalent and menacing
label: Paragraph

text: world.
label: Paragraph

text: The most substantial study of New Brutalism since Banham’s can be
label: Paragraph

text: found in Space, Hope, and Brutalism: English Architecture, 1945-1975
label: Title

text: (2015) by the British architectural historian Elain Harwood. Although
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalism became a worldwide trend, its greatest concentration was in
label: Paragraph

text: Britain, where public building authorities gave overwhelming support to
label: Paragraph

text: this new direction. A detailed account of that remarkable architectural
label: Paragraph

text: program is given by John Grindrod in his Concretopia: A Journey Around
label: Paragraph

text: the Rebuilding of Postwar Britain (2013), which lucidly evokes the political
label: Paragraph

text: and social climate that enabled this style to flourish in a country that before
label: Paragraph

text: World War IL had not embraced Modernism—except for its industrial
label: Paragraph

text: manifestations—as fully as Germany, France, the Netherlands, the Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: Union, Czechoslovakia, and Scandinavia.
label: Paragraph

text: Like so many other aspects of twentieth-century architecture, the origins
label: Paragraph

text: of Brutalism can be traced directly back to Le Corbusier, whose
label: Paragraph

text: pronouncement that “l’architecture, c’est avec des matiéres brutes établir
label: Paragraph

text: des rapports émouvants” (architecture is the establishing of moving
label: Paragraph

text: relationships with raw materials) became the veritable gospel of the
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalists. After he and Pierre Jeanneret completed their stunning series of
label: Paragraph

text: machinelike Purist villas of the 1920s and early 1930s, the Swiss-French
label: Paragraph

text: architect became deeply disillusioned with the creative limitations of
label: Paragraph

text: rationalism and began a decisive tum toward rougher materials and
label: Paragraph

text: biomorphic forms. These were first seen in his expressive use of concrete at
label: Paragraph

text: the Pavillon Suisse student housing at the Cité Internationale Universitaire
label: Paragraph

text: in Paris (1930-1931), and then even more evidently in his Villa Le Sextant
label: Paragraph

text: (1935) in Les Mathes, France, with its rough stone rubble walls that point
label: Paragraph

text: directly to the self-consciously primitive aesthetic of Brutalism.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s long-standing fascination with vernacular culture, amply
label: Paragraph

text: displayed in his 1911 diary of travels through Southern, Central, and
label: Paragraph

text: Eastern Europe (posthumously published as Le Voyage d’Orient), was
label: Paragraph

text: further strengthened by his friendship with Fernand Léger, who likewise
label: Paragraph

text: idealized folk traditions and sought a similar vitality in his own art as he,
label: Paragraph

text: too, moved away from an earlier technological aesthetic and toward a
label: Paragraph

text: vigorous, less refined late style. Although Le Corbusier’s theories had a
label: Paragraph

text: profound influence on the thinking of several generations of British
label: Paragraph

text: architects, their built works seldom rose to the master’s level, unlike their
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary counterparts in South America, especially the Brazilians
label: Paragraph

text: Ltcio Costa, Oscar Niemeyer, and Lina Bo Bardi, who used raw concrete
label: Paragraph

text: with a joyous bravado and sensual abandon rarely seen in British Brutalism.
label: Paragraph

text: At times, Brutalism could bring out the best in lesser architects whose
label: Paragraph

text: work before and after that phase does not seem as interesting, perhaps most
label: Paragraph

text: notably I. M. Pei. His firm’s early jobs for the real estate developer William
label: Paragraph

text: Zeckendorf Sr. were rather dull sub-Miesian efforts, while his late-career
label: Paragraph

text: dependence on cautiously segmented and genteely manipulated geometries
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited considerable technical suavity but little conceptual inventiveness.
label: Paragraph

text: However, during the 1960s the Pei office produced three of his strongest
label: Paragraph

text: designs, all in a Brutalist mode: the multitowered National Center for
label: Paragraph

text: Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colorado (1961-1967), which owes a
label: Paragraph

text: clear debt to Kahn’s highly publicized Richards labs; the monolithic
label: Paragraph

text: Everson Museum of Art in Syracuse, New York (1965-1968), influenced
label: Paragraph

text: by then-prevalent trends in American Minimalist sculpture; and the
label: Paragraph

text: shadowbox-like Sculpture Wing of the Des Moines Art Center in Iowa
label: Caption

text: (1966-1968), late-Corbusian in its heavily outlined and deeply recessed
label: Paragraph

text: framing. With this trio of relatively small but monumentally scaled
label: Paragraph

text: structures, Pei achieved a rare and surprising balance between powerful
label: Paragraph

text: expression and humane feeling largely unseen elsewhere in his extensive
label: Paragraph

text: oeuvre.
label: Paragraph

text: Contrary to the grungy, pockmarked, damp-stained concrete surfaces
label: Paragraph

text: typical of most Brutalist buildings, the exteriors of these three Pei structures
label: Paragraph

text: are all smoothly rendered, the difference owing to the careful craftsmanship
label: Paragraph

text: of wooden casting molds much more finely finished than usual and often
label: Paragraph

text: approaching the quality of furniture. Furthermore, the concrete for the
label: Paragraph

text: Boulder laboratory was mixed with finely ground local red sandstone to
label: Paragraph

text: harmonize with the surrounding mountainous terrain, whereas that for the
label: Paragraph

text: Syracuse gallery was similarly augmented with particles of the region’s
label: Paragraph

text: native gray granite. This exacting construction would remain a hallmark of
label: Paragraph

text: the Pei office and is epitomized by its Grand Louvre expansion of 1983—
label: Paragraph

text: 1993 in Paris, where the perfectionist concrete is indistinguishable from
label: Paragraph

text: tightly grained limestone. Such grace notes strengthen compositional clarity
label: Paragraph

text: without seeming overly precious, not unlike the work of Tadao Ando,
label: Paragraph

text: today’s foremost adept of elegant concrete construction, who is often,
label: Paragraph

text: though incorrectly, regarded as a neo-Brutalist.
label: Paragraph

text: The reasons why particular building styles are so prevalent in certain
label: Paragraph

text: cities—such as Byzantine in Ravenna, Gothic in Bruges, or Modernisme
label: Paragraph

text: (the Catalan variant of Art Nouveau) in Barcelona—are always rooted in
label: Paragraph

text: economics and politics. When stability and prosperity attract growing
label: Paragraph

text: populations and necessitate much new construction within short periods,
label: Paragraph

text: uncommon architectural coherence emerges. In post-World War II
label: Paragraph

text: America, the dynamic was rather the opposite, as rapid suburbanization
label: Paragraph

text: pushed several big cities, financially hard hit since the Great Depression,
label: Paragraph

text: further into decline. To stem the erosion of their tax base, municipalities
label: Paragraph

text: such as Philadelphia, St. Louis, and Boston embarked on comprehensive
label: Paragraph

text: plans to transform their run-down central districts.
label: Paragraph

text: The new Boston initiative of the 1960s—led by John F. Collins, the city’s
label: Paragraph

text: mayor for most of that decade, and implemented by Edward J. Logue,
label: Paragraph

text: prime mover of the Boston Redevelopment Authority—coincided with the
label: Paragraph

text: apogee of Brutalism and explains why that city became this country’s
label: Paragraph

text: foremost repository of this short-lived style. The roster of designers enlisted
label: Paragraph

text: to recast the creaking Hub of the Universe as an up-to-date metropolis
label: Paragraph

text: included several of the biggest names in twentieth-century architecture: Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier, Walter Gropius (then chief partner in the Cambridge,
label: Paragraph

text: Massachusetts, firm the Architects Collaborative), Josep Lluis Sert, Breuer,
label: Caption

text: Pei, and Rudolph. By and large, though, the results were less than
label: Paragraph

text: wonderful. The nexus of this undertaking was Government Center, a fifty-
label: Paragraph

text: six-acre site just to the west of the Colonial-era Faneuil Hall and the
label: Paragraph

text: nineteenth-century Quincy Market. This tripartite modern forum comprised
label: Paragraph

text: the John F. Kennedy Federal Building by the Architects Collaborative
label: Caption

text: (1961-1966); Boston City Hall by Kallmann, McKinnell & Knowles
label: Caption

text: (1962-1969); and the concrete superblock of Rudolph’s Government
label: Paragraph

text: Service Center (1962-1971).
label: Paragraph

text: The semi-enclosed street-level spaces beneath Rudolph’s ponderous and
label: Paragraph

text: overbearing ensemble—its public concourse recalls Piranesi’s imaginary
label: Paragraph

text: prisons without his sense of fantasy—provide an object lesson in how
label: Paragraph

text: seemingly infinite volumes can nonetheless feel alarmingly claustrophobic.
label: Paragraph

text: As much as a new generation of Rudolph zealots may hope for a wider
label: Paragraph

text: reappreciation of his designs, his posthumous upgrading seems unlikely to
label: Paragraph

text: be helped by the Government Service Center’s depressing hulk, with its
label: Paragraph

text: jumbled undercarriage of sequoia-like columns, bulging balconies, and
label: Paragraph

text: undulating stairways, all rendered in vertically corrugated textures of the
label: Paragraph

text: bush-hammered concrete that became his trademark. (The center’s
label: Paragraph

text: proposed twenty-three-story office tower and a series of surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: terraces were never executed because of funding cutbacks as the Great
label: Paragraph

text: Society gave way to the Vietnam War.)
label: Paragraph

text: The high-rise Kennedy Federal Building was a wan performance by the
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius firm, which had just inflicted the dreadful Pan Am Building (1960—
label: Paragraph

text: 1963) on New York City. None of the new Boston projects won as much
label: Paragraph

text: critical praise as Boston City Hall, which was widely hailed upon its
label: Paragraph

text: completion as the finest American public building of the postwar period.
label: Paragraph

text: But this top-heavy citadel, on the former site of the raffish Scollay Square
label: Paragraph

text: nightlife quarter, came to be seen by the public as forbidding and indeed
label: Paragraph

text: hostile, and there have been repeated calls for its demolition and
label: Paragraph

text: replacement with a more welcoming and transparent symbol of civic
label: Paragraph

text: engagement.
label: Paragraph

text: The best of the new Boston designs was a little gem commissioned by a
label: Paragraph

text: private institution: Le Corbusier’s Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts on
label: Title

text: the Harvard campus in Cambridge (1958-1963). One of only two works he
label: Paragraph

text: executed in the Western Hemisphere (the other was a house in postwar
label: Paragraph

text: Argentina), the Carpenter Center shows just how rich and attractive the
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalist vocabulary could be in the right hands. This five-story structure,
label: Paragraph

text: squeezed into a narrow site, juxtaposes grid-like masses (which contain art
label: Paragraph

text: studios) against sinuous ondulatures (walkways that slice through the
label: Paragraph

text: exterior) and a dramatically cranked ramp that rises from the sidewalk to
label: Paragraph

text: the entrance on the building’s second level. Both in its piquant ground plan
label: Paragraph

text: and in its lively elevations, this marvelously collaged composition’s play of
label: Paragraph

text: linear and curving elements brings to mind Picasso’s guitar sculptures of
label: Paragraph

text: 1912-1914, while the brisk marche Le Corbusier leads through these
label: Paragraph

text: powerful concrete volumes is akin to the kinetic internal circulation patterns
label: Paragraph

text: of Alvar Aalto, unsurpassed in his intuitive understanding of how to convey
label: Paragraph

text: delight by movement through space.
label: Paragraph

text: The postmillennial comeback of Brutalism is not surprising, given a
label: Paragraph

text: worldwide vogue for strenuously exhibitionistic architecture enabled by
label: Paragraph

text: computer design, which has resulted in grotesque behemoths far stranger
label: Paragraph

text: than anything achievable through the relatively low-tech means of concrete
label: Paragraph

text: construction. Some older observers will see this fascination with
label: Paragraph

text: grandiosity and ugliness as the return of the repressed, a reminder of why
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalism fell into disfavor and disrepute in the first place. This was never a
label: Paragraph

text: style that attempted to convey warmth, comfort, intimacy, or other qualities
label: Paragraph

text: we tend to associate with an enjoyable way of life, and thus it never won
label: Paragraph

text: much love except from architectural specialists. Brutalism posited an
label: Paragraph

text: unsentimental, not to say harsh, view of the modern world, and however
label: Paragraph

text: heroic its unflinching embodiment of hard realities may have been, most
label: Paragraph

text: people do not enjoy a daily diet of architectural anxiety and alienation,
label: Paragraph

text: especially in northern climates under cloudy skies.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the first signs of rejection came in J. G. Ballard’s dystopian novel
label: Paragraph

text: High-Rise (1975), which is set in a thinly fictionalized version of Emé
label: Paragraph

text: Goldfinger’s Trellick Tower of 1968-1972, in London’s North Kensington
label: Caption

text: (not far from an earlier Brutalist residential high-rise, Clifford Wearden and
label: Paragraph

text: Associates’ twenty-four-story Grenfell Tower of 1967, which caught fire in
label: Paragraph

text: 2017, resulting in the death of seventy-one residents). Goldfinger’s thirty-
label: Paragraph

text: one-story concrete-framed apartment block, commissioned by the Greater
label: Caption

text: London Council, was based on Le Corbusier’s original Unité in Marseilles,
label: Paragraph

text: although Goldfinger’s scheme is nearly twice as high as its prototype (see
label: Paragraph

text: Illustration 9a). Trellick Tower was well received by its first inhabitants, but
label: Paragraph

text: as was also true of contemporaneous public housing projects in the United
label: Paragraph

text: States—especially Minoru Yamasaki’s unfairly demonized Pruitt-Igoe
label: Paragraph

text: housing of 1950-1955 in St. Louis—it quickly descended into crime and
label: Paragraph

text: squalor as funds for its upkeep and security were slashed.
label: Paragraph

text: Neoconservative critics blamed the newfangled architecture rather than
label: Paragraph

text: larger forces of discriminatory economics, but as sociological studies have
label: Paragraph

text: since proven, the claim that tall residential complexes breed social malaise
label: Paragraph

text: is groundless. After Trellick Tower was privatized in the 1980s, when
label: Paragraph

text: Margaret Thatcher took the British government out of the public housing
label: Title

text: business, the building’s owner-residents increased protection from intruders
label: Paragraph

text: and paid for long-delayed repairs; it is now a highly desirable property
label: Paragraph

text: rightly appreciated for its design quality. Ironically enough, it stands as
label: Paragraph

text: Thatcher’s unwitting contribution to preserving the built legacy of the
label: Paragraph

text: munificent welfare state she worked so hard to destroy through her own
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive brand of brutalism. And its near contemporary, Grenfell Tower,
label: Paragraph

text: will long remain a symbol of what can happen when government abdicates
label: Paragraph

text: its regulatory—and moral—responsibilities in the realm of public welfare,
label: Paragraph

text: whichever political party is involved.
