text: LOUIS KAHN
label: Title

text: HOW ODD THAT the towering genius of architecture during the third quarter of
label: Paragraph

text: the twentieth century—when his most conventionally successful colleagues
label: Paragraph

text: prized innovation over tradition, analysis over intuition, and logic over
label: Paragraph

text: emotion—was a mystically inclined savant who sought to reconnect his
label: Paragraph

text: medium with its spiritual roots. Indeed, he ran wholly counter to prevailing
label: Paragraph

text: images of the modern architect. Rather than casting himself as a
label: Paragraph

text: technocratic superman along the lines of the young Le Corbusier or a
label: Paragraph

text: conduit between man and nature like the twinkling Frank Lloyd Wright, he
label: Paragraph

text: made his name with an architectural gran rifiuto, rejecting the commercial
label: Paragraph

text: blandishments of an increasingly corporate culture in favor of a quixotic
label: Paragraph

text: quest to recapture the archaic power of shelter at its most elemental.
label: Paragraph

text: This charismatic anachronism was Louis Kahn, who by the time he died
label: Paragraph

text: in 1974 at the age of seventy-three was widely and correctly considered
label: Paragraph

text: America’s foremost master builder, even though his mature career spanned
label: Paragraph

text: little more than two decades and he executed only about a dozen important
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. Posthumous revelations of Kahn’s messy personal history have
label: Paragraph

text: threatened to overshadow his immense professional accomplishments, yet
label: Paragraph

text: his aura has grown steadily, not just for what he achieved but also because
label: Paragraph

text: of what has taken place in the built environment since his death. After he
label: Paragraph

text: almost single-handedly restored architecture’s age-old status as an art form,
label: Paragraph

text: his legacy was quickly squandered by younger coprofessionals. From the
label: Paragraph

text: mid-1970s onward they have careened from one extreme, short-lived
label: Paragraph

text: stylistic fad to the next—Postmodernism, Deconstructivism, Blobitecture—
label: Paragraph

text: and lost sight of the profound values Kahn wanted to convey: timelessness,
label: Paragraph

text: solidity, nobility, and repose.
label: Paragraph

text: Although a great number of books on Kahn’s architecture were published
label: Paragraph

text: in the years immediately following his death, it took more than three
label: Paragraph

text: decades for a full-length biography to appear—Carter Wiseman’s Louis I.
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn: Beyond Time and Style: A Life in Architecture (2007). Another
label: Paragraph

text: decade would pass until a far more intimate account of his personal and
label: Paragraph

text: professional activities was presented by Wendy Lesser in You Say to Brick:
label: Paragraph

text: The Life of Louis Kahn (2017). Whereas Wiseman examines eight of the
label: Paragraph

text: architect’s principal buildings in depth, Lesser focuses on five of the same
label: Paragraph

text: works, what might be termed the Kahn Quintet: his Salk Institute for
label: Paragraph

text: Biological Studies of 1959-1965 in La Jolla, California; the Kimbell Art
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of 1966-1972 in Fort Worth, Texas; the Phillips Exeter Academy
label: Caption

text: Library of 1965-1971 in Exeter, New Hampshire; the Indian Institute of
label: Caption

text: Management of 1962-1974 in Ahmedabad, India; and the Sher-e-Bangla
label: Paragraph

text: Nagar, or National Assembly Building, of 1962-1983 in Dhaka,
label: Caption

text: Bangladesh (see front endpapers).
label: Paragraph

text: Each of those designs is a masterpiece, but all are also in some ways
label: Paragraph

text: imperfect, even the universally beloved Kimbell, with its mastery of the use
label: Paragraph

text: of light to show works of art against stone walls. Its big failure is the
label: Paragraph

text: parking lot that fronts the main entrance and brings to mind a suburban strip
label: Paragraph

text: mall, even though Kahn intended visitors to enter via the recessed courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: on the opposite side of the building, beautifully landscaped by Harriet
label: Caption

text: Pattison. Happily, what by default became the Kimbell’s rear fagade was
label: Paragraph

text: given new life after the opening of the freestanding Renzo Piano Pavilion of
label: Paragraph

text: 2008-2013 directly across from it.
label: Paragraph

text: Problems with some of Kahn’s other buildings have been more
label: Paragraph

text: numerous. The crushing monumentality he sometimes imposed on
label: Paragraph

text: functions more suited to intimacy is epitomized by the cubic Central Hall of
label: Paragraph

text: the Exeter library, which is dominated on each of its four sides by circular
label: Paragraph

text: concrete-framed openings thirty feet in diameter (see [llustration 10b).
label: Caption

text: Exonians call the nearby dining hall, also designed by Kahn, “the
label: Paragraph

text: crematorium” because of the four tall, ominous chimneys that loom over
label: Paragraph

text: the single-story structure. Yet that nickname could also apply to the
label: Paragraph

text: yawning round maws of the library atrium. No amount of nitpicking,
label: Paragraph

text: however, can diminish his overall contribution, which was nothing less than
label: Paragraph

text: a complete realignment of architecture’s deepest priorities.
label: Paragraph

text: That would not seem to be the expected agenda of an architect who (apart
label: Paragraph

text: from his fine government-sponsored housing projects in southeastern
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania with Oscar Stonorov during the 1930s and 1940s) didn’t
label: Paragraph

text: identify strongly with reformist social causes later on, even when they
label: Paragraph

text: became an urgent matter for many of his colleagues amid the upheavals of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1960s. However, once Kahn began to attain critical prominence, he
label: Paragraph

text: stuck to his determination to work solely for high-minded clients. Beyond
label: Paragraph

text: the patrons of the Kahn Quintet these included universities (Bryn Mawr
label: Paragraph

text: College, where he built his Erdman Hall Dormitories of 1960-1965);
label: Paragraph

text: museums (the Yale University Art Gallery of 1951-1953 and the Yale
label: Title

text: Center for British Art of 1966-1977); scientific institutions (the Richards
label: Paragraph

text: Medical Research Laboratories of 1957-1960 at the University of
label: Title

text: Pennsylvania); and religious groups (the First Unitarian Church and School
label: Paragraph

text: of 1959-1969 in Rochester, New York, and Temple Beth-El Synagogue of
label: Paragraph

text: 1966-1972 in Chappaqua, New York). How often does any architect get so
label: Paragraph

text: many prestigious opportunities, and, even more rarely, respond to them with
label: Paragraph

text: the high sense of purpose Kahn commanded?
label: Paragraph

text: His mature designs share a remarkable formal consistency, but without
label: Paragraph

text: the formulaic repetitiveness one sees, for example, in late-career Ludwig
label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe. After much trial and error, Kahn at last learned how to
label: Paragraph

text: make the grand gesture with simplicity and power. He drew on the gutsy
label: Paragraph

text: ethos of the Greco-Roman tradition with volumetric heft but no hint of
label: Paragraph

text: slavish imitation. His urge to create contemporary architecture that would
label: Paragraph

text: endure through the ages was clearly announced in his essay
label: Paragraph

text: “Monumentality” (1944), which began with the assertion: “Monumentality
label: Paragraph

text: in architecture may be defined as a quality, a spiritual quality inherent in a
label: Paragraph

text: structure which conveys the feeling of its eternity, that it cannot be added to
label: Paragraph

text: or changed.” Kahn’s design philosophy was based on a Platonic notion
label: Paragraph

text: similar to Michelangelo’s conviction that all forms are embedded within
label: Paragraph

text: materials and merely await the artist’s touch to be freed. The sculptor
label: Paragraph

text: believed that he needed only to chip away any parts of a marble block that
label: Paragraph

text: were not the David or the Pietd in order to discover those works within. In
label: Paragraph

text: tum, Kahn pared down his schemes to their most irreducible essentials—
label: Paragraph

text: monumental mass, pure geometry, numinous natural light—and jettisoned
label: Paragraph

text: the extraneous trimmings of Classicism without any loss of intensity.
label: Paragraph

text: Through his training at Penn under the French-born Beaux Arts—trained
label: Paragraph

text: architect Paul Philippe Cret, Kahn learned all the compositional elements of
label: Paragraph

text: the Classical vocabulary, which are evident in the grand, colonnaded,
label: Paragraph

text: temporary buildings he worked on during his first big job as principal
label: Paragraph

text: draftsman for the Sesqui-Centennial International Exposition of 1926 in
label: Caption

text: Philadelphia, for which Cret was the master planner. Cret’s particular
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on Beaux Arts principles such as bilateral symmetry and the
label: Paragraph

text: marche (the central processional route through a building) recurred with
label: Paragraph

text: particular force in Kahn’s late work. These are most evident at the Salk
label: Paragraph

text: Institute, with its mirror-image, serrated concrete wings flanking a central
label: Paragraph

text: plaza that sweeps toward the Pacific (see Illustration 10a), and at the
label: Paragraph

text: National Assembly Building in Dhaka, with its pairs of gigantic cubes and
label: Paragraph

text: cylinders perforated with colossal circular or triangular openings, all ringed
label: Caption

text: around a central rotunda.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet Kahn avoided what the architectural historian Sigfried Giedion
label: Paragraph

text: criticized as the besetting sin of American Beaux Arts design: “Simply and
label: Paragraph

text: mechanically transferring emotional luxury-forms from earlier periods to
label: Paragraph

text: our own.” However heavily the past weighed on Kahn’s thinking, he was no
label: Paragraph

text: historical revivalist, and his abstraction and transposition of ancient forms
label: Paragraph

text: to modern circumstances was on a par with that of such earlier giants as
label: Paragraph

text: John Soane and Edwin Lutyens, though he went much further than either in
label: Paragraph

text: dispensing with applied ornament. Less apparent was his enormous debt to
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier, especially the Swiss-French master’s consecration of concrete
label: Paragraph

text: as worthy of high-style architecture and mysterious modulation of light,
label: Paragraph

text: above all in the Ronchamp chapel, which he revered. Kahn was early to
label: Paragraph

text: identify Ronchamp as a hugely significant work, even while some of his
label: Paragraph

text: coprofessionals did not initially know what to make of this strange
label: Paragraph

text: biomorphic departure from its designer’s earlier machine aesthetic.
label: Paragraph

text: When he was about to begin construction on the Salk Institute, his first
label: Paragraph

text: major project in concrete, Kahn asked a new employee in his office, Fred
label: Paragraph

text: Langford, how much he knew about that material. When the young man
label: Paragraph

text: admitted, “Nothing,” his boss replied, “That makes two of us,” whereupon
label: Paragraph

text: Langford embarked on a crash course of self-education on the subject. With
label: Paragraph

text: amazing alacrity he mastered the fine points of a craft that until then had
label: Paragraph

text: not been executed at a very high level in the United States, and thereby
label: Paragraph

text: became one of the master’s most crucial technical collaborators.
label: Paragraph

text: The infelicitous title of Lesser’s biography refers to a typically gnomic
label: Paragraph

text: Kahnism about the inherent nature of materials: “You say to brick, ‘What
label: Paragraph

text: do you want brick?’ Brick says to you, ‘I like an arch.’” This imaginary
label: Paragraph

text: dialogue highlights Kahn’s surprisingly old-fashioned attitude toward
label: Paragraph

text: materials and their supposed imperatives—a utilitarian notion so at odds
label: Paragraph

text: with his insistent spirituality—derived from nineteenth-century British
label: Paragraph

text: sources, primarily John Ruskin. He indirectly absorbed Ruskin’s ideas from
label: Paragraph

text: an art teacher at Philadelphia’s excellent Central High School, a trained
label: Paragraph

text: architect who inspired the boy to pursue his future profession. As Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: recalled this adolescent revelation, “Architecture combined my love and
label: Paragraph

text: desire for artistic creation, painting, and being able to express and stand
label: Paragraph

text: out,” a neat summation of both his soaring artistic aspirations and
label: Paragraph

text: irrepressible egotism.
label: Paragraph

text: That latter quality was perversely reflected in his lifelong attitude toward
label: Paragraph

text: money. Although Kahn is always portrayed as a hopelessly inept
label: Paragraph

text: businessman, his disdain for filthy lucre was purposeful, and he remained
label: Paragraph

text: openly contemptuous of financial go-getters. As he told his longtime
label: Paragraph

text: engineer, August Komendant, who devised ingenious structural solutions
label: Paragraph

text: that were beyond Kahn’s ken, including the famous vaulted skylight
label: Paragraph

text: ceilings at the Kimbell:
label: Caption

text: If you are in the profession of architecture, it is likely that you are not
label: Paragraph

text: an architect. If you are an architect without thinking of the profession,
label: Paragraph

text: you might be one. The profession kills your incentive. . . .
label: Paragraph

text: You get yourself a good business character, you can really play golf
label: Paragraph

text: all day and your buildings will be built anyway. But what the devil is
label: Paragraph

text: that?
label: Paragraph

text: From the outset, Kahn was wary of accepting work that he feared would
label: Paragraph

text: cheapen his image as a great artist-architect. He boasted that “I have refused
label: Paragraph

text: thousands of dollars that were tainted,” and he died nearly half a million
label: Paragraph

text: dollars in debt. Two years after his death, the state of Pennsylvania rescued
label: Paragraph

text: his wife, Esther Israeli Kahn, from penury by buying his papers for
label: Paragraph

text: $450,000. (They are on deposit at Penn.) The architect depended on her
label: Paragraph

text: income as a medical researcher during most of their forty-three-year
label: Paragraph

text: marriage, and averred that his undying gratitude prevented him from
label: Paragraph

text: leaving her for either of the younger women he impregnated. He gave little
label: Paragraph

text: more than token amounts toward the upkeep of those satellite families, and
label: Paragraph

text: his widow angrily (if understandably) rejected pleas that she help out his
label: Paragraph

text: illegitimate children. “They’re bastards,” she declared. “They’re not entitled
label: Paragraph

text: to anything of Lou’s.”
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1940s and 1950s he took teaching positions at Yale, MIT, and
label: Paragraph

text: Princeton (to which he commuted while maintaining his architectural
label: Paragraph

text: practice in Philadelphia), and then ultimately at Penn, for the same reason
label: Paragraph

text: most other avant-garde architects do: to guarantee a steady income until
label: Paragraph

text: client fees were able to cover the costs of running an office. A large part of
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s legend rests on his fame as a pedagogue, and even though his
label: Paragraph

text: parallel teaching career was driven by financial necessity, he became
label: Paragraph

text: renowned for his ability to inspire students with a more elevated vision of
label: Paragraph

text: professional practice than the technically advanced but psychically stunted
label: Paragraph

text: approach characteristic of postwar American architectural education.
label: Paragraph

text: Although there are several published collections of the architect’s
label: Paragraph

text: lectures, Kahn at Penn: Transformative Teacher of Architecture (2015)
label: Caption

text: provided the first in-depth account of his activities as an educator. Its
label: Paragraph

text: author, James Williamson, was among the students from forty-three
label: Paragraph

text: countries who received degrees in the architect’s fabled master classes at
label: Paragraph

text: Penn between 1956 to 1974, testimony to Kahn’s global pull during his
label: Paragraph

text: final decades. That there were only sixteen women—including Denise Scott
label: Paragraph

text: Brown—among the course’s 427 graduates is an index of the gender
label: Paragraph

text: disparity that still persisted in architecture schools. (In recent years, upward
label: Paragraph

text: of 40 percent of architecture graduates have been women.) Many of Kahn’s
label: Paragraph

text: master class students reckoned the course to have been among the most
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinary experiences in their lives, but several of them harbored
label: Paragraph

text: reservations. As Williamson writes:
label: Paragraph

text: He seemed to discourage personal relationships with his students, and
label: Paragraph

text: my main impression of his personality was its combination of strength
label: Paragraph

text: and remoteness. Although he was usually kind enough, I recall few
label: Paragraph

text: overt expressions of concern for his students. Kahn’s idealism,
label: Paragraph

text: although inspiring, often seemed unrealistic, and in my later
label: Paragraph

text: professional practice I have continued to struggle to reconcile his lofty
label: Paragraph

text: ideals with the realities of the marketplace.
label: Paragraph

text: Another master class student, John Tyler Sidener Jr, known to the
label: Paragraph

text: professor as “you from California,” felt excluded by the studio’s abstruse
label: Paragraph

text: discourse and worshipful atmosphere:
label: Title

text: [Kahn] talked about the house as a sanctuary, a chapel, with a central
label: Paragraph

text: space ringed with columns like a small Pantheon. I wasn’t ready for
label: Paragraph

text: that. I’d spent too long on publicly funded school buildings, low-cost
label: Paragraph

text: housing, and other straight-forward projects. More difficult was this
label: Paragraph

text: abstract conversation; the hard-core students seemed like they were
label: Paragraph

text: clustered around a guru under a banyan tree, with conversations only
label: Paragraph

text: among Kahn... and a few chosen students.
label: Paragraph

text: But as others discerned, the most valuable lesson to be learned there was
label: Paragraph

text: less direct. John Raymond Griffin understood that Kahn’s intention was to
label: Paragraph

text: make his students
label: Title

text: critically examine our underlying thoughts about design . . . to begin
label: Paragraph

text: developing our own individual approaches—and not so much just
label: Paragraph

text: about architectural design—but also about the larger humanistic
label: Paragraph

text: principles and purposes which design could or should seek to reveal.
label: Paragraph

text: As the historical record amply indicates, Kahn was wildly conflicted
label: Paragraph

text: within himself: intellectually ambitious yet insufficiently educated save in
label: Paragraph

text: his specialty; seemingly warm and generous but often aloof and
label: Paragraph

text: monstrously selfish; endlessly loquacious yet maddeningly obscurantist; at
label: Paragraph

text: once a wise man and a spoiled child. Although an avid world traveler, he
label: Paragraph

text: never learned to drive a car. A keyboard virtuoso who helped pay for his
label: Paragraph

text: education with jobs as a movie-house organist, he could not read musical
label: Paragraph

text: notation. Physically he presented a similar bundle of contradictions. Though
label: Paragraph

text: he was short, often rumpled, and facially disfigured, with a high-pitched
label: Paragraph

text: voice and glasses so thick that he mockingly called himself Mr. Magoo after
label: Paragraph

text: the purblind cartoon character, he was catnip to the ladies. Kahn’s numerous
label: Paragraph

text: erotic intrigues confirm Henry Kissinger’s oft-quoted observation that
label: Paragraph

text: power is the ultimate aphrodisiac (though here it was a matter of cultural
label: Paragraph

text: cachet rather than political clout).
label: Paragraph

text: The deficiencies of Kahn’s appearance notwithstanding, many women
label: Paragraph

text: found him irresistibly attractive, including his longtime collaborator and
label: Paragraph

text: lover, Anne Griswold Tyng. Nearly twenty years his junior, she recalled
label: Paragraph

text: how “on swelteringly hot summer weekend charettes when Lou
label: Title

text: occasionally worked shirtless, it was hard not to notice how unusually
label: Paragraph

text: broad his lightly freckled shoulders were in proportion to his slim hips.”

text: strength, a printless, cat-like walk, glistening Tartar’s eyes—only
label: Paragraph

text: Scully here alludes to the accident that left the future architect with
label: Paragraph

text: horrific scars on his face and hands. In his native Estonia, the three-year-old
label: Paragraph

text: Leiser-Itze Schmulowsky (as Kahn was known until he arrived in
label: Paragraph

text: Philadelphia in 1906) was so mesmerized by the hypnotic glow of lighted
label: Paragraph

text: coals that he tried to gather them up and suffered burns so severe that they
label: Paragraph

text: nearly killed him. Though it might be facile to interpret Kahn’s strenuous
label: Paragraph

text: womanizing as overcompensation for his irrevocably damaged
label: Paragraph

text: countenance, many people seemed not to notice it at all, such was the
label: Paragraph

text: distracting force of his magnetic personality.
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn was unusually promiscuous by the standards of his time and place,
label: Paragraph

text: fathering three children by three women. The long-concealed chaos of his
label: Paragraph

text: private life was first revealed in 1997 with the publication of Louis Kahn to
label: Paragraph

text: Anne Tyng: The Rome Letters, 1953-1954, edited by their recipient. Tyng, a
label: Caption

text: glacially beautiful blond WASP who had been one of the first female
label: Paragraph

text: graduates at Harvard’s architecture school, was the golden shiksa goddess
label: Paragraph

text: of a Jewish architect’s dreams. When she became pregnant by Kahn and
label: Paragraph

text: decided to keep their child, she went to Italy, where her older brother lived,
label: Paragraph

text: which allowed her to give birth to Alexandra Tyng (who became a realist
label: Paragraph

text: painter and the spitting image of her father) far from the prying eyes of
label: Paragraph

text: proper Philadelphians.
label: Paragraph

text: Lesser identified yet another Kahn mistress previously un-mentioned in
label: Paragraph

text: the literature. Marie Kuo was a Chinese-born architect who worked in
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s firm and began a sexual relationship with him while Tyng was away
label: Paragraph

text: in Italy. By the end of the 1950s he was involved in overlapping affairs with
label: Paragraph

text: Kuo, Tyng, and Harriet Pattison, his landscape architect. In a scene worthy
label: Paragraph

text: of Les Liaisons dangereuses, Lesser tells how Tyng overheard an office
label: Paragraph

text: telephone call in which Kuo assured her mother that she was using birth
label: Paragraph

text: control and didn’t need to worry about an unwanted pregnancy. (Kahn, we
label: Paragraph

text: learn, would not use condoms, and didn’t like his women to take
label: Paragraph

text: precautions, either.) Although Kuo spoke Mandarin for privacy, she did not
label: Paragraph

text: realize that Tyng, who was born to Episcopal missionaries in China and
label: Paragraph

text: raised there, understood her every word.
label: Paragraph

text: The architect hardly limited himself to three mistresses, however. One
label: Paragraph

text: colleague recalled how at parties Kahn “would glom onto some younger
label: Paragraph

text: woman or other and just press them to the wall—very attractive women,
label: Paragraph

text: too. And some of them fell for it,” though this would be considered sexual
label: Paragraph

text: harassment or even assault today. Lesser also disclosed Esther Kahn’s long-
label: Paragraph

text: running affair with an acquaintance of her husband’s, an unnamed married
label: Paragraph

text: research scientist who taught at Penn and was blond and Gentile like Tyng.
label: Paragraph

text: According to the Kahns’ daughter, Sue Ann, the architect was “so
label: Paragraph

text: engrossed in his own world that he probably never even thought about it.”
label: Paragraph

text: But nothing exposed Kahn’s unorthodox family relations more than
label: Paragraph

text: Nathaniel Kahn’s documentary My Architect: A Son’s Journey (2003),
label: Paragraph

text: which was nominated for an Academy Award and became a sleeper box-
label: Paragraph

text: office hit. In it the director—whose mother is Pattison—joins his two older
label: Paragraph

text: half sisters (Sue Ann is his senior by twenty-two years, Alexandra by eight)
label: Paragraph

text: in a touching demonstration of how loving families can be forged under the
label: Paragraph

text: unlikeliest of circumstances. Alas, what they appeared to have most in
label: Paragraph

text: common was seeking the attention of an affectionate but ruthlessly self-
label: Paragraph

text: absorbed father who put his work before everything else. Whatever spiritual
label: Paragraph

text: transcendence Louis Kahn found in his architecture, much emotional
label: Paragraph

text: wreckage followed in the heedless egotist’s wake.
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas Wiseman’s biography follows a standard cradle-to-grave
label: Paragraph

text: chronology, Lesser inverts the narrative and begins with Kahn’s death, a
label: Paragraph

text: device often used when a demise is particularly unusual, dramatic, or
label: Paragraph

text: notorious. Her impressive research skills are on full display as she gives the
label: Paragraph

text: most complete account yet of the architect’s end in a men’s room at
label: Caption

text: Manhattan’s Pennsylvania Station on St. Patrick’s Day in 1974, after which
label: Paragraph

text: a perfect storm of procedural foul-ups resulted in his distraught families not
label: Paragraph

text: being notified until two days later. The author debunks several persistent
label: Paragraph

text: but erroneous notions about the episode, some held by his closest survivors,
label: Paragraph

text: and gives plausible explanations for what went wrong and why.
label: Paragraph

text: Posthumous medical diagnoses are impossible to verify, yet it does seem
label: Paragraph

text: likely that Kahn was a victim of excessive long-haul air voyages. To be
label: Paragraph

text: sure, architectural practice was an international affair well before modern
label: Paragraph

text: aviation, with masters from Bernini to Wright traveling to far-off lands in
label: Paragraph

text: search of work. But the advent of regular commercial jet service in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s put unprecedented pressure on architects to routinely transverse vast
label: Paragraph

text: distances to secure commissions, supervise construction, participate in
label: Paragraph

text: conferences, give lectures, fulfill visiting professorships, and accept awards,
label: Paragraph

text: all deemed desirable components of a major international career.
label: Paragraph

text: Cardiologists have since identified frequent and lengthy plane journeys
label: Paragraph

text: as a major risk factor for those with heart disease, and a cause of deep-vein
label: Paragraph

text: thrombosis, a clot that can now be prevented with advanced blood thinners.
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn—who in his final year complained of “indigestion,” a common
label: Paragraph

text: misunderstanding of a classic cardiac symptom—was felled by a fatal
label: Paragraph

text: coronary attack on the last leg of a grueling trek from Ahmedabad, his
label: Paragraph

text: eighth international trip in four months, several of them halfway around the
label: Paragraph

text: world. Such a marathon would have been hard on a younger, fitter man, but
label: Paragraph

text: the toll it took on this workaholic septuagenarian was catastrophic. Because
label: Paragraph

text: genetics are thought to have an important effect on longevity, and the
label: Paragraph

text: architect’s parents lived into their upper eighties, it might be said that Louis
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn flew himself to death, a Jet Age Icarus.

text: PAUL RUDOLPH
label: Title

text: A FALL FROM Critical grace is not uncommon in the arts, but somehow it
label: Paragraph

text: seems more surprising in architecture than in literature, music, or painting.
label: Paragraph

text: Buildings tend to remain in the public realm much longer and more
label: Paragraph

text: conspicuously than books that go out of print, operas that languish
label: Paragraph

text: unperformed, or paintings relegated to storage. By and large, architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: simply too expensive to destroy for mere matters of taste. There is no such
label: Paragraph

text: thing as “out of sight, out of mind” when it comes to an ugly building,
label: Paragraph

text: whatever the standards for judging one might be. Indeed, the benign neglect
label: Paragraph

text: of un-fashionable architecture in economically marginal areas has long been
label: Paragraph

text: an inestimable boon to historic preservation.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the most acclaimed mid-twentieth-century American architects,
label: Paragraph

text: none experienced a more precipitous reversal of fortune than Paul Rudolph.
label: Paragraph

text: During the late 1940s and early 1950s, Rudolph attracted well-deserved
label: Paragraph

text: attention for the more than two dozen houses he built on the west coast of
label: Paragraph

text: Florida. These small, sprightly structures displayed what the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: historian Robin Middleton aptly termed “a very bright-young-boyish
label: Paragraph

text: charm.” Rudolph’s informal, lightweight houses demonstrated his dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: manipulation of space, inventive use of new materials, and rejection of rote
label: Paragraph

text: domestic conventions. It was thrilling to imagine what he might do on a
label: Paragraph

text: larger scale with bigger budgets.
label: Paragraph

text: At the peak of his career, in the late 1950s and early 1960s, Rudolph was
label: Paragraph

text: widely deemed destined for greatness. With the death in 1961 of Eero
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen, then the preeminent architect of his generation, Rudolph appeared
label: Paragraph

text: ready to lead the American architectural avant-garde. (Louis Kahn, who
label: Paragraph

text: was considerably older than both men, began to be perceived as this
label: Paragraph

text: country’s most important contemporary architect only in the late 1960s.) As
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph’s renown grew, he became preoccupied with two concerns—self-
label: Paragraph

text: expression and monumentality—that were fundamentally at odds with the
label: Paragraph

text: empathetic touch and humane feel of his early works.
label: Paragraph

text: The extent to which modem architecture had become formulaic by
label: Paragraph

text: midcentury led Rudolph to ponder how he could stand out from the crowd.
label: Paragraph

text: His quest for a distinctive stylistic manner led him to adopt the tough
label: Paragraph

text: vocabulary of New Brutalism, with its vigorously sculptural compositions
label: Paragraph

text: that made the modular steel-and-glass grids of the Miesian school look
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat anemic and routine. Rudolph’s distinctively American version of
label: Paragraph

text: Brutalism diverged from that of his foreign peers in his attraction to
label: Paragraph

text: scenographic design—architecture that begins with a preconceived idea of
label: Paragraph

text: how a building should look from a specific vantage point, in contrast to the
label: Paragraph

text: Modernist belief that the internal functions of a structure should determine
label: Paragraph

text: its external form. However, despite the arresting profiles scenographic
label: Paragraph

text: design could engender—perhaps most famously in modem architecture the
label: Paragraph

text: sail-like rooflines of Jorn Utzon’s harborfront Sydney Opera House of
label: Caption

text: 1957-1973—the practice struck some as a throwback to nineteenth-century
label: Paragraph

text: Romanticism.
label: Paragraph

text: Another major difference in Rudolph’s approach was that instead of
label: Paragraph

text: using poured concrete like his counterparts abroad, he chose a less
label: Paragraph

text: demanding and more economical altemnative—the rough-finished precast
label: Paragraph

text: concrete blocks that became his hallmark. Poured-in-place concrete requires
label: Paragraph

text: costly wooden forms to contain the material until it hardens, whereas
label: Paragraph

text: precast blocks eliminate that expense and can be used like bricks. Because
label: Paragraph

text: he wanted to create more voluptuous volumes and richer surface textures
label: Paragraph

text: than was possible with standard concrete blocks, Rudolph designed a range
label: Paragraph

text: of precast components with rounded surfaces that could be combined to
label: Paragraph

text: make a variety of curving forms. These pieces were fabricated with vertical
label: Paragraph

text: ribs or flutes that mimicked the look of more labor-intensive bush-
label: Paragraph

text: hammered concrete, which is mechanically distressed to achieve a
label: Paragraph

text: corrugated surface (and which he used for his Yale Art and Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: Building). Whether handcrafted or prefabricated, these components gave
label: Paragraph

text: the exteriors of Rudolph’s buildings a fuzzy striped effect often likened to
label: Paragraph

text: corduroy, although of course not in any way soft.
label: Paragraph

text: Such was his publicity juggernaut that the press reflexively lauded
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph’s bombastic institutional schemes, epitomized by his eerily
label: Paragraph

text: cavernous, crushingly heavy Government Service Center in Boston of
label: Paragraph

text: 1962-1971—a fortresslike complex with a swirling, multilevel interior that
label: Paragraph

text: brings to mind the inner ear of some Brobdingnagian creature. The lack of
label: Paragraph

text: critical analysis such overbearing works received at the time is doubtless
label: Paragraph

text: attributable to the friendships Rudolph assiduously cultivated with editors
label: Paragraph

text: and critics in both the professional and general-interest press. Furthermore,
label: Paragraph

text: his striking black-and-white renderings—meticulous networks of tiny lines
label: Paragraph

text: that convey three-dimensional depth and look terrific in print—made him a
label: Paragraph

text: favorite of art directors eager to achieve layouts with powerful impact.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps prompted by the historian Sigfried Giedion’s influential 1944
label: Paragraph

text: essay “The Need for a New Monumentality”’—which argued that modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture lacked the imposing presence of earlier building styles—
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph sought to make his designs more monumental. Like many other
label: Paragraph

text: architects, he equated size with significance and attempted to turn even
label: Paragraph

text: lesser public commissions into major statements. A case in point is his
label: Paragraph

text: Orange County Government Center of 1963-1971 in Goshen, New York, a
label: Paragraph

text: grandiose pileup of boxy concrete forms that seems pompously
label: Paragraph

text: overreaching for a small-town office building.
label: Paragraph

text: When Rudolph stepped down as the dean of the Yale School of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture in 1965, he grandly announced that he was moving to New
label: Paragraph

text: York to become a skyscraper architect, a macho ambition that few true
label: Paragraph

text: artist-architects would harbor, let alone openly express. As it turned out, he
label: Paragraph

text: got to execute tall buildings only late in his career, but that did not stop him
label: Paragraph

text: from fantasizing about mammoth high-rise projects until he had the chance
label: Paragraph

text: to build them. Responding to the visionary megastructures proposed in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s by the international collaborative Team 10 and in the 1960s by the
label: Paragraph

text: Metabolist group in Japan and the Archigram group in Britain, Rudolph in
label: Paragraph

text: the late 1960s and early 1970s devised hypothetical Manhattan schemes for
label: Paragraph

text: gigantic agglomerations of mixed-use “plug-in” units that were to be
label: Paragraph

text: inserted into elongated and towering frameworks reminiscent of children’s
label: Paragraph

text: building kits like Lego bricks, Erector Sets, and Tinkertoys. (Imagining
label: Paragraph

text: such visionary projects was hardly confined to architects, as demonstrated
label: Paragraph

text: by Norman Mailer’s model for his “Mile High City,” some seven feet tall
label: Paragraph

text: and comprising more than 20,000 Lego pieces, which was used to illustrate
label: Paragraph

text: the dust jacket of his 1966 book Cannibals and Christians.)
label: Paragraph

text: Though fortunately none of Rudolph’s New York City megastructures
label: Paragraph

text: was ever built, he applied a low-rise version of the same concept to one of
label: Paragraph

text: the more imaginative American multiunit housing schemes of the period,
label: Paragraph

text: Oriental Masonic Gardens of 1968-1971 in New Haven (the exotic name of
label: Paragraph

text: which referred not to some fanciful real estate marketing concept but to the
label: Paragraph

text: fraternal organization that sponsored it). Here 148 prefabricated shoebox-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped units akin to mobile homes—which Rudolph dubbed “the twentieth-
label: Paragraph

text: century brick”—were grouped in right-angled clusters around courtyards
label: Paragraph

text: and stacked no higher than two stories. The barrel-vaulted roof of each
label: Paragraph

text: “brick” gave a lovely rippling rhythm to the slightly inclined twelve-and-a-
label: Paragraph

text: half-acre site. Yet as Rudolph later admitted, residents hated the place: their
label: Paragraph

text: dwellings leaked, some felt the development was as déclassé as a trailer
label: Paragraph

text: park, and only a decade after its completion this noble experiment was
label: Paragraph

text: demolished.
label: Paragraph

text: In his 2014 monograph on this complex and sometimes confounding
label: Paragraph

text: figure, the architectural historian Timothy M. Rohan emerged as the
label: Paragraph

text: foremost posthumous advocate of Rudolph’s works. Even though Rohan is
label: Paragraph

text: wholly sympathetic to his subject, he is far from uncritical about the factors
label: Paragraph

text: that contributed to Rudolph’s career decline. Rohan offers credible insights
label: Paragraph

text: into how Rudolph’s homosexuality was reflected in his work and suggests
label: Paragraph

text: that his characteristic juxtaposition of defensive, often concrete exteriors
label: Paragraph

text: and sensuous interiors parallels the dichotomy between his carefully
label: Paragraph

text: maintained straight public image and his concealed gay private life.
label: Paragraph

text: However, like several vanguard American artists of the 1960s—including
label: Paragraph

text: Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, and Andy Warhol—Rudolph (as well
label: Paragraph

text: as his architectural contemporaries Philip Johnson and Charles Moore) did
label: Paragraph

text: not deny his homosexuality, although none of them openly proclaimed it,
label: Paragraph

text: either.
label: Paragraph

text: Paul Marvin Rudolph was born in 1918 in southwestern Kentucky. His
label: Paragraph

text: father was an itinerant Methodist minister, and as Rudolph observed when
label: Paragraph

text: he was eighteen, “moving around and being a preacher’s son has been
label: Paragraph

text: hard,” although doubtless not nearly as difficult as his emerging awareness
label: Paragraph

text: of his sexuality given his family, geographic, and generational
label: Paragraph

text: circumstances. Yet the Rudolphs’ fourteen changes of address during his
label: Paragraph

text: peripatetic childhood also helped him develop an encyclopedic eye for
label: Paragraph

text: indigenous southern architectural forms. Sensitive and introverted, he took
label: Paragraph

text: refuge in art and music, and became such an accomplished pianist that he
label: Paragraph

text: contemplated a concert career until he placed second in a national
label: Paragraph

text: competition. His need to be number one suddenly emerged as such a strong
label: Paragraph

text: personal imperative that he there and then shifted his career ambition to the
label: Paragraph

text: building art.
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph studied architecture at the Alabama Polytechnic Institute (now
label: Paragraph

text: Auburn University), where at the precocious age of twenty-one he executed
label: Paragraph

text: his first building, for a professor at the school—the redbrick ranch-style
label: Paragraph

text: Atkinson house of 1940. His next project was his initial collaboration with
label: Paragraph

text: Ralph Twitchell, in whose Sarasota architectural office he worked during a
label: Paragraph

text: gap year before starting a graduate degree. The Twitchell house of 1941 in
label: Paragraph

text: Siesta Key, Florida, shows the clear influence of Frank Lloyd Wright, a
label: Paragraph

text: prime example of whose residential work—the Rosenbaum house of 1939
label: Paragraph

text: in Florence, Alabama—Rudolph had visited and admired. The Twitchell
label: Paragraph

text: house closely follows the economical formula Wright called Usonian—
label: Paragraph

text: usually featuring low roofs and open living areas. The Twitchell house had
label: Paragraph

text: low-slung massing, an overhanging roof, and concrete-block construction,
label: Paragraph

text: along with horizontal stained-wood siding and a compact kitchen.
label: Caption

text: Three months after Rudolph entered the Harvard Graduate School of
label: Paragraph

text: Design in 1941, the US entered World War II and he enlisted in the navy.
label: Paragraph

text: After taking maritime architecture courses at MIT, he was stationed at the
label: Paragraph

text: Brooklyn Navy Yard and put in charge of ship repair. The hands-on
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge he gained there had a direct effect on his later work, and
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph’s mastery of low-cost techniques for lightweight framing for
label: Paragraph

text: houses and new materials such as Cocoon (a spray-on plastic used to
label: Paragraph

text: mothball disused ship components) resurfaced in his ingenious postwar
label: Paragraph

text: designs. This was yet another example of how countless young architects
label: Paragraph

text: transformed their improvisatory wartime experiments into practices that
label: Paragraph

text: later entered the professional mainstream.
label: Paragraph

text: When peace came, Rudolph returned to the Twitchell office and then
label: Paragraph

text: completed his degree at Harvard, where he won a traveling fellowship that
label: Paragraph

text: allowed him to witness firsthand the building boom in Europe. He was
label: Paragraph

text: particularly taken by Le Corbusier’s Unité d’Habitation of 1947-1952 in
label: Paragraph

text: Marseille, with its monumental scale and expressive use of béton brut.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Twitchell made him a partner in 1950, Rudolph later insisted that
label: Paragraph

text: the designs credited to both men were entirely his own work. Never the
label: Paragraph

text: most collegial of collaborators, he broke with his early mentor in 1952 and
label: Paragraph

text: set up his own practice.
label: Paragraph

text: Eager to make a name for himself, avoid being typecast as a regional
label: Paragraph

text: residential specialist, and establish useful contacts nationwide, the hugely
label: Paragraph

text: ambitious Rudolph accepted teaching positions at architecture schools all
label: Paragraph

text: across the country, including Comell, Harvard, MIT, Penn, Tulane, UCLA,
label: Paragraph

text: and Yale, sometimes overlapping in impractical ways. With considerable
label: Paragraph

text: effort he juggled his dual design and educational career, and during the
label: Paragraph

text: academic year ran his small Sarasota practice via telephone and mail. In
label: Paragraph

text: short order he was awarded such high-profile jobs as the installation for the
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Modern Art’s wildly popular 1955 photography exhibition “The
label: Paragraph

text: Family of Man”; the Jewett Arts Center of 1955-1958 at Wellesley College
label: Caption

text: in Massachusetts, a redbrick complex with moderized Gothic overtones
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of Basil Spence’s concurrent work in Britain; and several
label: Paragraph

text: building projects in New Haven, where he became dean of the Yale School
label: Paragraph

text: of Architecture in 1958. It was a heady ascent for the shy but striving
label: Paragraph

text: preacher’s boy.
label: Paragraph

text: Ironically enough, the project that halted Rudolph’s rapid career
label: Paragraph

text: advancement was the Yale Art and Architecture Building of 1958-1963, the
label: Paragraph

text: plum commission he received soon after arriving in New Haven (see
label: Paragraph

text: Illustration 11a). This was the latest in university president A. Whitney
label: Paragraph

text: Griswold’s admirable program to bring the best of contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: architecture to the campus, which included works by Kahn, Saarinen,
label: Paragraph

text: Johnson, and Gordon Bunshaft. As a series of Rudolph’s preparatory
label: Paragraph

text: renderings show, he gradually but relentlessly inflated the A&A Building
label: Paragraph

text: (as it was known) from a relatively modest colonnaded structure in his
label: Paragraph

text: initial version into the Brutalist behemoth that was erected—a nearly cubic
label: Paragraph

text: core surrounded by a phalanx of windowless towers as forbidding as those
label: Paragraph

text: of a medieval castle.
label: Paragraph

text: The building’s many functional flaws soon became unavoidable—thirty-
label: Paragraph

text: seven different levels were crammed into its seven stories, a preposterous
label: Paragraph

text: overelaboration of space—and as the social upheavals of the 1960s
label: Paragraph

text: unfolded, the heroic ethos Rudolph tried to evoke came across to rebellious
label: Paragraph

text: students as authoritarian posturing. His successor as dean, the scholarly
label: Paragraph

text: postmodernist Charles Moore, held a view of architecture diametrically
label: Paragraph

text: opposed to Rudolph’s, and had far greater knowledge of and respect for
label: Paragraph

text: both historical and vernacular traditions. As Moore slyly proclaimed, “I
label: Paragraph

text: disapprove of the Art and Architecture Building whole-heartedly because it
label: Paragraph

text: is such a personal manifestation for non-personal use. However, I enjoy
label: Paragraph

text: very much being in it.”
label: Paragraph

text: To improve the structure’s ill-resolved spatial organization, Moore
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged students to take matters into their own hands and reconfigure
label: Paragraph

text: studio spaces as they saw fit. He turned Rudolph’s stately penthouse, which
label: Paragraph

text: had been used for entertaining and as guest quarters for eminent visitors,
label: Paragraph

text: into a student coffeehouse. Haphazardly altered and poorly maintained, the
label: Paragraph

text: A&A Building under Moore’s deanship became a countercultural mess.
label: Paragraph

text: Then, in June 1969, a mysterious fire gutted the structure. Although the
label: Paragraph

text: cause was never determined, Rudolph went to his grave convinced that
label: Paragraph

text: Moore had somehow incited the destruction of his misunderstood
label: Paragraph

text: masterpiece. (The building was salvaged, unsympathetically rehabbed, and
label: Paragraph

text: then finally restored by Gwathmey Siegel & Associates in 2007-2008.)
label: Paragraph

text: With his reputation in decline as architectural tastes shifted to more user-
label: Paragraph

text: friendly schemes, Rudolph pinned his hopes for a comeback on his largest-
label: Paragraph

text: ever residential scheme, the Bass house of 1970-1972 in Fort Worth,
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned by the Texas oil heir Sid R. Bass and his first wife, Anne.
label: Paragraph

text: The A&A Building went up while Bass was a Yale undergraduate and he
label: Paragraph

text: deeply admired its architect. The admiration between Bass and Rudolph
label: Paragraph

text: was mutual, and the architect referred to his patron as “my Renaissance
label: Paragraph

text: prince.” Rudolph saw the Bass residence as his equivalent of Fallingwater,
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright’s most famous house, which helped revive the master’s
label: Paragraph

text: career after a long dry spell. Rudolph’s scheme took many cues from that
label: Paragraph

text: legendary prototype, most notably its tiered arrangement of balconies
label: Paragraph

text: thrusting outward from a central mast like huge domino tiles set at right
label: Paragraph

text: angles to one another.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the Basses’ site lacked the inherent drama of the Appalachian
label: Paragraph

text: ravine where Wright found a waterfall from which all blessings flowed.
label: Paragraph

text: Even the addition of an artificial pond by the landscape architect Robert
label: Paragraph

text: Zion didn’t do the trick in Fort Worth. However, thanks to the clients’
label: Paragraph

text: ample funding, Rudolph was able to use costlier materials and attain a much
label: Paragraph

text: higher level of execution than ever before. The white-painted steel
label: Paragraph

text: framework of the Bass house is as precisely crafted as that of its model,
label: Paragraph

text: Ludwig Mies van der Rohe’s Farnsworth house of 1946-1951 in Plano,
label: Caption

text: Illinois. And instead of the painted wood siding of Rudolph’s early houses,
label: Paragraph

text: here he used white porcelain-coated aluminum panels, a deluxe cladding
label: Paragraph

text: component favored by the then-rising star Richard Meier.
label: Paragraph

text: While the expansive (and expensive) Bass house is a far more pleasing
label: Paragraph

text: composition than Rudolph’s Brutalist public works, it offers another
label: Paragraph

text: example of his deep-seated urge to overcomplicate things, not least in his
label: Paragraph

text: dragging out the entry sequence to a tedious extreme. He calculated that a
label: Paragraph

text: visitor would make eight turns and ascend fifteen feet in traveling from the
label: Paragraph

text: front door to the living room. In contrast, at Alvar Aalto’s incomparable
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Mairea of 1935-1938 in Noormarkku, Finland, visitors move directly
label: Paragraph

text: from the entry to the heart of this extensive layout in a matter of seconds.
label: Paragraph

text: Sadly for Rudolph, the Basses did not want images of their house to be
label: Paragraph

text: published because of security concerns. Without being splashed over the
label: Paragraph

text: pages of glossy shelter magazines it did not have the restorative effect on
label: Paragraph

text: his reputation that its architect had so fervently wished for, and his critical
label: Paragraph

text: rehabilitation never materialized.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the critic Michael Sorkin praised Rudolph’s own Manhattan
label: Paragraph

text: penthouse of 1977-1997 as “one of the most amazing pieces of modern
label: Paragraph

text: urban domestic architecture produced in this country,” I had quite a
label: Paragraph

text: different experience when Rudolph invited me and my wife to a buffet
label: Paragraph

text: dinner there in 1986, after an opening of his drawings at the Max Protetch
label: Paragraph

text: Gallery. Throughout that multistory apartment (built atop an existing
label: Paragraph

text: Beekman Place town house, the lower portions of which the owner rented
label: Paragraph

text: out for extra income), surface finishes and details were astonishingly
label: Paragraph

text: shoddy. For example, railings that in photographs seemed to be made of
label: Paragraph

text: polished chrome were actually covered in peeling Mylar. Floor levels
label: Paragraph

text: shifted up or down every few feet for no apparent reason, and narrow
label: Paragraph

text: Plexiglas catwalks spanned chasms open to the stories below. There was so
label: Paragraph

text: little continuous floor space amid the cavernous volumes that guests that
label: Paragraph

text: evening huddled on the small carpeted platforms like Little Eva on the ice
label: Paragraph

text: floes.
label: Paragraph

text: Odd sources of dim illumination—underneath stair treads and behind
label: Paragraph

text: floating wall panels—made navigation treacherous, especially for such
label: Paragraph

text: older luminaries as the designer Ray Eames and the architectural historian
label: Paragraph

text: Vincent Scully. There was much stumbling and tripping as we tried to
label: Paragraph

text: negotiate the labyrinthine circulation paths to and from the food and drinks,
label: Paragraph

text: and even when we were seated mishaps continued. A large modular coffee
label: Paragraph

text: table appeared to be composed of alternating cubes of reflective and matte
label: Paragraph

text: black Lucite. But when someone set a drink down on one of the matte
label: Paragraph

text: squares, it turned out to be a void and the glass crashed to the story below.
label: Paragraph

text: The architect and his longtime, much younger Swiss companion, Ernst
label: Paragraph

text: Wagner, proudly conducted a house tour, which included such unanticipated
label: Paragraph

text: sights as a clear Plexiglas bathtub that was fully visible from the level
label: Paragraph

text: below. This voyeuristic detail seemed a latter-day equivalent of the architect
label: Paragraph

text: Stanford White’s notorious red velvet swing, beneath which he would stand
label: Paragraph

text: and look up the skirts of young girls he fancied. Whatever erotic allure
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph’s exhibitionist showpiece might have possessed was subverted by
label: Paragraph

text: deposits of unidentifiable green matter in the tub’s corners.
label: Paragraph

text: Understandably, the Rudolph penthouse has become a source of
label: Paragraph

text: comment among queer theorists. The owner’s jaw-dropping bedroom
label: Paragraph

text: featured floor-to-ceiling mirrors that reflected a white marble Roman male
label: Caption

text: torso and, mounted on the wall behind the white-fur-covered bed, a
label: Paragraph

text: superscale advertising billboard image of a shirtless, hirsute young man
label: Paragraph

text: being pawed by a passel of adoring young women. When a story on this
label: Paragraph

text: startling interior was published in The New York Times Magazine in 1967,
label: Paragraph

text: some saw it as the architect’s inadvertent coming out. By the time of our
label: Paragraph

text: visit the white-fur bedspread had been replaced by one of white leather
label: Paragraph

text: perforated with metal grommets, which prompted another guest, the
label: Paragraph

text: longtime MoMA trustee Barbara Jakobson, to ask our host, “What do you
label: Paragraph

text: call this, Paul, the Stud Room?,” which caused him to blush deeply.
label: Paragraph

text: But as Rohan notes, “Though highly self-aware and self-critical, Rudolph
label: Paragraph

text: had several psychological or cognitive blind spots, such as believing that
label: Paragraph

text: his homosexuality was not apparent to others.” He was of course entitled to
label: Paragraph

text: create for himself whatever fantasy environment he liked, but the penthouse
label: Paragraph

text: was dangerous for some visitors. As we bid good night to our host, Scully
label: Paragraph

text: spoke for several of us when he said, “Thanks, Paul, it’s been a terrifying
label: Paragraph

text: evening.”
label: Paragraph

text: It is one thing to be uncomfortable in someone else’s house but quite
label: Paragraph

text: another to feel not at home in your own. Alexander Hirsch, who
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned a town house on Manhattan’s Upper East Side from Rudolph
label: Caption

text: in 1966-1967, never fully acclimated to that twenty-five-foot-wide
label: Paragraph

text: structure, which he shared with his companion, Lewis Turner. To be sure, it
label: Paragraph

text: is a handsome design, fronted by a brown glass facade framed in a
label: Paragraph

text: monochromatic, Mondrian-like pattern of brown-painted steel I-beams.
label: Paragraph

text: Visitors enter through a low-ceilinged vestibule and thence into a dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: double-height living room with a balcony that surrounds its upper
label: Caption

text: periphery. This raised level is reachable only by a flight of floating stair
label: Paragraph

text: treads that jut out from the side wall without risers or a bannister. The two
label: Paragraph

text: original inhabitants, then in their sixties, felt this was an accident waiting to
label: Paragraph

text: happen and tended to stay away from that part of the interior.
label: Paragraph

text: Soon after the couple moved in, Rudolph took it upon himself to add a
label: Paragraph

text: large mural to their living room while they were away on vacation. His
label: Caption

text: campy composition was based on an Italian quattrocento painting that, as
label: Paragraph

text: Rohan writes, “depicted stylized men in tight-fitting Renaissance costumes
label: Paragraph

text: with leggings and codpieces.” The owner bridled at this unauthorized
label: Paragraph

text: imposition and refused to pay Rudolph’s $1,500 fee, the two stopped
label: Paragraph

text: speaking, and a few years later Hirsch sold the house. Stories such as this,
label: Paragraph

text: as well as press reports of several lawsuits lodged against Rudolph, made
label: Paragraph

text: potential clients think twice before hiring him, and his career went into free
label: Paragraph

text: fall.
label: Paragraph

text: As Rudolph’s American commissions dried up, this already solitary
label: Paragraph

text: figure retreated even further into himself. Though his prospects in this
label: Paragraph

text: country never recovered, he found an eager new constituency in Southeast
label: Paragraph

text: Asia. The glitzy high-rises he erected there during the 1980s and 1990s—
label: Paragraph

text: typified by his Bond Centre of 1984-1988, a mixed-use office and hotel
label: Paragraph

text: complex in Hong Kong, conjoined twin towers bulging with “saddlebags”
label: Paragraph

text: and clad in mirror glass—gave him the semblance of renewed success, but
label: Paragraph

text: he never stopped believing he’d been robbed of his rightful place atop the
label: Paragraph

text: hierarchy of modern architects. In his seventies Rudolph was diagnosed
label: Paragraph

text: with mesothelioma, a cancer caused by prolonged exposure to asbestos—an
label: Paragraph

text: occupational hazard in the building trades—and he died in 1997.
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph’s diminished posthumous stature is reflected in the unusual
label: Paragraph

text: number of his buildings that have been destroyed. The most regrettable loss
label: Paragraph

text: has been his Riverview High School of 1957-1958 in Sarasota, which was
label: Paragraph

text: torn down in 2009. This early essay in what we now call green architecture
label: Paragraph

text: —building design that takes regional environmental factors into account,
label: Paragraph

text: especially for climate control—was a sprawling low-rise complex with an
label: Paragraph

text: excellent natural ventilation system. However, because the school could not
label: Paragraph

text: easily be retrofitted for mechanical air-conditioning, now considered
label: Paragraph

text: essential in Florida, it was needlessly trashed, instead of being converted to
label: Paragraph

text: another use that could have borne the cost of the renovation and upkeep.
label: Paragraph

text: And although a plan was floated to save the endangered Orange County
label: Paragraph

text: Government Center by converting that dilapidated structure into a
label: Paragraph

text: community arts center, the central portion of the building was razed in
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph’s finest work by far was the Tuskegee University Chapel of
label: Paragraph

text: 1960-1969 at the historically black college in Tuskegee, Alabama. This
label: Paragraph

text: nondenominational chapel’s angular redbrick exterior, unusually minimalist
label: Paragraph

text: for Rudolph, conceals one of the most impressive twentieth-century
label: Paragraph

text: religious spaces in America. The wedge-shaped, brick-walled nave tapers
label: Paragraph

text: slightly as one nears the chancel, which is configured like an African-
label: Paragraph

text: American gospel church with risers for a choir, instead of a conventional
label: Paragraph

text: Christian altar. Most prominent is the pulpit, raised high above the
label: Paragraph

text: congregation and surmounted by a sleek projecting canopy that signifies the
label: Paragraph

text: importance of preaching in the black religious experience. Most affecting of
label: Paragraph

text: all is the supernal illumination that pours down from lateral skylights and
label: Paragraph

text: imparts a spiritual aura like that achieved by Aalto in his magnificent
label: Paragraph

text: postwar churches.
label: Paragraph

text: Above all, the Tuskegee chapel exudes an embracing quality
label: Paragraph

text: conspicuously missing in so much of Rudolph’s other late work, and hints
label: Paragraph

text: at what he might have accomplished had he stepped out of his defensive
label: Paragraph

text: shell more often. The fact that Brutalism went out of fashion was less a
label: Paragraph

text: factor in his professional decline than his innate inwardness. Louis Kahn,
label: Paragraph

text: who many consider a Brutalist as well, was far more adept at imbuing his
label: Paragraph

text: monumental concrete forms with a nobility and humanity that eluded
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolph. That crucial difference largely accounts for the vast but not unjust
label: Paragraph

text: disparity in their historical standing today.
