text: MINORU YAMASAKI
label: Title

text: NOW THAT I’M about to tum seventy I finally feel able to reveal a shameful
label: Paragraph

text: secret: I was a teenage Yamasaki addict. I have no good excuse for why I
label: Paragraph

text: got hooked, but Minoru Yamasaki was the first contemporary architect who
label: Paragraph

text: entranced me. I had already begun my architectural self-education with the
label: Paragraph

text: early writings of Ada Louise Huxtable in The New York Times, where in
label: Paragraph

text: 1962 she praised the plans for Yamasaki’s Robertson Hall of 1961-1965
label: Paragraph

text: (home of Princeton University’s Woodrow Wilson School of Public and
label: Paragraph

text: International Affairs) for the way in which “Greco-Roman and Far Eastern
label: Paragraph

text: influences blend in a series of slender classic columns of Oriental lightness,
label: Paragraph

text: in a top floor suggesting the cornice of a temple, and in a reflecting pool”
label: Caption

text: and for how “the undertones of the past emerge subtly in a quite advanced
label: Paragraph

text: and experimental construction” (see [lustration 12a). I thought it was
label: Paragraph

text: wonderful, too. So much so that as the editor in chief of my high school
label: Paragraph

text: yearbook, I dragged the baffled members of the National Honor Society
label: Paragraph

text: fifty miles northeast from our unphotogenic hometown of Camden, New
label: Paragraph

text: Jersey, to have a group picture taken with us lined up along the white
label: Paragraph

text: quartzite colonnade of this newly completed Princeton Parthenon.
label: Caption

text: My youthful infatuation with Yamasaki accelerated in January 1963,
label: Paragraph

text: when he appeared on the cover of Time, an honor earlier bestowed on such
label: Paragraph

text: master builders as Frank Lloyd Wright, Le Corbusier, Richard Neutra, and
label: Paragraph

text: Eero Saarinen. This accolade seemed likely to propel the fifty-year-old
label: Paragraph

text: Seattle-born Nisei to the very top of his profession. But he never quite made
label: Paragraph

text: it, and more than three decades after Yamasaki’s death he is unenviably
label: Paragraph

text: remembered for two large projects that imploded in the most notorious
label: Paragraph

text: building collapses of modern times. Although neither of these sensationally
label: Paragraph

text: publicized endings was in any way his fault—and indeed his understanding
label: Paragraph

text: of advanced engineering prevented the second from being an even worse
label: Paragraph

text: catastrophe—his critical standing has never risen from the ashes, and he is
label: Paragraph

text: now regarded, if at all, as a period curiosity.
label: Paragraph

text: My disillusionment with Yamasaki began with an eye-opening
label: Paragraph

text: undergraduate survey course on moder architecture given at Columbia in
label: Paragraph

text: the late 1960s by Eugene Santomasso, a charismatic young instructor who
label: Paragraph

text: had studied at Yale with the legendary architectural historian Vincent
label: Paragraph

text: Scully. Santomasso echoed his mentor’s conviction that the period’s
label: Paragraph

text: foremost architect was Louis Kahn and likewise disparaged Yamasaki,
label: Paragraph

text: whose Wayne State University conference center of 1955-1958 in Detroit,
label: Paragraph

text: with its diamond-patterned glass-roofed atrium, Scully dismissed as a
label: Paragraph

text: “twittering aviary.” By 1972 even Huxtable was having second thoughts,
label: Paragraph

text: and in a dramatic volte-face, ten years after she lauded Roberston Hall she
label: Paragraph

text: found it characteristic of the “acrobatic novelties and vacuous vulgarities”
label: Paragraph

text: of postwar American campus design. She sealed the deal when she
label: Paragraph

text: pinpointed the stylistic contradiction in Yamasaki’s design for New York
label: Paragraph

text: City’s World Trade Center of 1962-1976: “Here we have the world’s
label: Paragraph

text: daintiest architecture for the world’s biggest buildings.” Although it is often
label: Paragraph

text: assumed that taste is innate, it most certainly can be taught, particularly to
label: Paragraph

text: the young and impressionable.
label: Paragraph

text: But time marches on, and so does the forty-year rule in architectural
label: Paragraph

text: history, whereby once-admired but subsequently underestimated designers
label: Paragraph

text: capture the interest of young scholars in search of figures who still await
label: Paragraph

text: full evaluation. Buildings long deemed passé and unsuccessful can
label: Paragraph

text: suddenly seem fresh and intriguing to a new generation, just as yesterday’s
label: Paragraph

text: tacky decorative designs can become tomorrow’s next cool thing. This has
label: Paragraph

text: been evident in the steady postmillennial flow of monographs on mid-
label: Paragraph

text: twentieth-century architects who have undergone a downward critical
label: Paragraph

text: reversal akin to that of Yamasaki—especially Saarinen, Edward Durell
label: Paragraph

text: Stone, and Paul Rudolph, none of whom now commands the high artistic
label: Paragraph

text: respect they all enjoyed around 1960.
label: Paragraph

text: Minoru Yamasaki was born in Seattle in 1912, the son of Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: immigrants who had recently come to America for better economic
label: Title

text: opportunity but found little. After Congress passed the Chinese Exclusion
label: Paragraph

text: Act of 1882, employers encouraged immigration from Japan to fill low-
label: Paragraph

text: wage jobs Americans did not want. A similar reaction against the Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: later resulted in the Immigration Act of 1924, which banned all Asians from
label: Paragraph

text: immigrating and doubtless fed the bigotry that confronted the young
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki. Late in life he still harbored bitter feelings about the racial
label: Paragraph

text: prejudice he faced while growing up, which persisted for decades even as
label: Paragraph

text: he found the financial success that had eluded his shoe-salesman father.
label: Paragraph

text: However, it was a case not only of race but of class, and there was a
label: Paragraph

text: world of difference between his experience and that of the Chinese-born
label: Paragraph

text: I. M. Pei, only five years his junior. The MIT-educated Pei came from an
label: Paragraph

text: aristocratic family, had a faultless instinct for social relations, married an
label: Paragraph

text: equally patrician Chinese Wellesley graduate—a prime minister, an
label: Paragraph

text: ambassador, a bank president, and assorted literati are in the couple’s
label: Paragraph

text: genealogies—and they were smoothly accepted into the highest echelons of
label: Paragraph

text: the American establishment.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike many future architects, Yamasaki did not have artistic leanings as
label: Paragraph

text: a boy; he excelled instead at math and science, which presaged his keen
label: Paragraph

text: interest in engineering. But when his Tokyo-based architect uncle, Koken
label: Paragraph

text: Ito (no relation to the Pritzker Prize winner Toyo Ito), visited Seattle en
label: Paragraph

text: route to a job in Chicago, the teenager was so entranced by architectural
label: Paragraph

text: drawings he showed him that he instantly decided to follow his relative’s
label: Paragraph

text: career path. He began the University of Washington’s five-year Beaux
label: Paragraph

text: Arts—oriented architecture program weeks before the 1929 market crash,
label: Paragraph

text: and during the Great Depression paid for his education with dangerous and
label: Paragraph

text: exhausting summer stints in the Alaska salmon-canning industry.
label: Paragraph

text: Upon graduation Yamasaki headed straight for New York City, where he
label: Paragraph

text: felt he could escape the discrimination he suffered in Seattle. But like many
label: Paragraph

text: of his coprofessionals, during the slump he could not find full-time work,
label: Paragraph

text: and survived on odd jobs until he was hired in 1938 by Shreve, Lamb &
label: Paragraph

text: Harmon, the architects of the Empire State Building, conceived seven years
label: Paragraph

text: earlier. He was assigned to the design team for Parkchester, a vast middle-
label: Paragraph

text: income housing estate in the Bronx sponsored by the Metropolitan Life
label: Paragraph

text: Insurance Company, the first such development in the US to apply the
label: Paragraph

text: “towers in the park” concept espoused by Le Corbusier in his unexecuted
label: Paragraph

text: Ville Radieuse (Radiant City) of 1924, which proposed high-rise apartment
label: Paragraph

text: buildings widely spaced among parklike grounds to supplant densely settled
label: Paragraph

text: mid-rise neighborhoods.
label: Paragraph

text: During World War II, Yamasaki oversaw construction of the firm’s huge
label: Paragraph

text: naval training station on Lake Seneca in up-state New York, which gave
label: Paragraph

text: him the organizational skills needed to manage large-scale schemes. While
label: Paragraph

text: occupied with this patriotic work, he had to rescue his parents from being
label: Paragraph

text: put into an internment camp on the West Coast and brought them to New
label: Paragraph

text: York, where they were crammed together with the architect, his new wife,
label: Paragraph

text: and his medical-student brother in a one-bedroom apartment.
label: Paragraph

text: When civilian construction resumed after the war, he was recruited by
label: Paragraph

text: Detroit’s foremost architecture office, Smith, Hinchman & Grylls, to
label: Paragraph

text: become its chief designer and take the firm in a more Modernist direction.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite his increase in status and income, Yamasaki still had not escaped
label: Paragraph

text: racism. Although now well able to afford a house in the upscale Detroit
label: Paragraph

text: suburbs of Birmingham, Bloomfield Hills, and Grosse Pointe, he found it
label: Paragraph

text: impossible for an Asian-American to breach those all-white enclaves and
label: Paragraph

text: eventually bought a nineteenth-century farmhouse in an unincorporated
label: Paragraph

text: township twenty miles from his office.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Yamasaki was already well aware of the priorities of
label: Paragraph

text: commercial architectural practice—at Shreve, Lamb & Harmon, one
label: Caption

text: partner’s mantra was “Finance dictates fenestration, rent rolls rule the parti
label: Paragraph

text: [the organizational concept of a  building]”—he quickly became
label: Paragraph

text: disillusioned in his new position. As he later observed, “The makeup of a
label: Paragraph

text: large (several hundred men) office is such that its primary concern has to be
label: Paragraph

text: to make as much money as possible, forcing it to take almost any kind of
label: Paragraph

text: work.” In such firms, “the turnover . . . works against the creation of
label: Paragraph

text: sensitive, responsive architecture.” Furthermore, he recalled, “I was never
label: Paragraph

text: permitted to meet with the client” if design changes were called for, and
label: Paragraph

text: although this might be attributed to corporate bureaucracy, it is hard not to
label: Paragraph

text: wonder if there was a racial component to his exclusion.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1949 Yamasaki and two office colleagues, Joseph Leinweber and
label: Paragraph

text: George Hellmuth, set up their own partnership in Detroit, and because of
label: Paragraph

text: important contacts that the St. Louis—born Hellmuth had in his hometown,
label: Paragraph

text: they opened a second branch there. (Hellmuth went on to found Hellmuth,
label: Paragraph

text: Obata + Kassabaum, now known as HOK, the largest architecture firm in
label: Paragraph

text: the US.) The combination of Hellmuth’s local connections and Yamasaki’s
label: Paragraph

text: Parkchester credentials quickly won them big commissions for public
label: Paragraph

text: housing in St. Louis, which at the time was in the throes of a thoroughgoing
label: Paragraph

text: slum clearance and urban renewal campaign.
label: Paragraph

text: But if Yamasaki had already been frustrated by the economic incentives
label: Paragraph

text: of large commercial architecture firms, such constraints were nothing
label: Paragraph

text: compared to those imposed by the Federal Public Housing Authority, the
label: Paragraph

text: New Deal agency that regulated the planning, design, and construction of
label: Paragraph

text: what became known as “the projects.” It has been correctly noted that
label: Paragraph

text: architects of speculative skyscrapers are so limited by economic factors that
label: Paragraph

text: they can do little more than decorate the exterior of a bulk predetermined by
label: Paragraph

text: cost accountants. Yamasaki found himself in much the same position when
label: Paragraph

text: he planned his most controversial work, the Pruitt-[goe Apartments of
label: Paragraph

text: 1950-1956 in St. Louis.
label: Caption

text: Although he kept abreast of recent trends in social housing in Europe, he
label: Paragraph

text: was stymied in applying those new ideas in this commission because every
label: Paragraph

text: design decision was subject to a plethora of bureaucratic regulations. The
label: Paragraph

text: countless mandated requirements—from the minimum size of rooms to the
label: Paragraph

text: disposition of windows, closets, and appliances—make one wonder how
label: Paragraph

text: any architect could juggle so many competing demands, stick to the
label: Paragraph

text: prohibitively low budget prescribed for each unit (under $1,750 per
label: Paragraph

text: apartment, or around $18,000 today), and still come up with a coherent, let
label: Paragraph

text: alone beautiful, design.
label: Paragraph

text: Whatever small grace notes Yamasaki was able to eke out under these
label: Paragraph

text: restrictive circumstances were further undermined by budget cuts during the
label: Paragraph

text: Korean War, which began in 1950 just as his plans were being completed.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, the final results, however compromised, were met with
label: Paragraph

text: grateful enthusiasm by the first inhabitants of Pruitt-lgoe—African-
label: Paragraph

text: Americans who found the racially segregated development to be a vast
label: Paragraph

text: improvement over the degrading living conditions they had been inured to.
label: Paragraph

text: This was confirmed by original residents of the complex who were
label: Paragraph

text: interviewed by the filmmaker Chad Freidrichs for his corrective 2011
label: Paragraph

text: documentary, The Pruitt-Igoe Myth. Their appreciative testimony refuted
label: Paragraph

text: the persistent canard that the alleged debacle of postwar public housing in
label: Paragraph

text: America—to say nothing of modern architecture as a whole—could be
label: Paragraph

text: summed up by this noble St. Louis experiment, which ended when the
label: Paragraph

text: dilapidated, crime-ridden project was demolished, a victim of not so benign
label: Paragraph

text: neglect, only eighteen years after it opened.
label: Paragraph

text: The misconception that high-rise public housing was responsible for
label: Paragraph

text: social malaise because of its design attributes has been promoted by many
label: Paragraph

text: opponents of Modernist architecture, most notably the critic Charles Jencks,
label: Paragraph

text: who began his 1977 polemic The Language of Post-Modern Architecture by
label: Paragraph

text: writing:
label: Title

text: Modern architecture died in St. Louis, Missouri on July 15, 1972 at
label: Paragraph

text: 3.32 pm (or thereabouts) when the infamous Pruitt-Igoe scheme, or
label: Paragraph

text: rather several of its slab blocks, were given the final coup de grace by
label: Paragraph

text: dynamite. Previously it had been vandalised, mutilated and defaced by
label: Paragraph

text: its black inhabitants, and although millions of dollars were pumped
label: Paragraph

text: back, trying to keep it alive (fixing the broken elevators, repairing
label: Paragraph

text: smashed windows, repainting), it was finally put out of its misery.
label: Paragraph

text: However, as has been amply confirmed by well-informed sociologists,
label: Paragraph

text: including the housing specialist Herbert Gans, the problems that were
label: Paragraph

text: allowed to get so unmanageably out of control at Pruitt-[goe were not
label: Paragraph

text: architectural in origin. Rather, they had mainly to do with reductions in
label: Paragraph

text: basic maintenance and social services as government funding for Great
label: Title

text: Society programs was shifted to the Vietnam War.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, Jencks’s assertion has remained indelibly fixed in the public
label: Paragraph

text: imagination, as indicated by the Victoria and Albert Museum’s 2011 design
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition “Postmodernism: Style and Subversion, 1970-1990,” which
label: Paragraph

text: opened with an enormous photomural of the Pruitt-Igoe towers collapsing
label: Paragraph

text: amid clouds of dust, like some lurid Victorian tableau of Samson pulling
label: Paragraph

text: down the pillars of the temple. No architect likes to see his work destroyed,
label: Paragraph

text: but Yamasaki felt deeply humiliated by the ignominious end of Pruitt-Igoe,
label: Paragraph

text: and a few years afterward he wrote that “of the buildings we have been
label: Paragraph

text: involved with over the years [ hate this one the most.”

text: None of this could have been foretold at the time of Pruitt-Igoe’s
label: Paragraph

text: completion, and during the 1950s Yamasaki racked up one enviable
label: Paragraph

text: commission after another. His Lambert-St. Louis Airport Terminal of
label: Paragraph

text: 1951-1956, with its sequence of four triple-vaulted concrete canopies,
label: Paragraph

text: although not quite as audacious as Saarinen’s TWA Terminal of 1956-1962
label: Paragraph

text: in New York City, nonetheless conveys a similarly evocative image of Jet
label: Paragraph

text: Age dynamism. Yamasaki was esteemed enough to be chosen for the State
label: Paragraph

text: Department’s embassy architecture program—an initiative meant to
label: Paragraph

text: advertise the Modernist supremacy of the US—and designed the US
label: Paragraph

text: Consulate of 1954-1956 in Kobe, Japan.
label: Paragraph

text: There he came up with a low-rise grouping of three flat-roofed
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular structures set around a traditional Japanese landscape garden. In
label: Paragraph

text: a nod to the local vernacular, he suspended a contemporary metal
label: Paragraph

text: adaptation of bamboo sudare blinds—which although immobile work well
label: Paragraph

text: to filter daylight—from the projecting upper perimeter of each story. During
label: Paragraph

text: this commission the architect’s exploration of his ancestral homeland
label: Paragraph

text: intensified a growing desire to bring a more spiritual element—“serenity,
label: Paragraph

text: surprise, and delight,” as he put it—to his work.
label: Paragraph

text: In purely formalist terms, however, it is often hard to distinguish
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki’s designs from those of his even more celebrated rival Edward
label: Paragraph

text: Durell Stone, who likewise espoused an approach meant to be more
label: Paragraph

text: visually enticing than the glass-walled boxes of the debased commercial
label: Paragraph

text: version of the late International Style. The main difference between the two
label: Paragraph

text: architects, it now seems, is that Stone wrapped his travertine-clad
label: Paragraph

text: shoeboxes in pierced screens of vaguely Mughal derivation, whereas
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki preferred outer scrims of faux-Gothic appliqués and, later on,
label: Paragraph

text: stylized classical colonnades more familiar to Beverly Hills than to the
label: Paragraph

text: seven hills of Rome. In due course a confusing repetitiveness set in to
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki’s work, and it was hard to tell from their exaggerated but
label: Paragraph

text: superficial surface effects whether the building underneath was a synagogue
label: Paragraph

text: on Chicago’s North Shore or an airport in Dhahran, given how closely the
label: Paragraph

text: Islamo-Gothic facades of those two buildings resembled each other.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1962 Yamasaki completed his most prestigious commission yet: the
label: Paragraph

text: United States Science Pavilion at the Century 21 Exposition, more
label: Caption

text: commonly known as the Seattle World’s Fair. This interconnected cluster of
label: Paragraph

text: six rectangular white pavilions (now called the Pacific Science Center) is
label: Paragraph

text: surfaced with stylized Gothic tracery and hovers above a series of fountain-
label: Paragraph

text: studded reflecting pools interspersed with plazas. Over the ensemble soars a
label: Paragraph

text: freestanding group of five schematic Gothic arches meant to reinforce the
label: Paragraph

text: quasi-religious symbolism of what one commentator has called this “virtual
label: Paragraph

text: cathedral of science.” Yet the architectural hit of the exposition was the
label: Paragraph

text: Space Needle, Edward E. Carlson and John Graham Jr.’s Jetsons-like
label: Paragraph

text: observation tower, then the tallest structure west of the Mississippi. With its
label: Paragraph

text: hipster-futuristic styling—like a flying saucer perched atop a
label: Paragraph

text: hyperelongated tripod—the Space Needle remains a perennial tourist
label: Paragraph

text: attraction, while Yamasaki’s time-warp design evokes a stage set on a 1960s
label: Paragraph

text: Ed Sullivan Show excerpt from Camelot.
label: Caption

text: The acclaim that greeted his Seattle World’s Fair designs, however, led to
label: Paragraph

text: two major high-rise commissions in that city—the IBM Building of 1962-
label: Paragraph

text: 1964 (which proved that even the simplest architectural box can be
label: Paragraph

text: awkwardly proportioned) and the Rainier Bank Tower of 1972-1977, both
label: Paragraph

text: of which, with white exteriors of narrowly spaced vertical ribbing, look
label: Paragraph

text: much like the skyscrapers Stone was producing at the same time, including
label: Paragraph

text: his General Motors Building of 1963-1968 in New York City. Leaving
label: Paragraph

text: aside such oddities as Yamasaki’s US Pavilion of 1958-1959 at the World
label: Paragraph

text: Agricultural Fair in New Delhi—with a sea of gilded onion domes worthy
label: Paragraph

text: of Las Vegas’s Aladdin Hotel—the most bizarre thing he ever created was
label: Paragraph

text: the Rainier Bank Tower. This twenty-nine-story office block is hoisted atop
label: Paragraph

text: an upwardly flaring, windowless eleven-story concrete pedestal that at its
label: Paragraph

text: base is only half the width of the superstructure it supports. Although a tour
label: Paragraph

text: de force of engineering, the precarious-looking building remains deeply
label: Paragraph

text: unsettling, especially in the earthquake-prone Pacific Northwest.
label: Paragraph

text: Thanks to his burgeoning reputation as a skyscraper architect with an
label: Paragraph

text: artistic aura, Yamasaki was an obvious candidate for the most ambitious
label: Paragraph

text: American urban design initiative of the 1960s—the World Trade Center in
label: Paragraph

text: New York City. This was the pet project of David Rockefeller, the president
label: Paragraph

text: of Chase Manhattan Bank, who wanted to shore up the faltering value of his
label: Paragraph

text: family’s Lower Manhattan real estate holdings as financial services firms
label: Title

text: moved from the Wall Street area to midtown or the suburbs. He pursued this
label: Paragraph

text: grandiose scheme, which never had a sound economic rationale, with the
label: Paragraph

text: backing of his older brother, New York governor Nelson Rockefeller, whose
label: Paragraph

text: long tenure in Albany overlapped with most of this fourteen-year
label: Paragraph

text: undertaking (see frontispiece). The state’s chief executive used every power
label: Paragraph

text: at his disposal to push the quixotic endeavor to completion, including the
label: Paragraph

text: involvement of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the bistate
label: Paragraph

text: agency under his political control. The Port Authority had not previously
label: Paragraph

text: been involved in such an enormous real estate speculation, which
label: Paragraph

text: comprised ten million square feet of office space that landed on the market
label: Paragraph

text: with a thud during the worst recession in decades.
label: Paragraph

text: The terrible truth is that Yamasaki’s posthumous reputation would still be
label: Paragraph

text: languishing in obscurity were it not for the disaster of September 11, 2001,
label: Paragraph

text: which propelled him back into the public consciousness for the worst
label: Paragraph

text: possible reason. Whatever one might think about the aesthetics of his
label: Paragraph

text: poorly received World Trade Center project, there is no question that the
label: Paragraph

text: loss of life in the terrorist attack was greatly reduced because of the
label: Paragraph

text: innovative engineering he employed for the Twin Towers. Notwithstanding
label: Paragraph

text: widespread shock that the skyscrapers collapsed with such swiftness—the
label: Paragraph

text: South Tower, the second to be hit, fell after fifty-six minutes, while it took
label: Paragraph

text: 102 minutes for the North Tower to go down—the real miracle was that
label: Paragraph

text: these severely damaged hulks remained standing for as long as they did.
label: Paragraph

text: This allowed an estimated 14,000 to 17,000 people to escape, although
label: Paragraph

text: many were trapped above the stories hit by the planes, where death was
label: Paragraph

text: inevitable because emergency stairways were severed.
label: Paragraph

text: An unavoidable problem of skyscraper design is that the higher a
label: Paragraph

text: structure, the more elevators are needed, thus reducing rentable floor space.
label: Paragraph

text: And in the case of standard steel- or concrete-frame construction, the
label: Paragraph

text: number of extra inner columns needed to strengthen super-tall towers adds
label: Paragraph

text: to the problem. In order to increase the World Trade Center’s cost-
label: Paragraph

text: effectiveness by keeping each story of the towers as free as possible from
label: Paragraph

text: internal barriers—a necessity in commercial real estate by the 1960s, when
label: Paragraph

text: the open-office concept began to take hold—Yamasaki decided on a
label: Paragraph

text: structural system (devised by the Seattle-based engineer John Skilling)
label: Paragraph

text: whereby the buildings’ external walls, made of colossal, hollow steel tubes,
label: Paragraph

text: became the principal load-bearing support, allowing for unusually open
label: Paragraph

text: interiors.
label: Paragraph

text: Had Yamasaki conformed to conventional internal  steel-frame
label: Paragraph

text: techniques, experts concur, the buildings would have snapped upon the
label: Paragraph

text: planes’ collision and collapsed much sooner and farther afield than they
label: Paragraph

text: did, with a significantly higher death toll. Indeed, as James Glanz and Eric
label: Paragraph

text: Lipton write in their authoritative City in the Sky: The Rise and Fall of the
label: Paragraph

text: World Trade Center (2003), an aviation impact study conducted in 1964 to
label: Paragraph

text: gauge how the structures would withstand being crashed into by a Boeing
label: Paragraph

text: 707 had concluded:
label: Paragraph

text: The Skilling firm’s “total concept” would not just give the twin towers
label: Paragraph

text: a huge margin of reserve strength to help them survive the initial
label: Paragraph

text: impact; the peculiarities of their design would let them act almost like
label: Paragraph

text: a living being to resist overall failure and collapse even when
label: Paragraph

text: grievously damaged by the plane.
label: Paragraph

text: In the end, what destroyed the buildings was the conflagration fed by tens
label: Paragraph

text: of thousands of gallons of jet fuel, as was fiendishly projected by the plot’s
label: Paragraph

text: mastermind, Osama bin Laden, who had a degree in civil engineering.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the World Trade Center fully conformed to fire-safety
label: Paragraph

text: standards at the time of its completion, there were misgivings during the
label: Paragraph

text: planning phase about whether the super-wide Vierendeel trusses that
label: Paragraph

text: enabled the open-floor spaces, a new concept at the time, were sufficiently
label: Paragraph

text: fireproofed to withstand such an eventuality. It was the weakening of those
label: Paragraph

text: elegantly elongated supports, which sagged as fire rapidly spread across the
label: Paragraph

text: uncompartmentalized interiors, that caused the Twin Towers’ concrete
label: Paragraph

text: floors to collapse onto one another, after which the outer perimeter gave
label: Paragraph

text: way. By that time Yamasaki had been dead for nearly fifteen years and was
label: Paragraph

text: spared a loss that surely would have been infinitely more painful to him
label: Paragraph

text: than even his unjustly maligned Pruitt-Igoe.
label: Paragraph

text: LINA BO BARDI
label: Title

text: THE ONE HUNDREDTH birthday of an overlooked creative innovator
label: Title

text: sometimes coincides with the revival of a reputation that is already well
label: Paragraph

text: already underway. That was the case with the overdue posthumous
label: Paragraph

text: lionization of the Italian-Brazilian architect Lina Bo Bardi, who was born in
label: Paragraph

text: Rome in 1914 and died in 1992 in her adopted South American home-land
label: Paragraph

text: at the age of seventy-seven. Bo Bardi’s two most important realized
label: Paragraph

text: schemes are in Sdo Paulo—the Museum of Art (1957-1969) and the SESC
label: Paragraph

text: Pompeia, a leisure and cultural center (1977-1986). They are of such
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional quality that one can readily understand why their designer was
label: Paragraph

text: at last accorded a high place in the male-dominated canon, though not why
label: Paragraph

text: these works did not propel her immediately to the front rank of the
label: Paragraph

text: profession during her lifetime. These incontestable masterpieces, omitted
label: Paragraph

text: from general histories of Modern architecture for decades, would not have
label: Paragraph

text: been so long overlooked were they made by a man.
label: Paragraph

text: Intriguingly contradictory but intelligently resolved, Bo Bardi’s designs
label: Paragraph

text: are structurally audacious yet uncommonly comfortable, unapologetically
label: Paragraph

text: untidy yet conceptually rigorous, and confidently dynamic yet suggestively
label: Paragraph

text: hybrid. Although her architecture stands squarely in the Modernist tradition,
label: Paragraph

text: she rejected the aggressively machinelike aesthetic favored by many of her
label: Paragraph

text: male contemporaries, preferring a more relaxed and nuanced vernacular
label: Paragraph

text: approach. However, as her ingenious recycling of a disused factory into the
label: Paragraph

text: Pompeia complex demonstrates, she could also embrace industrialism’s
label: Paragraph

text: authentic manifestations and make them invitingly human. This is high-tech
label: Paragraph

text: that responds to everyday needs and uses modern technical advances to
label: Paragraph

text: serve them, rather than the more typical postindustrial tendency to put
label: Paragraph

text: structural showmanship ahead of all other concerns.
label: Paragraph

text: Some commentators have interpreted Bo Bardi’s belated popularity as a
label: Paragraph

text: reaction against the all-pervasive commercialism, rampant celebrity-
label: Paragraph

text: mongering, and dispiriting lack of social awareness in postmillennial
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. Small wonder that the architect Kazuyo Sejima of the Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: firm SANAA, the director of the 2010 Venice Architecture Biennale,
label: Paragraph

text: organized a concise Bo Bardi retrospective as the centerpiece of that
label: Paragraph

text: prestigious international exhibition. Many viewers felt that Bo Bardi’s
label: Paragraph

text: decades-old designs easily outclassed the sprawling show’s surfeit of eye-
label: Paragraph

text: catching but shallow contemporary offerings.
label: Paragraph

text: Typical of the esteem Bo Bardi now commands is her prominent
label: Paragraph

text: inclusion in Jean-Louis Cohen’s authoritative but revisionist survey The
label: Paragraph

text: Future of Architecture Since 1889 (2012), which features a full-page color
label: Paragraph

text: illustration of Pompeia. She also figures conspicuously in the introduction
label: Paragraph

text: to Kathleen James-Chakraborty’s Architecture Since 1400 (2014), which
label: Paragraph

text: includes two photos of the architect’s residence, the Glass House of 1950-
label: Caption

text: 1951 in Sao Paulo. And in Why We Build: Power and Desire in Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: (2013), the British architecture critic Rowan Moore devotes an entire
label: Paragraph

text: chapter to Bo Bardi, whom he calls “the most underrated architect of the
label: Paragraph

text: twentieth century.” But the most important factor in this newfound
label: Paragraph

text: recognition has been Lina Bo Bardi (2013), the first full-length life-and-
label: Paragraph

text: works, by Zeuler R. M. de A. Lima, an architect and professor at
label: Paragraph

text: Washington University in St. Louis. Lima’s detailed but well-paced
label: Paragraph

text: monograph is a feat of primary-source scholarship and thoughtful analysis
label: Paragraph

text: in which he does a masterful job of candidly assessing his brilliant,
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat erratic, and not always truthful subject. This important
label: Paragraph

text: contribution to the literature will long remain the essential Bo Bardi
label: Paragraph

text: publication.
label: Paragraph

text: Complementing it is Cathrine Veikos’s Lina Bo Bardi: The Theory of
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural Practice (2014), the first English translation of the architect’s
label: Paragraph

text: Propaedeutic Contribution to the Teaching of Architecture Theory (1957),
label: Paragraph

text: the fullest exposition of her design philosophy. (The title’s obscure first
label: Paragraph

text: word means a preliminary introduction to further study.) Bo Bardi’s heavily
label: Paragraph

text: illustrated and footnoted text—similar in format to Robert Venturi’s later
label: Paragraph

text: but far more famous Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture (1966)
label: Paragraph

text: —reveals her deep grounding in the Classical tradition, a product of her
label: Paragraph

text: interwar Roman architectural education. Also like Venturi, she extracts
label: Paragraph

text: applicable contemporary lessons from historical prototypes rather than
label: Paragraph

text: mining them for directly replicable motifs.
label: Paragraph

text: Her analogies are most forcefully advanced through provocative
label: Paragraph

text: juxtapositions of images. She finds Ludwig Mies van der Rohe’s Seagram
label: Paragraph

text: Building in New York a modern counterpart of the Platonically perfect
label: Paragraph

text: proportions Raphael devised for his Church of Sant’Eligio degli Orefici in
label: Paragraph

text: Rome. And in pairing a high-rise fantasy project by the Renaissance
label: Paragraph

text: architect Filarete with a photo of Cass Gilbert’s Woolworth Building in
label: Caption

text: New York, she wonders, “Was [Filarete] anticipating the skyscraper?,” then
label: Paragraph

text: answers her own question by asserting that “in the history of men of genius
label: Paragraph

text: can be found the germs of all anticipations.”
label: Paragraph

text: Stones Against Diamonds, a collection of Bo Bardi’s writings, was issued
label: Paragraph

text: by London’s Architectural Association in 2012. In addition to twenty-two
label: Paragraph

text: articles she wrote in Italy and Brazil, it includes the transcript of her last
label: Paragraph

text: lecture, in which she acknowledges her considerable debt to the British
label: Paragraph

text: scholar Geoffrey Scott’s seminal book The Architecture of Humanism: A
label: Paragraph

text: Study in the History of Taste (1914). Her invocation of this now somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: unfashionable text is typical of her contrarian but principled nature.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout her writings, Bo Bardi’s sardonic wit and argumentative
label: Paragraph

text: personality repeatedly surface, imparting a worldly-wise tone that makes
label: Paragraph

text: Stones Against Diamonds anything but a dry educational treatise. In a
label: Paragraph

text: profession where personal appearance and public presentation matter a
label: Paragraph

text: great deal, Bo Bardi (as her photographs show) might be seen as the Anna
label: Paragraph

text: Magnani of architecture—an earthy, passionate, careworn, chain-smoking,
label: Paragraph

text: impulsively outspoken character fed up with the hypocrisy of polite society.
label: Paragraph

text: One perceptive friend, the publisher and playwright Valentino Bompiani,
label: Paragraph

text: tellingly dubbed her la dea stanca (the tired goddess). A defiant outsider
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility emerges from the architect’s prickly but heartfelt
label: Paragraph

text: pronouncements on the place of architecture in modern society, suffused
label: Paragraph

text: with a certain resignation quite unlike the utopian optimism of the first-
label: Paragraph

text: generation Modernists. Yet even Bo Bardi at her most cynical could not
label: Paragraph

text: have imagined the postmillennial worldwide epidemic of freakishly
label: Paragraph

text: exhibitionistic construction, marketed as advanced artistic vision but often
label: Paragraph

text: devoid of the most basic concern for communal life and environmental
label: Paragraph

text: impact.
label: Paragraph

text: Also clear is her belief that design pedagogy ought to discourage what
label: Paragraph

text: she called “the complex of the individualistic architect”—not as a means of
label: Paragraph

text: stifling personal creativity but “to create a collective consciousness of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in schools, the opposite of an arrogant individualism.” This
label: Paragraph

text: might well be taken as an instinctively feminist stance, given women’s
label: Paragraph

text: known ability to work more cooperatively in professional groups than their
label: Paragraph

text: male counterparts.
label: Paragraph

text: On the other hand, she stubbornly refused to recant her Communist
label: Paragraph

text: affiliations, even after the horrors of the Gulag had been revealed, and like
label: Paragraph

text: many pioneering women in her profession she believed more in personal
label: Paragraph

text: advancement than in solidarity in sisterhood. Thus, in a 1989 lecture, she
label: Paragraph

text: could deliver the pugnacious and off-putting pronouncement that “I am
label: Paragraph

text: Stalinist and anti-feminist.” In fact, her vision of architecture and her actual
label: Paragraph

text: work were anything but Stalinist.
label: Paragraph

text: Why Bo Bardi had been denied her rightful prominence for so long is not
label: Paragraph

text: difficult to explain. Ingrained prejudice against women in the building art
label: Paragraph

text: prevailed throughout most of the twentieth century and still has not been
label: Paragraph

text: fully eradicated. Even the best-remembered female Modernist architects
label: Paragraph

text: who came of professional age during the decade after World War I and just
label: Paragraph

text: before Bo Bardi—Margarete Schiitte-Lihotzky, Lilly Reich, and Charlotte
label: Paragraph

text: Perriand—were customarily assigned interior-design tasks by architectural
label: Paragraph

text: offices headed and largely staffed by men.
label: Paragraph

text: This enforced male/female division of labor remained the norm until the
label: Paragraph

text: end of World War II, when women finally became principals in
label: Paragraph

text: architectural firms, though they were not always acknowledged as such.
label: Paragraph

text: (Natalie de Blois, a former Skidmore, Owings & Merrill partner who died
label: Paragraph

text: in 2013 at ninety-two, was responsible for designs sometimes attributed to
label: Paragraph

text: the firm’s senior designer, Gordon Bunshaft, such as her jewel-like Pepsi-
label: Paragraph

text: Cola Building of 1958-1960 in New York City). The few postwar women
label: Paragraph

text: architects who did receive rightful recognition worked in partnership with
label: Paragraph

text: their husbands, including the British team of Alison and Peter Smithson and
label: Paragraph

text: the American couple Denise Scott Brown and Robert Venturi.
label: Paragraph

text: Achillina di Enrico Bo was born four months after the outbreak of World
label: Paragraph

text: War I to a family who lived in a Roman working-class neighborhood near
label: Paragraph

text: the Vatican. From an early age Lina, as she was known, harbored
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinary, not to say grandiose, ambitions. “I never wanted to be
label: Paragraph

text: young,” she later recalled. “What I really wanted was to have a history. At
label: Paragraph

text: the age of twenty-five, I wanted to write my memoirs, but I didn’t have the
label: Paragraph

text: material.” Like many other women who went on to achieve success in
label: Paragraph

text: male-dominated professions, she identified with her father, a small-time
label: Paragraph

text: building contractor with artistic yearnings. (An amateur painter, he
label: Paragraph

text: befriended Giorgio de Chirico, who did a portrait of the young Lina.) She
label: Paragraph

text: displayed unusual skill at drawing, and in 1930 entered the Liceo Artistico
label: Paragraph

text: di Roma. Upon receiving her degree four years later, she enrolled at the
label: Paragraph

text: Rome School of Architecture, where two professors had a decisive impact
label: Paragraph

text: on her architectural thinking.
label: Paragraph

text: The historian and urban planner Gustavo Giovannoni was a strong
label: Paragraph

text: advocate of ambientismo (contextualism)—designing buildings to fit in
label: Paragraph

text: with their immediate surroundings in scale and material—as well as a
label: Paragraph

text: staunch preservationist. Her other early mentor, Marcello Piacentini, the
label: Paragraph

text: president of the National Fascist Union of Architects, undertook huge
label: Paragraph

text: Stripped Classical commissions for the Mussolini regime that included a
label: Paragraph

text: new campus for the University of Rome and the city’s EUR district
label: Caption

text: (planned for the subsequently aborted 1942 World’s Fair). Especially strong
label: Paragraph

text: was Piacentini’s emphasis on being an architetto totale—a complete
label: Paragraph

text: architect, equally conversant with new construction, restoration of old
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, and city planning (a range Bo Bardi extended even further to
label: Paragraph

text: include the design of interiors, furniture, and jewelry).
label: Paragraph

text: She received her degree in 1939 and then moved to Milan, where the
label: Paragraph

text: progressive design scene was much more drawn to the rationalist ideas of
label: Paragraph

text: the Bauhaus and Le Corbusier than to Mussolini Modernism. Two months
label: Paragraph

text: after her arrival, Italy entered World War II, a time “when nothing was
label: Paragraph

text: built, only destroyed,” as she put it. Bo supported herself during the conflict
label: Paragraph

text: with graphic design and illustration jobs, especially for Lo Stile, a design
label: Paragraph

text: magazine spun off by the architect and industrial designer Gio Ponti from
label: Paragraph

text: his influential journal Domus. In 1946 she married Pietro Maria Bardi, a
label: Paragraph

text: journalist and art dealer fourteen years her senior, who had cultivated strong
label: Paragraph

text: ties to Mussolini. As Zeuler Lima points out, there is no evidence to support
label: Paragraph

text: her claim that she had worked with the anti-Fascist resistance, and although
label: Paragraph

text: she aligned herself with the Communist Party after 1943, her close
label: Paragraph

text: association with Ponti—whose early support for Mussolini has been
label: Paragraph

text: rationalized by apologists as more patriotic than ideological—impelled the
label: Paragraph

text: newly married couple to quit Italy when the Communists gained
label: Paragraph

text: ascendance in the first post-war elections.
label: Paragraph

text: Pietro Bardi already had connections in Brazil, where he traveled in 1934
label: Paragraph

text: to sell art to prosperous Italian expatriates. With his dismal postwar
label: Paragraph

text: prospects in Italy, friends in Rome’s Brazilian embassy set up a series of
label: Paragraph

text: commercial exhibitions for him in Rio de Janeiro. There he attracted the
label: Paragraph

text: attention of the culturally ambitious press magnate Assis Chateaubriand
label: Paragraph

text: (known as Chatd), who wanted to foster a Brazilian arts scene
label: Paragraph

text: commensurate with the country’s increasing international identity as a
label: Paragraph

text: major center of modern architecture, an emergence signaled by “Brazil
label: Paragraph

text: Builds: Architecture New and Old, 1652-1942,” a popular exhibition held
label: Paragraph

text: at New York’s Museum of Modern Art in 1943.
label: Caption

text: Bo Bardi, who had yet to build anything, received a chilly reception from
label: Paragraph

text: the leading figures of the country’s architectural avant-garde. Lucio Costa
label: Paragraph

text: told her, “You’re so dull, so many drawings,” while his colleague Oscar
label: Paragraph

text: Niemeyer averred that “Europeans make things seem too complicated.” Yet
label: Paragraph

text: she contradicted both those competitive put-downs with her first completed
label: Paragraph

text: work, the Casa de Vidro (Glass House), the sublimely simple yet
label: Paragraph

text: uncommonly elegant residence she created for herself and her husband in
label: Paragraph

text: Sdo Paulo. Not the least interesting aspect of this rectangular Minimalist
label: Paragraph

text: structure with transparent peripheral walls is its close relation to two more
label: Paragraph

text: renowned contemporaneous domestic designs: Mies van der Rohe’s
label: Paragraph

text: Farnsworth house of 1945-1951 in Plano, Illinois, and Philip Johnson’s
label: Caption

text: Glass House of 1949-1950 in New Canaan, Connecticut. Yet the
label: Paragraph

text: considerable differences among this trio of glass houses tell us a great deal
label: Paragraph

text: about why Bo Bardi has gained such an ardent postmillennial following.
label: Paragraph

text: The much-vaunted intention of Mies’s and Johnson’s inhabitable glass
label: Paragraph

text: vitrines was to make interiors at one with nature. Johnson referred to the
label: Paragraph

text: sylvan views from his Glass House as “the world’s most expensive
label: Paragraph

text: wallpaper,” but as often happened with this self-critical nihilist, his
label: Paragraph

text: wisecrack contained a kernel of harsh truth. Both his and Mies’s shoebox-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped structures present themselves as industrially made objects, but they
label: Paragraph

text: were in fact exquisitely custom-crafted villas for the rich. The Casa de
label: Paragraph

text: Vidro is much like the Mies and Johnson houses (all are more or less flat-
label: Paragraph

text: topped, though the roof of the Brazilian version inclines slightly downward
label: Paragraph

text: from a center ridge for rain run-off). However, Bo Bardi’s house differs
label: Paragraph

text: from the others in being sited on a steep hillside, to say nothing of being
label: Paragraph

text: considerably more economical than its expensively detailed American
label: Paragraph

text: analogs. And the underlying concrete slab of the Sao Paulo residence is
label: Paragraph

text: elevated on a series of tall, thin aluminum poles, with the structure fully
label: Paragraph

text: touching the earth only at the uppermost, rear portion of the slope.
label: Paragraph

text: This was the first building to be erected in a newly developed residential
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhood, and completion photos depict a rather barren setting
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of the Hollywood Hills. Indeed, Bo Bardi’s lightweight, open-
label: Paragraph

text: to-the-outdoors design, framed in thin members of white-painted metal,
label: Paragraph

text: brings to mind the experimental Case Study Houses of the late 1940s and
label: Paragraph

text: early 1950s in Southern California. Yet just a few years after its
label: Paragraph

text: construction, the Casa de Vidro was engulfed in a lush tangle of greenery,
label: Paragraph

text: and it now feels like a subtropical tree house.
label: Paragraph

text: Bo Bardi’s populist outlook was antithetical to the grandiose vision
label: Paragraph

text: realized in the Brazilian heartland by Costa and Niemeyer—the former’s
label: Paragraph

text: urban plan and the latter’s principal structures for Brasilia, the start-from-
label: Paragraph

text: scratch capital city decreed by President Juscelino Kubitschek de Oliveira
label: Paragraph

text: in 1956 and essentially completed within his five-year term of office.
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas Bo Bardi was immediately taken by her new country’s
label: Paragraph

text: multicultural folkloric traditions and multiracial vernacular culture, her
label: Paragraph

text: best-known Brazilian coprofessionals were much more concerned with how
label: Paragraph

text: to recast an essentially European Baroque monumentality in High
label: Paragraph

text: Modernist terms.
label: Paragraph

text: Furthermore, the creators of Brasilia paid scant attention to the housing
label: Paragraph

text: and transportation needs of the sizable labor force needed to serve the
label: Paragraph

text: capital city’s bureaucracy. These omissions resulted in a host of messy ad
label: Paragraph

text: hoc stopgaps by local residents to correct Costa and Niemeyer’s enormous
label: Paragraph

text: functional lapses. Bo Bardi was one of the few contemporary critics of
label: Paragraph

text: these architectural stars, and certainly the most insightful. In 1958, just as
label: Paragraph

text: construction of Brasilia was getting underway, she wrote “architecture or
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture’—a short, urgent warning about the disturbing direction
label: Paragraph

text: Niemeyer’s schemes were taking, away from his smaller early works (today
label: Paragraph

text: his most admired designs) and toward the megalomaniacal scale typified by
label: Paragraph

text: the new city’s flying saucer—like parliament building:
label: Paragraph

text: More than the buildings of Brasilia—which, according to Niemeyer
label: Paragraph

text: himself, are irreproachable in their conception and purity—we like the
label: Paragraph

text: church in Pampulha and the house in Vassouras, which have attracted
label: Paragraph

text: international attention on account of their simplicity, their human
label: Paragraph

text: proportions, the modest and poetic expression of a life that rejects that
label: Paragraph

text: very despondency, that struggle between social needs and architecture
label: Paragraph

text: —the struggle that Niemeyer claims to have overcome by setting out,
label: Paragraph

text: as the aim of his architecture, a formal position that denies all human
label: Paragraph

text: values. ...
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast, Bo Bardi found ways to combine the large dimensions
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate to the public sphere with an intimate scale that gives the users
label: Paragraph

text: of her buildings a sense of both individual presence and group connection
label: Paragraph

text: that Niemeyer was generally unable to achieve in his works from Brasilia
label: Paragraph

text: onward, when colossal geometric formalism became his overriding
label: Paragraph

text: principle. An unlikely, but in her hands fully integrated balance between the
label: Paragraph

text: monumental and the personal was achieved with striking imagination in the
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Art of SAo Paulo (MASP), an institution founded in 1947 by
label: Paragraph

text: Chat6, directed by Pietro Bardi, and during its first decade housed in
label: Paragraph

text: temporary display spaces designed by his wife within existing structures.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the Bardis’ beliefs was that pictures ought not to be hung on a
label: Paragraph

text: wall like bourgeois decorative elements but instead displayed on
label: Paragraph

text: freestanding easels that give a closer idea of their means of production.
label: Paragraph

text: Thanks to Chatd’s strong-arm acquisition tactics—the unscrupulous
label: Paragraph

text: publisher, who has been called the Brazilian Citizen Kane, blackmailed
label: Paragraph

text: prominent figures with threats of newspaper exposés in returm for
label: Paragraph

text: “donations” of cash and art to his new museum—Pietro Bardi was able to
label: Paragraph

text: quickly assemble what at that time was the most important public art
label: Paragraph

text: collection in South America with works, for example, by Manet, Cézanne,
label: Paragraph

text: and Van Gogh.
label: Paragraph

text: MASP offered a revolutionary rethinking of the art museum and was the
label: Paragraph

text: embodiment of the Bardis’ belief in architecture as a prime agent for social
label: Paragraph

text: cohesion rather than aesthetic self-indulgence or a benefactor’s status. Their
label: Paragraph

text: innovative ideas about the museum as an educational institution responsive
label: Paragraph

text: to the public and not just a repository of precious objects were reflected in
label: Paragraph

text: Bo Bardi’s equally inventive design solutions for welcoming entry areas,
label: Paragraph

text: flexible exhibition spaces, and a casual atmosphere that emphasized art as a
label: Paragraph

text: pleasure for everyone, not just an informed elite. To be sure, Edward Durell
label: Paragraph

text: Stone and Philip L. Goodwin’s Museum of Modern Art of 1936-1939 in
label: Paragraph

text: New York had already made a notable departure from the formality and
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality of traditional Beaux Arts gallery design and toward a
label: Paragraph

text: relaxed domestic scale that reminded twentieth-century New Yorkers more
label: Paragraph

text: of their apartments than of princely palaces. But MASP took such
label: Paragraph

text: democratic notions even further, though its architectonic presence is
label: Paragraph

text: anything but recessive.
label: Paragraph

text: In an unexecuted 1952 scheme for a museum at the seashore (illustrated
label: Paragraph

text: on the cover of Habitat, the influential art-and-design magazine the Bardis
label: Caption

text: founded), Bo Bardi devised an elongated shoebox form that would have
label: Paragraph

text: been hoisted one story above the ground by four inverted, squared-off U-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped trusses of red-painted steel clamped across the gallery enclosure’s
label: Paragraph

text: narrower dimension. In a further refinement of that unusual format, MASP
label: Paragraph

text: is an even bolder feat of engineering, with just two gigantic red-painted
label: Paragraph

text: steel trusses that span and support the two-story glass-walled gallery
label: Caption

text: container longitudinally rather than laterally (see Illustration 13a). The
label: Paragraph

text: configuration provides two urbanistic benefits: it elevates the museum
label: Paragraph

text: above the busy vehicular traffic streets that flank it to the north and south,
label: Paragraph

text: and the underside of the building creates a roof for the open-sided gathering
label: Paragraph

text: place at ground level. This large outdoor space, protected from sudden
label: Paragraph

text: tropical downpours, is used for public events of all sorts, and remains one
label: Paragraph

text: of Séo Paulo’s most memorable modern civic venues.
label: Paragraph

text: The open-plan exhibition areas suspended above this plaza were
label: Paragraph

text: conceived to be optimally adaptable for various kinds of art, with
label: Paragraph

text: interchangeable partitions and freestanding display elements. Curators were
label: Paragraph

text: thereby encouraged to rethink visitors’ progression through exhibitions,
label: Paragraph

text: which in conventional institutions with fixed walls allows little or no
label: Paragraph

text: deviation from a strictly imposed route. The wide-ranging possibilities here
label: Paragraph

text: give an entirely different character to the art-viewing experience, and the
label: Paragraph

text: MASP approach is now standard practice at contemporary art institutions,
label: Paragraph

text: especially because the unpredictable display requirements for today’s large
label: Paragraph

text: installation pieces, video art, and other nontraditional mediums—so
label: Paragraph

text: different from even the most advanced painting and sculpture of the Bardis’
label: Paragraph

text: heyday—have made easily transformable interiors mandatory.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the ground-level public space of MASP functions wonderfully
label: Paragraph

text: as a social condenser, it is surpassed in that respect by Bo Bardi’s final
label: Paragraph

text: major work, the SESC Pompeia leisure center. Many early Modernists,
label: Paragraph

text: most conspicuously Le Corbusier and Walter Gropius, admired the no-
label: Paragraph

text: nonsense functionalist aesthetic of late-nineteenth- and early-twentieth-
label: Paragraph

text: century industrial structures. In homage, they designed schools, cultural
label: Paragraph

text: institutions, and residences that closely resembled utilitarian construction
label: Paragraph

text: (signified by Le Corbusier’s famous definition of the house as “a machine
label: Paragraph

text: for living in”). By the 1970s this practice had become so accepted that
label: Paragraph

text: forward-thinking architects and their patrons decided to convert actual
label: Paragraph

text: factories and warehouses into museums, theaters, and other arts facilities
label: Paragraph

text: rather than trying to replicate the industrial look from scratch.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1971, Brazil’s Servigo Social de Comércio (SESC, the public outreach
label: Paragraph

text: arm of the country’s trade organizations, established to quell unrest among
label: Paragraph

text: laborers) acquired an obsolete 1938 steel-barrel factory in a working-class
label: Paragraph

text: Sdo Paulo quarter for a community center (see Illustration 13b). SESC
label: Paragraph

text: originally planned to tear down the prefabricated, reinforced-concrete
label: Paragraph

text: structure to make way for a new building. But the recent and much-
label: Paragraph

text: publicized success of San Francisco’s Ghirardelli Square of 1962—1965—an
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned chocolate factory that the architect William Wurster and the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape architect Lawrence Halprin reconceived as a retail-and-restaurant
label: Paragraph

text: complex and became a major tourist attraction—prompted the decision to
label: Paragraph

text: retain the existing Sdo Paulo structure.
label: Paragraph

text: Because it had already been temporarily retrofitted and clearly worked
label: Paragraph

text: well as a neighborhood gathering place, Bo Bardi advised that this fine
label: Paragraph

text: example of industrial architecture (based on the pioneering structural
label: Paragraph

text: concepts of the French engineer Francois Hennebique) merely be tidied up
label: Paragraph

text: and preserved. Into that imposing shell—dominated by soaring concrete
label: Paragraph

text: volumes that bring to mind the monumental Brutalism of Louis Kahn—she
label: Paragraph

text: inserted her comprehensive series of domestically scaled innovations, each
label: Paragraph

text: fulfilling a specific function.
label: Paragraph

text: These included everything from her colorful and tactile interior and
label: Paragraph

text: furniture designs to her programming for exhibitions and performances. In
label: Paragraph

text: her egalitarian view of art, both high art and popular culture were presented
label: Paragraph

text: without hierarchical distinctions in the center’s flexible display galleries. A
label: Paragraph

text: wide range of educational and vocational activities are still offered in
label: Paragraph

text: classrooms and a library, but there is also a full array of sports facilities
label: Paragraph

text: (including a swimming pool), areas where people can play games, meet
label: Paragraph

text: friends, and socialize in a variety of ways, as well as a theater and a
label: Paragraph

text: community lunch restaurant that at night becomes a beer garden. As Zeuler
label: Paragraph

text: Lima writes:
label: Paragraph

text: SESC Pompeia offered a concrete example of one of Bo Bardi’s main
label: Paragraph

text: pursuits: to show that “culture is a fact of everyday reality,’ not a
label: Paragraph

text: special event or even the domain of the educated elite... . [She]
label: Paragraph

text: imagined it, as many in the center’s staff still do, as an antidote to
label: Paragraph

text: consumer society and a space for human imagination and shared
label: Title

text: participation.
label: Paragraph

text: With the Pompeia commission, Bo Bardi cut out the middleman, as it
label: Paragraph

text: were, by adapting an old factory while preserving its gritty character. This
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable advance in architectural thinking anticipated the widespread
label: Paragraph

text: vogue for recycling former industrial facilities into exhibition galleries,
label: Paragraph

text: epitomized by Richard Gluckman’s transformation of a warehouse into the
label: Paragraph

text: Dia Center for the Arts in New York (1987) and Jacques Herzog and Pierre
label: Paragraph

text: de Meuron’s conversion of London’s Bankside Power Station into the Tate
label: Title

text: Modern (1995-2000). Furthermore, Bo Bardi’s celebration of her design’s
label: Paragraph

text: workaday origins and its overwhelmingly warm reception make it a direct
label: Paragraph

text: antecedent of New York City’s post-millennial public-works wonder, the
label: Paragraph

text: High Line (2003-2014), which likewise turned derelict infrastructure into
label: Paragraph

text: an instantly beloved community treasure.
label: Paragraph

text: On the cover of Zeuler Lima’s splendid study is an image that perfectly
label: Paragraph

text: sums up what might be called the Bo Bardi Touch. This black-and-white
label: Paragraph

text: photographic detail shows an irregular opening cut into a concrete wall of
label: Paragraph

text: the architect’s Teatro Gregério de Matos of 1986-1987 in the Brazilian city
label: Paragraph

text: of Salvador (one of nine theaters she designed). Instead of the geometric
label: Paragraph

text: precision associated with the Bauhaus, this amoeboid aperture—which she
label: Paragraph

text: called a fustella (perforation punch, in Italian)—brings to mind a rougher
label: Paragraph

text: version of the free-form outlines of Alvar Aalto’s biomorphic Savoy Vase
label: Caption

text: (1936). Executed with the nonchalant facture typical of Bo Bardi, this
label: Paragraph

text: unruly form reminds us that she much preferred to focus on how
label: Paragraph

text: architecture feels rather than the way it looks. Robert Venturi famously
label: Paragraph

text: wrote, “I am for messy vitality over obvious unity,” and in that same spirit
label: Paragraph

text: the designs of Lina Bo Bardi exert a vivifying and unifying effect that
label: Paragraph

text: architecture can impart only when the need for a better social life is
label: Paragraph

text: genuinely important to the architect’s imagination.
