text: FREI OTTO
label: Title

text: FEW ARTISTS CAN be said to have fundamentally reshaped the basic nature of
label: Paragraph

text: their medium, as did James Joyce by supplanting the linear narrative of the
label: Paragraph

text: conventional novel with a swirling stream of consciousness, or Wassily
label: Paragraph

text: Kandinsky by expanding painting from the depiction of realistic scenes to
label: Paragraph

text: an abstract evocation of inward emotions, or Alexander Calder by
label: Paragraph

text: transforming sculpture from a static earthbound mass into a kinetic object
label: Paragraph

text: floating through space. Thus although twentieth-century architecture was
label: Paragraph

text: replete with countless innovations in structure and materials, none of its
label: Paragraph

text: practitioners rethought the very basics of construction and presented an
label: Paragraph

text: alternative to millennia of received design concepts more successfully than
label: Paragraph

text: the German architect and engineer Frei Otto.
label: Paragraph

text: During his heyday in the 1960s and 1970s, Otto had an enormous
label: Paragraph

text: influence on younger architects who followed his example and thought
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the repetitive shoebox forms that dominated postwar commercial
label: Paragraph

text: design. Otto’s great contribution was the modern tensile tent, its exterior
label: Paragraph

text: made from synthetic materials reinforced with metal mesh, unlike its cloth
label: Paragraph

text: antecedents. Perfected in the 1950s and brought to worldwide attention
label: Paragraph

text: during the next two decades, Otto’s ideas have since become so pervasive
label: Paragraph

text: that the advances he pioneered are now perceived as a generic development
label: Paragraph

text: rather than attributable to a single person, which has contributed to amnesia
label: Paragraph

text: about his central place in twentieth-century architectural history.
label: Paragraph

text: Otto’s hallmark inventions—lightweight tensile and membrane canopies
label: Paragraph

text: that can shelter large areas both economically and beautifully—were no pie-
label: Paragraph

text: in-the-sky visionary proposals like those of so many of his avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: contemporaries. Instead, these eminently practical schemes offered
label: Paragraph

text: imaginative solutions to real problems, but also pointed the way to freer
label: Paragraph

text: attitudes that would flourish, though with very mixed results, toward the
label: Paragraph

text: end of the millennium. In his 1996 essay “Architektur Natur,” Otto
label: Paragraph

text: provocatively asserted that all architects can be assigned to one of three
label: Paragraph

text: categories: “Arrangeur, Diebe und Erfinder” (arrangers, thieves, and
label: Paragraph

text: inventors). By arrangers he clearly meant those who merely manipulate
label: Paragraph

text: known forms into other configurations, while of course the thieves even
label: Paragraph

text: more expeditiously steal the ideas of others. And given the countless
label: Paragraph

text: uncredited knockoffs of his designs he surely must have considered the
label: Paragraph

text: second group as the most numerous.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet to the end of his life Otto remained remarkably modest about his own
label: Paragraph

text: achievements, and when he was informed that he was about to be given the
label: Paragraph

text: Pritzker Architecture Prize at the age of eighty-nine, he averred that “I have
label: Paragraph

text: never done anything to gain this prize.” Others demurred, and if he would
label: Paragraph

text: not explicitly describe himself as an inventor, his most knowledgeable and
label: Paragraph

text: accomplished colleagues certainly would. He was known to be
label: Paragraph

text: exceptionally generous in stressing the broadly collaborative nature of the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural process in a profession where many design principals arrogate
label: Paragraph

text: a disproportionate amount of credit for themselves. The brilliant Irish
label: Paragraph

text: structural engineer Peter Rice (1935—-1992)—who worked closely with Otto
label: Paragraph

text: but is now perhaps best remembered for his louvered ceiling light-filtering
label: Paragraph

text: system at Renzo Piano’s Menil Collection of 1982-1986 in Houston—
label: Paragraph

text: placed Otto firmly among the Erfinder when in his book An Engineer
label: Paragraph

text: Imagines (1994) he likened him to the British Victorian mechanical and
label: Paragraph

text: civil engineer Isambard Kingdom Brunel, the innovative builder of bridges,
label: Paragraph

text: tunnels, railways, and ships at the apogee of the Industrial Revolution:
label: Paragraph

text: Think of the way Brunel worked and the kind of things he did, the
label: Paragraph

text: broad range of activities he covered. He must have worked similarly to
label: Paragraph

text: Frei. Frei uses intuition backed up by physics rather than mathematics.
label: Paragraph

text: He has a strong physical sense. . .. We should call him an inventor.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike Brunel, however, Otto’s commissions were not always prompted
label: Paragraph

text: by social movements of the highest import, which may have something to
label: Paragraph

text: do with why his reputation is not stronger today. For example, in 1977 he
label: Paragraph

text: devised a system of upwardly flaring, umbrellalike stage canopies of white
label: Paragraph

text: fabric for the British rock band Pink Floyd’s In the Flesh international
label: Caption

text: concert tour. Easily dismantled and moved from one performance venue to
label: Paragraph

text: the next, Otto’s sheltering design gave the impression of a field of Art
label: Paragraph

text: Nouveau flowers and represented a degree of visual artistic seriousness
label: Paragraph

text: rarely equaled in the world of rock and roll, but still, it was only rock and
label: Paragraph

text: roll.
label: Paragraph

text: By the time Otto died, in 2017, less than three months shy of his ninetieth
label: Paragraph

text: birthday, he had become a virtually forgotten figure among the general
label: Paragraph

text: public, and even architectural devotees could be forgiven for thinking that
label: Paragraph

text: he had expired years earlier. This was largely owed to his having executed
label: Paragraph

text: very few projects during his last decades, and his path-breaking schemes
label: Paragraph

text: had long been eclipsed by far more dramatic structures made possible by
label: Paragraph

text: computer-aided design, which was in its infancy during his creative prime.
label: Paragraph

text: Otto’s most conspicuous late-career effort was his collaboration with the
label: Paragraph

text: much-younger Shigeru Ban (a major exponent of variations on the
label: Paragraph

text: German’s lightweight structures, though often made of more low-tech
label: Paragraph

text: materials) for the Japanese pavilion of 1997-1999 at Expo 2000 in
label: Paragraph

text: Hannover, Germany. This approximately oblong, clear-span exhibition hall
label: Caption

text: was overarched by an undulating latticed roof composed of reinforced
label: Paragraph

text: cardboard tubes (a Ban signature). It swelled upward in three equal
label: Paragraph

text: segments and evoked the buoyant biomporphic spirit of Otto’s work of a
label: Paragraph

text: half-century before, while reconfirming his strong effect on successive
label: Paragraph

text: generations of followers.
label: Paragraph

text: Frei Paul Otto was born in 1925 near Chemnitz in Saxony but grew up in
label: Paragraph

text: Berlin. His uncommon first name—which means “free” in German and was
label: Paragraph

text: his mother’s personal motto—reflected the liberal values of his idealistic
label: Paragraph

text: parents, members of the Deutscher Werkbund (German Work Federation), a
label: Paragraph

text: social reform group that promoted, among other causes, decent modem
label: Paragraph

text: housing for all, educating the public in principles of good design, and closer
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration between craftsmen and industry. Otto’s father and grandfather
label: Paragraph

text: were both sculptors engaged primarily in carving gravestones, and it was
label: Paragraph

text: expected that young Frei would follow them in the family business. A
label: Paragraph

text: teacher at his vocational school introduced the teenaged Otto to sail gliding
label: Paragraph

text: —then a popular sport in the flat, lake-studded terrain around Berlin—
label: Paragraph

text: which shaped his fascination for lightweight structures. He also showed an
label: Paragraph

text: unusual aptitude for making models, and it was decided that he was talented
label: Paragraph

text: enough to merit training as a master builder.
label: Paragraph

text: He commenced his architectural studies at the Technische Hochschule
label: Paragraph

text: Berlin in 1943, but soon afterward he was conscripted into the Luftwaffe
label: Paragraph

text: because of his expertise in amateur aviation, a fortunate assignment at a
label: Paragraph

text: time when German ground forces were being decimated on the Eastern
label: Paragraph

text: Front. Captured by the Allies, he was incarcerated for two years in France
label: Paragraph

text: near Chartres, during which he served as a prison-camp architect, a position
label: Paragraph

text: that forced him to address the most basic function of architecture—cover
label: Paragraph

text: from the elements—which under wartime circumstances had to be provided
label: Paragraph

text: quickly, economically, and improvisationally, requirements that would
label: Paragraph

text: establish Otto’s principal priorities and define them thereafter. He later
label: Paragraph

text: explained that the daily sight of the spires of Chartres Cathedral inspired
label: Paragraph

text: him to devise the tented structures that offered the most immediate solution
label: Paragraph

text: to the need for shelter in the camp.
label: Paragraph

text: After his release, he resumed his education at his old school (which had
label: Paragraph

text: been renamed the Technische Universitat Berlin) and confronted the central
label: Paragraph

text: challenge of his emergent generation of German architects: how to create
label: Title

text: large-scale buildings that avoided any taint of Nazi design, which was
label: Paragraph

text: typified by a ponderous, ornamentally stripped Classicism rendered in
label: Paragraph

text: heavy materials, particularly stone. Otto’s familiarity with aeronautical
label: Paragraph

text: engineering led him to devise a diametric alternative to that forbidden
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality. He began to experiment with ultralightweight forms that
label: Paragraph

text: derived from thin-membrane airplane parts made from reinforced fabric, the
label: Paragraph

text: antithesis of the crushing mass favored by Hitler and his chief architectural
label: Paragraph

text: henchman, Albert Speer.
label: Caption

text: In 1950 Otto won a travel stipend that allowed him to visit the United
label: Paragraph

text: States for six months, where with remarkable self-confidence for a twenty-
label: Paragraph

text: five-year-old he gained introductions to several of the loftiest pioneers of
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture, then in the final phases of their careers, including
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright, Erich Mendelsohn, Richard Neutra, and Ludwig Mies
label: Title

text: van der Rohe. In due course he became particularly close to Mies, to the
label: Paragraph

text: extent that when the aged master was building his Neue Nationalgalerie of
label: Paragraph

text: 1965-1968 in Berlin, he turned to Otto for advice on the museum’s
label: Paragraph

text: unusually large free-span roof, whereupon the younger architecture
label: Paragraph

text: suggested an elegant correction to calculations that allowed for fewer and
label: Paragraph

text: less-conspicuous interior supports. This successful recommendation
label: Paragraph

text: reflected Otto’s equal authority as both an engineer and an architect, a rare
label: Paragraph

text: combination in that many master builders must collaborate with structural
label: Paragraph

text: consultants to determine if what they have designed will actually stand up,
label: Paragraph

text: as did Louis Kahn with his indispensable engineering adviser, August
label: Paragraph

text: Komendant.
label: Paragraph

text: One of Otto’s earliest public successes was the gossamer-light dance
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion he designed in 1957 for the Federal Garden Exhibition in Cologne,
label: Paragraph

text: a five-peaked, mast-supported, white-fabric canopy in the highly stylized
label: Caption

text: shape of an exotic bloom, which nicely evoked the botanical theme of the
label: Paragraph

text: event. This scheme was in effect a sketch for his much larger essays in this
label: Paragraph

text: same mode over the years to come, for although not all architectural ideas
label: Paragraph

text: first essayed in small dimensions can be successfully enlarged, Otto’s could,
label: Paragraph

text: almost without exception. Furthermore, in contrast to many of his
label: Paragraph

text: contemporaries, he rejected the Neoprimitive Brutalist aesthetic favored by
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier after World War II, as well as the widespread New Brutalism
label: Paragraph

text: that followed it. Otto’s organic approach was much more like that of Antoni
label: Paragraph

text: Gaudi, whose extensive research into naturally occurring structures was
label: Paragraph

text: likewise the basis for startlingly new architectural forms that appear
label: Paragraph

text: deceptively delicate yet possess the power of industrial elements. Otto took
label: Paragraph

text: his cues from phenomena such as the way soap film spans a gap with
label: Paragraph

text: maximum efficiency or the extraordinary tensile strength displayed by
label: Paragraph

text: fragile-looking but in fact quite resilient spiderwebs.

text: In order to advance his theories and apply them to a wider variety of
label: Paragraph

text: uses, in 1964 Otto founded his think tank-cum-studio, the Institut ftir leichte
label: Paragraph

text: Flachentragwerke (Institute for Lightweight Structures), at the University of
label: Paragraph

text: Stuttgart. It, and his professional office, Atelier Frei Otto, located in the
label: Paragraph

text: small town of Warmbronn west of Stuttgart—became the central vehicles
label: Paragraph

text: for developing his ideas and the training grounds for several generations of
label: Paragraph

text: followers who disseminated his concepts internationally. Among the latter
label: Paragraph

text: is Otto’s frequent collaborator Mahmoud Bodo Rasch, who developed a
label: Paragraph

text: thriving practice in the Middle East, where his tented coverings and large
label: Paragraph

text: retractable umbrellas have been widely used for shading outdoor public
label: Paragraph

text: spaces, especially at religious pilgrimage sites.
label: Paragraph

text: Otto felt a special kinship with his three-decade-older American
label: Paragraph

text: counterpart R. Buckminster Fuller, a fellow enthusiast of lightweight
label: Paragraph

text: structures and the father of the geodesic dome, his greatest structural
label: Paragraph

text: innovation. The self-aggrandizing fabulist Fuller and the self-effacing
label: Paragraph

text: moralist Otto could not have been more different personally, but their
label: Paragraph

text: ingenious designs shared similar limitations. Though both were widely
label: Paragraph

text: promoted as panaceas for a host of architectural tasks, Fuller’s domes and
label: Paragraph

text: Otto’s tents were essentially roofing systems. Despite those structures’
label: Paragraph

text: ability to economically shelter an interior, it was much trickier to subdivide
label: Paragraph

text: their internal volumes for specific functional purposes, a drawback that
label: Paragraph

text: inhibited their wider acceptance.
label: Paragraph

text: The curvature of a geodesic structure renders space around its inner
label: Paragraph

text: periphery almost useless for at least several feet as it meets the ground,
label: Paragraph

text: while the center of a dome of substantial size is often higher than required
label: Paragraph

text: except for purely structural reasons. Similarly, a large tensile tent must be
label: Paragraph

text: suspended from vertical supports that can disrupt an internal expanse, and
label: Paragraph

text: the problem of how the roof turns into a wall was often inadequately
label: Paragraph

text: resolved.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 1960s, after a decade of designing increasingly large, more
label: Paragraph

text: complex tents for trade shows and outdoor stages in several German and
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss cities, Otto received two high-profile, career-defining commissions.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps aware that no German architect of the postwar period had yet
label: Paragraph

text: achieved the international renown achieved by such celebrated figures as
label: Paragraph

text: Mies, Mendelsohn, and Walter Gropius, the West German government
label: Title

text: asked him to design both its display at Expo 67, the Montreal world’s fair
label: Paragraph

text: (see Illustration 14a), and a vast multistructure complex for the 1972
label: Paragraph

text: Olympics in Munich. Together, Otto’s eye-catching experiments made his
label: Paragraph

text: international reputation, as well as that of his engineering associate Jérg
label: Paragraph

text: Schlaich. What appears even more impressive in hindsight is that until the
label: Paragraph

text: early 1970s, Otto created his structures without the benefit of today’s
label: Paragraph

text: sophisticated software, and instead worked out the complicated dynamics of
label: Paragraph

text: each effort with costly, labor-intensive study models.
label: Paragraph

text: His German Pavilion at the Montreal exposition caused a sensation, not
label: Paragraph

text: least because its swooping profile had a decidedly Romantic air to it, quite
label: Paragraph

text: different from the undisputed architectural hit of the fair, Habitat 67, by the
label: Paragraph

text: Israeli-born Canadian Moshe Safdie. This 146-unit housing complex, which
label: Paragraph

text: resembles a pileup of Lego blocks, was rightly praised for its refreshing
label: Paragraph

text: combination of sculptural power (the result of the architect’s skillful
label: Paragraph

text: composition of 348 identical prefabricated concrete modules), his
label: Paragraph

text: commitment to humane scale, and his welcome departure from the
label: Paragraph

text: predominance of the monolithic high-rise postwar apartment block as
label: Paragraph

text: defined by Le Corbusier’s Unité d’ Habitation. In contrast to this pragmatic
label: Paragraph

text: paradigm of multiunit housing, Otto’s ethereal, high-masted, peak-roofed
label: Paragraph

text: German Pavilion was the stuff of fairy-tale visions. One can thus
label: Paragraph

text: understand his disclaimer, delivered when he was honored with an
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition in Munich on the occasion of his eightieth birthday, that “Ich
label: Paragraph

text: habe wenig gebaut. Ich habe viele Luftschlésser ersonnen.” (I have built
label: Paragraph

text: little. | have dreamed up many castles in the air.)
label: Paragraph

text: That same feeling permeated his Olympic scheme five years later. I was
label: Paragraph

text: in Munich during the 1972 games and still recall the thrilling effect of
label: Paragraph

text: dappled sunlight that filtered through the translucent fabric overhead as one
label: Paragraph

text: walked through the curving sequence of exhibition and refreshment tents
label: Paragraph

text: that snaked around the Olympic Stadium. (For this commission, Schlaich
label: Paragraph

text: invented a new set of computer analysis tools to execute Otto’s design, a
label: Paragraph

text: historic first in the profession.) Otto’s next major commission—which
label: Paragraph

text: along with Montreal and Munich comprise his three most significant
label: Paragraph

text: projects—was the Manheim Multihalle of 1970-1975, an exhibition center
label: Paragraph

text: most notable for its sinuous wood-lath latticed roof. The American
label: Paragraph

text: structural engineer Guy Nordenson, peerless in his ability to clearly explain
label: Paragraph

text: the work of his coprofessionals to a lay audience, described Otto’s great trio
label: Paragraph

text: in almost poetic terms in this excerpt from his obituary of the German
label: Paragraph

text: master for Artforum:
label: Title

text: Despite their rational origin in the minimal surfaces of mathematics
label: Paragraph

text: (famously explored through soap-film models) the Montreal, Munich,
label: Paragraph

text: and Mannheim roofs are exquisite forms that hover somewhere
label: Paragraph

text: between landscape and cloud, their airy, immaterial structures belying
label: Paragraph

text: their size. ...
label: Paragraph

text: The composition of these structures—the tilt of the masts, the varied
label: Paragraph

text: sizes and extent of the webs of cable or wood lath—have the inevitable
label: Paragraph

text: quality of the most carefully contrived landscapes. While the
label: Paragraph

text: authorship of each of the three projects is spread between [sic] the
label: Paragraph

text: many collaborators, the language is clearly one invented by Otto.
label: Paragraph

text: Where we should correctly place Otto in the history of modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture remains an open question. The work of Frank Gehry has shown
label: Paragraph

text: how digital programming tools that were unavailable to Otto—who was
label: Paragraph

text: nonetheless the very first to use computer-generated data to plan his
label: Paragraph

text: Munich stadium scheme, three decades before Gehry’s epochal
label: Paragraph

text: Guggenheim Museum Bilbao—could advance an audacious recasting of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture from rectilinear convention to free-form exuberance. Many
label: Paragraph

text: earlier precursors to these developments have been suggested, from the
label: Paragraph

text: German Expressionist Hermann Finsterlin to the Danish modernist Jorn
label: Title

text: Utzon, for whose Sydney Opera House of 1957-1973 Otto served as a
label: Paragraph

text: structural consultant after the building’s completion had ground to a halt
label: Paragraph

text: until the means to execute this unconventional design were finally worked
label: Paragraph

text: out.
label: Paragraph

text: Yet Otto—whose extremely early use of aeronautic prototypes was
label: Paragraph

text: paralleled decades later by Gehry’s brilliant adaptation of CATIA software
label: Paragraph

text: (devised for the design of irregularly shaped airplane components) to
label: Paragraph

text: architectural applications—now seems the most convincing forerunner of
label: Paragraph

text: today’s boundless biomorphism. However directly these connections are
label: Paragraph

text: reckoned, there can be no doubt that Otto helped lift his homeland out of
label: Paragraph

text: the darkest period in its political and cultural history through his
label: Paragraph

text: marvelously wrought designs, which conveyed not only stunning technical
label: Paragraph

text: finesse but, more importantly, a spiritual lightness of being.
label: Paragraph

text: On March 9, 2015—two months after being informed confidentially that
label: Paragraph

text: he’d been named the fortieth recipient of the Pritzker Architecture Prize—
label: Paragraph

text: Otto died, and just under the wire, as the award’s rather nebulous and
label: Paragraph

text: occasionally malleable bylaws stipulate that it cannot be given
label: Paragraph

text: posthumously. By again reaching into what might be termed the back
label: Paragraph

text: catalog of twentieth-century architecture, the jury’s decision to honor Otto
label: Paragraph

text: recalled the joint bestowal of the 1988 prize on Oscar Niemeyer and
label: Paragraph

text: Gordon Bunshaft, who were then eighty and seventy-nine respectively.
label: Paragraph

text: Though long past their creative prime, they personified a meridian moment
label: Paragraph

text: of High Modernism, and the same might be inferred about the selection of
label: Paragraph

text: Otto at a time of irresolute architectural values.
label: Paragraph

text: In his late-life mediation “Architektur Natur,” Otto had harked back to
label: Paragraph

text: one of the most familiar (if also most frequently misunderstood) dictums of
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism, “weniger ist mehr” (less is more), which is now most closely
label: Paragraph

text: associated with Mies (who apparently first invoked it only as late as 1947)
label: Paragraph

text: but was used in various similar forms by several artists and writers during
label: Paragraph

text: the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Yet Otto obviously was intrigued
label: Paragraph

text: by this formulation in quite another way from the stylistic reductivism it
label: Paragraph

text: represented to the Minimalist Mies:
label: Paragraph

text: “Less is more,” this phrase fascinates me: fewer houses, less material,
label: Paragraph

text: less concrete, less energy but for use with that which is available for
label: Paragraph

text: humanistic uses. .. . To build in concert with nature and to make much
label: Paragraph

text: out of little. Better to build nothing at all than to build too much!
label: Paragraph

text: Those were old and new goals.
label: Paragraph

text: If Otto were some medieval master intent on putting his indelible mark
label: Paragraph

text: on Baukunst—the building art—one can fully imagine him making a
label: Paragraph

text: personal motto from four German words in that declaration of principles:
label: Paragraph

text: “Aus wenig viel machen” (To make much out of little). This is a rare
label: Paragraph

text: sentiment to be embraced by an architect, since most of them are driven to
label: Paragraph

text: make even more out of much, and thus Otto’s selfless embrace of the exact
label: Paragraph

text: opposite remains all the more extraordinary and moving.

text: FRANK GEHRY
label: Title

text: STRANGE AS IT would have seemed when he burst upon the avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: architectural scene four decades ago, Frank Gehry, the volcanic improviser
label: Paragraph

text: of free-form structures unlike anything seen since the irrational fantasies of
label: Paragraph

text: German Expressionists in the early twentieth century, eventually attained
label: Paragraph

text: the stature of those visionaries’ antithetical contemporary Ludwig Mies van
label: Title

text: der Rohe, the hyperrational codifier of modern architectural reason. Though
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s design precepts have been nowhere nearly as regularized as Mies’s,
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry Technologies—the computer-programming offshoot of his Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles—based office, Gehry Partners—pioneered and later disseminated
label: Paragraph

text: the digital means for architects to realize irregular structural shapes
label: Paragraph

text: (colloquially known as Blobitecture) of a kind once attainable only through
label: Paragraph

text: laborious craftsmanship, like those of Antoni Gaudi. The world today
label: Paragraph

text: perceives the building art in an entirely different light thanks to Gehry, not
label: Paragraph

text: least because of his firm’s software, which has given countless others the
label: Paragraph

text: ability to design just as unconventionally as he has.
label: Paragraph

text: The Gehry office’s breakthrough application to architecture of the
label: Paragraph

text: aeronautical computer-design program CATIA enabled the construction of
label: Paragraph

text: his masterpiece, the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao of 1991-1997 in Spain.
label: Paragraph

text: The rapturous reception of that building led to the so-called Bilbao Effect, a
label: Paragraph

text: salubrious influence on the city’s economy that in tum has spurred
label: Paragraph

text: countless other municipalities to fund grandiose architectural schemes to
label: Paragraph

text: attract cultural tourism. Gehry’s software has since made the creation of
label: Paragraph

text: eccentric buildings economically feasible for clients who once would have
label: Paragraph

text: rejected deviations from the cost-efficient regularity of Mies’s rectilinear
label: Paragraph

text: modular formula. As a result, Gehry’s transformative contribution has
label: Paragraph

text: become an intrinsic part of present-day practice, which makes it easy to
label: Paragraph

text: take his revolutionary advances for granted, in the same way that Mies’s
label: Paragraph

text: were by the end of his life.
label: Paragraph

text: Recognition of Gehry’s singular place in contemporary architecture was
label: Paragraph

text: particularly evident in Paris during the fall of 2014 with the opening of his
label: Paragraph

text: Fondation Louis Vuitton of 2005-2014 (see Illustration 15b) and a
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneous Centre Pompidou retrospective of his six-decade career. This
label: Paragraph

text: large show, which comprised 255 drawings and 67 models covering 60
label: Paragraph

text: projects, traced his rise from a scrappy maverick with artistic hankerings to
label: Paragraph

text: the most important American architect since Louis Kahn. It was at least a
label: Paragraph

text: thrice-told tale (if one counts the Walker Art Center’s reputation-making
label: Paragraph

text: 1986 Gehry survey organized by Mildred Friedman, who also curated the
label: Paragraph

text: Guggenheim Museum overview in 2001) but one well worth reiterating,
label: Paragraph

text: considering his immense impact on the redirection of modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry spent the first twenty years of his career as a very creditable
label: Paragraph

text: commercial architect for figures as divergent as Victor Gruen (the Los
label: Paragraph

text: Angeles—based Viennese émigré often called the father of the American
label: Paragraph

text: shopping mall) and the more socially conscious James Rouse (who
label: Paragraph

text: promoted racially integrated communities such as the Rouse Company’s
label: Paragraph

text: new town of Columbia, Maryland, where Gehry executed several
label: Caption

text: buildings). As his artistic ambitions came to the fore, Gehry set up his own
label: Paragraph

text: office in Los Angeles in 1962 and began to produce self-consciously avant-
label: Paragraph

text: garde designs. What stands out most about those early independent works is
label: Paragraph

text: an essential and quite touching humility, a quality present even in such
label: Paragraph

text: radical proposals as his unexecuted Familian house of 1977-1978, a
label: Paragraph

text: multiangular design for a Santa Monica site that evokes a veritable
label: Paragraph

text: avalanche of lumber. But even though that client got cold feet, the project
label: Paragraph

text: now looks perfectly plausible as a home because Gehry during the
label: Paragraph

text: intervening decades has so thoroughly reshaped our basic notions of
label: Paragraph

text: habitability.
label: Paragraph

text: However, Gehry’s postmillennial work has tended to be anything but
label: Paragraph

text: humble. This is especially true of his extravagant Fondation Louis Vuitton,
label: Paragraph

text: which is the equivalent of fifteen stories high and from certain angles
label: Paragraph

text: imparts the over-bearing aggressiveness projected by the tilting Cor-Ten
label: Paragraph

text: steel sculptures of the architect’s competitive friend—or perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: “frenemy”—Richard Serra. The Vuitton building, which occupies a verdant
label: Caption

text: site in the northern part of the Bois de Boulogne, was an instant popular hit.
label: Paragraph

text: It continues a long history of Parisian modern wonders at once novel and
label: Paragraph

text: bizarre, typified by the Montgolfier balloon, Foucault’s pendulum, the
label: Paragraph

text: Eiffel Tower, and the Spirit of St. Louis, all of which combined
label: Paragraph

text: technological novelty with conceptual audacity and drew tout le monde to
label: Paragraph

text: come out and gawk at the latest sensation in the city that for centuries has
label: Paragraph

text: been the world’s epicenter of new fashions of every sort.
label: Paragraph

text: The Pompidou’s exhibition subliminally suggested that if there has been
label: Paragraph

text: a climactic year for Gehry it may well have come with the completion of
label: Paragraph

text: the Walt Disney Concert Hall of 1989-2003 in Los Angeles, which proved
label: Paragraph

text: that he could maintain his extraordinary level of success after Bilbao.
label: Paragraph

text: Between Disney and Vuitton he executed some twenty-three commissions,
label: Paragraph

text: but with several exceptions—such as his superb IAC Building of 2003-—
label: Paragraph

text: 2007 on the West Side Highway in Manhattan’s Chelsea district, a mid-rise
label: Caption

text: office building clad in curving white-fritted glass—few of those post-
label: Paragraph

text: Disney efforts are likely to be counted among the highlights of Gehry’s
label: Paragraph

text: oeuvre.
label: Paragraph

text: For example, the awkward Peter B. Lewis Science Library of 2002-2008
label: Paragraph

text: at Princeton University makes a disappointing memorial to its donor, who
label: Paragraph

text: was Gehry’s most generous client. The architect has termed his unbuilt

label: Caption

text: An admirable example of a contemporary art center built by a luxury
label: Paragraph

text: goods purveyor is the Fondation Cartier, which was founded in 1984 and a
label: Paragraph

text: designs, this rectilinear, multilayered glass-walled structure has aged

label: Paragraph

text: also because of excellent maintenance. More importantly, the Fondation
label: Paragraph

text: Cartier’s programming has been consistently superb. To be sure, using art
label: Paragraph

text: and architecture to increase the cachet of expensive consumer goods is
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption
