text: flourishes were toned down in the interest of focusing on the art within, as
label: Paragraph

text: is the case at the Cartier Foundation, which eschews its sponsor’s double-C
label: Paragraph

text: logo.
label: Paragraph

text: It is axiomatic among architecture editors and art directors that if a
label: Paragraph

text: building is not very good, then one should use images of it at sundown; if it
label: Paragraph

text: is worse than that, show it reflected in water at twilight; if it is truly awful,
label: Paragraph

text: shoot it after dark in the snow. This perhaps explains why several
label: Paragraph

text: publications, including Architectural Digest, Vanity Fair, and The New York
label: Paragraph

text: Times, depicted Gehry’s Vuitton gallery in a dim crepuscular glow, rising
label: Paragraph

text: above its shallow pools and dramatic stepped cascade. Recourse to special
label: Paragraph

text: photographic lighting does address one of this building’s basic
label: Paragraph

text: shortcomings, however, for in a city where it is overcast much of the time, a
label: Paragraph

text: glass-skinned structure is bound to look rather dull quite often, which is true
label: Paragraph

text: of the Fondation Louis Vuitton, despite Gehry’s best efforts to imbue it with
label: Paragraph

text: high drama.
label: Paragraph

text: The twin peaks of Gehry’s career—Bilbao and Disney—are both clad in
label: Paragraph

text: the silvery titanium that became the hallmark material of his career’s
label: Paragraph

text: second half, superseding the chain-link fencing, corrugated metal, and
label: Paragraph

text: chicken-wire glass that gave his early experimental work a louche,
label: Paragraph

text: combative quality that repelled some potential clients but earned him street
label: Paragraph

text: cred as a tough avant-garde artist. Glass was chosen for the Vuitton
label: Paragraph

text: gallery’s exterior because of restrictions imposed by the city to keep the
label: Paragraph

text: building from appearing too massive. The structure is enveloped by a dozen
label: Paragraph

text: gigantic steel-framed, white-fritted-glass “sails’ in a _ series of
label: Paragraph

text: complementary arcs hoisted on an elaborate armature of 179 steel and wood
label: Paragraph

text: tripods. These curving, billboard-like surfaces thrust outward from the
label: Paragraph

text: “icebergs,” as Gehry called the concrete-paneled internal gallery structures.
label: Paragraph

text: The lifting looks very heavy indeed, and at points the concatenation of
label: Paragraph

text: multiple support elements seems like a chaotic pileup of Mark di Suvero
label: Paragraph

text: sculptures. It then becomes easy to believe the astonishing statistic that this
label: Paragraph

text: building contains more than twice the steel used in the Eiffel Tower.
label: Paragraph

text: By adopting such a costly and effortful dual structural system—there
label: Paragraph

text: seem to be two buildings in one here, just as Santiago Calatrava’s overly
label: Paragraph

text: complicated bridges are said to duplicate their task—Gehry was able to
label: Paragraph

text: combine a sensuously sculptural carapace of glass with workable display
label: Paragraph

text: spaces within (a format he earlier employed for a very different function at
label: Paragraph

text: his Hotel Marqués de Riscal of 1999-2006 in Spain). He was stung by
label: Paragraph

text: criticism that his most famous structure is inimical to art—“Every museum
label: Paragraph

text: director I know hated Bilbao,” he claimed, with much hyperbole and typical
label: Paragraph

text: self-pity. Thus even though the eccentric interior volumes of his
label: Paragraph

text: masterpiece are in fact wonderfully hospitable to certain kinds of art, such
label: Paragraph

text: as Serra’s sculptures (it also includes several conventional galleries), he
label: Paragraph

text: clearly wanted to avoid difficulties in showing the LVMH collection.
label: Paragraph

text: In its clear separation between free-form exterior and straightforward
label: Paragraph

text: interior, the Vuitton building also recalls Gehry’s Richard B. Fisher Center
label: Paragraph

text: for the Performing Arts of 1997-2003 at Bard College in Annandale-on-
label: Caption

text: Hudson, New York. There, a utilitarian shed of the sort that might be used
label: Paragraph

text: for a suburban big-box store is fronted with billowing titanium sheets, a
label: Paragraph

text: contrast not unlike Palladio’s Venetian churches with their highly
label: Paragraph

text: articulated stone facades and mundane brick side and rear elevations.
label: Caption

text: Although hardly on a par with Gehry’s Experience Music Project of 1995—
label: Paragraph

text: 2000 (now the Museum of Pop Culture) in Seattle, arguably the worst
label: Paragraph

text: building of his entire career, the Fondation Louis Vuitton is notably lacking
label: Paragraph

text: in repose, a quality not incompatible with dynamism, as both Bilbao and
label: Paragraph

text: Disney demonstrate.
label: Paragraph

text: The metal skins of the Bilbao museum and the Los Angeles auditorium
label: Caption

text: conceal the necessary workings beneath serenely opaque surfaces. In
label: Paragraph

text: contrast, the Vuitton building’s translucent exterior reveals a plethora of
label: Paragraph

text: angular underpinnings that would have been best left hidden. This
label: Paragraph

text: building’s obviously high level of execution has caused some observers to
label: Paragraph

text: question whether it could possibly have cost only $135 million, a widely
label: Paragraph

text: reported figure that LVMH will neither confirm nor deny. As Claverie told
label: Paragraph

text: The New York Times, “In philanthropy, we never express figures because we
label: Paragraph

text: want the dream and the emotion to speak for itself [sic].”
label: Paragraph

text: On its south flank the Fondation Louis Vuitton fronts one of the
label: Paragraph

text: undulating roadways that snake through the Bois in the English Romantic
label: Paragraph

text: manner. Passing into the main portal on that elevation, one enters a vast,
label: Paragraph

text: amorphous central court some thirty feet high. This space is surmounted by
label: Paragraph

text: a flat ceiling with banal detailing more befitting a suburban outlet mall than
label: Paragraph

text: a high-style art museum. Tilting outer glass walls offer views of the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding park, with a pleasant café on the north side enlivened by a
label: Paragraph

text: swarming school of Gehry’s whimsical plastic-laminate Fish Lamps, first
label: Caption

text: produced in the 1980s, suspended from the ceiling.
label: Paragraph

text: Adjacent to this entry area is the upper level of a double-height
label: Paragraph

text: auditorium. Oddly for an interior that frequently will need to be darkened
label: Paragraph

text: for performances, it has two large glass window walls with blackout
label: Paragraph

text: curtains concealed above them. Here is displayed one of several site-
label: Paragraph

text: specific works the foundation commissioned for the building—a vertically
label: Paragraph

text: striped, rainbow-spectrum stage curtain (which could be easily confused
label: Paragraph

text: with a gay pride flag) and five monochromatic panels by Ellsworth Kelly,
label: Caption

text: which are positioned around the large room and double as acoustical
label: Paragraph

text: absorption baffles. Moving outward from the building’s core one quickly
label: Paragraph

text: becomes dis-oriented. For a structure with such a plethora of circulation—
label: Paragraph

text: corridors, stairways, catwalks, escalators, and elevators seem to spring up at
label: Paragraph

text: every tum—it is difficult to make your way methodically from gallery to
label: Paragraph

text: gallery and from level to level.
label: Paragraph

text: The most enjoyable parts of the structure are its outdoor terraces, which
label: Paragraph

text: encircle the “icebergs” at different levels. Some of them offer panoramic
label: Paragraph

text: views of Paris beyond the treetops of the Bois. The upper reaches of
label: Paragraph

text: Gehry’s vitreous spinnakers provide an intriguing frame for some of the
label: Paragraph

text: vistas, though they occlude others and create landscape slivers that
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan real estate brokers would term partial park views. It was once
label: Paragraph

text: said of the Eiffel Tower that it was the most agreeable spot in Paris because
label: Paragraph

text: it was the one place where one could not see the Eiffel Tower. That is not at
label: Paragraph

text: all the case with the Fondation Louis Vuitton, but it may take some time
label: Paragraph

text: before it fulfills its ambitious mission to become an equal among the City of
label: Paragraph

text: Light’s formidable array of cultural landmarks.
label: Paragraph

text: RENZO PIANO
label: Title

text: THE SINGULAR POSITION held by Renzo Piano—among the most respected
label: Paragraph

text: master builders at the end of the twentieth and the beginning of the twenty-
label: Paragraph

text: first century, when he seemed to have a veritable monopoly on the most
label: Paragraph

text: prestigious cultural commissions—owed much to a pervasive (if seldom
label: Paragraph

text: articulated) fear among benefactors of cultural institutions that the building
label: Paragraph

text: art in some essential sense had moved beyond their comprehension. The
label: Paragraph

text: unexpected emergence of Frank Gehry as his generation’s most celebrated
label: Paragraph

text: architect, confirmed by his ecstatically praised Guggenheim Museum
label: Paragraph

text: Bilbao, created a slipstream of rapid acceptance for such younger
label: Paragraph

text: practitioners as Zaha Hadid, Daniel Libeskind, and Santiago Calatrava, all
label: Paragraph

text: exponents of what has been called the architecture of spectacle, which
label: Paragraph

text: emphasizes extreme novelty and high drama rather than qualities of
label: Paragraph

text: timelessness, beauty, and repose that were more prized in earlier epochs.
label: Paragraph

text: Following the Bilbao sensation, uncertainty about how well this kind of
label: Paragraph

text: exhibitionistic design would pass the test of time brought many museum
label: Paragraph

text: building committees to Piano, whose Menil Collection of 1982-1986 in
label: Paragraph

text: Houston has certainly done just that. If anything, the Menil is now even
label: Paragraph

text: more esteemed than when it first opened. Piano’s next museum jobs in
label: Paragraph

text: Texas—his Cy Twombly Gallery of 1992-1995 next to the Menil in
label: Paragraph

text: Houston and Nasher Sculpture Center of 1999-2003 in Dallas—teiterated
label: Caption

text: his unparalleled understanding of how to harness the harsh daylight of the
label: Paragraph

text: Sun Belt to maximum effect in naturally illuminated interiors. This
label: Paragraph

text: particular skill, along with his reputation for a dependably understated
label: Paragraph

text: elegance and an exceptionally agreeable personal demeanor not always
label: Paragraph

text: found among avant-garde architects, made him the obvious candidate for
label: Paragraph

text: yet another Texas commission, one of the utmost sensitivity: an addition to
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Kahn’s revered Kimbell Art Museum of 1966-1972 in Fort Worth, by
label: Caption

text: general consensus the greatest gallery building of the modern era.
label: Paragraph

text: The announcement that Piano had been chosen for this delicate task was
label: Paragraph

text: greeted with widespread relief among architectural aficionados, for clearly
label: Paragraph

text: the job was in safe hands. It also prevented some from raising the indelicate
label: Paragraph

text: question of why this project was being undertaken in the first place. For if
label: Paragraph

text: the Kimbell’s undeniable magic derives from its being about as perfect as
label: Paragraph

text: any art museum could possibly be, why mess with success? Yet even this
label: Paragraph

text: most gemlike and personal of institutions—an oasis of intimacy in a period
label: Paragraph

text: when both the physical size and attendance figures of museums are
label: Paragraph

text: aggressively aggrandized to the detriment of viewing art—could not escape
label: Paragraph

text: the plutocratic peer-group pressure that demands that museums expand in
label: Paragraph

text: every respect.
label: Paragraph

text: Happily, the addition to the Kimbell—chivalrously named the Renzo
label: Paragraph

text: Piano Pavilion to honor its designer and emphasize it as a separate
label: Paragraph

text: architectural entity instead of an appendage of Kahn’s original structure—
label: Paragraph

text: turned out to be far from the desecration some feared (see Illustration 16a).
label: Paragraph

text: About the worst one could say about it is that the $135 million building is
label: Paragraph

text: not very distinguished, especially in light of the Nasher only thirty-two
label: Paragraph

text: miles away in Dallas. When I revisited the Nasher at the time of the Piano
label: Paragraph

text: addition’s opening, the older building struck me as its designer’s equivalent
label: Paragraph

text: of Kahn’s Kimbell, a warm and embracing fusion of art and architecture
label: Paragraph

text: that seems increasingly remarkable each time one returns. It defies precise
label: Paragraph

text: definition of exactly why it is so wonderful, that elusive quality of all truly
label: Paragraph

text: great architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: To be sure, matters would be much improved had the freestanding Renzo
label: Paragraph

text: Piano Pavilion been placed elsewhere on the Kimbell’s ample property—
label: Paragraph

text: specifically a vacant lot just across Van Cliburn Way to the east of the Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: galleries, used as an auxiliary parking lot for Tadao Ando’s Modem Art
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Fort Worth (1997-2002). Piano devised a promising initial plan
label: Paragraph

text: for that unobtrusive location, but the Modern Art Museum wanted to keep
label: Paragraph

text: the parking lot (even though the land is actually owned by the Kimbell) and
label: Paragraph

text: a different scheme was prepared for the site to the west of the Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: building, where the 101,000-square-foot addition now stands. Those closest
label: Paragraph

text: to the project privately reported that the museum’s longtime president and
label: Paragraph

text: chairman, Kay Kimbell Forston—a niece and namesake of Kay Kimbell,
label: Paragraph

text: the Fort Worth entrepreneur who upon his death in 1964 left his entire
label: Paragraph

text: fortune of $100 million, big money in those days, to create the museum—
label: Paragraph

text: hoped to avoid conflict with Anne Windfohr Marion, a Modern Art
label: Paragraph

text: Museum trustee and local social powerhouse, and thus did not press her
label: Paragraph

text: property rights. On matters such as this the history of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes hinges.
label: Paragraph

text: The new pavilion’s design reiterates the format Piano has used in several
label: Paragraph

text: other museum buildings: a low-rise rectangle with a flat overhanging roof
label: Paragraph

text: supported by a modern version of the Classical colonnade, a single
label: Paragraph

text: continuous row of columns set out from the structure’s outer walls and
label: Paragraph

text: supporting the extended roof above the configuration, first seen at the Menil
label: Caption

text: Collection. However, here there is an odd disjunction between the
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat vacant three-hundred-foot-long entry fagade—from which you
label: Paragraph

text: see the Kahn building across a broad grassy lawn—and the busy one-
label: Paragraph

text: hundred-foot-long side elevations, which overlook streets to the north and
label: Paragraph

text: south.
label: Paragraph

text: The Piano addition is connected to the Kahn building by an underground
label: Paragraph

text: parking garage and by a walkway across the lawn between them. Most
label: Paragraph

text: visitors will leave their cars in the garage and ascend by stairs or elevator to
label: Paragraph

text: the new structure; there is no direct access for the public to the Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: building from the garage, though those using the original aboveground
label: Paragraph

text: parking lot will enter the old galleries through the east door as before. A
label: Paragraph

text: subterranean tunnel between the two can be used upon request by people in
label: Paragraph

text: wheelchairs.
label: Paragraph

text: The pavilion’s tripartite front is bland beyond the worst norms of
label: Paragraph

text: Minimalism, with a pair of blank concrete walls that frame a central
label: Paragraph

text: segment of ground-to-roof glass panels and portals, the detailing of which is
label: Paragraph

text: routine at best. As one stands in the west-facing courtyard of the Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: building—with its famous grove of yaupon hollies designed by Harriet
label: Paragraph

text: Pattison, the architect’s landscape architect and mother of his son, Nathaniel
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn—the Piano addition nearly fades away. Alas, the same cannot be said
label: Paragraph

text: of its overwrought north and south ends, which seem ill-proportioned
label: Paragraph

text: thanks to the massive, hundred-foot-long, gray-stained, laminated Douglas
label: Paragraph

text: fir roof beams that jut beyond the glass walls beneath them and give the
label: Paragraph

text: composition a top-heavy quality reminiscent of 1970s Brutalism.
label: Paragraph

text: Supporting those narrower elevations, a row of eleven squared-off concrete
label: Paragraph

text: columns (echoing the corner supports of the Kahn gallery’s porticoes) are
label: Paragraph

text: spaced a mere ten feet apart and thus make the building appear to be
label: Paragraph

text: sinking under its own weight.
label: Paragraph

text: The Renzo Piano Pavilion is actually two separate structures conjoined:
label: Paragraph

text: an entry-and-gallery pavilion, behind which, half-buried beneath a green-
label: Paragraph

text: roof earth berm, is a subterranean component that contains a double-height,
label: Paragraph

text: 298-seat auditorium; a handsome library; various education facilities,
label: Paragraph

text: including classrooms and children’s art studios; and a cave-like gallery
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to works of Asian art. The main virtue of this crepuscular space is
label: Paragraph

text: that it allows fragile works with stringent light-control requirements—such
label: Paragraph

text: as scrolls, screens, and textiles—to be displayed together. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: deferential gestures to the Kahn building, the addition blocks the once
label: Paragraph

text: westward-sweeping vista toward another comerstone of Fort Worth’s
label: Paragraph

text: estimable cultural district, Philip Johnson’s Amon Carter Museum of
label: Caption

text: American Art of 1958-1961, from his so-called Ballet School Period of
label: Paragraph

text: fussy sub-Classicism. Though hardly in the same architectural league as
label: Paragraph

text: Kahn’s Kimbell, the Amon Carter when seen from a distance did possess a
label: Paragraph

text: certain campy charm akin to a folly at the terminus of a Baroque garden
label: Paragraph

text: axis. However, that view is now obscured behind an ungainly concrete
label: Paragraph

text: retaining wall that props up the submerged portions of the Renzo Piano
label: Paragraph

text: Pavilion.
label: Paragraph

text: In an initial miscalculation, the Kimbell decided to temporarily display
label: Paragraph

text: its permanent collection in the Piano Pavilion while it housed a 2013
label: Paragraph

text: inaugural loan exhibition, “The Age of Picasso and Matisse: Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Masters from the Art Institute of Chicago,” made possible by the temporary
label: Paragraph

text: dislocation of that museum’s best twentieth-century paintings. Ironically,
label: Paragraph

text: this superb show owed something to Piano as well, because the works
label: Paragraph

text: became available when the problem-plagued third floor of his Modern
label: Paragraph

text: Wing of 2001-2009 at the Art Institute was closed for seven months of
label: Paragraph

text: repair work only four years after the addition’s completion. The switch
label: Paragraph

text: invited some unfortunate comparisons. Kahn’s interiors, with their
label: Paragraph

text: celebrated skylit concrete ceiling vaults and use of creamy travertine on the
label: Caption

text: walls, virtually caress pictures shown within them, in an almost uncanny
label: Paragraph

text: melding of sensitively proportioned volume and mysteriously modulated
label: Paragraph

text: light. Not surprisingly, the Art Institute’s finest modern pictures looked
label: Paragraph

text: better in the original Kimbell than they ever have at home.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the Kimbell’s Old Master paintings could be adequately viewed
label: Paragraph

text: when temporarily installed in Piano’s new galleries, they unquestionably
label: Paragraph

text: seemed less magical there than they customarily do in Kahn’s spaces, where
label: Paragraph

text: they fairly glow. The works that fare best in the Piano Pavilion’s three
label: Paragraph

text: major display areas are the non-European sculptures mounted in the
label: Paragraph

text: pellucidly lit north gallery (illuminated, as is the south gallery, by a
label: Paragraph

text: combination of natural and artificial overhead lighting). Among them are
label: Paragraph

text: the museum’s choice pre-Columbian artifacts and superb African tribal
label: Paragraph

text: objects, the latter exemplified by an Ife terra-cotta head, circa 1100-1300
label: Paragraph

text: CE, one of the finest treasures from that continent in this hemisphere. The
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion’s best feature is its exquisitely wrought concrete walls—supervised
label: Paragraph

text: by the Dottor Group, an Italian architectural restoration firm—which were
label: Paragraph

text: poured in unusually large and smoothly finished wooden formworks to
label: Paragraph

text: minimize the seams and circular indentations that can be so distracting
label: Paragraph

text: when viewing art against conventionally made concrete surfaces. The
label: Paragraph

text: material exudes a low-key silvery sheen thanks to a 2 percent addition of
label: Paragraph

text: titanium to the ingredients. It is the most ravishing concrete I have ever
label: Paragraph

text: seen in the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: On a whole, though, the Renzo Piano Pavilion quickly faded into the
label: Paragraph

text: middle rank of Piano’s oeuvre, neither at the top (the Nasher and Menil) nor
label: Paragraph

text: the bottom (the Broad Contemporary Art Museum of 2003-2008 in Los
label: Caption

text: Angeles and the Morgan Library and Museum of 2000-2006 in New York).
label: Paragraph

text: The Fort Worth pavilion is but one of the architect’s twenty-five museum
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, and he cannot be expected to produce a hit every time. One can
label: Paragraph

text: easily imagine an outcome at the Kimbell better in several respects—a
label: Paragraph

text: structure lighter, more ethereal, and livelier than this dull affair. Yet we
label: Paragraph

text: should also be grateful that the designer and his client were so cautious. The
label: Paragraph

text: most important requirement they faced vis-a-vis Kahn’s masterpiece could
label: Paragraph

text: be summed up in the opening words of the Hippocratic oath—‘“First, do no
label: Paragraph

text: harm”—and in that respect they undoubtedly succeeded. The extreme
label: Paragraph

text: preoccupation over the success or failure of the Renzo Piano Pavilion is
label: Paragraph

text: indicative of the dominance that architecture has disproportionately
label: Paragraph

text: assumed in the evaluation of art institutions since Gehry’s Guggenheim
label: Paragraph

text: Bilbao. This is not to say that the buildings in which works of art are
label: Paragraph

text: housed should be beside the point, but great architecture alone does not
label: Paragraph

text: guarantee a great museum.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the low-rise, colonnaded rectangle has been Piano’s most
label: Paragraph

text: familiar museum format, he has diverged from it several times, as in the
label: Paragraph

text: undulating steel-framed roof of his Zentrum Paul Klee of 1999-2005 in
label: Caption

text: Bern, Switzerland, and the sail-like glass canopy that overarches his Astrup
label: Paragraph

text: Fearnley Museum of Modern Art of 2009-2012 in Oslo. Another
label: Caption

text: postmillennial museum design by his Paris office—the Fondation Jér6me
label: Caption

text: Seydoux-Pathé of 2006-2014 in Paris—is similarly biomorphic, and yet the
label: Paragraph

text: architect also had to take into account the landmark structure behind which
label: Paragraph

text: his scheme was to be erected. (Although this nineteenth-century vestige is
label: Paragraph

text: hardly a major treasure on a par with the Kimbell, the city of Paris carefully
label: Paragraph

text: guards the overall texture of is architectural fabric, and buildings that are
label: Paragraph

text: not of the highest significance are protected all the same.)
label: Paragraph

text: In the fall of 2014, while Je tout Paris and architecture enthusiasts were
label: Paragraph

text: agog over the debut of Gehry’s assertively spectacular and lavishly
label: Paragraph

text: publicized Fondation Louis Vuitton in the Bois de Boulogne (see
label: Caption

text: Illustration 15b), Piano’s little gem opened with no fanfare five miles to the
label: Paragraph

text: southeast in the 13th arrondissement (not far from Dominique Perrault’s
label: Paragraph

text: quadruple-glass-towered Bibliothéque Nationale de France of 1989-1995).
label: Caption

text: The Fondation Jér6me Seydoux-Pathé is a museum, archive, and
label: Paragraph

text: cinematheque for Pathé, the pioneering French film company (see
label: Paragraph

text: Illustration 16b). With its ingenious demonstration of how to insert a work
label: Paragraph

text: of avant-garde architecture into a historic setting, this voluptuously swelling
label: Paragraph

text: aluminum-and-glass-clad form—instantly likened to an armadillo—ranks
label: Paragraph

text: among Piano’s best works.
label: Paragraph

text: At just 23,000 square feet, Piano’s five-story jewel displays his particular
label: Paragraph

text: strengths to perfection: the sleek engineering of its bold forms, the exquisite
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmanship of its interior finishes, the way its arching translucent roof
label: Paragraph

text: skillfully modulates daylight, and the aura of elevated calm throughout.
label: Paragraph

text: These same qualities likewise typify what I have called the Piano Quartet,
label: Paragraph

text: the four intimately scaled art galleries (Menil, Twombly, Nasher, and
label: Paragraph

text: Beyeler Foundation Museum) at the core of his achievement. The discreetly
label: Paragraph

text: restrained Pathé Foundation, on the broad Avenue des Gobelins, occupies a
label: Paragraph

text: keyhole-shaped footprint connected to the back of a freestanding Beaux
label: Caption

text: Arts fagade with an entry arch featuring Neoclassical bas-reliefs of Drama
label: Caption

text: and Comedy by the young Auguste Rodin. This site once housed the
label: Paragraph

text: Théatre des Gobelins, an early cinema owned by the Pathé company, which
label: Paragraph

text: was founded at the dawn of cinematography in 1896.
label: Paragraph

text: The ground floor of the new building is raked upward about six feet from
label: Paragraph

text: front to back, toward a small garden landscaped with birch trees visible
label: Paragraph

text: through a glass wall at the rear of the site. Stairs lead down to a
label: Paragraph

text: subterranean seventy-seat screening room for silent films, adjoining an
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition gallery where early-twentieth-century Pathé movie posters are
label: Paragraph

text: displayed. On the second story is another gallery, devoted to an array of
label: Paragraph

text: period movie cameras and projectors set out on a long, narrow platform
label: Paragraph

text: without protective glass, which gives the antique cinematic hardware the air
label: Paragraph

text: of a contemporary sculpture installation.
label: Paragraph

text: The two levels above this are devoted to climate-controlled archival
label: Paragraph

text: storage and offices, and then, at the very top of the building, Piano’s piéce
label: Paragraph

text: de résistance: the research center. This soaring open-plan space, which
label: Paragraph

text: encloses a conference area as well as desks for researchers, is defined by a
label: Paragraph

text: sequence of thirty-eight laminated larchwood arches that increase in size
label: Caption

text: toward the center of the dazzling glass-roofed aerie. The canopy’s outer
label: Paragraph

text: surface is clad with approximately seven thousand perforated aluminum
label: Paragraph

text: louvers that filter daylight but afford soft-focus views of the surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: cityscape. The graceful ebb and flow of the double-curved roof and the
label: Paragraph

text: immaculate facture of the wooden parabolas that support it impart an
label: Paragraph

text: organic, Aalto-like warmth to what otherwise might have seemed a chilly
label: Paragraph

text: high-tech exercise in precision engineering. Attention to detail throughout
label: Paragraph

text: is impressive but unobtrusive, perhaps most tellingly in the internal
label: Paragraph

text: stairways, a necessity on which some firms would not expend much effort.
label: Paragraph

text: These vertical circulation spaces have unpainted concrete walls almost as
label: Paragraph

text: smoothly finished as those in the Renzo Piano Pavilion, and here are ideally
label: Paragraph

text: complemented by yellow-and-orange linoleum flooring on the steps and
label: Paragraph

text: landings, as well as by stylish squared-off stainless-steel handrails.
label: Paragraph

text: Choosing Piano for this project was somewhat of a family affair. The
label: Paragraph

text: building was commissioned by Pathé’s CEO, the billionaire Jéréme
label: Paragraph

text: Seydoux, whose relatives have had a notable association with the architect
label: Paragraph

text: dating back to his early career. Seydoux’s mother was a member of the
label: Paragraph

text: hugely rich Schlumberger clan, whose oil equipment firm is headquartered
label: Paragraph

text: near Paris in a Piano building of 1981-1984. She was also a first cousin of
label: Paragraph

text: Dominique de Menil, née Schlumberger, the legendary Franco-American
label: Paragraph

text: art collector and aesthete who with her husband, John, commissioned the
label: Paragraph

text: Menil Collection.
label: Paragraph

text: In certain respects the Fondation Jér6me Seydoux-Pathé brings to mind
label: Paragraph

text: the DZ Bank Building of 1995-2001 in Berlin by Gehry, who similarly
label: Paragraph

text: juxtaposed a decorous classicizing facade (of his own design, rather than a
label: Paragraph

text: vestige as in the Paris project) with biomorphic volumes concealed behind
label: Paragraph

text: it. In Gehry’s scheme, a horsehead-like stainless-steel-wrapped conference
label: Paragraph

text: room is set within a fish-form glass-roofed atrium. The Pathé foundation’s
label: Paragraph

text: billowing metal-and-glass-clad roof is barely visible from the Avenue des
label: Paragraph

text: Gobelins, and is best viewed from the small garden tucked behind the
label: Paragraph

text: structure. In both instances, the conservative character of the buildings’
label: Paragraph

text: immediate neighborhood has been respected, while visitors experience an
label: Paragraph

text: unexpected spatial revelation as they move inside.
label: Paragraph

text: However, the Pathé building is wholly different from Gehry’s hulking
label: Paragraph

text: Fondation Louis Vuitton, not only in its structural suavity and
label: Paragraph

text: organizational clarity but also in the former’s notable reticence, antithetical
label: Paragraph

text: to the Vuitton show-place’s insistent self-advertisement. To be sure, there is
label: Paragraph

text: also a great disparity in size between the two structures: Gehry’s rises fifty-
label: Paragraph

text: six feet higher and is a hundred thousand square feet larger. But the real
label: Paragraph

text: dichotomy is not just architectural but spiritual. The splendid Fondation
label: Paragraph

text: Jér6me Seydoux-Pathé quietly amplifies the cultural contributions of its
label: Paragraph

text: sponsor’s historic enterprise, rather than exploiting artistic cachet as a mere
label: Paragraph

text: promotional and marketing tool. The scant attention the Pathé facility
label: Paragraph

text: received upon its completion, especially in contrast to the media feeding
label: Paragraph

text: frenzy that surrounded the opening of the Vuitton gallery, is all the more a
label: Paragraph

text: pity since it far surpasses other, much higher-profile museum projects by
label: Paragraph

text: the Renzo Piano Building Workshop (RPBW). The firm’s compact but
label: Paragraph

text: corporate-looking additions to the Morgan Library and Museum and
label: Paragraph

text: Boston’s Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum of 2005-2012 have
label: Paragraph

text: disappointed many admirers of those venerable institutions.
label: Paragraph

text: The fall of 2014 also saw the opening of the Piano firm’s renovation and
label: Paragraph

text: expansion of the Harvard Art Museums—a project that consolidated the
label: Paragraph

text: university’s Fogg Art Museum, Busch-Reisinger Museum, and Arthur M.
label: Paragraph

text: Sackler Museum. This scheme drew sharp criticism for the way it connects
label: Paragraph

text: the new ensemble to Le Corbusier’s adjacent Carpenter Center for the
label: Paragraph

text: Visual Arts of 1959-1962. The Princeton architectural historian Beatriz
label: Caption

text: Colomina went so far as to denounce it as “a crime against humanity” for
label: Paragraph

text: the damage she claims it does to the “mythical” Le Corbusier building. Yet
label: Paragraph

text: the following May, RPBW’s Whitney Museum of American Art of 2009-
label: Paragraph

text: 2015 in New York City’s Meatpacking District drew strong praise from
label: Paragraph

text: most critics and was an instant hit with the public after the museum moved
label: Paragraph

text: its collections from Marcel Breuer’s landmark Brutalist building of 1963-
label: Paragraph

text: 1966 on Manhattan’s Upper East Side.
label: Caption

text: These highly variable outcomes indicate that far from being able to
label: Paragraph

text: guarantee that his buildings will resist seeming dated decades after their
label: Paragraph

text: completion—a claim Piano has never made in any case—this undoubted
label: Paragraph

text: master is no more able than any other architect to escape shifting
label: Paragraph

text: perceptions of long-term transcendence. One plausible explanation for the
label: Paragraph

text: uneven reception of his firm’s output is its extraordinarily high volume of
label: Paragraph

text: one-off cultural commissions. These projects are far more time-consuming
label: Paragraph

text: than commercial structures, which involve repetitive tasks that in most
label: Paragraph

text: firms are routinely handled by assistants rather than principals. Another
label: Paragraph

text: factor is almost certainly the individual design team in charge of each
label: Paragraph

text: highly collaborative scheme, and a formidable task therefore awaits future
label: Paragraph

text: architectural historians in trying to unravel why and how the Piano office
label: Paragraph

text: operated at its best.
label: Paragraph

text: DAVID CHILDS / SANTIAGO CALATRAVA
label: Title

text: NO URBAN DESIGN project in modern American experience aroused such high
label: Paragraph

text: expectations and intense scrutiny as the rebuilding of the World Trade
label: Paragraph

text: Center site in New York City. It took fifteen years after the terrorist assault
label: Paragraph

text: of September 11, 2001, for the principal structures of this sixteen-acre
label: Paragraph

text: parcel in Lower Manhattan to be completed. In a field where time is money
label: Paragraph

text: in a very direct sense (because of interest payments on the vast sums
label: Paragraph

text: borrowed to finance big construction projects), such a long gestation period
label: Paragraph

text: usually signifies not judicious deliberation on the part of planners,
label: Paragraph

text: developers, designers, engineers, and contractors but rather economic,
label: Paragraph

text: political, or bureaucratic problems that can impede a speedy and cost-
label: Paragraph

text: efficient conclusion. Indeed, the revival of the devastated World Trade
label: Paragraph

text: Center site was repeatedly dogged by obstacles of every conceivable sort
label: Paragraph

text: from start to finish.
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast to this slow-motion rollout, it took less than a decade to erect
label: Paragraph

text: the Associated Architects’ twenty-two-acre, fourteen-building Rockefeller
label: Caption

text: Center of 1930-1939, which was accomplished without benefit of the
label: Paragraph

text: countless technological advances devised since then or the mammoth
label: Paragraph

text: government subsidies allocated to the remaking of what became known as
label: Paragraph

text: Ground Zero. That swiftness was owed in part to the project being
label: Paragraph

text: underwritten by the richest family in America during the Great Depression,
label: Paragraph

text: when jobs were scarce and both designers and laborers were grateful for
label: Paragraph

text: work, but the endeavor was a logistical triumph nonetheless. With Ground
label: Paragraph

text: Zero, the lengthy delay reflected the project’s divided and ambiguous
label: Paragraph

text: leadership as well as the fractious political tenor of the times.
label: Paragraph

text: Who was really in charge of this undertaking remained a persistent and
label: Paragraph

text: vexing question throughout. However, as several studies have made
label: Paragraph

text: abundantly clear, the transformation of the World Trade Center site was
label: Paragraph

text: hampered to a shameful degree by the intransigent self-interest of both
label: Paragraph

text: individuals and institutions. As a result, an effort ostensibly meant to
label: Paragraph

text: display our country’s unified spirit in response to an unprecedented
label: Paragraph

text: calamity instead showed that communal altruism of the sort that helped
label: Paragraph

text: America survive the Great Depression and triumph in World War II had
label: Paragraph

text: largely become a thing of the past. Although all major construction schemes
label: Paragraph

text: face tremendous problems, the World Trade Center rebuilding encapsulates
label: Paragraph

text: everything that is wrong with urban development in a period when, as in so
label: Paragraph

text: many other aspects of our public life, the communal good of the many is
label: Paragraph

text: sacrificed to the selfish gain of the few.
label: Paragraph

text: The actual and emotional centerpiece of the grouping is the magnificent
label: Paragraph

text: National September 11 Memorial of 2003-2011, the hypnotic pair of
label: Paragraph

text: reflecting pools recording the names of victims by the architect Michael
label: Caption

text: Arad, and the surrounding park by the landscape architect Peter Walker,
label: Paragraph

text: which was dedicated on the tenth anniversary of the disaster. In May 2014
label: Paragraph

text: came the opening of the adjacent National September 11 Museum, a much
label: Paragraph

text: less successful design that resulted from a shotgun marriage between two
label: Paragraph

text: wholly mismatched firms, the high-style Norwegian-based collaborative
label: Paragraph

text: Snghetta (which designed the trendily off-kilter exterior) and the workaday
label: Paragraph

text: New York office Davis Brody Bond (responsible for the awkward interiors).
label: Paragraph

text: This doomed division of labor produced a disjointed building that
label: Paragraph

text: unintentionally mirrors the continuing conflicts over the way the 2001
label: Paragraph

text: attacks should be interpreted.
label: Paragraph

text: Three of the five reflective, glass-skinned office towers that will
label: Paragraph

text: ultimately surround Arad’s pools were finished fifteen years after the
label: Paragraph

text: attack: the vapid 7 World Trade Center (2006) by David Childs of
label: Caption

text: Skidmore, Owings & Merrill; the equally disappointing 4 World Trade
label: Title

text: Center (2013) by Fumihiko Maki; and the Western Hemisphere’s tallest
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper, Childs’s One World Trade Center (2013), a 1,776-foot-tall
label: Paragraph

text: monolith that supplants Minoru Yamasaki’s Twin Towers of 1966-1977
label: Paragraph

text: (see Illustration 17a). Not as bad architecturally as it is conceptually, One
label: Paragraph

text: World Trade Center is faute de mieux the best of the lot.
label: Paragraph

text: The chief virtues of this building—which was initially dubbed the
label: Paragraph

text: Freedom Tower by New York Governor George Pataki but later
label: Caption

text: “rebranded” to tone down jingoistic associations that might scare off
label: Paragraph

text: potential tenants—are that it effectively addresses the huge open space to its
label: Paragraph

text: south, including Arad and Walker’s memorial, and overpowers its lackluster
label: Paragraph

text: neighbors. Though hardly an intriguing work of architecture, it nonetheless
label: Paragraph

text: succeeds in anchoring the unruly scrum of contiguous lower structures
label: Paragraph

text: through the sheer force of its gigantic scale and simple sculptural presence.
label: Paragraph

text: The building’s symmetrical, upwardly tapering, prismatic contours make it
label: Paragraph

text: stand out clearly against the Lower Manhattan skyline, especially when
label: Paragraph

text: slanting sunlight gives its four angled comers a clear contrast against the
label: Paragraph

text: rest of its mirrorlike glass cladding. If not ideally proportioned in its height-
label: Paragraph

text: to-mass ratio, Childs’s tower comes close enough to being an agreeable
label: Paragraph

text: composition and is a notable improvement over the architect’s other
label: Paragraph

text: conspicuous Manhattan skyscrapers—the chunky Postmodern campanile of
label: Paragraph

text: his Worldwide Plaza of 1986-1989 in Midtown West (which occupies the
label: Paragraph

text: entire city block between 49th and 50th Streets and Eighth and Ninth
label: Caption

text: Avenues) and his glitzy twin-towered Time Warner Center of 2000-2003 on
label: Paragraph

text: Columbus Circle.
label: Paragraph

text: David Magie Childs, who could reasonably claim to be the most
label: Paragraph

text: successful corporate architect in postmillennial America, was born in 1941
label: Paragraph

text: in Princeton, where his father was a professor of classics at the university.
label: Paragraph

text: After prepping at Deerfield he went to Yale and then its school of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, where he received a masters degree in 1967. Four years later
label: Paragraph

text: he joined the Washington, D.C., branch of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill
label: Paragraph

text: (SOM), the large multicity (and later multinational) firm, and in 1984
label: Paragraph

text: moved to its New York office, where he was named chairman in 1991 and
label: Paragraph

text: served in that post for a decade. A fixture in the empyrean of American
label: Paragraph

text: design officialdom, Childs was a member of the National Capital Planning
label: Paragraph

text: Commission, chairman of the US Commission of Fine Arts, and has sat on
label: Paragraph

text: the boards of numerous cultural institutions, including the Museum of
label: Paragraph

text: Modern Art. Better connected than this you do not get in the world of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The way in which Childs secured the Freedom Tower/One World Trade
label: Title

text: Center job for SOM but himself in particular could provide a master class in
label: Paragraph

text: the politics of major league architecture and urbanism. The details of
label: Paragraph

text: Childs’s eventual emergence at the forefront of a huge field of contenders is
label: Paragraph

text: far too complex to fully recapitulate here. Briefly, though, just six weeks
label: Paragraph

text: before the 2001 disaster, the New York real estate developer Larry
label: Paragraph

text: Silverstein bought a ninety-nine-year lease on the World Trade Center from
label: Paragraph

text: the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and then hired SOM to
label: Paragraph

text: renovate the Twin Towers. Three decades after the double colossi first
label: Caption

text: opened they were in a generally run-down condition and not at all
label: Paragraph

text: competitive with more recently built, technologically advanced skyscrapers
label: Paragraph

text: in Lower Manhattan. Thus SOM was already on the scene by September 11,
label: Paragraph

text: and it was delusional for anyone to think that the full-service megafirm
label: Paragraph

text: would relinquish such an immensely lucrative reconstruction job, which
label: Paragraph

text: was only its to lose, not anyone else’s to win.
label: Paragraph

text: This was well understood by Childs, who stood aside from the clamor
label: Paragraph

text: that surrounded what most people imagined to be an open competition to
label: Paragraph

text: determine the site’s future. As a seasoned veteran of New York City real
label: Paragraph

text: estate wars—the intricacies of which can scarcely be comprehended by
label: Paragraph

text: even the most experienced outsiders, as was discovered by Yoshio
label: Paragraph

text: Taniguchi during the construction of his Museum of Modern Art expansion
label: Paragraph

text: of 1997—2004—Childs knew that property rights in this country supersede
label: Paragraph

text: all other considerations when it comes to building in the public realm.
label: Paragraph

text: Furthermore, he understood that government officials would have no
label: Paragraph

text: recourse other than to go along with decisions made by Ground Zero’s
label: Paragraph

text: lawful leaseholder, unless they were prepared to give in to Silverstein’s
label: Paragraph

text: outrageous financial demands. Longtime observers of the New York
label: Paragraph

text: construction industry barely raised an eyebrow when they saw the clueless
label: Paragraph

text: tyro Daniel Libeskind, nominal master planner of the Trade Center site,
label: Caption

text: blown away like tumbleweed.
label: Paragraph

text: Anticipating this, Childs and his SOM team produced a_ fully
label: Paragraph

text: implementable design in record time. Unparalleled security concerns
label: Paragraph

text: required that the reinforced concrete-and-steel base of One World Trade
label: Paragraph

text: Center, approximately nineteen stories high, be as impenetrable as a 1950s
label: Paragraph

text: atomic bomb shelter. In a dubious attempt to prettify this veritable
label: Paragraph

text: fortification, Childs originally intended to cover it with two thousand clear
label: Paragraph

text: prismatic glass panels and welded aluminum-and-glass screens. However,
label: Paragraph

text: after $10 million had been spent on this decorative flourish, it proved too
label: Paragraph

text: technically daunting to execute, and more conventional glazing was
label: Paragraph

text: substituted. In the end, One World Trade Center, which cost $3.9 billion—
label: Paragraph

text: nearly twice the price of Western Europe’s tallest building, Renzo Piano’s
label: Paragraph

text: $1.9 billion Shard of 2000-2013, on London’s South Bank—became the
label: Paragraph

text: world’s most expensive skyscraper by a wide margin.
label: Paragraph

text: The tower’s interior is far stranger than its straightforward exterior,
label: Paragraph

text: understandably because of urgent protective measures. Visitors to the
label: Paragraph

text: observatory on the 102nd floor (2.3 million came during its first year) are
label: Paragraph

text: shepherded through a labyrinthine series of unnervingly lighted and plastic-
label: Paragraph

text: feeling walkways and holding areas on the ground floor, where security
label: Paragraph

text: checks are made before they arrive at the Sky Pod Elevators. These lifts
label: Paragraph

text: propel them to the summit in forty-two seconds, while an animated time-
label: Paragraph

text: lapse video, brilliantly designed by the California firms Blur Studio and
label: Paragraph

text: Hettema Group, plays on nine seventy-nine-inch high-definition screens
label: Paragraph

text: that line the elevator cabs. This simulation imagines how an eastward
label: Paragraph

text: outlook from the site appeared during the past five centuries, beginning
label: Paragraph

text: with lightly forested marshes circa 1500 and, a century later, gabled Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: houses that pop up and vanish. In due course the skyscrapers that made
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan world-famous shoot heavenward and are replaced by ever-taller
label: Paragraph

text: ones. Finally, for a fleeting four seconds, we catch a peripheral glimpse of
label: Paragraph

text: one of the vertically striped Twin Towers, which swiftly vanishes, happily
label: Paragraph

text: without any sign of what took place. One exits from this intense ride
label: Paragraph

text: thankful for the majestic panoramic views that extend peacefully in every
label: Paragraph

text: direction beyond the glass-walled rooftop gallery.
label: Paragraph

text: Without knowledge of Ground Zero’s terrible history, Childs’s design
label: Paragraph

text: would seem even less exceptional, just another super-colossal, shiny
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper made possible by all sorts of advanced engineering marvels but
label: Paragraph

text: unmistakably a thing of the past because of its fundamental lack of forward-
label: Paragraph

text: thinking urban planning ideas. It seems impossible to see this as anything
label: Paragraph

text: other than a placeholder for half of what once stood in its approximate
label: Paragraph

text: place, a feeling reinforced by the eloquent voids of Arad’s heartrending
label: Paragraph

text: memorial right in front of it.
label: Paragraph

text: The most architecturally ambitious portion of the ensemble, Santiago
label: Paragraph

text: Calatrava’s World Trade Center Transportation Hub (commonly called the
label: Paragraph

text: Oculus), opened to the public in 2016, though with no fanfare whatever,
label: Paragraph

text: doubtless to avoid drawing further attention to this stupendous waste of
label: Paragraph

text: public funds. Born in Valencia in 1951, Calatrava studied architecture in his
label: Paragraph

text: hometown before taking a doctorate in civil engineering from the
label: Paragraph

text: Eidgendssische Technische Hochschule (ETH) in Zurich in 1981. His rise
label: Paragraph

text: was astoundingly rapid, and by the time he was thirty he had completed
label: Paragraph

text: eight projects—most of them transportation infrastructure—in Switzerland,
label: Paragraph

text: Germany, and Spain. The Transportation Hub commission was a direct
label: Paragraph

text: result of Calatrava’s determination, as he turned fifty in 2001, to widen his
label: Paragraph

text: wildly successful Zurich-based practice to the United States. When he got
label: Paragraph

text: the job in 2003, he opened a New York office with the coy corporate name
label: Paragraph

text: of Festina Lente LLP (Latin for “make haste slowly”) to oversee its
label: Paragraph

text: execution. As things transpired, the project took twelve years to finish
label: Paragraph

text: instead of the five originally promised, and part of its exorbitant $4 billion
label: Paragraph

text: price will be paid over decades to come by commuters in the form of higher
label: Paragraph

text: transit fares. The fortune spent on this kitschy jeu d’esprit—nearly twice its
label: Paragraph

text: already unconscionable initial estimate of $2.2 billion—is even more
label: Paragraph

text: outrageous for a facility that serves only 40,000 commuters on an average
label: Paragraph

text: weekday, as opposed to the 750,000 who pass through Grand Central
label: Paragraph

text: Terminal daily. Astoundingly, the Transportation Hub wound up costing $1
label: Paragraph

text: billion more than One World Trade Center itself.
label: Paragraph

text: Calatrava’s budgetary excesses were already well known among
label: Paragraph

text: professionals by the time he received this commission. But the Lower
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan Development Corporation (LMDC)—the joint city-state body
label: Paragraph

text: established to carry out the reconstruction—had just gone through a
label: Paragraph

text: bruising public struggle to select a master planner for the entire site, and in
label: Paragraph

text: its eagerness for an architectural showpiece paid insufficient attention to the
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish architect’s troublesome track record and fell for the maudlin
label: Paragraph

text: sentimentalism of his design. What was originally likened by its creator to a
label: Paragraph

text: fluttering paloma de la paz (dove of peace) because of its white, winglike,
label: Paragraph

text: upwardly flaring rooflines seems more like a steroidal stegosaurus that
label: Paragraph

text: wandered onto the set of a sci-fi flick and died there (see Illustration 17c).
label: Paragraph

text: And instead of an ennobling civic concourse on the order of Grand Central
label: Paragraph

text: or Charles Follen McKim’s endlessly lamented Pennsylvania Station, what
label: Paragraph

text: we now have on top of the new transit facilities is an eerily dead-feeling,
label: Paragraph

text: retro-futuristic, Space Age Gothic shopping mall with acres of highly
label: Paragraph

text: polished, very slippery white marble flooring like some urban tundra (see
label: Paragraph

text: Illustration 17b).
label: Paragraph

text: Formally known as Westfield World Trade Center, it is filled with the
label: Paragraph

text: same predictable mix of chain retailers one can find in countless airports
label: Paragraph

text: worldwide: Banana Republic, Hugo Boss, Breitling, Dior, and on through
label: Paragraph

text: the global designer-label alphabet. (The Westfield Corporation is an
label: Paragraph

text: Australian-based British-American shopping center company.) Far from
label: Paragraph

text: this being the “exhilarating nave of a genuine people’s cathedral” that Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Goldberger claimed it to be in Vanity Fair, Calatrava’s superfluous
label: Paragraph

text: shopping shrine is merely what the Germans call a Konsumtempel (temple
label: Paragraph

text: of consumption), and a generic one at that.
label: Paragraph

text: Still to come among the ensemble’s components are 2 World Trade
label: Paragraph

text: Center by the Bjarke Ingels Group (BIG) and 3 World Trade Center by the
label: Paragraph

text: office of Richard Rogers. Plans are doubtful for a putative 5 World Trade
label: Paragraph

text: Center (to replace the former Deutsche Bank Building, which was
label: Paragraph

text: irreparably damaged by debris from the collapse of the Twin Towers and
label: Paragraph

text: laboriously dismantled) and no architect has been selected. And there will
label: Paragraph

text: be no 6 World Trade Center to replace that eight-story component of
label: Paragraph

text: Yamasaki’s original five-building World Trade Center ensemble, also
label: Paragraph

text: destroyed on September 11.
label: Paragraph

text: The prodigious public interest in the resurrection of Ground Zero quickly
label: Paragraph

text: prompted three books about the first phases of the effort, all aimed at a
label: Paragraph

text: general readership and published within four months of one another around
label: Paragraph

text: the disaster’s third anniversary. Goldberger’s Up from Zero: Politics,
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture, and the Rebuilding of New York (2004) was one of his
label: Paragraph

text: typically well-reported but never indiscreet overviews. Philip Nobel’s
label: Paragraph

text: Sixteen Acres: Architecture and the Outrageous Struggle for the Future of
label: Title

text: Ground Zero (2005) offered a juicier, more anecdotal account of the same
label: Paragraph

text: events. But both books suffered from a lack of adequate illustrations, a
label: Paragraph

text: shortcoming rectified by Suzanne Stephens’s pictorially rich compendium
label: Paragraph

text: Imagining Ground Zero: Official and Unofficial Proposals for the World
label: Title

text: Trade Center Site (2004).
label: Caption

text: A decade after that initial flurry of publications, what is likely to remain
label: Paragraph

text: the definitive account of this tortuous and unedifying saga appeared, Lynne
label: Paragraph

text: B. Sagalyn’s Power at Ground Zero: Politics, Money, and the Remaking of
label: Title

text: Lower Manhattan (2016). Sagalyn, who retired as a professor of real estate
label: Paragraph

text: at the Columbia University Business School, insists that there are no heroes
label: Paragraph

text: or villains in her narrative. However, her meticulous and exceptionally clear
label: Paragraph

text: exposition of the essential facts provides more than enough evidence for
label: Paragraph

text: readers to come to their own, and often damning, conclusions, especially
label: Paragraph

text: about Silverstein.
label: Paragraph

text: Her exhaustive research exposed some fascinating interrelationships in
label: Paragraph

text: the upper echelons of the city’s power elite, which will be unsurprising to
label: Paragraph

text: those who know how the financial and cultural capital of the US really
label: Paragraph

text: works, and insider glimpses are rarely documented as directly as she does
label: Paragraph

text: here. For example, she tells how the well-connected attorney Edward
label: Paragraph

text: Hayes, a “New York political infighter” and “go-to guy,” urged Governor
label: Paragraph

text: Pataki, a former Columbia Law School contemporary of his, to pick Daniel
label: Paragraph

text: Libeskind’s scheme in the competition for the site’s master plan. Hayes had
label: Paragraph

text: been introduced to Libeskind and his business-manager wife, Nina, by
label: Paragraph

text: Victoria Newhouse—an architectural historian and the wife of the
label: Paragraph

text: publishing magnate S. I. Newhouse Jr—who was avid to see Libeskind win
label: Paragraph

text: the commission. Pataki reassured Hayes that he was already in favor of
label: Paragraph

text: Libeskind’s proposal and indeed intervened at the last moment to ensure
label: Paragraph

text: that he was chosen. It was a pyrrhic victory for the architect, however.
label: Paragraph

text: Libeskind assumed that winning the contest would also entitle him to
label: Paragraph

text: design the Freedom Tower, but because of his limited experience with such
label: Paragraph

text: large-scale projects, he was forced to collaborate with Childs, who edged
label: Paragraph

text: him out of the commission with Machiavellian dispatch.
label: Paragraph

text: Si Newhouse resurfaces later in the story when the question of who
label: Paragraph

text: would actually occupy the Freedom Tower becomes an urgent matter. His
label: Paragraph

text: Condé Nast Publications was identified as the ideal “anchor tenant” by
label: Paragraph

text: Silverstein’s long-time leasing broker, Mary Ann Tighe of CBRE, the
label: Paragraph

text: world’s largest commercial real estate services firm, who had known the
label: Paragraph

text: publisher for decades. Given the perceived danger of another terrorist
label: Paragraph

text: attack, this would not be an easy sell, but Tighe recalled that Condé Nast
label: Paragraph

text: had been previously receptive to an undesirable address at the right price: it
label: Paragraph

text: relocated from its longtime Madison Avenue headquarters to the newly built
label: Paragraph

text: 4 Times Square in 1999, when that area still had a seedy aura. The
label: Paragraph

text: developer of 4 Times Square, the Durst Organization, received tax
label: Paragraph

text: incentives estimated at more than $280 million, which allowed it to give
label: Paragraph

text: Condé Nast very favorable terms, a classic example of corporate welfare at
label: Paragraph

text: taxpayer expense. Durst partnered with the cash-strapped Silverstein on
label: Paragraph

text: One World Trade Center once it became an active, risk-free proposition,
label: Paragraph

text: and Condé Nast agreed to move to Ground Zero when it was offered yet
label: Paragraph

text: another sweetheart deal on a property widely deemed to be very difficult to
label: Paragraph

text: rent.
label: Paragraph

text: A more visible display of influence was orchestrated by Herbert
label: Paragraph

text: Muschamp, the New York Times architecture critic from 1992 to 2004. As
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Gehry told the writer Clay Risen, the architect and the critic dined
label: Paragraph

text: together in Manhattan the night before the Twin Towers attack, and the
label: Paragraph

text: ensuing catastrophe so traumatized Muschamp that he felt unable to leave
label: Paragraph

text: his forty-fourth-floor Tribeca apartment, several blocks north of Ground
label: Paragraph

text: Zero, for some time afterward. Thus he deprived the Newspaper of Record
label: Paragraph

text: of his immediate insights on the biggest architectural news story of modern
label: Paragraph

text: times for nearly three weeks. Perhaps to compensate for this glaring lapse,
label: Paragraph

text: he organized a special issue of The New York Times Magazine that
label: Paragraph

text: presented his notions of how the site ought to be reconfigured, which was
label: Paragraph

text: published the Sunday before the first anniversary of September 11.
label: Paragraph

text: Muschamp had been dismayed that several months earlier the LMDC and
label: Paragraph

text: the Port Authority had selected the architectural and planning office Beyer
label: Paragraph

text: Blinder Belle (BBB) to develop a master plan. Although that partnership
label: Paragraph

text: had won universal praise for its exemplary restoration of Grand Central
label: Paragraph

text: Station that began in 1990, the Times critic deemed BBB insufficiently
label: Paragraph

text: adventurous for this assignment. Accordingly he invited many of his
label: Paragraph

text: favorite practitioners, older figures of the New York avant-garde as well as
label: Paragraph

text: younger trendsetters, to submit their own ideas and assigned parts of the
label: Paragraph

text: project to them. The fact that these hypothetical schemes lacked even the
label: Paragraph

text: most basic information that architects need to draw up design proposals—a
label: Paragraph

text: budget and a functional program beyond vague designations (school, arts
label: Title

text: center, and the like}—seemed not to bother either Muschamp or his
label: Paragraph

text: nominees. As Sagalyn writes in one of her rare overt expressions of
label: Paragraph

text: disapproval:
label: Title

text: This was not city building. Architecture may be art and city building
label: Paragraph

text: calls for artlike understanding of the fabric of a place, but a city is not
label: Paragraph

text: a blank canvas to paint at will as Muschamp was advocating with his
label: Paragraph

text: study project, most unrealistically. . . .
label: Paragraph

text: Irresponsibly, Muschamp had preemptively pronounced his personal
label: Paragraph

text: opinion of what was likely to result before BBB had even drawn a
label: Paragraph

text: single line. Did this belong in the news section of the paper? Where
label: Paragraph

text: does the press cross the line between presenting the news to inform the
label: Paragraph

text: public and aiming to become a player by advocating a particular vision
label: Paragraph

text: —other than on the editorial page?
label: Paragraph

text: Yet this self-appointed planner was scarcely oblivious to urban design
label: Paragraph

text: realpolitik (nor were the LMDC and the Port Authority, which swiftly
label: Paragraph

text: withdrew the commission from BBB and announced an open competition to
label: Paragraph

text: find a new planning firm). Immediately after Libeskind’s master plan was
label: Paragraph

text: chosen over Rafael Vifioly’s proposal—the latter centered by a scaffold-
label: Paragraph

text: like, smaller reiteration of the Twin Towers that Muschamp championed but
label: Paragraph

text: that Pataki tactlessly likened to a pair of skeletons—the critic made an
label: Paragraph

text: astonishing volte-face and wrote that the best scheme had won after all.
label: Paragraph

text: This aesthetic influence-peddling, whether in the back corridors of
label: Paragraph

text: government, the salons of the powerful, or the nation’s most prestigious
label: Paragraph

text: newspaper, was nothing compared to the nonstop machinations of the
label: Paragraph

text: pivotal figure in this tawdry drama, Silverstein, who before September 11
label: Paragraph

text: had been considered a fairly minor player and something of a bottom-fisher
label: Paragraph

text: among the big-deal machers of the New York real estate establishment.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Sagalyn’s portrait of Silverstein accords with the general outlines
label: Paragraph

text: of previously published reports, here he emerges even more unfavorably as
label: Paragraph

text: his actions are recounted in greater detail than ever before, thanks to the
label: Paragraph

text: author’s extensive interviews and her informants’ willingness to speak
label: Paragraph

text: candidly about him (an indication of how much rancor he aroused). At the
label: Paragraph

text: heart of the matter was Silverstein’s unshakable determination that all ten
label: Paragraph

text: million square feet of office space lost in the Twin Towers’ collapse be
label: Paragraph

text: replaced, a position driven by his desire to protect the maximum future
label: Paragraph

text: profitability of his investment.
label: Paragraph

text: However, this did not accord with the changing economic realities of
label: Paragraph

text: postmillennial Lower Manhattan, and his sheer stubbornness struck the
label: Paragraph

text: New York City mayor Michael Bloomberg and the technocratic urbanists
label: Title

text: around him as fundamentally uninformed and misguided (to put it in the
label: Paragraph

text: most polite terms). Sagalyn quotes Daniel Doctoroff, Bloomberg’s deputy
label: Paragraph

text: mayor for economic development and rebuilding, as pointing out that
label: Paragraph

text: “Lower Manhattan before 9/11 had a growing residential population, but it
label: Paragraph

text: had been losing worker population since 1970,” even as the construction of
label: Paragraph

text: the original World Trade Center was still underway. The changing
label: Paragraph

text: demographic needs of this part of the city, Doctoroff said, “were swept
label: Paragraph

text: under the rug in the wake of 9/11 by this kind of nostalgia for the World
label: Paragraph

text: Trade Center and the tremendous emotion that existed.”
label: Paragraph

text: The Bloomberg administration favored a varied mix of components with
label: Paragraph

text: less emphasis on offices and more housing units, in line with the growing
label: Paragraph

text: residential character of the Financial District, where many old commercial
label: Paragraph

text: buildings that are no longer suitable for today’s high-tech businesses had
label: Paragraph

text: already been converted to apartments, often very costly ones, a trend that
label: Paragraph

text: continued apace during the second decade of the millennium. But
label: Paragraph

text: Silverstein’s representatives (including Tighe) aggressively pressed his case
label: Paragraph

text: for a full ten-million-square-foot build-out, and hammered home the
label: Paragraph

text: questionable assertion that the boom-or-bust nature of New York City
label: Paragraph

text: building cycles demanded readiness for the next inevitable upswing (this
label: Paragraph

text: was before the international market meltdown of 2008). Conveniently
label: Paragraph

text: omitted by the developer’s team was the financial history of the World
label: Paragraph

text: Trade Center. The complex was built during a recessionary period, and it
label: Paragraph

text: took until the 1980s for it to finally turn a profit; it did so only because of
label: Paragraph

text: the artificial life support of state government agencies that had been
label: Paragraph

text: transplanted to the Twin Towers by New York governor Nelson Rockefeller,
label: Paragraph

text: a brother of that quixotic scheme’s mastermind, David Rockefeller, who
label: Paragraph

text: held top positions at the Chase Manhattan Bank from 1957 to 1981.
label: Paragraph

text: Bloomberg and his advisers repeatedly tried to gain control of the
label: Paragraph

text: beleaguered project and impose the focused leadership and purposeful
label: Paragraph

text: direction it lacked. Their most ingenious attempt was a Solomonic solution
label: Paragraph

text: advanced by Roy Bahat, then a twenty-four-year-old aide to Doctoroff, who
label: Paragraph

text: suggested a swap of the land underneath Kennedy and LaGuardia airports
label: Paragraph

text: —the city owns that real estate but the Port Authority runs the facilities on
label: Paragraph

text: it—in return for the Trade Center acreage, owned by the Port Authority.
label: Paragraph

text: This would have allowed the city to invoke eminent domain, cancel
label: Paragraph

text: Silverstein’s lease, and be done with him. Although the Times praised this
label: Paragraph

text: as “the most creative idea to arise from the Lower Manhattan
label: Paragraph

text: redevelopment process so far,” the trade-off foundered not only because of
label: Paragraph

text: the tangled economics of how evaluations for the respective assets would be
label: Paragraph

text: calculated but also because it was stymied by officials who foresaw
label: Paragraph

text: themselves losing power if the deal went through.
label: Paragraph

text: As is typical of such betrayals of the public trust, there was more than
label: Paragraph

text: enough blame to go around. Sagalyn names names, and they include Port
label: Paragraph

text: Authority vice-chairman Charles Gargano, described by the author as “‘a
label: Paragraph

text: loyal Pataki soldier’. . . said to be riled by the swap proposal, a threat to his
label: Paragraph

text: influence; he had already been ‘a loser in a bid to control the [LMDC]’. In
label: Paragraph

text: the end it was a political decision—for Governor Pataki.” At that time
label: Paragraph

text: Pataki harbored presidential ambitions and felt that his continuing
label: Paragraph

text: involvement in rebuilding Ground Zero would elevate his national
label: Paragraph

text: reputation. As a result of these and other complications, the swap died in
label: Paragraph

text: June 2003.
label: Paragraph

text: Whatever one might think of Bloomberg’s often high-handed approach to
label: Paragraph

text: urbanism and civic governance, which tended to favor corporate interests at
label: Paragraph

text: the expense of other concerns, there can be little doubt that he did a number
label: Paragraph

text: of very good things for New York City during his long tenure as mayor and
label: Paragraph

text: would have been a far better overseer of the World Trade Center
label: Paragraph

text: redevelopment than any other major figure on the scene at that time.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the institutions involved in the rebuilding, none is portrayed more
label: Paragraph

text: critically by Sagalyn than the Port Authority, and rightly so. Its preference
label: Paragraph

text: for investing in chancy real estate speculations instead of focusing on an
label: Paragraph

text: overburdened transportation system and crumbling regional infrastructure
label: Title

text: remains a long-running scandal, and a thorough overhaul of that bistate
label: Paragraph

text: agency would seem to be the only solution to correcting the abuses detailed
label: Paragraph

text: so revealingly by Sagalyn.
label: Paragraph

text: High among other factors that greatly complicated the rebuilding of the
label: Paragraph

text: Trade Center site were recent advances in DNA verification methods. The
label: Paragraph

text: conjunction of those new capacities with the 2001 catastrophe served as the
label: Paragraph

text: basis for a thoughtful and solidly informed meditation, Who Owns the
label: Paragraph

text: Dead?: The Science and Politics of Death at Ground Zero (2016) by Jay D.
label: Caption

text: Aronson, a professor at Carnegie Mellon University and director of its
label: Paragraph

text: Center for Human Rights Science. Because it is now easier than ever to
label: Paragraph

text: identify human remains found at sites of mass disasters, expectations ran
label: Paragraph

text: high among many bereaved families that they might reclaim some corporeal
label: Paragraph

text: vestige of their dead relatives. It was once expected that those lost at sea
label: Paragraph

text: would lie forever asleep in the deep, much as soldiers killed in foreign wars
label: Paragraph

text: would be buried near where they fell. However, modern science has
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged a broad belief that the retrieval of physical matter, no matter
label: Paragraph

text: how tiny, is essential to attaining “closure”—that vaunted but elusive goal
label: Paragraph

text: of contemporary grieving.
label: Paragraph

text: Fifteen years after the catastrophe, remains of 1,113 of the disaster’s
label: Paragraph

text: victims—or some 40 percent of the death toll—were still unidentified. At
label: Paragraph

text: several points during the slow, painstaking, dignified, and respectful
label: Paragraph

text: recovery process, officials announced that the search had been concluded,
label: Paragraph

text: but family members who had not yet been given definitive physical proof
label: Paragraph

text: demanded further forensic analysis. As it turned out, though, spot checks
label: Paragraph

text: confirmed that minute amounts of residue from the victims were still
label: Paragraph

text: discernible in the surrounding area, a finding that prompted an even more
label: Paragraph

text: microscopic investigation, which in some areas went inch by inch through
label: Paragraph

text: newly discovered concentrations of possible physical evidence. This
label: Paragraph

text: renewed task was pursued with a vigilance that the participating experts
label: Paragraph

text: vouchsafed was much more thorough than any they had witnessed before,
label: Paragraph

text: and it verged on the exactitude of an archaeological dig. As a result,
label: Paragraph

text: additional names were subsequently associated with the powdery
label: Paragraph

text: particulate.
label: Paragraph

text: But to what end was this search increasingly obsessive? As Aronson
label: Paragraph

text: writes:
label: Paragraph

text: The thought of unidentified remains is unnerving, especially for a
label: Paragraph

text: society that wants to believe it has the technical capacity to provide
label: Paragraph

text: some measure of certainty in an uncertain world. . . . It is ironic, then,
label: Paragraph

text: that the individualization of the victims of the World Trade Center has
label: Paragraph

text: made it more politically palatable for the US government to engage in
label: Paragraph

text: a seemingly perpetual war that has created innumerable casualties in
label: Paragraph

text: Afghanistan, Iraq, Pakistan, Yemen, and elsewhere.
label: Paragraph

text: The truth of the matter, though, was that no one—the dead of September 11,
label: Paragraph

text: their survivors, or the American public at large—would be allowed to rest
label: Paragraph

text: in peace.
