text: ALEXANDER GORLIN
label: Title

text: THE SKYLINE OF New York went through a century and a quarter of
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly dramatic changes after the completion of Bradford Gilbert’s
label: Paragraph

text: steel-framed, eleven-story Tower Building of 1889, arguably the city’s first
label: Paragraph

text: skyscraper, which was demolished in 1914. But during the second decade of
label: Paragraph

text: the twenty-first century a strange and sudden transformation altered New
label: Title

text: York’s character radically. Although a rash of so-called sliver towers
label: Paragraph

text: emerged in Manhattan during the 1980s, often on midblock sites that
label: Paragraph

text: exploited loopholes in zoning laws, none of them made a notable impact on
label: Paragraph

text: the city’s vertical profile. But that began to change when New York became
label: Paragraph

text: a magnet for international capital on a scale unprecedented in its history.
label: Paragraph

text: Since New York’s founding in the early seventeenth century as a Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: trading outpost, most of its residents have been renters rather than owners.
label: Paragraph

text: From the pre-Revolutionary period until World War IU, tenants were
label: Paragraph

text: uniformly given three months’ notice of annual rent increases on February 1
label: Paragraph

text: (known as Rent Day). Many then sought cheaper deals, and when all leases
label: Paragraph

text: expired on May 1 (called Moving Day), as many as a million residents
label: Paragraph

text: changed homes. Beginning in 2014, another, more specialized real estate
label: Paragraph

text: frenzy took hold in the city, signaling a recovery from the collapse of
label: Paragraph

text: financial markets in 2008, and its most visible manifestations involved
label: Paragraph

text: some of the world’s richest people. In December 2014 a long-anticipated
label: Paragraph

text: threshold was crossed when a duplex penthouse atop the French architect
label: Paragraph

text: Christian de Portzamparce’s One57 condominium of 2009-2014, built by the
label: Paragraph

text: Extell Development Company on West 57th Street between Sixth and
label: Caption

text: Seventh Avenues, sold for $100,471,452.77 (see Illustration 18a). In the
label: Paragraph

text: same year, seven more apartments in that building changed hands for
label: Paragraph

text: between $32 million and $56 million each, which together accounted for
label: Paragraph

text: more than a third of New York’s two dozen biggest residential transactions
label: Paragraph

text: of 2014. In January 2015 a duplex there fetched $90 million.
label: Paragraph

text: Portzamparc’s tower of monetary power stands two blocks south of
label: Paragraph

text: Central Park, at the epicenter of Manhattan’s densest concentration of top-
label: Paragraph

text: of-the-line apartment construction since Fifth and Park Avenues were built
label: Paragraph

text: up between the two world wars. The block directly west of One57 awaits
label: Paragraph

text: the completion of another Extell venture, Nordstrom Tower of 2014-2019,
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Adrian Smith (architect of the world’s tallest structure, the Burj
label: Caption

text: Khalifa of 2003-2010 in Dubai) and Gordon Gill. Comprising a branch of
label: Paragraph

text: the Nordstrom’s fashion retailer at street level, a hotel above the store, and
label: Paragraph

text: condos on the uppermost stories—unobstructed park views commence at
label: Paragraph

text: 225 feet, hence this sequence—it rises next to and over Henry
label: Paragraph

text: Hardenbergh’s Art Students League of 1891-1892 and will become the
label: Paragraph

text: city’s tallest residential building at 1,775 feet when it opens.
label: Paragraph

text: Nordstrom’s effortful piggybacking was made possible not only by
label: Paragraph

text: creative engineering but also by the developer’s purchase of the art school’s
label: Paragraph

text: air rights—that is, the titular transfer of empty vertical space above nearby
label: Paragraph

text: buildings never used to the full extent permissible by zoning laws. Such
label: Paragraph

text: stratagems are an essential part of the complex legal and economic equation
label: Paragraph

text: (what the skyscraper historian Carol Willis has termed “invisible
label: Paragraph

text: Monopoly,” after the board game) that has allowed these super-tall, super-
label: Paragraph

text: thin towers to multiply in Midtown North, as planners and police call the
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhood.
label: Paragraph

text: Several similar towers are underway around 23rd Street near Madison
label: Paragraph

text: Square and in Lower Manhattan, but the rarefied calculus of this niche
label: Paragraph

text: market hinges on location. Thus, even though seasoned New Yorkers have
label: Paragraph

text: long deemed Central Park South somewhat socially marginal—during the
label: Paragraph

text: 1980s brokers dubbed it “Mistress Row” for the many kept women with
label: Paragraph

text: apartments there—or the province of out-of-towners who frequented its
label: Paragraph

text: fancy hotels (the Plaza, the St. Moritz, Essex House) and _ touristy
label: Paragraph

text: restaurants (Trader Vic’s, Rumpelmayer’s, Mickey Mantle’s—which are
label: Paragraph

text: now gone), foreign buyers still consider it the golden core of the Big Apple.
label: Paragraph

text: On the same block as One57, SHoP Architects’ 111 West 57th Street will
label: Paragraph

text: have the dubious distinction of being the world’s slenderest building, thanks
label: Paragraph

text: to the extreme contrast between its tiny 60-foot-wide base and attenuated
label: Paragraph

text: 1,421-foot height. By way of comparison, the base-to-height ratio of
label: Paragraph

text: Minoru Yamasaki’s World Trade Center was 1:7; 111 West 57th Street’s
label: Paragraph

text: will be 1:23. Like both One57 and Nordstrom, 111 will have a glass curtain
label: Paragraph

text: wall, and its full-floor apartments will all afford views north to Central Park
label: Paragraph

text: panoramas. Despite its being a technical feat of engineering—the building
label: Paragraph

text: is heavily weighted at its top to stabilize it in high winds—111 will be an
label: Paragraph

text: annoyingly intrusive and yet strangely elusive urban presence, the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural equivalent of Chauncey Gardner, Peter Sellers’s here-but-not-
label: Paragraph

text: here character in Hal Ashby’s film Being There (1979).
label: Paragraph

text: The two financial prototypes for this new breed of ultra-luxury towers
label: Paragraph

text: were David Childs and Mustafa Kemal Abadan’s Time Warner Center of
label: Paragraph

text: 2000-2003 on Columbus Circle and Robert A. M. Stern’s 15 Central Park
label: Caption

text: West of 2005-2008, both a few blocks north of 57th Street. These
label: Paragraph

text: condominiums were specifically designed to attract an emergent class of
label: Paragraph

text: plutocrats who might have difficulty buying into Manhattan’s most
label: Paragraph

text: exclusive cooperative apartment buildings, whose boards of directors,
label: Paragraph

text: unaccountable to antidiscrimination laws, routinely blackballed Jews,
label: Paragraph

text: blacks, gays, single women, show-business performers, or anyone whose
label: Paragraph

text: source of wealth they considered less than respectable.
label: Paragraph

text: The 1990s witnessed the high-tech, telecommunications, and dot-com
label: Paragraph

text: booms, the rise of hedge funds, the privatization of the former Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: Union’s natural resources, and the ascendance of China’s state-controlled
label: Paragraph

text: capitalism. Together, these developments radically altered standards of
label: Paragraph

text: private wealth worldwide. In the top bracket of Manhattan real estate there
label: Paragraph

text: were said to be only fifty or so extremely desirable apartment houses,
label: Paragraph

text: symptomatic of the oddly persistent scarcity of premium housing in
label: Paragraph

text: America’s financial hub. Here was a gaping hole at the high end of the
label: Paragraph

text: market begging to be filled, and if nature abhors a vacuum, no less do New
label: Paragraph

text: York real estate developers hate missing out on a sure source of big money.
label: Paragraph

text: Although major fortunes have increasingly trumped religious, racial, or
label: Paragraph

text: social biases, some Manhattan co-ops require purchasers to have liquid
label: Paragraph

text: assets equal to many multiples of an apartment’s price, which has limited
label: Paragraph

text: sales of them to an even smaller portion of the so-called one percent. If you
label: Paragraph

text: buy a co-op, you buy shares in the building; if you want to leave, it is up to
label: Paragraph

text: you to sell the shares to someone who can win approval of the board of
label: Paragraph

text: directors. Conversely, if a condominium board turns down a sale it must
label: Paragraph

text: buy back the apartment, an effective deterrent to rejection. Thus the off-
label: Paragraph

text: spring of deposed African dictators are as welcome at condos as Social
label: Paragraph

text: Register scions, and this ease of access has attracted shady characters who
label: Paragraph

text: would never get past the boards of the toniest old-guard citadels.
label: Paragraph

text: Well after 15 Central Park West was completed, high-priced resales there
label: Paragraph

text: continued to dominate the Big Deals column in The New York Times
label: Paragraph

text: Sunday real estate section, which celebrated each week’s largest residential
label: Paragraph

text: property closings. Until the $100 million blockbuster at One57 in 2014, the
label: Paragraph

text: most expensive apartment in town had been 15 Central Park West’s
label: Paragraph

text: penthouse, which the former Citigroup CEO Sanford Weill sold in 2011 to a
label: Paragraph

text: daughter of a Russian oligarch for $88 million. Weill more than doubled his
label: Paragraph

text: investment four years after buying the full-floor flat for a then-record $42.4
label: Paragraph

text: million. Nothing succeeds commercially like mimicry of success, and
label: Paragraph

text: Stern’s limestone-clad, neotraditional design for that building was closely
label: Paragraph

text: modeled after the 1920s and 1930s apartment houses of Rosario Candela,
label: Paragraph

text: the Sicilian-bom architect whose uncommonly capacious, generously
label: Paragraph

text: detailed apartments are widely judged the city’s most coveted. (The second-
label: Paragraph

text: costliest New York residential transfer in 2014 amounted to $71 million at
label: Paragraph

text: Candela’s legendary 740 Park Avenue.) Stern’s 15 Central Park West has
label: Paragraph

text: been termed “the Limestone Jesus” because this $950 million endeavor was
label: Paragraph

text: seen by many to have miraculously risen from the dead after the 2008 crash
label: Paragraph

text: killed off several other grandiose development schemes.
label: Paragraph

text: The stupendous financial success of 15 Central Park West has brought its
label: Paragraph

text: architect many more apartment building commissions, including 220
label: Paragraph

text: Central Park South, a condominium two blocks due north of Nordstrom—
label: Paragraph

text: so due that the buildings’ respective developers waged a costly legal battle
label: Paragraph

text: because 220 would have blocked Nordstrom’s park views. The lawsuit was
label: Paragraph

text: settled when each party agreed to shift its tower—Stern’s to the west, Smith
label: Paragraph

text: and Gill’s to the east—and Extell received $194 million from the builder at
label: Paragraph

text: 220 Central Park South for an adjoining Central Park South parking garage,
label: Caption

text: demolition of which allowed construction to proceed. The two broader
label: Paragraph

text: elevations of Stern’s building face east—west rather than north-south, but at
label: Paragraph

text: a mere 950 feet it will rank only tenth-highest among Manhattan
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers. This late-Deco pastiche in some ways is preferable to the other
label: Paragraph

text: new condos crowding the area, which, faute de mieux, indicates the
label: Paragraph

text: generally low architectural state of New York’s postmillennial housing for
label: Paragraph

text: the super-rich.
label: Paragraph

text: The Manhattan high-rise that had everyone talking when it seemed to
label: Paragraph

text: materialize almost overnight during the summer of 2014 is 432 Park
label: Paragraph

text: Avenue, the skinny eighty-nine-story spire that soars above the northwest
label: Paragraph

text: comer of East 56th Street and Park on the site of the old Drake Hotel (see
label: Caption

text: Illustration 18b). It was designed by the New York-based architect Rafael
label: Paragraph

text: Vifioly, and became the highest residential structure in the Western
label: Paragraph

text: Hemisphere at 1,397 feet, as well as New York City’s second-tallest
label: Paragraph

text: building (after David Childs’s One World Trade Center). Actually, it was
label: Paragraph

text: the loftiest by twenty-eight feet in terms of habitable space, since a
label: Paragraph

text: broadcasting mast accounts for the uppermost 408 feet of the Childs tower.
label: Paragraph

text: Many observers have reported being bemused, not to say unnerved, by
label: Paragraph

text: the Vifioly building’s strange ubiquitousness. Visible throughout all five
label: Paragraph

text: boroughs and as far away as Long Island and New Jersey, the tower startles
label: Paragraph

text: both visitors and natives with its looming omnipresence, and seems to
label: Paragraph

text: follow you around like a bad conscience. One doesn’t hear much about 432
label: Paragraph

text: Park’s design for the good reason that artistic niceties are almost beside the
label: Paragraph

text: point in the mathematical conjuring that brought it and its peers into being.
label: Paragraph

text: You could even say this structure resembles a three-dimensional balance
label: Paragraph

text: sheet more than a fully articulated architectural facade. And while Stern
label: Paragraph

text: clings to a passé Postmodernism—his Manhattan jobs are drenched in a
label: Paragraph

text: gooey nostalgia tinged with outer-borough longing akin to Gershwin via
label: Paragraph

text: Woody Allen—Vifioly hews closely to the reductive aesthetic of High
label: Paragraph

text: Modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Rafael Vifioly Beceiro was born in 1944 in Montevideo, Uruguay. His
label: Paragraph

text: father was a movie director with twenty-eight films to his credit, his mother
label: Paragraph

text: a mathematics teacher. After receiving degrees in architecture from the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Buenos Aires in 1968 and 1969, he worked for the better part
label: Paragraph

text: of the next decade in Argentina. His early activities there became a sudden
label: Paragraph

text: controversy in 2003 when, on the moming the master planner for the
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilding of the World Trade Center was to be selected, The Wall Street
label: Paragraph

text: Journal published a front-page story recounting that Vifioly had worked for
label: Paragraph

text: the murderous right-wing military junta that sponsored the FIFA World Cup
label: Paragraph

text: stadium of 1976-1978 in Mendoza, Argentina. Although Vifioly was indeed
label: Paragraph

text: a member of the design team for that arena, he immigrated to the United
label: Paragraph

text: States the year it was completed, and set up his own office in Manhattan in
label: Paragraph

text: 1983. However, the eleventh-hour Journal story may have been damaging
label: Paragraph

text: enough to tip the scales in favor of the other finalist, Daniel Libeskind, who
label: Paragraph

text: won the coveted Ground Zero commission.
label: Paragraph

text: This was a rare setback for Vifioly, but not his only case of bad publicity.
label: Paragraph

text: His 20 Fenchurch Street skyscraper of 2009-2014 in London’s financial
label: Paragraph

text: district—nicknamed “the Walkie-Talkie”—acted as a concave mirror that
label: Paragraph

text: focused hotspots of up to 243 degrees Fahrenheit on its immediate
label: Paragraph

text: surroundings. A similar problem also occurred at the architect’s Vdara
label: Paragraph

text: Hotel of 2006-2009 in Las Vegas, where what workers called “the Vdara
label: Paragraph

text: death ray” was strong enough to melt plastic cups and burn hair. In both
label: Paragraph

text: instances the buildings’ surfaces were given a protective film to reduce this
label: Paragraph

text: solar effect, which Vifioly blamed on global warming.
label: Paragraph

text: Although less laser-like in its environmental impact, the exterior of
label: Paragraph

text: Vifioly’s 432 Park Avenue imparts a graphic feel accentuated by the flatness
label: Paragraph

text: of the building’s four identical sides, as well as the bold contrast between its
label: Paragraph

text: dark glass windows (six large square panes per story) and white concrete
label: Caption

text: panels that frame the Minimalist fenestration. But what most sets this oddly
label: Paragraph

text: disturbing composition apart is the way it shoots straight upward to its full,
label: Paragraph

text: vertiginous height, with none of the horizontal setbacks or vertical
label: Paragraph

text: indentations that define the classic Art Deco apartment houses Stern cribs
label: Paragraph

text: for his pastiches.
label: Paragraph

text: Together with the Viftoly building’s relatively small footprint (ninety-
label: Paragraph

text: three feet square, about one quarter the length of a football field), this
label: Paragraph

text: uninterrupted ascent was made possible by city regulations that waive
label: Paragraph

text: upper-story “wedding cake” setback requirements—instituted in 1916 to
label: Paragraph

text: prevent overbuilt Lower Manhattan streets from turning into lightless,
label: Paragraph

text: airless canyons—but only if a building occupies no more than one quarter
label: Paragraph

text: of its lot. Yet when prices for Manhattan residences in prime locations
label: Paragraph

text: started going through the roof, it hardly seemed wasteful to leave 75 percent
label: Paragraph

text: of a plot empty on a $1.25 billion speculation like 432 Park.
label: Paragraph

text: Among these proportionally attenuated but financially overloaded
label: Paragraph

text: towers, design elements not directly tied to profit were often downgraded or
label: Paragraph

text: eliminated as overall costs climbed. For example, Portzamparc poetically
label: Paragraph

text: predicted that the rippling glass exterior he initially planned for One57
label: Paragraph

text: would evoke a cascading waterfall. As executed, however, the flat surface
label: Paragraph

text: of the building’s variously blue, gray, and silver panes fades into a pixelated
label: Paragraph

text: blur even from a short distance. With these mathematically generated super-
label: Paragraph

text: spires, it’s best to paraphrase Mae West: “Architecture has nothing to do
label: Paragraph

text: with it.”
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural prestige, however, had a great deal to do with why
label: Paragraph

text: Portzamparc was chosen for this assignment in the first place, specifically
label: Paragraph

text: his being awarded the the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 1994, just before
label: Paragraph

text: his fiftieth birthday, reportedly thanks to the strenuous electioneering of
label: Paragraph

text: Ada Louise Huxtable, the longtime New York Times architecture critic and
label: Paragraph

text: Pritzker juror. Portzamparc’s selection was surprising given his relative lack
label: Paragraph

text: of built works, and was based largely on the City of Music of 1984-1995 in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris, a lesser component of President Francois Mitterrand’s Grands Projets,
label: Paragraph

text: the series of eight major public works that more famously include I. M.
label: Paragraph

text: Pei’s Louvre Pyramid and Gae Aulenti’s Musée d’Orsay.
label: Paragraph

text: Portzamparc was born in Casablanca in 1944, the son of a peripatetic
label: Paragraph

text: French army officer. He began studying architecture at the Ecole des
label: Paragraph

text: Beaux-Arts in Paris in 1962, amid what his countrymen now nostalgically
label: Paragraph

text: call les trente glorieuses—the thirty glorious years from 1945 to 1975
label: Title

text: bracketed by the end of World War II and the OPEC oil embargo, a period
label: Paragraph

text: of economic growth that saw France recoup much of the international
label: Paragraph

text: prestige it lost with its humiliating defeat and occupation by Nazi Germany.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite that general post-war optimism, the young Portzamparc questioned
label: Paragraph

text: whether he wanted to become an architect at all, and it took him seven years
label: Paragraph

text: to receive his degree.
label: Paragraph

text: Upon graduation he did not work as a design architect but became
label: Paragraph

text: involved with sociologically oriented research groups that investigated
label: Paragraph

text: urban housing patterns and practices. He applied ideas that he learned
label: Paragraph

text: through direct contact with residents to his first major built project, Les
label: Paragraph

text: Hautes Formes of 1975-1979, a six-building, 209-unit cluster of social
label: Paragraph

text: housing sponsored by the city of Paris in the 13th arrondissement. The
label: Paragraph

text: scheme struck a sensible balance between then-fashionable Postmodernist
label: Paragraph

text: and older Modernist approaches, which has saved it from now seeming as
label: Paragraph

text: dated as contemporaneous Postmodern housing estates near Paris by
label: Paragraph

text: Ricardo Bofill, Manuel Nufiez, and others. Portzamparc opened his own
label: Paragraph

text: architectural office in 1980, but his roster of seventeen completed works
label: Paragraph

text: over the ensuing three-and-a-half decades hardly seems as impressive as the
label: Paragraph

text: output of most other Pritzker winners. Yet so potent is the imprimatur of
label: Paragraph

text: that prize that Portzamparc—still not a household name beyond architecture
label: Paragraph

text: experts—was deemed desirable enough by One57’s developers to serve as a
label: Paragraph

text: lure for international buyers.
label: Paragraph

text: The convergent forces that have shaped Manhattan’s super-tall, super-
label: Paragraph

text: thin towers were examined in “Sky High and the Logic of Luxury,” an
label: Paragraph

text: illuminating exhibition held in 2013 at the Skyscraper Museum in New
label: Paragraph

text: York just as these remarkable mutants were beginning to drastically alter
label: Paragraph

text: the cityscape. If anything, this prescient overview curated by Carol Willis
label: Paragraph

text: came a bit too prematurely to fully benefit from the dawning public
label: Paragraph

text: awareness that a singular departure was upon us. As she wrote for the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition’s wall texts:
label: Title

text: Beginning around 2012, sales of condos in ultra-luxury buildings
label: Paragraph

text: reached $8,000-$10,000 per sq.ft. and in some cases even higher.
label: Paragraph

text: These records have set a new standard that developers use to raise the
label: Paragraph

text: budget for project expenses. The “logic of luxury” is the idea that high
label: Paragraph

text: development costs for a project are good business strategy if they can
label: Paragraph

text: produce extraordinary profits. .. .
label: Paragraph

text: Expensive land and air rights, “starchitect” design fees, special
label: Paragraph

text: engineering and construction, extra-high ceilings, and abundant
label: Paragraph

text: amenities all factor in a simple math that stratospheric sale prices
label: Paragraph

text: justify... .
label: Paragraph

text: Sophisticated engineering and advances in material strengths have
label: Paragraph

text: made these spindles possible, but it is the excited market for premium
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan real estate that is driving both heights and prices skyward.
label: Paragraph

text: Predicated on Central Park views and other exceptional vistas, these
label: Paragraph

text: aeries appeal to a distinct clientele to whom developers direct their
label: Paragraph

text: marketing psychology.
label: Paragraph

text: Willis is not the only analyst to draw direct connections between the
label: Paragraph

text: sudden emergence of this construction binge and the workings of high
label: Paragraph

text: finance. Now more New York real estate than ever is held by absentee
label: Paragraph

text: owners, and in at least five large Manhattan condominiums most units are
label: Paragraph

text: not primary residences. Although many such pieds-a-terre are doubtless
label: Paragraph

text: used by Americans, they are most attractive to foreign nationals eager to
label: Paragraph

text: secure a foothold in the US in the event of trouble in their homelands.
label: Paragraph

text: International capital flight has thus been the decisive impetus in this
label: Paragraph

text: booming sector of the New York property market, as people from all over
label: Paragraph

text: the world seek a relatively stable haven for themselves and their assets.
label: Paragraph

text: In February 2015, The New York Times published “Towers of Secrecy,” a
label: Paragraph

text: five-part investigative series by Louise Story and Stephanie Saul that
label: Paragraph

text: focused on condominium buyers from four countries (India, Malaysia,
label: Paragraph

text: Mexico, and Russia). They revealed how clandestine ownership of
label: Paragraph

text: apartments in the city’s most expensive buildings is often abetted through
label: Paragraph

text: shell companies, to say nothing of a veritable industry of New York City
label: Paragraph

text: facilitators. For example, the reporters found that a majority of apartments
label: Paragraph

text: in a half-dozen luxury condos were nominally owned through entities that
label: Paragraph

text: are often obscure, including One57 (77 percent), Time Warmer Center (64
label: Paragraph

text: percent), and 15 Central Park West (58 percent). And 58 percent of New
label: Paragraph

text: York City condominiums are paid for entirely in cash, which makes buyers
label: Paragraph

text: more untraceable because no mortgage documentation is involved. As Story
label: Paragraph

text: and Saul write:
label: Paragraph

text: An entire chain of people involved in high-end real estate sales—
label: Paragraph

text: lawyers, accountants, title brokers, escrow agents, real estate agents,
label: Paragraph

text: condo boards and building workers—often operate with blinders on.
label: Paragraph

text: As Rudy Tauscher, a former manager of condos at Time Warner, said:
label: Paragraph

text: “The building doesn’t know where the money is coming from. We’re
label: Paragraph

text: not interested.”
label: Paragraph

text: A report jointly issued in February 2015 by Wealth-X (a self-described
label: Paragraph

text: “private wealth consultancy”) and Sotheby’s International Real Estate
label: Title

text: confirmed that New York had become the world’s favorite refuge for
label: Paragraph

text: second-home buyers from abroad (London was number two, though that
label: Paragraph

text: status is now uncertain because of Brexit). The largest proportion of non-
label: Paragraph

text: American purchasers of residential real estate in the city were British,
label: Paragraph

text: contradicting conventional wisdom that Russians and Chinese were
label: Paragraph

text: dominant. Although The New York Times reported that in the year ending in
label: Paragraph

text: March 2014 Chinese buyers accounted for $22 billion in real estate sales in
label: Paragraph

text: the US—almost a quarter of all purchases by foreigners—they prefer
label: Paragraph

text: suburban houses to metropolitan apartments. According to one Sotheby’s
label: Paragraph

text: broker, “New York City is the concrete jungle, much like Beijing or
label: Paragraph

text: Shanghai. Long Island offers fresh air, no pollution, the waterfront.”
label: Paragraph

text: Whether such strong foreign interest can be sustained given the xenophobic
label: Paragraph

text: worldview of the Trump administration and its imposition of travel bans
label: Title

text: remains to be seen.
label: Paragraph

text: The stratospheric amounts at stake in these Manhattan towers perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: can best be understood by comparison with today’s contemporary art
label: Paragraph

text: market, where multimillion-dollar paintings and sculptures have become
label: Paragraph

text: favored instruments in the global transfer of vast and largely unregulated
label: Paragraph

text: sums. The more expensive the object, the more money can be shifted
label: Paragraph

text: internationally in one transaction, with the artworks themselves—mere
label: Paragraph

text: markers to some degree—making a useful stopover at the Geneva Freeport,
label: Paragraph

text: the tax-free air entrepdt in Switzerland used by dealers and collectors to
label: Paragraph

text: reduce or eliminate import duties and value-added taxes. However, much as
label: Paragraph

text: the new super-tall New York condos may serve that same general purpose,
label: Paragraph

text: these are no works of art. If, as Goethe posited, architecture is frozen music,
label: Paragraph

text: then these buildings are vertical money.
label: Paragraph

text: Interestingly, there’s a clear architectural disparity between the bloated
label: Paragraph

text: behemoths of Midtown North and the smaller, livelier, but scarcely
label: Paragraph

text: inexpensive condominiums clustered around the High Line two miles to the
label: Paragraph

text: southwest in Chelsea. Unlike the rebuilt 57th Street corridor, which quickly
label: Paragraph

text: became known as Billionaires’ Row—where city-planning loopholes have
label: Paragraph

text: been cunningly exploited to capitalize on the immense profits to be reaped
label: Paragraph

text: from supersized condominiums—areas adjacent to the High Line have not
label: Paragraph

text: been “up-zoned.” Higher buildings are largely confined to nearby north—
label: Paragraph

text: south avenues.
label: Paragraph

text: The enormous popular success of the High Line and the arty cachet of its
label: Paragraph

text: environs have made this a much sought after neighborhood among affluent
label: Paragraph

text: young creative sorts. The city’s principal contemporary art galleries now
label: Paragraph

text: crowd the trestle in the West 10s and 20s, and the Whitney Museum of
label: Paragraph

text: American Art saw its attendance figures triple after it moved into its new
label: Paragraph

text: home at the southern end of the linear park in 2015. As a result, developers
label: Paragraph

text: have been willing to sponsor architecturally inventive schemes in West
label: Paragraph

text: Chelsea to appeal to an audience more aesthetically sophisticated than the
label: Paragraph

text: cautious foreign investors who gravitate to blue-chip Midtown North.
label: Paragraph

text: The art world favorite Annabelle Selldorf has designed both galleries and
label: Paragraph

text: apartments near the High Line. However, developers favor Pritzker Prize
label: Paragraph

text: winners for the implicit cultural validation they bring to a project, as
label: Paragraph

text: Portzamparc did when Extell hired him to design One57. The Pritzker
label: Paragraph

text: laureates Shigeru Ban and Jean Nouvel have built condominiums near the
label: Paragraph

text: High Line, and one of the last works designed by the award’s 2004
label: Paragraph

text: recipient, Zaha Hadid, is her thirty-nine-unit condo of 2013-2018 at 28th
label: Paragraph

text: Street. This swoopingly streamlined eleven-story composition—in a retro-
label: Paragraph

text: futuristic style—rivaled prices achieved in Midtown North with a penthouse
label: Paragraph

text: that had a reported $35 million asking price. And that building’s developer,
label: Paragraph

text: Related Companies, enlisted yet another Pritzker honoree, Rem Koolhaas of
label: Paragraph

text: the firm OMA, to do a condo next to the High Line at West 18th Street.
label: Paragraph

text: In tandem with all this high-priced development, New York City housing
label: Paragraph

text: since the turn of the millennium has become far less affordable (especially
label: Paragraph

text: for young people, except for those who work in financial services,
label: Paragraph

text: information technology, or other highly lucrative fields). In 2016 the
label: Paragraph

text: median price paid for apartments in the city rose to a new high of $1.2
label: Paragraph

text: million, with the median for condos reaching $3.1 million. Gone are the
label: Paragraph

text: days when aspiring writers, artists, actors, dancers, and other low-earming
label: Title

text: bohemians could count on finding a solo dwelling in Manhattan. Apart
label: Paragraph

text: from the new-found fashionableness of Brooklyn—whose hippest sections
label: Paragraph

text: are now prohibitively expensive—even the remotest reaches of the five
label: Paragraph

text: boroughs are being gentrified, and longtime tenants sometimes find
label: Paragraph

text: themselves priced out of their neighborhoods.
label: Paragraph

text: To combat this trend, New York State Senator Brad Hoylman of
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan in 2014 said he would sponsor a bill to impose a property tax
label: Paragraph

text: surcharge on nonprimary residences in New York City valued at $5 million
label: Paragraph

text: and higher, which one study says could generate some $665 million to
label: Paragraph

text: subsidize low- and middle-income housing. Predictably, the city’s powerful
label: Paragraph

text: real estate industry—largely controlled by a few dozen family-owned firms,
label: Paragraph

text: some with long-standing ties to politicians of both major parties—
label: Paragraph

text: vigorously opposed the idea. Nonetheless, this brave initiative was surely
label: Paragraph

text: more equitable than incentives given to developers of Manhattan’s new
label: Paragraph

text: safe-deposit boxes in the sky. As Charles V. Bagli reported in the Times in
label: Paragraph

text: February 2015, under New York City’s Property Tax Exemption Program,
label: Paragraph

text: known as 421a, the $100 million apartment at One57 qualified for a 95
label: Paragraph

text: percent tax cut worth about $360,000. (Such abatements decrease over time
label: Paragraph

text: and usually expire in twenty-five years or less.)
label: Paragraph

text: In return for these breaks, developers were required to create housing for
label: Paragraph

text: low-income tenants, but fewer than 10 percent of new dwellings in the city
label: Paragraph

text: have been earmarked as such. Some of those subsidized units are located in
label: Paragraph

text: the new luxury towers themselves (though in a few instances are accessible
label: Paragraph

text: only through a separate entrance that activists have scorned as “the poor
label: Paragraph

text: door”). Developers can also support off-site affordable housing in order to
label: Paragraph

text: qualify apartments for 421a status, as Extell did with One57 by
label: Paragraph

text: underwriting sixty-six such units in the Bronx. However, in his 2015 State
label: Paragraph

text: of the City address, Mayor Bill de Blasio asserted that “the city has for
label: Paragraph

text: decades let developers write their own rules. . . . Sometimes projects
label: Paragraph

text: included affordable housing . . . but far too often, they did not.”
label: Paragraph

text: De Blasio identified six neighborhoods outside Manhattan where
label: Paragraph

text: developers would be compelled to build 80,000 units of affordable housing
label: Paragraph

text: over the next decade, and twice that number of market-rate properties in
label: Paragraph

text: general. In postmillennial New York, no one has it as bad as the growing
label: Paragraph

text: homeless population, which between 2006 and 2014 increased by 93
label: Paragraph

text: percent to more than 60,000, a good-sized city in itself. By the end of 2017
label: Paragraph

text: that number had ballooned to 76,000, a 4 percent increase over the
label: Paragraph

text: preceding year.
label: Paragraph

text: Appropriately enough considering those appalling figures, the finest
label: Paragraph

text: apartment building completed in New York City during this marathon of
label: Paragraph

text: hyper-expensive construction is Alexander Gorlin’s Boston Road
label: Paragraph

text: Supportive Housing of 2013-2016, which was created specifically to help
label: Paragraph

text: alleviate the homeless crisis (see Illustration 18c). In several respects this
label: Paragraph

text: twelve-story, 154-unit structure in the gritty Morrisania section of the South
label: Caption

text: Bronx is far from the aeries of Billionaires’ Row and the avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: condos around the High Line. It fairly jumps out of its drab surroundings
label: Paragraph

text: thanks to its crisp colorful design, with a strikingly fresh, deceptively
label: Paragraph

text: simple, but carefully composed facade that mixes and mashes bright metal
label: Paragraph

text: panels in syncopated rhythms that make you wonder why so many New
label: Paragraph

text: York City buildings have to be so boring.
label: Paragraph

text: Easily visible on the southern horizon from the upper stories of Gorlin’s
label: Caption

text: building is the inescapable 432 Park Avenue. Yet although these two
label: Paragraph

text: residences were erected with vastly disparate budgets and entirely different
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitants in mind, the notable contrast in quality between Vifioly’s magic
label: Paragraph

text: beanstalk and Gorlin’s pragmatic gem proves that America’s ever-widening
label: Paragraph

text: gap between rich and poor is neither inevitable nor unbridgeable when it
label: Paragraph

text: comes to architecture. Boston Road was conceived not for society’s most
label: Paragraph

text: privileged members but for its least—once-homeless elderly people,
label: Paragraph

text: survivors of HIV/AIDS, and the growing ranks of the urban poor. Still,
label: Paragraph

text: beauty is as beauty does, and the strong social underpinnings of Boston
label: Paragraph

text: Road give it a significance beyond mere good looks.
label: Paragraph

text: Gorlin knows both components of this equation better than most of his
label: Paragraph

text: fellow American professionals. Born to a middle-class family in Queens,
label: Paragraph

text: New York, in 1955, he studied architecture as an undergraduate at Cooper
label: Paragraph

text: Union during the mid-1970s. He went on to get a master’s degree from
label: Paragraph

text: Yale, which exposed him to a more patrician view of architecture. After
label: Paragraph

text: stints working for I. M. Pei and Kohn Pedersen Fox, Gorlin founded his
label: Paragraph

text: own New York office in 1987. On the one hand, he does a thriving business
label: Paragraph

text: in clean-lined, exquisitely detailed Modernist houses and interiors for the
label: Paragraph

text: rich, as well as aesthetically ambitious synagogues for wealthy Jewish
label: Paragraph

text: congregations. On the other hand, he feels a moral obligation to do less
label: Paragraph

text: remunerative but more socially beneficial work, and subsidizes the time he
label: Paragraph

text: spends on such undertakings with the proceeds from his more lucrative
label: Paragraph

text: commissions, like an architectural Robin Hood. Thus a substantial part of
label: Paragraph

text: his practice has been devoted to collaborations with Breaking Ground—a
label: Paragraph

text: private organization founded (as Common Ground) in 1990 to address
label: Paragraph

text: homelessness with housing that reintegrates residents into the community
label: Paragraph

text: rather than simply sheltering them. This initiative seems a particularly vital
label: Paragraph

text: contribution now that new publicly financed dwellings are a thing of the
label: Paragraph

text: past.
label: Paragraph

text: The quality of design Gorlin has achieved with the Boston Road
label: Paragraph

text: Supportive Housing, for which he had a very limited construction budget of
label: Paragraph

text: $30 million, or about $325 per square foot, approximately half what luxury
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan condos were built for at that time, is extraordinary by any
label: Paragraph

text: standard. Boston Road’s most arresting physical aspect is its handsome
label: Paragraph

text: exterior. Unlike almost all other mid-block buildings in big cities, which
label: Paragraph

text: usually have unfinished-looking sides and backs, each elevation of this L-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped configuration is as fully surfaced and detailed as the lively street
label: Paragraph

text: facade. The structure is clad in dark gray brick, a perfect foil for the
label: Paragraph

text: primary and secondary hues Gorlin chose for the metal panels between
label: Paragraph

text: windows. The interiors are equally successful and show how much can be
label: Paragraph

text: achieved with very little. The apartments—all 350-foot studios with a
label: Paragraph

text: private, windowless bath and _ integral kitchen—are virtually
label: Paragraph

text: indistinguishable from a new breed of “micro-apartments” that began
label: Paragraph

text: appearing around the same time in New York in response to skyrocketing
label: Paragraph

text: real estate values. At one of them, Camel Place on Manhattan’s East 27th
label: Paragraph

text: Street, a 360-square-foot studio rented in 2015 for $2,920 a month, as
label: Paragraph

text: opposed to $550 here (where fees are gauged on ability to pay).
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to Boston Road’s shared amenities—which include an
label: Paragraph

text: exercise room with fitness machines on a par with commercial gyms, a bike
label: Paragraph

text: room, a computer center, and a laundry room—the facility contains ample
label: Paragraph

text: common areas for its full array of social services. Among them are a
label: Paragraph

text: resident nurse, a twelve-step program, nutritional and weight-loss guidance,
label: Paragraph

text: career counseling, and discussion groups, all aimed at propelling residents
label: Paragraph

text: into self-sufficient lives among the larger community. As other Breaking
label: Paragraph

text: Ground facilities have demonstrated, these all-important support and
label: Paragraph

text: monitoring activities can prevent recidivism to a remarkable extent. Boston
label: Paragraph

text: Road’s model of a mixed population of former vagrants alongside low-
label: Paragraph

text: income workers is an important step forward in destigmatizing
label: Paragraph

text: homelessness, and the proximity of employed residents with others just off
label: Paragraph

text: the streets likewise provides a potentially motivating example of self-help.
label: Paragraph

text: None of the demographic shifts reflected in these New York City housing
label: Paragraph

text: patterns, high and low, is accidental. During his twelve years in office,
label: Paragraph

text: Mayor Bloomberg repeatedly declared his intention to make New York—
label: Paragraph

text: long renowned for turning generations of poor immigrants into middle-class
label: Paragraph

text: taxpayers—into what the political blogger Alex Pareene has characterized
label: Paragraph

text: as the billionaire businessman’s “perfectly engineered technocratic dream
label: Paragraph

text: city.” As Bloomberg said in 2013, “If we could get every billionaire around
label: Paragraph

text: the world to move here it would be a godsend.” In fact, he believes that
label: Paragraph

text: economic inequality in the city is attributable not to growing poverty among
label: Paragraph

text: the many but to burgeoning wealth among the few:
label: Paragraph

text: Such persistent Reagan-era fantasies of trickle-down economics aside,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: This race to erect ever-higher, ever-more-luxurious Manhattan
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: York City bragging rights for the world’s tallest building, as one record-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: New York’s postmillennial claimants to that lineage possesses an iota of the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: renowned as America’s signal contribution to modern architectural form—
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: MAYA LIN
label: Title

text: OLDER ARTISTS WHO struggle futilely for recognition often envy those who
label: Paragraph

text: achieve great success at an early age. But never being able to surpass or
label: Paragraph

text: even equal a youthful triumph can be a cruel fate for those who believe you
label: Paragraph

text: are only as good as your latest work. This is the potentially daunting reality
label: Paragraph

text: that Maya Lin has lived with since she skyrocketed to fame at the age of
label: Paragraph

text: twenty-one, when during her senior year as a Yale undergraduate
label: Paragraph

text: architecture major she won the open design competition that resulted in the
label: Paragraph

text: most influential public monument created since World War I: the Vietnam
label: Paragraph

text: Veterans Memorial of 1981-1982 in Washington, D.C. (see Illustration
label: Caption

text: Although Lin’s rigorously abstract scheme—devoid of the
label: Paragraph

text: representational elements and allegorical imagery typical of war
label: Paragraph

text: monuments since ancient times—provoked great controversy in some
label: Paragraph

text: quarters when it was chosen from among the 1,421 contest entries, her
label: Paragraph

text: powerful melding of the period’s two main avant-garde sculptural
label: Paragraph

text: developments, Minimalism and Earth Art, fundamentally recast popular
label: Paragraph

text: notions of commemorative architecture. This symmetrical composition of
label: Paragraph

text: two wedge-shaped, vertically paneled, polished black granite walls, set at a
label: Caption

text: 125-degree angle to each other and sunk ten feet below grade at their
label: Paragraph

text: deepest, is inscribed with the names of 58,307 American military personnel
label: Paragraph

text: who died as a result of the Vietnam War between 1957 and 1975.
label: Paragraph

text: The sloping walkway parallel to this 493-foot-long expanse of stone
label: Paragraph

text: begins at street level and then reaches its nadir at the monument’s midpoint.
label: Paragraph

text: The transit along the declivity gives one the palpable impression of being
label: Paragraph

text: swamped by a tide of mortality as the rows of names rise higher and higher
label: Paragraph

text: above one’s head. Then, as the pedestrian path begins to ascend at the
label: Paragraph

text: structure’s midpoint, the opposite occurs, the sensation ebbing and abating
label: Paragraph

text: as one reaches the flat expanse of the National Mall once again, filled with
label: Paragraph

text: relief that the flood of names has finally ended. It is not uncommon to see
label: Paragraph

text: visitors in tears after they have negotiated this symbolic abyss, a journey
label: Paragraph

text: made all the more unnerving because of the unconsoling directness of the
label: Paragraph

text: experience. However, the stunning physical immediacy of Lin’s design
label: Paragraph

text: could not be conveyed in preparatory drawings or models, and thus its
label: Paragraph

text: visceral impact was unanticipated by many until the monument was
label: Paragraph

text: completed.
label: Paragraph

text: The adage that success has many fathers but failure is an orphan certainly
label: Paragraph

text: pertains to those involved with the Vietnam Veterans Memorial
label: Paragraph

text: commission, although the person most responsible for its triumphant
label: Paragraph

text: outcome—the artist herself—has never tried to arrogate sole credit for what
label: Paragraph

text: became a hugely complicated and highly politicized process. Robert
label: Paragraph

text: Doubek, who served as the executive director of the Vietnam Veterans
label: Paragraph

text: Memorial Fund (the nonprofit organization created in 1979 to raise money
label: Paragraph

text: for the monument’s construction), in 2015 published a heartfelt memoir of
label: Paragraph

text: the struggle to bring this patriotic dream to fruition, and he was not at all
label: Paragraph

text: reticent in aggrandizing the part he played. As the definite article in his
label: Paragraph

text: subtitle suggests, Creating the Vietnam Veterans Memorial: The Inside
label: Paragraph

text: Story is not only a first-person but also a one-sided account of this
label: Paragraph

text: frequently contentious saga.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, for all its flaws and self-serving paybacks, this is a valuable
label: Paragraph

text: contribution to the memorial’s historiography, above all in Doubek’s
label: Paragraph

text: portrayal of the conflicting forces that vied for supremacy. We get a vivid
label: Paragraph

text: sense of the emotions Lin’s design aroused among those who felt her
label: Paragraph

text: scheme was disrespectful to the memory of the fallen because of its
label: Paragraph

text: uncompromising abstraction and the way it is dug into the earth—a grave, a
label: Paragraph

text: pit, a latrine, detractors charged—rather than physically elevated to a
label: Paragraph

text: position of high honor.
label: Paragraph

text: Doubek admits that he was no fan of Lin’s design as it emerged from the
label: Paragraph

text: crowd of other submissions during the selection process. “[Her] sketches
label: Paragraph

text: and drawings were very amateurish,” he writes, “and the black shapes said
label: Paragraph

text: nothing to me. ‘What the hell is that?’ I had thought.” A very different
label: Paragraph

text: reaction came from the West Point—trained Jack Wheeler, co-founder (with
label: Paragraph

text: another former soldier, Jan Scruggs) and chairman of the Vietnam Veterans
label: Paragraph

text: Memorial Fund, who instantly declared, “It’s a work of genius.” Doubek
label: Paragraph

text: still didn’t get it.
label: Paragraph

text: “T had anticipated a messiah emerging from the mists of competition-
label: Paragraph

text: land,” he recalls of his first meeting with Lin. “But she didn’t have a lot to
label: Paragraph

text: say and didn’t seem to know or care much about us. I felt like I had let a
label: Paragraph

text: genie out of the bottle only to have the genie chill out.” Things between
label: Paragraph

text: them never improved greatly, and in the book’s postscript the author sourly
label: Paragraph

text: notes that it was only in 2007 that “Lin for the first time expressed thanks to
label: Paragraph

text: me and the others with VVMF,” oblivious to why it may have taken her so
label: Paragraph

text: long. But Doubek’s obtuseness was far from the worst adversity Lin faced,
label: Paragraph

text: as she endured vicious sexist and racist attacks from those outraged that an
label: Paragraph

text: Asian woman—a “gook,” many openly said—should determine how the
label: Paragraph

text: Vietnam War was memorialized for the ages.
label: Paragraph

text: Concerted objections to Lin’s design among veterans’ groups led to the
label: Paragraph

text: addition of a naturalistic bronze statue, Frederick Hart’s The Three Soldiers,
label: Caption

text: which depicts a trio of zombielike combatants who exhibit the so-called
label: Paragraph

text: thousand-yard stare of battle-hardened warriors. Unveiled a year after the
label: Paragraph

text: main memorial’s completion, this kitschy tableau was at least placed far
label: Paragraph

text: enough away from the great earthwork to inflict minimum damage. Not
label: Paragraph

text: surprisingly, Hart’s hyper-masculine lineup spurred feminists in turn to
label: Paragraph

text: demand yet another sculptural supplement to the site, which resulted in the
label: Paragraph

text: Vietnam Women’s Memorial (1993), a bronze figural group by Glenna
label: Paragraph

text: Goodacre that shows three servicewomen tending to a wounded GI in the
label: Paragraph

text: attitudes of an overcrowded but still male-centered Pietd.
label: Paragraph

text: The pervasive influence of Lin’s masterwork has been repeatedly
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrated in a period when traditional forms of architecture and
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture have come to seem wholly inadequate in memorializing events
label: Paragraph

text: once deemed unimaginable, most clearly the attack on the World Trade
label: Paragraph

text: Center in 2001. Michael Arad and Peter Walker’s National September 11
label: Caption

text: Memorial on the site of that catastrophe reinterprets several of Lin’s
label: Paragraph

text: concepts in highly original ways. So as not to become architecture’s Lady
label: Paragraph

text: of Perpetual Mourning, she has turned down all but three subsequent offers
label: Paragraph

text: to design memorials, including that at Ground Zero. (The other two
label: Paragraph

text: commemorative commissions she accepted were the Civil Rights Memorial
label: Paragraph

text: of 1989 in Montgomery, Alabama, and the Women’s Table of 1993 at Yale,
label: Paragraph

text: which was commissioned in 1989 to mark twenty years of coeducation at
label: Paragraph

text: her alma mater.) She has promised that her final effort in that vein will be
label: Paragraph

text: What Is Missing?, which is intended to raise awareness of species
label: Paragraph

text: extinction and protection.
label: Paragraph

text: Lin turned instead to environmental sculptures, as well as to a smaller
label: Paragraph

text: number of modestly scaled buildings that have led some to underestimate
label: Paragraph

text: her degree of professional ambition. Yet in contrast to architecture as many
label: Paragraph

text: men in the profession still would define it—the bigger, costlier, and showier
label: Paragraph

text: the better—her meditative view of the building art provides a means for
label: Paragraph

text: expressing poetic impulses about humanity’s place in the natural, rather
label: Paragraph

text: than man-made, environment. Indeed, Lin’s steadfast determination to
label: Paragraph

text: ignore the corruptions of modern publicity—that fatal addiction of
label: Paragraph

text: postmillennial culture, signified in her profession by the hideous neologism
label: Paragraph

text: “starchitect”—has been among her most important qualities.
label: Paragraph

text: It could be said that such indifference is easy for someone whose place in
label: Paragraph

text: architectural history is already secure. But the blatant degree to which some
label: Paragraph

text: of Lin’s colleagues in the profession, female as well as male, have fallen in
label: Paragraph

text: with the contemporary celebrity industry offers a cautionary contrast. When
label: Paragraph

text: Jerry Seinfeld was once asked how he could ever possibly exceed the
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenal success of his eponymous TV sitcom, which ended in 1998, he
label: Paragraph

text: replied in words that echo Lin’s attitude: “There’s only one way to top it.
label: Paragraph

text: And that’s to remain an artist and not a ‘star.’”

text: Maya Ying Lin was born in 1959 to culturally sophisticated and
label: Paragraph

text: professionally accomplished Chinese immigrants in Athens, Ohio, where
label: Paragraph

text: her parents—who met as students at the University of Washington—moved
label: Paragraph

text: that year to take up posts at Ohio University. Her mother, Julia Ming-hui
label: Paragraph

text: Chang Lin, was a poet and scholar of Chinese literature. Her father, Henry
label: Paragraph

text: Huan Lin, a renowned studio potter, founded the school’s ceramics program
label: Paragraph

text: and later became the dean of its College of Fine Arts. His older half sister,
label: Paragraph

text: Lin Huiyin, China’s first female architect, married the architect Liang
label: Paragraph

text: Sicheng, known as the father of modern architecture in his country. Liang,
label: Paragraph

text: who studied at the University of Pennsylvania under the Classicist Paul Cret
label: Paragraph

text: (as did his exact contemporary Louis Kahn), maintained close ties to the
label: Paragraph

text: West, and after World War II served as China’s representative on the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural advisory committee that oversaw the design of the United
label: Paragraph

text: Nations headquarters in New York. His posthumously published Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture: A Pictorial History (1984) remains the basic English-language
label: Paragraph

text: introduction to that subject.
label: Paragraph

text: Maya Lin’s more distant antecedents were no less distinguished, as was
label: Paragraph

text: revealed in a 2016 episode of the PBS series Finding Your Roots, with
label: Paragraph

text: Henry Louis Gates Jr., in which the Harvard historian showed her a copy of
label: Paragraph

text: a scroll that purportedly traces the Lin family’s origins directly back to her
label: Paragraph

text: ninety-ninth great-grandfather in 1092 BCE. Gates also identified one of
label: Paragraph

text: her maternal great-grandmothers, Ye Deyi (born 1885), a gynecologist and
label: Paragraph

text: pediatrician who was among China’s first female physicians. Lin’s self-
label: Paragraph

text: assurance in entering a field still dominated by men doubtless owes much to
label: Paragraph

text: her parents’ encouragement, but it is hard not to wonder if genetics also
label: Paragraph

text: played a significant part.
label: Paragraph

text: Her gift for the sympathetic placement of architecture within a landscape
label: Paragraph

text: is of a piece with her strong sculptural instincts, and most evident in her
label: Paragraph

text: work at Haley Farm, the 157-acre rural campus of the Children’s Defense
label: Paragraph

text: Fund in northeastern Tennessee. Her two buildings there, though quite
label: Paragraph

text: different from each other, are nonetheless alike in their thoughtful siting,
label: Paragraph

text: humane scale, humble materials, and appropriateness to their function, and
label: Paragraph

text: symbolically evoke the enclave’s purpose as a training and conference
label: Paragraph

text: center for young community activists of color. Her first project on the
label: Paragraph

text: property—the Langston Hughes Library of 1999—was a remodeling of an
label: Paragraph

text: 1860s barn of a form particular to the region: a rectangular shed raised one
label: Caption

text: story above the ground, atop a considerably smaller pair of grain-storage
label: Caption

text: cribs composed of horizontally stacked logs. (A similar top-heavy
label: Paragraph

text: configuration is seen in Scandinavian folk architecture.) Lin treated the
label: Paragraph

text: existing building as a precious historic artifact, but to support the significant
label: Paragraph

text: added weight of heavily laden bookshelves she inserted an entirely new
label: Paragraph

text: steel framework within the wood-frame structure.
label: Caption

text: She employed an equally timeless form for the nearby Riggio-Lynch
label: Paragraph

text: Chapel of 2004, a simple but beautifully crafted wooden structure whose
label: Paragraph

text: subtly curving contours recall those of a boat, a reference that harks back to
label: Paragraph

text: early Christian iconography of the church as a barque akin to that of Jesus
label: Paragraph

text: and his apostles as they fished on the Sea of Galilee (see [llustration 19b).
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, the architectural term “nave”—the main enclosure of a sanctuary—
label: Paragraph

text: derives from the Latin navis (ship). An extra layer of symbolism attaches to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: willows. The finely crafted but economical unpainted particleboard interior
label: Paragraph

text: of the windowless chapel is illuminated by skylights, and one’s focus is
label: Paragraph

text: directed to the central pulpit in the grand tradition of black preaching
label: Paragraph

text: churches.
label: Paragraph

text: Lin has demonstrated a similar topographic sensitivity in her remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: series of earthwork sculptures, which began with The Wave Field (1995). It
label: Paragraph

text: was commissioned for the interior courtyard of an aerospace building at the
label: Paragraph

text: University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, which was named in memory of an
label: Paragraph

text: alumnus, Francois-Xavier Bagnoud, a helicopter rescue pilot who died in an
label: Paragraph

text: air accident at age twenty-four. (He was a great-grandson of Simén Patifio,
label: Paragraph

text: the Bolivian “Tin King,” and The Wave Field was underwritten by
label: Paragraph

text: Bagnoud’s philanthropic mother.) Eager to express the freedom and fluidity
label: Paragraph

text: of youth and aeronautics, Lin found inspiration in the undulating, parallel
label: Paragraph

text: lines of a water current called a Stokes wave. Using that pattern as a model,
label: Paragraph

text: she demarcated a one-hundred-foot square, had its surface shaped on the
label: Paragraph

text: diagonal into rows of swelling grass-covered hillocks three to five feet high,
label: Paragraph

text: and achieved an effect of rippling propulsion akin to a verdant meadow
label: Paragraph

text: beneath the rotors of a chopper during liftoff.
label: Paragraph

text: At once specific in its commemorative purpose but generalized in its
label: Paragraph

text: abstract, hypnotic beauty, The Wave Field, now a popular campus gathering
label: Paragraph

text: place, demonstrates Lin’s genius for transforming profound personal loss
label: Paragraph

text: into a force for social cohesion, no less so than in her most famous work.
label: Paragraph

text: The architect has since produced two variations on this theme: Flutter
label: Paragraph

text: (2005), for a federal courthouse in Miami, Florida; and the eleven-acre
label: Paragraph

text: Storm King Wavefield (2009) at Storm King, the sculpture park in Orange
label: Caption

text: County, New York. The latter installation is more extensive than its
label: Paragraph

text: predecessors not only in area but also in the size of the waves, which here
label: Paragraph

text: vary from ten to eighteen feet high, with a separation of some forty feet
label: Paragraph

text: between each row of mounds, proportions that approximate the sensation of
label: Paragraph

text: being on a stormy sea where one’s view of the horizon is blocked by tall
label: Paragraph

text: swells. Storm King Wavefield gives those who climb up and down the
label: Paragraph

text: slopes to reach its centermost folds a palpable sense of being engulfed by
label: Paragraph

text: the forces of nature, an immersive experience not unlike that of the Vietnam
label: Paragraph

text: Veterans Memorial, but without the political meaning imputed to that earlier
label: Paragraph

text: work.

text: Related to the wave fields but more reminiscent of the land forms built
label: Paragraph

text: over a five-thousand-year period by Native American cultures collectively
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Eleven Minute Line (2004) at the Wands Foundation sculpture park in
label: Caption

text: southern Sweden and Kentucky Line (2008) near Louisville, both of which
label: Paragraph

text: extend like gigantic snakes across their rural settings. These works are less
label: Paragraph

text: pictographic than their ancient antecedents, which often represented living
label: Paragraph

text: creatures; their most obvious model is the Great Serpent Mound in
label: Paragraph

text: southwestern Ohio, which has been dated to the eleventh century but may
label: Paragraph

text: be much older. Like many such constructions (unless they are cut into a
label: Paragraph

text: hillside) their patterns are most discernible from overhead, and thus Lin’s
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: wave fields, which exert a far stronger effect on the viewer.
label: Paragraph

text: Since 2008, Lin has been represented by the New York-based Pace
label: Paragraph

text: Gallery, one of the four so-called megadealers (along with Gagosian,
label: Paragraph

text: Hauser & Wirth, and David Zwirner) that have increasingly monopolized
label: Paragraph

text: the very high end of the international art trade since the start of the
label: Paragraph

text: millennium. One of the principal motivating factors behind Earth Art was to
label: Paragraph

text: create works whose environmental, site-specific nature would negate the
label: Paragraph

text: commercial commodification that disturbed many young artists during the
label: Paragraph

text: late 1960s. However, in order to finance such costly undertakings as
label: Paragraph

text: Michael Heizer’s massive earthworks or Christo and Jeanne-Claude’s
label: Paragraph

text: grandiose wrappings, these visionaries also created salable, domestically
label: Paragraph

text: scaled objects to underwrite their endeavors.
label: Paragraph

text: Furthermore, since the greatest examples of Earth Art—including Robert
label: Paragraph

text: Smithson’s Spiral Jetty on Utah’s Great Salt Lake, Walter De Maria’s
label: Paragraph

text: Lightning Field in western New Mexico, and James Turrell’s Roden Crater
label: Paragraph

text: in Arizona’s Painted Desert—tend to be in remote locations, more
label: Paragraph

text: physically accessible manifestations of such colossal conceptions are
label: Paragraph

text: essential to gain critical and financial support for projects that otherwise
label: Paragraph

text: might remain intriguing hypotheses on paper. Lin, for her part, is the most
label: Paragraph

text: ethical of artists and there is nothing venal about her assertion that “I
label: Paragraph

text: wanted to transfer what I was exploring in my outdoor installations to the
label: Paragraph

text: confines of a museum.”

text: Her Around the World x 3 (2014) is a twelve-foot-wide floor piece
label: Paragraph

text: comprising three concentric rings of white marble, an arrangement that
label: Paragraph

text: immediately suggests Richard Long’s circular aggregations of rough-hewn
label: Paragraph

text: stones on a flat surface. The upper surfaces of this tripartite, target-like
label: Paragraph

text: composition are naturalistically carved at various heights to suggest
label: Paragraph

text: comparative elevations of points around the globe including the North Pole,
label: Paragraph

text: Iceland, the Ural Mountains, the Bering Strait, New York City, Ecuador,
label: Caption

text: Indonesia, Kenya, and the Democratic Republic of Congo. Given several
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: change, rising sea levels, and the disastrous effect that global warming is
label: Paragraph

text: already having on the world’s coastlines, one assumes that the aim of this
label: Paragraph

text: beautiful object is to dramatize that present threat in readily comprehensible
label: Paragraph

text: form. What is certain is that the elegant surface Lin achieves here—which
label: Paragraph

text: attains a level of suave semi-primitive effect reminiscent of Isamu
label: Paragraph

text: Noguchi’s half-raw, half-polished stone sculptures—can also divert
label: Paragraph

text: attention from the urgency of her important if inchoately articulated
label: Paragraph

text: message. Her desire to bring the grandeur of untamed nature into a gallery
label: Paragraph

text: setting can seem a bit too self-defeatingly well-mannered compared to
label: Paragraph

text: grittier efforts of other Earth artists, especially Long and Heizer.

text: Lin came of professional age at the conjunction of two immense changes
label: Paragraph

text: in architectural culture: the increasing acceptance of women in a field that
label: Paragraph

text: had long restricted them to subsidiary roles, and a renewed sense that what
label: Paragraph

text: during the modern period had come to be seen primarily as a technical
label: Paragraph

text: discipline was an art form as well. Thanks to her culturally supportive
label: Paragraph

text: upbringing, youthful acclaim, and preternatural self-confidence in following
label: Paragraph

text: multidisciplinary pursuits without a careerist agenda, Lin has freed herself
label: Paragraph

text: from the entrapments of the infernal fame machine. If all her experiments
label: Paragraph

text: do not lead to a breakthrough as momentous as her defining hour in 1981,
label: Paragraph

text: she nonetheless has established herself as a model of what architecture can
label: Paragraph

text: become in the hands of a woman unafraid to pursue a different path.
label: Paragraph

text: 1a. Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, Central Park, New York City,
label: Caption

text: 1857-1873. They won the contest for this vast urban oasis with a design that
label: Paragraph

text: connects the surrounding city through an ingenious separation of vehicular
label: Paragraph

text: and pedestrian traffic. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 1b. Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, North Woods, Central Park,
label: Caption

text: New York City, 1857-1873. Inspired by English Romantic landscape design,
label: Caption

text: the collaborators devised many natural-looking but wholly man-made
label: Paragraph

text: tableaux, such as this cascade in a forest glen. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 2a. Antoni Gaudi, Temple Expiatori de la Sagrada Familia, Barcelona,
label: Caption

text: 1882-. The obsessive focus of Gaudi’s life, his still-incomplete votary shrine
label: Paragraph

text: to the Holy Family is an exuberant hymn to faith. Despite its improvisational
label: Paragraph

text: appearance, he carefully engineered the structure through extensive models
label: Paragraph

text: and stress tests.
label: Paragraph

text: 2b. Antoni Gaudi, Casa Mila, Barcelona, 1905-1910. Nicknamed La
label: Caption

text: Pedrera (the quarry) because of its rough-hewn geological character, this
label: Paragraph

text: nine-story limestone-clad apartment building is uncommonly fluid in the
label: Paragraph

text: way it wraps around a corner site, and relates to Belgian and French Art
label: Paragraph

text: Nouvean. [Image credit]
