text: 3a. Frank Lloyd Wright, Rosenwald Foundation School (unbuilt project),
label: Caption

text: Normal and Agricultural Institute, Hampton, Virginia, 1928. Wright’s
label: Caption

text: proposed vocational school for poor blacks is punctuated by a tall, double-A-
label: Paragraph

text: frame structure antithetical to his ground-hugging Prairie Houses of the early
label: Paragraph

text: 1900s. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 3b. Frank Lloyd Wright, Little Farms Unit project (unbuilt project), 1932-
label: Caption

text: 1933. This prototype for a Depression Era back-to-the-land resettlement
label: Paragraph

text: scheme based on regional subsistence agriculture anticipates the sleek,
label: Paragraph

text: streamlined forms of the architect's Johnson Wax building later in that
label: Paragraph

text: troubled decade. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 4a. Josef Hoffmann, Sanatorium Purkersdorf, Purkersdorf, Austria, 1903-
label: Caption

text: 1905. Modern notions that easy-to-clean interiors free of extraneous
label: Paragraph

text: ornament are essential to good health altered hospital and health care design.
label: Paragraph

text: The severe exterior of this hydrotherapy spa reflects the belief that simplicity
label: Paragraph

text: is sanitary. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 4b. Josef Hoffmann, Palais Stoclet, Brussels, 1913-1915, The most opulent
label: Caption

text: of the architect’s commissions was this marble-clad mansion, for which he
label: Paragraph

text: designed everything from tableware to gardens. Its dining room glitters with
label: Paragraph

text: a mosaic mural by his fellow Viennese Gustav Klimt. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 5a. Edwin Lutyens, Munstead Wood, Godalming, Surrey, 1893-1897.
label: Caption

text: Although this country house is based on rural vernacular traditions, Lutyens
label: Paragraph

text: arranged it as an efficient home office for a modern working woman—the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape designer Gertrude Jekyll—and included a photographic darkroom,
label: Paragraph

text: rare at that time. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 5b. Edwin Lutyens, Memorial to the Missing of the Somme, Theipval,
label: Caption

text: France, 1927-1932. The antithesis of a triumphal arch, this disturbing
label: Paragraph

text: composition seems to cry out like a monstrous mouth and lists names of
label: Paragraph

text: British soldiers lost in World War I's worst battle. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: faa if i i
label: Title

text: 6a. Jan Duiker and Bernard Bijvoet, Sanatorium Zonnestraal, Hilversum, the
label: Caption

text: Netherlands, 1926-1931. Dedicated to healing diamond cutters who
label: Caption

text: contracted tuberculosis through their work, these lightweight pavilions
label: Paragraph

text: stressed the curative powers of sunlight and air. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 6b. Jan Duiker and Bernard Bijvoet, Openlucht School, Amsterdam, the
label: Caption

text: Netherlands, 1929-1930. The health craze for outdoor education found
label: Paragraph

text: urban expression in a structure with walls that could disappear in a daring
label: Paragraph

text: display of modern engineering. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 7a. Albert Speer, Volkshalle, Germania (unbuilt project), Berlin, 1938.
label: Caption

text: Cynosure of the chief Nazi architect’s plan to remake Berlin into the world’s
label: Paragraph

text: capital was a 72-story-high dome meant to hold 180,000. Speer used slave
label: Paragraph

text: labor to cut stone for this, his most megalomaniacal design. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 7b. Gerdy Troost, Great Hall, Berghof, Berchtesgaden, Bavaria, 1935-1937.
label: Caption

text: Hitler’s favorite decorator, Troost took over her husband’s architecture
label: Paragraph

text: practice after his death and wielded huge influence. The living room of this
label: Paragraph

text: alpine retreat featured a panoramic window that rolled down fully. [Image
label: Caption

text: credit]
label: Title

text: 8a, Alfred Levitt, Levittown Cape Cod house, Hempstead, New York, 1947.
label: Caption

text: The most famous of America’s mass-production residential builders, the
label: Paragraph

text: Levitts capitalized on generous government subsidies for veterans and pent-
label: Paragraph

text: up demand for affordable family housing as postwar suburbs boomed.
label: Paragraph

text: [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 9a. Emn6 Goldfinger, Trellick Tower, London, 1968-1972. A paragon of
label: Caption

text: New Brutalism in Britain, where that tough-looking style emerged under the
label: Paragraph

text: postwar Labour welfare state, this concrete apartment house was inspired by
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier’s Unité d’habitation in Marseille. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 10a. Louis Kahn, Salk Institute for Biological Studies, La Jolla, California,
label: Caption

text: 1959-1965. Kahn’s Beaux Arts training is clear in this symmetrical
label: Paragraph

text: laboratory complex facing the Pacific. The Mexican Minimalist architect
label: Caption

text: Luis Barragan suggested a bare plaza. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 10b. Louis Kahn, Phillips Exeter Academy Library, Exeter, New Hampshire,
label: Caption

text: 1965-1971. The soaring atrium of this prep school study center is given
label: Caption

text: monumental scale by four thirty-foot-wide concrete oculi, warmed by wood-
label: Caption

text: faced balconies. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 11a. Paul Rudolph, Art and Architecture Building, Yale University, New
label: Caption

text: Haven, Connecticut, 1958-1963. Boldly claiming a prominent street corner,
label: Caption

text: Rudolph’s intricate Brutalist structure juggles thirty-seven levels within its
label: Paragraph

text: seven-story textured concrete carapace. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 12a. Minoru Yamasaki, Robertson Hall, Woodrow Wilson School of Public
label: Caption

text: and International Affairs, Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey,
label: Caption

text: 1961-1965. A prime example of Yamasaki’s penchant for stylized Classical
label: Paragraph

text: or Gothic motifs. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 13a. Lina Bo Bardi, Museum of Art of Sao Paulo, Brazil, 1957-1969. Had
label: Caption

text: Bo Bardi been a male architect working in the US or Europe rather than a
label: Paragraph

text: woman in South America, her inventive schemes—like this structurally
label: Paragraph

text: audacious gallery—would have garnered more acclaim during her lifetime.
label: Paragraph

text: [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 13b. Lina Bo Bardi, SESC Pompeia leisure center, Sao Paulo, Brazil, 1977—
label: Caption

text: 1986. Recycled from a 1930s factory, this community services facility for a
label: Caption

text: working-class neighborhood recaptures the dynamism admired in early
label: Paragraph

text: industrial design. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 14a. Frei Otto and Rolf Gutbrod, German Pavilion, Expo 67, Montreal,
label: Caption

text: Quebec, Canada, 1965-1967. Among the most influential concepts in
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture, Otto’s lightweight tensile and membrane structures
label: Title

text: elevated the mundane task of roofing large areas. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 15a. Frank Gehry, New York by Gehry at Eight Spruce Street, New York
label: Caption

text: City, 2003-2011. To cut costs, one elevation of this otherwise undulating
label: Paragraph

text: apartment tower was left as flat as a routine office building. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 15b. Frank Gehry, Fondation Louis Vuitton, Paris, 2005-2014. The luxury
label: Caption

text: goods conglomerate LVMH hired Gehry, by then the world’s most
label: Paragraph

text: celebrated architect, to create a dramatic kunsthalle for its owner’s art
label: Paragraph

text: collection in the Bois de Boulogne, and an implicit advertisement for the
label: Paragraph

text: company. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 16a. Renzo Piano Building Workshop, Renzo Piano Pavilion, Kimbell Art
label: Caption

text: Museum, Fort Worth, 2007-2013. In his addition to Kahn’s landmark, Piano
label: Caption

text: reiterated the colonnaded pavilion format he more successfully initiated at
label: Paragraph

text: Houston’s Menil Collection. [Image credit]
label: Caption

text: 16b. Renzo Piano Building Workshop, Fondation Jér6me Seydoux-Pathé,
label: Caption

text: Paris, 2006-2014. Atop this gemlike cinematheque and film archive, a
label: Caption

text: vaulted ceiling opens to expansive views of the surrounding city. [Image

text: 19a. Maya Lin, Vietnam Veterans Memorial, Washington, D.C., 1981-1982.
label: Caption

text: Lin’s Minimalist earthwork, inspired by avant-garde trends in 1970s
label: Paragraph

text: 19b. Maya Lin, Riggio-Lynch Chapel, Clinton, Tennessee, 2004. The
label: Caption

label: Caption

text: training campus evokes Christian symbolism of the church as ship of
